div2.entryFree:
alphabetical letter g *
The nineteenth letter of the alphabet: called gayonN. It is one of the letters termed Haloqiy~ap [or faucial], (L, TA,) its place of utterance being the upper part of the fauces, near to that of H, (TA in art. gyn,) the same place as that of x, (L, TA,) [from which it differs in being pronounced with the voice, for] it is of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal], (L, TA, and K in art. gyn,) and of those that are termed musotaEoliyap [q. v.]; one should not reiterate the voice in uttering it, so as to exceed what is right, nor neglect exactness in respect of its place of utterance, so as to render it obscure, but should make it thoroughly distinct, and clear: it is not an augmentative letter: and [it is said that] it is not substituted [for another letter]: (K in art. gyn:) [but this is a mistake; for] it is substituted for two letters; for x, in gaTara biyadihi, aor. yagoTiru, meaning xaTara, aor. yaxoTiru, mentioned by IJ and several others, (MF, TA,) and in gaTara bi*anabihi for xaTara; (TA in art. xTr;) and for E, in lagan~a for laEan~a, mentioned by Ibn-Umm- Kásim and others, (MF, TA,) [and in na$uwgN for na$uwgN,] and in Airomagal~a for AiromaEal~a, and also in Algayonu as signifying “ thirst ” and “ the clouds. ” (TA in art. gyn.) -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes A thousand.]

1 gab~ati AlA_ibilu * , (S,) or AlmaA$iyapu, (Msb, K,) aor.
gabi3a , inf. n. gab~N (S, Msb, K) and gubuwbN, (Msb, K,) The camels, (S,) or cattle, (Msb, K,) came to water, (S,) or drank, (Msb, K,) on alternate days; one day and not the next day. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (IAth, TA,) gab~a said of a man means He came visiting at intervals of some days, or after some days. (AA, IAth, TA.) [See also gib~N: and see gubayosN.] ― -b3- And gab~a Eani Alqawomi, (Ks, S, Msb, K,) aor.
gabu3a , the verb in this case being of the class of qatala, [but this is contr. to analogy, as well as to the derivation,] inf. n. gib~N, with kesr, He came to the people, or party, day after day: (Msb:) or, as also Alqawoma ↓ Agb~, he came to the people, or party, on alternate days, coming one day and not the next: (Ks, S, K:) or he came to them once in two days or more. (TA.) It is said in a trad., fiY EiyaAdapi AlmariyDi ↓ A^agib~uwA waA^arobiEuwA Visit ye the sick on alternate days and after intervals of two days: (S, TA:) not every day, lest he find your visits to be troublesome. (TA. [See also art. rbE.]) And you say, ↓ A^agobabotuhu, inf. n. A_igobaAbN, meaning I visited him [once] in every week. (A.) ― -b4- And hence gab~ato said of a fever. (Msb.) gab~ati AlHum~aY and ↓ A^agab~at signify the same: (S:) you say, gab~ato Ealayohi AlHum~aY, The fever came upon him, (Msb,) or attacked him, (K,) one day and intermitted one day; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^agab~atohu and ↓ A^agab~ato Ealayohi. (K.) [See also gib~N.] ― -b5- You say also, gab~a EinodanaA, (S, L, K,) and ↓ Agb~, (L, K,) He passed the night, or a night, at our abode. (S, L, K.) Hence the saying, ruwayoda Al$~iEora yagib~a [so accord. to the TA, Hat~aY being understood, accord. to the explanation of Meyd, but in the CK, and in one of my copies of the S, and in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 522, yagib~u,] (S, K,) i. e. Leave thou the poetry until some days shall have passed, that thou mayest see what will be its result, whether it will be praised or dispraised: (Meyd, TA:) or it may be from gab~at said of a fever, and may thus mean, leave thou the poetry to be kept back from people, [or to be intermitted,] i. e. do not repeat it to people in an uninterrupted manner, lest they become weary. (Meyd. [See also art. rwd.]) ― -b6- And [hence] gab~a, (T, S, L, Msb, K,) aor.
gabi3a , (L, Msb,) inf. n. gab~N and gib~N and gubuwbN and gubuwbapN, (L,) said of food, (L, Msb,) and of dates, or especially of flesh-meat as some say, (L,) It remained throughout a night, whether it became corrupt or not: (L, Msb:) and, said of food, it became altered [for the worse] in its odour: (L:) or, said of flesh-meat, it became stinking: (T, S, K;) as also ↓ Agb~: (T, K:) and it (a thing) became corrupt. (TA. [See also 2.]) ― -b7- gab~ati AlA^umuwru means The affairs, or events, came to, or arrived at, their ends, conclusions, latter or last parts or states, issues, or results. (S, TA.) ― -b8- And gab~a Al$~ay^ou fiY nafosihi, aor.
gabi3a , inf. n. gab~N, [app. meaning The thing came into his mind,] is a phrase mentioned by Th. (TA.)

2 gb~b fiY AlHaAjapi * , (S, O,) inf. n. tagobiybN, (K,) He was remiss; or did not exert himself, or act vigorously or strenuously; (S, O, K;) in the needful affair: (S, O:) [and] so fiyhaA ↓ tgb~b [if not a mistranscription]. (Thus in a copy of the A.) [Hence,] kataba A_ilayohi yugab~ibu mino huloki Almusolimiyna, (TA,) or Eano halaAki Almslmyn, (thus in the O,) (tropical:) He wrote to him not acquainting him with the great number that had perished of the Muslims: (O, TA:) a metaphorical mode of expression; as though he were remiss, or fell short, in making known the essential state of the case. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- And gb~b signifies also It (a thing) became very corrupt. (TA. [See also 1, last sentence but two.]) -A2- gb~b Al$~aApa, (O, L, *) inf. n. as above, (L, K,) He (a wolf) seized the sheep, or goat, by its throat, (O, K,) and fixed his canine teeth in it: (O:) or attacked the sheep, or goat, and broke its neck: and also left it with some remains of life in it. (L.) And gb~b Al*~iy^obu fiY Alganami The wolf made, or did, mischief among the sheep, or goats. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence, app.,] gb~b Eani Alqawomi, (S, O,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He repelled from, or defended, the people, or party: (S, O, K:) so say Ks and Th. (TA.)

4 A^agoba3a see 1, in seven places. ― -b2- You say also, laA yugib~unaA EaTaAw^uhu His gift will not come to us on alternate days, but will come every day. (S, O, K. *) ― -b3- And Agb~t AlHaluwbapu The milch camel yielded milk on alternate days. (A.) And Agb~t AlA_ibilu The camels did not yield milk every day. (TA.) ― -b4- See again 1, last sentence but two. -A2- Agb~ AlA_ibila He watered the camels on alternate days: (S, O, Msb: *) from gib~N [q. v.]. (S, O.) -A3- And A^agab~aniY is said by Th to signify waqaEa biY [app. meaning He fell upon me in fight]. (TA.)

5 tagb~b * is app. from Algib~u in the sense of AlEaAqibapu, and thus syn. with taEaq~aba signifying He looked to the consequence, end, issue, or result, of an affair: see its part. n. mutagab~ibo, below.] ― -b2- See [also] 2, first sentence.
8 Agtb~t Alxayolu * see Agtv~t.

R. Q. 1 gabogaba *
He acted dishonestly in buying and selling. (AA, TA.)

gub~N *
A sea dashing so that it goes far, or runs, upon the land: (JK, K, TA:) pl. gub~aAnN. (TA.) ― -b2- And Depressed land: pl. [of pauc.] A^agobaAbN and [of mult.] gubuwbN (K, TA) and gub~aAnN. (TA.)

gib~N * [a subst., like Zimo'N,] A coming (of camels, S, O) to water on alternate days; coming to the water one day and not the next day: (S, O, K:) or after [being kept from it] a day and two nights: or pasturing one day and coming to the water the next day; and this is the gib~ of the ass. (TA.) [And wirodu Algib~i signifies The coming of camels to the water in the second of two nights (as is shown by the context of a passage in which it occurs in the S and O and K voce TalaqN), or in the second of two days.] But the saying of a rájiz,
waHum~araAtN $urobuhun~a gib~u
means And hummarahs [a species of birds] whose drinking is every hour or every little while (kul~a saAEapK). (S, O.) ― -b2- Also [for sayoru gib~K] A journey of two days [whereof one is without any watering of the camels; i. e. in the case of which they are watered only on the first and third of three days]. (TA in art. nbj.) ― -b3- And A visiting once in every week: (S, O, K:) so says El-Hasan: (S, O:) or at intervals of some days: after some days: (AA, IAth: [see also its verb:]) from the same word used in relation to camels. (IAth.) One says, zuro gib~FA tazodado Hub~FA [or, accord. to common usage, Hib~FA, to assimilate it to gib~FA, Visit once a week, or at intervals of some days; not frequently, or not every day: so thou shalt have more love: a prov., respecting which see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 587; where gub~FA is put for gib~FA]. (S, O.) [See another ex. voce taraj~ala, last sentence.] The saying of Zeyd-el-Fawáris
yaraAniY AlEaduw~u baEoda gib~i liqaAy^ihi
means [The enemy will see me] after the day of meeting with him by a day. (Ham p. 732.) ― -b4- And The coming, or attacking, of a fever one day and intermitting one day: from the same word used in relation to camels. (S, O, Msb.) ― -b5- And A tertian fever; that attacks one day and intermits one day: (K, TA:) you say Hum~aY gib~N [a tertian fever]; using it as an epithet: (TA:) and Hum~aY Algib~i. (Msb in art. vlv.) ― -b6- And The end; conclusion; latter, or last, part or state; issue; or result; syn. EaAqibapN, (S, A, MA, O, Msb, K,) and A=xirN; (S, * O, * TA;) of an affair, (S, A, O, Msb,) of any kind, (S, O,) or of a thing; (K;) as also ↓ magab~apN, (MA, O, Msb, K,) and ↓ migab~N. (MA.) And [hence] gib~a means After; syn. baEoda: thus in the phrases gib~a AlA^a*aAni [After the call to prayer] and gib~a Als~alaAmi [After salutation or the salutation]: and one says,
gib~a AlS~abaAHi yaHomadu Alqawomu Als~uraY
[After daybreak, the party commend nightjourneying: but more commonly, Einoda AlS~abaAHi: see art. srY]. (TA.) ― -b7- maA='N gib~N means Distant water: (A, TA:) and miyaAhN A^agobaAbN distant waters. (A, K, TA.)

gub~apN *
A sufficiency of the means of subsistence: (O, K, TA:) and so guD~apN. (TA.) -A2- And gub~apu, (S, O,) without Al, (K,) [and imperfectly decl.,] is the name of An eaglet that belonged to the Benoo-Yeshkur, (S, O, K,) and to which a certain story, or tradition, relates. (S, O,)

gababN * and ↓ gabogabN The flesh that hangs down under the part beneath the chin and lower jaw: (K;) or what hangs down beneath that part of an ox or cow [i. e. the dewlap], and beneath the beak of the cock: (S, O:) and the wrinkled skin of the part where the lower hairs of the chin grow: and the former word, what hangs down under the part beneath the lower jaw of the ox or cow and of the sheep or goat: and the gbgb is [what hangs down under the part beneath the lower mandible] of the cock and of the bull [i. e. the wattle of the cock and the dewlap of the bull]: (Lth, TA:) and this is also used in relation to an old woman: (Ks, TA:) and, metaphorically, in relation to the chameleon: and in like manner in relation to the stallion-camel, [as meaning the part below the under jaw,] as the camel has really no gbgb: (TA:) [the pl. of gababN is A^agobaAbN: see TimoTimN.]

gabiybN * : see gaAb~N. -A2- Also A small and narrow water-course, from the hard and elevated part of a mountain, or of a tract of land: or in plain. or level, land: (TA:) and a watercourse that is not deep, and in which are [trees of the species called] TaloH: pl. [of pauc.] A^agib~apN and [of mult.] gub~aAnN. (JK.) -A3- [And An affair or a business (“ res, negotium ”). (Freytag, from the Deewán of Jereer.)]

gabiybapN *
Milk (S, O, K) of sheep or goats (S, O) drawn in the early morning, upon which other is milked at night, and which is then churned (S, O, K) on the morrow: (S, O:) [and] accord. to IAar, camel's milk such as is termed muraw~ab [q. v.]: and the milk that is termed raAy^ib [q. v.]: (TA:) A'Obeyd is related on the authority of Sh to have assigned this last meaning to gbybp (TA, voce gabiybapN.)
gub~iy~apN * and gib~iy~apN: see gub~iy~apN, in art. gb.

gaAb~N * [part. n. of gab~a]. You say A_ibilN gaAb~apN and gawaAb~u Camels coming to water, or drinking, on alternate days. (As, S, O, K.) ― -b2- And Flesh-meat that has remained throughout a night: (S, O:) or stinking flesh-meat: (TA:) or food, and dates, and, as also ↓ gabiybN, flesh-meat, that has remained throughout a night, whether it have become corrupt or not: (L:) and applied also to bread. (S and K in art. byt.) ― -b3- And najomN gaAb~N means A fixed star [app. because of its twinkling, or shining with intermitted light]. (A.)

gabogabN * : see gababN. -A2- Also A place where victims are sacrificed: (O, TA:) or Algabogabu, (S, O, K, TA,) particularly, (TA,) a small mountain, (S, O, K, TA,) which is the place of sacrifice, (S, O,) in Minè: (S, K:) or the place in which was ElLát, at Et-Táïf: or the place where they used there to sacrifice to El-Lát: or gabogabN is an appellation of any place of sacrifice in Minè. (TA.) ― -b2- And Algabogabu is the name of An idol (SanamN), (O, K, TA,) which they used to worship in the Time of Ignorance, and upon which (Ealayohi) they used to sacrifice; (O, TA; *) and IDrd says that some called it Algabogabu [q. v.], with the unpointed E: (O:) or a stone which was set up before the idol, for, or [dedicated] to, Menáf, opposite the corner of the Black Stone [of the Kaabeh]; and there were two [whereof each was] thus called. (TA.)

tagib~apN *
False testimony: (K, TA:) of the measure tafoEilapN, [being originally tagobibapN,] from gab~aba Al*~iy^obu fiY Alganami, or from gab~aba signifying “ it became very corrupt. ” (IAth, TA.)
rajulN magib~N * [A man having a tertian fever, as is indicated in the TA,] is mentioned on the authority of AZ, in the form of an act. part. n. (TA.) -A2- And Almugib~u means The lion. (O, K.)
migab~N * : see gib~N, last sentence but two.
magab~ahN * : see gib~N, last sentence but two.
mugab~abapN * A ewe, or goat, that is milked on alternate days. (IAar, S, K.) -A2- And mugab~abN A bull having a gabab [or dewlap]. (Ham p. 293.)

[
mutagab~ibN * app. A man looking to the consequence, end, issue, or result, of an affair; like mutaEaq~ibN: see a verse in the Ham p. 154, and the verse next preceding it: and see its verb, above.]

1 gabava * , (S, O,) aor.
gabava , (TK,) inf. n. gabovN, (S, O, K,) He moistened, and beat up, or mingled, [the preparation of curd called] A^aqiT with clarified butter. (Fr, S, O, K.) [See also Eabava, of which it is a dial. var.; and Eabavati AlmaroA^apu, and Eabava AlA^aqiTa.]
9 Agbv~ * , inf. n. AigobivaAvN, He, or it, was, or became, A^agobav, (S, O, K,) i. e., of a colour inclining to that of dust, (S,) or dust-coloured. (O.)
gubovapN * [formed by transposition from bugovapN] A colour inclining to that of dust: (TA:) or dustcolour. (O.)

gabiyvapN * [The preparation of curd called] A^aqoiT moistened, and beaten up, or mingled, with clarified butter. (Fr, S, O, K.) [See also gabiyvapN, of which it is a dial. var.] ― -b2- And I. q. gabiyvapN in its [other] meanings. (O, * K.)

A^agobavu *
i. q. A^abogavu, (S, O, K,) from which it is formed by transposition, (S, O,) Of a colour inclining to that of dust: (TA:) or dust-coloured. (O.)

1 gabara * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
gabura , (S, Msb,) inf. n. gubuwrN, (Msb, K,) He, or it, (a thing, S) remained, lasted, or continued: (S, Msb, TA:) and (Msb) he (a man, JK) tarried, stayed, or waited. (JK, Zbd, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And He, or it, passed, passed away, or went away. (Msb, K.) It is sometimes used in this latter sense; (Msb;) and thus it has two contr. significations. (Msb, K.) ― -b3- And It was future. (KL.) -A2- See also 9. -A3- gabira: see 5, last two sentences. ― -b2- Also, this last, aor.
gabara , (S, K,) inf. n. gabarN, (S,) said of a wound, (S, K,) It was, or became, in a corrupt state: (K:) or it became in a healing state, and then became recrudescent: (S:) or it was always recrudescent: and it became in a healing state upon, or over, corruptness: (IKtt, TA:) or it healed externally while in a withering state internally. (L.) ― -b3- And [hence, perhaps,] gabira said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or hid enmity, or violent hatred, in his heart. (IKtt, TA.)

2 gb~r Aln~aAqapa * : see 5. ― -b2- [Hence, app., as inf. n. of the pass. verb,] Alt~agobiyru signifies The milk's becoming drawn up or withdrawn [from the udder]. (TA.) -A2- gb~rhu, inf. n. tagobiyrN, He sullied, or sprinkled, him, or it, with dust. (K.) ― -b2- See also 4, in two places. ― -b3- [Hence,] tagobiyrN signifies also A reciting of poetry, or verses, in the praising, or glorifying, of God, in which the performers trill, or quaver, and prolong, the voice; whence the epithet mugab~irap; as though the persons thus called, being affected with a lively emotion, danced, and raised the dust: thus accord. to Lth: (TA:) or the saying laA A_il`ha A_il~aA A@ll~`hu, (IDrd, IKtt, K, TA,) in the praising, or glorifying, of God: (K, TA:) or it signifies, (IDrd, TA,) or signifies also, (IKtt, K, TA,) the reiterating the voice in reciting [the Kur-án] &c. (IDrd, IKtt, K, TA) Esh-Shá- fi'ee is related to have said that, in his opinion, this tagobiyr was instituted by the zanaAdiqap [pl. of zinodiyqN, q. v.], in order that they might turn away [others thereby] from the [simple] praising, or glorifying, of God, and from the reciting of the Kur-án. (Az, TA.) -A3- gb~r Dayofahu, inf. n. as above, He gave his guest, to eat, guboraAn [meaning dates thus termed]: (TA:) the verb thus used is like lah~aja [and lam~aja &c.]. (L, TA.) -A4- maA gab~arato A_il~aA liTalabi AlmiraA='i is a saying mentioned by AZ [app. meaning She did not oppose and then acquiesce save for the purpose of obstinate disputation]: see gabarN. (TA.)

4 Agbr *
He (a man) raised the dust; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ gb~r, (S, K,) inf. n. tagobiyrN. (S.) [Hence,] fiY wajohihi ↓ gab~ara [so, evidently, but written in the TA without any syll. signs, lit. He raised the dust in his face; meaning,] (assumed tropical:) he outwent him; outstripped him; went, or got, before him. (TA.) ― -b2- And Agbr fiY Talabi AlHaAjapi (assumed tropical:) He strove, laboured, exerted himself, or employed himself vigorously or diligently, in seeking after the thing that he wanted; (ISk, S, K;) he hasted, made haste, or was quick, in doing so; as though, by reason of his eagerness and quickness, he raised the dust. (TA.) ― -b3- A^agobarotu fiY Al$~ay^oi (assumed tropical:) I set about, or commenced, doing the thing. (IKtt.) ― -b4- A^agobarato EalayonaA Als~amaA='u (assumed tropical:) The sky rained upon us vehemently. (S, * K, * TA.) -A2- See also 9.

5 tgb~r Aln~aAqapa *
He milked the camel, drawing what remained in her udder; (Z, Sgh, K, TA;) as also ↓ gab~arahaA. (Ham p. 527.) ― -b2- Hence the following saying, of a people who had increased and multiplied, on their being asked how it was that they had increased: kun~aA laA nalotabiy^u AlS~agiyra walaA natagab~aru Alkabiyra (assumed tropical:) We used not to take the first seed of the young, nor the remainder of the seed of the old; meaning the marrying them, from eagerness to procreate. (TA. [But laA is there omitted in both clauses, and nalotabisu is put by mistake for nalotabiy^u.]) [See also art. lbA^.] ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) tgb~r mina AlmaroA^api waladF (S, K) (assumed tropical:) He got offspring from the woman [she being old]. (K.) It is related that a certain man, (S, K, TA,) an Arab of the desert, (Z,) 'Othmán, accord. to the K, but correctly, as in the Genealogies of Ibn-El-Kelbee, Ghanm (ganomN) with gheyn moved by fet-h, and a quiescent noon, (TA,) the son of Habeeb (K, TA) the son of Kaab the son of Bekr the son of Yeshkur the son of Wáïl, (TA,) married a woman advanced in age, (S, Z,) Rakáshi the daughter of 'Ámir, (K,) and it was said to him, “ She is old: ” (S, * K, * TA:) whereupon he said, laEal~iY A^atagab~aru minohaA waladFA (S, K) May-be I shall get from her offspring: (TA:) and when a son was born to him, he named him gubaru, (S, K,) like gumaru; (S;) and he became the father of a tribe. (TA.) -A2- tgb~r also signifies He, or it, became sullied, or sprinkled, with dust; (TA;) as also ↓ gabira. (L.) You say also Alt~amoru ↓ gabira The dates, or dried dates, became dusty. (TA.)

9 Agbr~ * , (S, K,) inf. n. AigobiraArN, (S,) It was, or became, dust-coloured; of a colour like dust; (S, K;) as also ↓ gabara, (K,) inf. n. guyuwrN and guborapN; (TA;) and ↓ A^agobara, (K,) inf. n. A_igobaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a day) became very dusty. (Aboo-'Alee, K.)

guborN *
A remain, remainder, remnant, relic, or residue, (S, K,) of a thing; (K;) generally, of the blood of the menses, (K,) and of milk in the udder: (S, K:) as also ↓ gub~arN: (Msb, K:) or ↓ gub~arN is a pl. of guborN: [but if so it is extr.:] (TA:) or the pl. of guborN is A^agobaArN: (S, K:) and ↓ gub~arN is pl. of ↓ gaAbirN [used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant]; (A'Obeyd, TA;) and signifies remains, &c.: (A'Obeyd, S, TA:) and ↓ gub~araAtN is a pl. pl.; i. e., pl. of ↓ gub~arN. (A'Obeyd, TA.) You say bihaA guborN mino labanK In her (the camel) is a remain of milk. (S.) And ↓ gub~aru AlHayoDi signifies The remains [of the blood] of the menses; (S;) as also guboruhu. (Ham p. 37.) And AlmaraDi ↓ gub~aru The remains of the disease. (S.) And in like manner, All~ayoli ↓ gub~aru (S) The last part, and the remains, of the night. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Amr Ibn-El-Ás, maA taA^ab~aTatoniY AlA_imaA='u walaA AlmaA=liY ↓ HamalatoniY AlbagaAyaA fiY gub~araAti [Female slaves did not carry me under their armpits,] i. e., female slaves did not have the office of rearing me, nor did prostitutes carry me in the remains of the rags used for the menses. (TA.) And in another trad., mino A^aholi AlkitaAbi ↓ falamo yaboqa A_il~aA gub~araAtN, or A^aholi ↓ gub~aru AlkitaAbi, accord. to different relations, i. e. And there remained not save remains of the people of the Scripture, or the remains &c. (TA.) And in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, bifanaAy^ihi A^aEonuzN dar~uhun~a guyorN [In the court of his house were some she-goats whose flow of milk was a mere remain of what it had been,] meaning, little. (L.) [See also gaAbirN.]
giborN * (assumed tropical:) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or concealed enmity and violent hatred: (K, TA:) like gimorN. (TA.)

gabarN *
A remaining, lasting, or continuance; (TA;) and so ↓ magobarN. (Ham p. 225.) ― -b2- [And by some of the grammarians it is used as signifying The future: see also gaAbirN.] -A2- Also A certain disease in the interior of the foot of a camel. (K.) ― -b2- And A morbid affection in a vein, that will hardly, or in nowise, be cured. (TA.) [See also gabirN.] ― -b3- daAhiyapu Algabari (said by A'Obeyd to be from the phrase juroHN gabirN [q. v.], TA) means A calamity, or misfortune, (JK, S, K,) of great magnitude, (S,) which, (JK, S,) or the like whereof, (K,) is such that no way of escape therefrom will be found: (JK, S, * K: *) or a trial, or an affliction, that will hardly, or in nowise, depart: (TA:) or a person who opposes thee, disagreeing with thee, and then returns, or has regard, to thy saying; (K, TA;) whence the saying, mentioned by AZ, A_il~aA liTalabi AlmiraA='i ↓ maA gab~arato. (TA. [See 2, last sentence.]) ― -b4- Sam~aA='u Algabari, occurring in a verse of El- Hirmázee in praise of El-Mundhir Ibn-Járood, to whom it is applied, is expl. by Z as meaning The serpent that dwells near to a small water in a place where it collects and stagnates, and that will not be approached. (TA.) And [it is said that] Algabaru signifies Water little in quantity. (O.) -A3- Also Dust, or earth; syn. turaAbN. (K.) [See also gubaArN.]

juroHN gabirN *
A wound in a corrupt state: (K:) or that becomes in a healing state upon, or over, corruptness, and then becomes recrudescent after having healed. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, EiroqN gabirN A vein constantly becoming recrudescent; (S, TA;) called in Pers. [and hence in Arabic] naAsuwr [q. v.]. (TA.) -A2- naAqapN gadirapN gabirapN gamirapN A she-camel that remains, or lags, behind the other camels in being driven. (L in art. gdr.)

gubarN *
A kind [or species] of fish; as also ↓ gawobarN. (O, K.)

gaborapN *
A sullying, or sprinkle, of, or with, dust. (TA.)

guborapN *
Dust-colour; a colour like dust: (S, L, K:) and a dusty hue of complexion arising from
grief or anxiety and the like. (L.) ― -b2- See also gubaArN.
gabarapN * : see gubaArN: -A2- and see also A^agobaru, latter half.
gaboraA='u * : see gubayoraA='u. [For other meanings, see the masc., A^agobaru.]

guboraAnN *
Two ripe dates upon one base; pl. gabaAriynu: (K, TA:) so says A'Obeyd: or two, or three, full-grown unripe dates upon one base; and it has no pl. of its own radical letters: or, accord. to AHn, several small green dates that come forth upon one base. (TA.)

guboruwrN *
A certain small bird of the passerine kind, (O, L, K, TA,) dust-coloured: (O, L, TA:) so says AHát in the “ Book of Birds: ” pl. gabaAriyrN: (O:) it is the same as is mentioned in an earlier part of this art. in the K by the name of ↓ guboruwn, which is a mistranscription. (TA.)
guboruwnN * : see what next precedes.

gubaArN * and ↓ gabarapN signify the same, (S, L, K,) as also ↓ guborapN; (IAar, K:) i. e. Dust; syn. rahajN: (L:) or the first, dust raised and spreading: (L:) or what remains of dust raised and spreading: (B, TA:) and the second, the moving to and fro of dust. (L.) ― -b2- You say Talaba fulaAnFA famaA $aq~a gubaArahu (assumed tropical:) [He pursued after such a one but did not cleave his dust;] i. e., he did not overtake him. (TA.) And maA yu$aq~u gubaAruhu, and maA yuHaT~u gubaAruhu, (assumed tropical:) He is not to be outgone, outstripped, or got before. (TA.) [See also baAEa fulaAnN EalaY bayoEi fulaAnK, in art. byE.] ― -b3- laA gubaAra Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) [There is no dust upon it; meaning, it (a phrase or the like) is clear, or perspicuous, or free from obscurity; like the saying laA Eafara fiyhi, or laA Eafora lahu]. (TA, in many places.)

gabiyrN *
A sort of dates. (K, TA.)

gubayoraA='u * [dim. of gaboraA='u]: see A^agobaru, in two places. ― -b2- Also A certain plant [or tree], (K,) well known, (S,) growing in the plains; (TA;) [the service-tree, or sorb: or its fruit: so called in the present day: as is also the “ inula undulata: ”] and so ↓ gaboraA='u: (K:) so called because of the colour of its leaves; the fruit of which, when it appears, becomes intensely red: (TA:) or the former is the tree, and the latter is the fruit: or the converse is the case: (K:) the sing. and pl. are alike: all this says AHn, in his “ Book of Plants. ” (TA.) -A2- Also A kind of beverage, ($araAb, S, K, or nabiy*, Msb,) which intoxicates, made by the Abyssinians, (S,) from *urap [or millet]; (S, Msb, K;) also called sukurokap: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or wine [or cider] made from the wellknown fruit of the same name [the service-apple]. (Th, TA.) [See also mizorN.] It is said in a trad., A_iy~aAkumo waA@lgubayoraA='a faA_in~ahaA xamoru AlEaAlami (S, Mgh, TA) Avoid ye the beverage called gbyrA'; for it is like the wine that is commonly known of all men: there is no distinction to be made between the two drinks (Mgh, TA) with respect to prohibition. (TA.) In another trad., it is called gubayoraA='u Als~akari; to distinguish it from a kind of gbyrA' made of dates, or dried dates. (Mgh.)
gub~arN * and gub~araAtN: see guborN, passim.

gaAbirN *
Remaining; lasting; continuing: (Az, S, IAmb, Mgh:) this is the sense in which it is used by the Arabs: (Az:) or it is the meaning most commonly obtaining among them: (IAmb:) tarrying; staying; waiting: pl. gub~arN: (K:) and the pl. of gaAbirapN is gawaAbiru. (TA.) You say qawomN gub~arN [A people remaining, &c.]. (TA.) And guy~aru Aln~aAsi The later of mankind. (TA.) And huwa gaAbiru baniY fulaAnK He is the relic of the sons of such a one. (TA.) And AlgaAbiru mina All~ayoli What remains of the night. (TA.) And jawofu All~ayoli AlgaAbiru The last division of the night. (Mgh.) And AlEa$oru AlgawaAbiru mino $ahori ramaDaAna The remaining, or last, ten nights of the month of Ramadán. (TA.) And qaTaEa A@ll~`hu gaAbirahu wadaAbirahu [May God cut off the last, and what remains, of him, or it: or may God extirpate him]. (TA.) See also guborN -A2- Passing; passing away; going away: past: syn. maADK; (Az, S, IAmb, Mgh;) or *aAhibN: (K:) so accord. to some of the lexicologists: (Az:) or so used sometimes, as, for instance, by the poet El-Aashà: (IAmb:) thus it bears two contr. significations. (S.) You say, A^anota gaAbirN gadFAwa*ikoruka gaAbirN A^abadFA [Thou passest away to-morrow, but thy fame remaineth for ever]. (TA.) -A3- [Future time. See an ex. in the first of the verses cited voce Hayovu. The meaning of “ remaining ” seems equally appropriate in that verse: but gAbr is often used by grammarians in the last of the senses expl. above.]
gawobarN * : see gubarN.
AlgaAbirapu * means AlbaAqiyapu [The lasting, or everlasting, state of existence]; (K, TA;) i. e. AlA=xirapu [the latter, or last, state]. (TA.)

A^agobaru *
Dust-coloured; of a colour like dust: (S:) [fem. gaboraA='u: and pl. guborN.] ― -b2- AlA^agobaru (assumed tropical:) The wolf; (K, TA;) because of his [dusty] colour: like AlA^agovaru. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlgaboraA='u (assumed tropical:) The female of the Hajal [or partridge]. (K.) ― -b4- Also (AlgaboraA='u) (tropical:) The earth; (S, IAth, Msb, K;) because of its dusty colour; or because of the dust that is upon it: (TA:) opposed to AlxaDoraA='u, which means “ the sky, ” or “ heaven. ” (IAth.) ― -b5- And you say, jaA='a EalaY gaboraA='i AlZ~ahori (assumed tropical:) He came on foot: (Z, TA:) [i. e.] he came upon the earth, or ground; and so AlZ~ahori ↓ jaA='u EalaY gubayoraA='i: (M, TA:) or the latter means, he returned without his having obtained, or attained, anything: (T, TA:) or he returned without his having been able to accomplish the object of his want. (El-Ahmar, TA.) And tarakahu AlZ~ahori ↓ EalaY gubayoraA='i (assumed tropical:) He left him in the possession of nothing: (M, TA:) accord. to Zeyd Ibn-Kethweh, it is said by one who has contended in an altercation with another and overcome him so as to become master of all that was in his hands: in all the copies of the K, [probably in consequence of an omission by an early transcriber,] it is expl. as meaning he returned disappointed, or unsuccessful; and so trkh ElY gaboraA='i AlZhr. (TA.) ― -b6- banuw AlgaboraA='i (assumed tropical:) The poor, needy, or indigent; (S, IB, K, TA;) [to which is strangely added in one of my copies of the S and the guests;] so called because of their cleaving to the dust: (IB, TA:) and gaboraA='u Aln~aAsi likewise means the poor of mankind: or, as some say, the former means strangers from their homes: (TA:) or strangers, (K,) or persons, (TA,) who assemble together for [the drinking of] beverage, or wine, without mutual acquaintance: (K, TA:) or persons who contribute equally to the expenses which they have to incur in journeys: all of these meanings have been assigned to it in explaining a verse of Tarafeh: [see EM p. 85:] and it is also expl. in the A as meaning persons of whom one knows not to what family, or tribe, they belong: (TA:) and [it is said that] Aibonu gaboraA='a signifies the thief, or robber. (T in art. bnY.) ― -b7- gaboraA='u also signifies (assumed tropical:) Land abounding with coverts of the kind termed xamar [q. v.]: (TA:) and land abounding with trees; (K;) or so A^aroDN gaboraA='u; (TA;) as also ↓ gabarapN. (K.) ― -b8- Also (assumed tropical:) Herbage in plain, or soft, land. (Sgh, K.) [This is said in the TA to be more probably with v; but I do not find any meaning like this assigned to gavoraA='u.] ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) A species of plant. (S. [App. that called gubayoraA='u, q. v.]) ― -b10- waToA^apN gaboraA='u (assumed tropical:) A footstep, or footprint, that is becoming obliterated, or effaced: (S, A, K:) or such as is recent. (K. [See also dahomaA='u, voce A^adohamu.]) ― -b11- And Eiz~N A^agabaru (assumed tropical:) Might departing; (K, TA;) becoming effaced. (TA.) ― -b12- sanapN gaboraA='u (assumed tropical:) A year of drought; (IAth, K;) a year in which is no rain: (TA in art. $hb:) pl. guborN: so called because of the dustiness of the tracts of the horizon therein from paucity [or want] of rain, and of the ground from there being no herbage. (IAth.) ― -b13- And juwEN A^agobaru (assumed tropical:) Severe hanger or famine. (TA.)
magobarN * : see gabarN, first sentence.
mugobar~N * A camel the interior of whose foot is in a withering state. (As, TA.)

mugab~irapN *
A party of men praising, or glorifying, God, by saying laA A_il`aha A_il~aA A@ll~`hu, and reiterating the the voice in reciting [the Kur-án] &c.: (Lth, K, TA:) accord. to Zj, (TA,) so called because of their exciting men to be desirous of the gaAbirap, which means the baAqiyap [or lasting, or everlasting, state of existence], (K, TA,) and to be undesirous of the evanescent, which is the present, state (TA.) [See 2.]

migobaArN * A palm-tree (naxolapN) that becomes overspread with dust. (AHn, K.) -A2- And A she-camel that abounds with milk after the abounding therewith of those that have brought forth with her. (K.)

mugobuwrN *
i. q. mugovuwrN [q. v.]: (Kr, K:) the latter is the more approved term. (TA.)

1 gabasa * , (K,) aor.
gabusa , (TK,) inf. n. gabosN; (TA;) and gabisa, aor.
gabasa , inf. n. gabasN and gubosapN; (IKtt,
TA;) and ↓ A^agobasa, (K,) in some copies of the K, erroneously, Aigobas~a; (TA;) and ↓ AigobaAs~a; (As, K;) It (the night, TA) was, or became, dark. (K.) [See also gabi$a.] -A2- gabasa wajohahu He blackened his face. (TA.)
4 A^agobasa see 1. ― -b2- Agbs Al*~iy^obu, inf. n. A_igobaAsN, [The wolf was, or became, of the colour termed gabas, and gubosap.] (TA.)
11 A_igobaAos~a see the first paragraph.

gabasN * The darkness of the end, or last part, of the night; as also gaba$N: (Lth:) or the darkness of the beginning, or first part, of the night; and gb$, that of the end, or last part, thereof: (TA:) or the former has the first of the abovementioned significations; as also galasN; and gb$, the second of those significations. (ElKhattábee, MF.) [See also gaba$N.] And Darkness [absolutely]; as also ↓ gubosapN: or ↓ both signify whiteness in which is a duskiness or dinginess: (K:) or the former, (S,) and ↓ the latter, (A,) a colour like that of ashes; (S, A;) i. e., whiteness in which is a duskiness or dinginess: (S:) or ↓ the latter, a hue between dust-colour inclining to black and dust-colour properly so called: (IDrd:) or a colour between black and yellow. (TA.) [See also galasN.]
gubosapN * : see gabasN, in four places.

laA A=tiyka maA gabaA gubayosN * means I will not come to thee ever: (S, K:) but the origin of this saying is unknown: (K:) IAar said that he knew it not: (S:) or, accord. to him, it means, while time lasts: it seems that he did not know it at first, and then thus explained it: (T, TA:) accord. to some, gubayosN is an abbreviated dim. of A^agobasu, and means the wolf; (S, K; *) and gabaA is originally gab~a, the A being substituted for one of the letters of duplication, as in taqaD~aY for taqaD~aDa; (S;) and the saying means I will not come to thee as long as the wolf comes now and then (yaA^otiY gib~FA) to the sheep or goats. (S, K. *)

A^agobasu *
Ash-coloured; (Mgh;) of a colour like that of ashes; (S;) of a dingy, or dusky, white; applied to a wolf: (S, K:) or it is an epithet applied to any wolf: or, applied to a wolf, light, or active, and greedy: fem. gabosaA='u: (TA:) pl. gubosN. (K.) ― -b2- Applied to an ass, Black. (TA.) ― -b3- warodN A^agobasu, applied to a horse, [app., Of a dusky bay colour;] i. q. samanod; (Mgh, K;) what the Persians call by the latter term: (S, TA:) it is [a colour] desired by them. (TA.)

1 gabi$a * , aor.
gaba$a , (inf. n. gaba$N; TK) and ↓ A^agoba$a; It (the night) had somewhat remaining of it: (K, TK:) or was dark in its end, or last part, (O, K, TK,) with a darkness intermixed with whiteness: (TK:) or both of these verbs; (TA;) or gaba$a, (aor.
gabi$a ; TA) and ↓ A^agoba$a; (A'Obeyd, O, TA;) it (the night) was, or became, dark, (A'Obeyd, O, TA,) in its end. (O.) [See also gaba$N, below: and see Eabisa.] -A2- gaba$ahu, (aor.
gabi$a , TA) i. q. ga$amahu [He wronged him, &c.]. (Aboo-Málik, O, TA. [See also 5.]) ― -b2- And He deceived him, Eano HaAjatihi [of the object of his want]. (Lh, O, TA.)
4 A^agoba$a see 1, in two places.

5 tgb~$hu *
He wronged him: (O, K: [see also 1:]) or he made a false claim upon him: (K, TA:) or so tgb~$hu bidaEowaY baATilapK: (O:) so says As: (O, TA:) and tEb~$hu is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.)

gaba$N * The darkness [or duskiness] of the end, or last part, of the night; (S, K;) as also ↓ gubo$apN: (K, TA:) or of the part next to daybreak: or when daybreak commences: and sometimes in the beginning, or first part, of the night: (TA:) or the remains of darkness mixed with the whiteness of daybreak, so that the true dawn (AlxayoTu AlA^aboyaDu) becomes distinguished from the false dawn (AlxayoTu AlA^asowadu); as also gabasN and galasN: (Az, TA:) or a remaining portion of the night; (S, K;) as also gaba$u AlS~uboHi: (Mgh:) or intense darkness: pl. A^agobaA$N. (S, Mgh, K.) A^agobaA$u All~ayoli and A^agobaAsuhu both signify The remains of the night. (Yaakoob, TA.) [See also gabasN.]
gabi$N * : see A^agoba$u.
gubo$apN * : see gaba$N. ― -b2- Also Intense blackness with smoothness; like dulomapN; in the colours of beasts or horses and the like. (TA.)

gaAbi$N *
A wronger, &c., syn. gaA$imN, (AZ, O, TA,) in the K, erroneously, gaAmi$, (TA,) of others: (AZ, O, TA:) and a dishonest adviser, syn. gaA$~N, (K, TA,) of them: (TA:) and a deceiver. (K, TA.)
A^agoba$u * A dark night; as also ↓ gabi$N. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- A beast or horse or the like of the colour termed gubo$apN: fem. gabo$aA='u. (TA.)

1 gabaTahu * aor.
gabiTa , (S, K,) inf. n. gaboTN, (S,) He felt with his hand his (a ram's) A^aloyap [i. e. rump, or tail, or fat of the tail,] in order to see if he were fat or not: (S, K:) and he felt it (his back) with his hand in order to know whether he were lean or fat: (Lth, K: *) and in like manner the verb is used in relation to a she-camel. (TA.) -A2- gabaTahu, aor.
gabiTa ; (ISk, Az, S, Msb, K;) and gabiTahu, aor.
gabaTa ; (Ibn-Buzurj, Sgh, K;) inf. n. gaboTN (ISk, Az, S, Msb, K) and giboTapN, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) He regarded him [with unenvious emulation, i. e.] with a wish for the like of his condition, (ISk, Az, S,) meaning a good condition, (Az,) or for the like of that which he had attained, (Msb,) or for a blessing, (K,) and that it might not pass away, (ISk, K,) or without desiring that it should pass away, (Az, S, Msb,) from the latter person: (ISk, Az, S, Msb, K:) the doing so is not HasadN, (Az, S, Msb,) for this implies the desire that what is wished for may pass away from its possessor; (Az, Msb;) or it is a kind of Hasad, of a more moderate quality: (Az:) or giboTapN and gaboTN have the signification shown above, and are also syn. with HasadN; (K;) this latter meaning is assigned to gaboTN by IAar; and it is said that the Arabs use gaboTN in the sense of HasadN metonymically; (TA;) [so that gabaTahu and gabiTahu may also mean (tropical:) he envied him; &c.; see an ex. in a prov. cited voce baTonN; but it is said that] HasadN, when it is for courage and the like, is syn. with giboTapN, and then it implies admiration, without a wish that the thing admired may pass away from its possessor. (Msb in art. Hsd.) You say, gabaTahu bihi, (S,) and Ealayohi, (IAth,) and fiyhi, (Msb,) He regarded him with a wish for the like of it, meaning a thing or state which he had attained, without desiring that it should pass away from the latter person. (S, IAth, * Msb.) Mohammad was asked, “ Does AlgaboT injure? ” and he answered, “ Yes, like as AlxaboT injures: ” or, accord. to the relation of A'Obeyd, “ No, save as AlxaboT injures the [trees called] EiDaAh: ” (Az, TA:) [see xabaTa:] by AlgyT meaning, accord. to some, AlHasad: (TA:) or a kind thereof, of a more moderate quality; injurious, but not so injurious as AlHsd whereby one wishes that a blessing may pass away from his brother; AlxbT meaning the beating off the leaves of trees; after which they become replaced, without there resulting any injury therefrom to the stock and branches: moreover, AlgbT sometimes occasions the smiting of its object with the evil eye. (Az, TA.) [See also giboTapN, below.] -A3- Accord. to IKtt, gabaTa signifies also He lied; but perhaps it is a mistranscription for EabaTa, which has this meaning; for it is not mentioned by any other. (TA.)

2 gab~aTa It is said in a trad., jaA='a wahumo yuSal~uwna fayajoEala yugab~iTuhumo; thus it is related, meaning, [He came to them while they were praying, and he began] to incite them to wish for the like of that action: if related without teshdeed, [yagobiTuhumo,] the meaning is, to regard them with a wish for the like condition, because of their forwardness to prayer. (Nh, K.)

4 A^agobaTa see 8. -A2- AgbT Alr~aHola EalaY Zahori AlbaEiyri, (S,) or ElY Ald~aAb~api, (K,) He kept the saddle constantly (S, K) upon the back of the camel, (S,) or upon the beast, (K,) not putting it down from him. (S.) ― -b2- A_igobaATN also signifies The continuing constantly riding. (ISk.) And A^agobaTuwA EalaY rikaAbihimo fiY Als~ayori They kept the saddles on their travellingcamels night and day, not putting them down, in journeying. (ISh.) ― -b3- Hence, (A, TA,) A^agobaTato Ealayohi AlHum~aY (tropical:) The fever continued upon him; (S, K, TA;) as though it set the gabiyT upon him, to ride him; like as you say, rakibatohu AlHum~aY, and AimotaTatohu, and AirotaHalatohu: (A, TA:) or clave to him: (TA:) or did not quit him for some days; as also A^agomaTato, and A^arodamato. (As.) ― -b4- And A^agobaTati Als~amaA='u (tropical:) The sky rained continually. (S, Msb, K, TA.)
And A^agobaTa EalayonaA AlmaTaru (tropical:) The rain continued upon us incessantly, rain following close upon rain. (Aboo-Kheyreh.) ― -b5- And A^agobaTa Aln~abaAtu (tropical:) The herbage covered the land, and became dense, as though it were from a single grain. (K, TA.)

8 AgtbT *
He was, or became, regarded [with unenvious emulation, i. e.,] with a wish for the like of his condition, without its being desired that it should pass away from him: (S:) or he was, or became, in such a condition that he was regarded with a wish for the like thereof, without its being desired that it should pass away from him: (Táj el-Masádir, TA:) or he rejoiced, or became rejoiced, in being in a good condition; (K;) or in blessing bestowed upon him: (TA:) or he was grateful, or thankful, to God for blessing, or bounty, bestowed upon him: (L:) and the same, (K,) or ↓ A^agobaTa, inf. n. A_igobaATN, accord. to the L, (TA,) he was, or became, in a good state or condition; in a state of happiness; (L, K;) and of enjoyment, or wellbeing. (L.) You say, laqiYa maA yugotabaTu Ealayohi [He met with, or experienced, that for which one would be regarded with unenvious emulation, i. e., with a wish to be in the like condition, without its being desired that it should pass away from him]. (TA in art. fwz.) -A2- The saying,
xaw~aY qaliylFA gayora maA A@gotibaATi
cited by Th, but not expl. by him, is held by ISd to mean [He (referring to a camel) lay down, or did so making his belly to be separated somewhat from the ground], not resting upon a wide gabiyT [q. v.] of ground, but upon a place not even, and not depressed. (TA.)

gaboTN * [originally an inf. n.]: see giboTapN. -A2- Also, and ↓ giboTN, Handfuls of reaped corn or seed-produce: pl. gubuwTN, (K, TA,) and, it is said, gubuTN: or [rather] accord. to Et-Táïfee, gubuwTN signifies the handfuls which, when the wheat is reaped, are put one by one; and gaboTN is the sing.: or, as AHn says, gubuwTN signifies the scattered handfuls of reaped corn or seed-produce; one of which is termed gaboTN. (TA.)
giboTN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

guboTapN *
A strap in the [leathern water-bag called] mazaAdap, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) like the $iraAk [of the sandal], (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) which is put upon the extremities of the two skins [whereof the mzAdp is mainly composed] and then strongly sewed. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

giboTapN *
A good state or condition; (S, L, Msb, K;) a state of happiness; (L, K;) and of enjoyment, or wellbeing; (L;) as also ↓ gaboTN, in the saying, Aall~`hum~a gaboTFA laA haboTFA, meaning, O God, we ask of Thee a good state or condition [&c.], (S, K,) and we put our trust in Thee for preservation that we may not be brought down from our state, (S, TA,) or that we may not be abased and humbled: (TA:) or place us in a station for which we may be regarded [with unenvious emulation, i. e.,] with a wish to be in the like condition without its being desired that it should pass away from us, (K, * TA,) and remove from us the stations of abasement and humiliation: (TA:) or [we ask of Thee] exaltation, not humiliation; and increase of thy bounty, not declension nor diminution. (TA.) [See also 1, second sentence.]
samaA='N gabaTaY * (tropical:) A sky raining continually (Jm, K) during two or three days; (Jm;) as also gamaTaY. (TA.)
gayuwTN * A she-camel whose fatness is not to be known unless she be felt with the hand. (K, TA.)

gabiyTN *
A [camel's saddle of the kind called] raHol, (S, Msb,) for women, (S,) upon which the [vehicle called] hawodaj is bound: (S, Msb:) or an elegant kind of raHol, depressed in its middle: (TA:) or a vehicle like the pads (A^ukuf [in the CK, erroneously, Aakuf~]) of the [species of camels called] baxaAtiY~, (K,) which is tented over with a [framework such as is called] $ijaAz, and is for women of birth: (Az, TA:) or, as some say, of which the pad (qatab) is made not in the [usual] make of pads (A^aqotaAb): (TA:) or a rHl of which the pad (qatab) and the [curved wooden parts called] A^aHonaA=' are one [i. e., app., conjoined]: (K:) pl. gubuTN. (S, Msb, K.) The pl. is also applied to the pieces of wood in camels' saddles; and to such are likened Persian bows, (S, TA,) because of their curvature. (IAth.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Depressed land or ground: (S, K:) or a wide and even tract of land of which the two extremities are elevated, (K,) like the form of the camel's saddle so called, of which the middle is depressed: (TA:) also (assumed tropical:) a channel of water furrowed in a tract such as is termed quf~, (K, TA,) like a valley in width, having between it and another such channel meadows and herbage: pl. as above. (TA.)

gaAbiTN * act. part. n. of 1, (S, K,) as expl. in the first sentence: (S:) -A2- and also as expl. in the second sentence: (K:) pl., accord. to the K, gubuTN, like kutubN; but correctly, gub~aTN, like suk~arN, as in the L. (TA.)

farasN mugobaTu AlkaAvibapi * (tropical:) A horse high in the withers; likened to the form of the gabiyT; accord. to Lth: in the A, as though he had on him a gbyT. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aroDN mugobaTapN, with fet-h, (K,) i. e., in the form of the pass. part. n., not with fet-h, to the first letter, (TA,) Land covered with dense herbage, as though it were from a single grain. (AHn, K.) ― -b3- sayorN mugobaTN (assumed tropical:) Journey continued without rest; as also mugomaTN. (ISh.)
Hum~aY mugobiTapN * (tropical:) Continual fever. (TA.)

magobuwTN * and ↓ mugotabiTN Regarded [with unenvious emulation, i. e.,] with a wish for the like condition, without its being desired that it should pass away from him: (S, TA:) in a good state, or condition; in a state of happiness; and of enjoyment, or wellbeing; as also ↓ mugotabaTN. (TA.)
mugotabaTN * and mugotabiTN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 gabaqahu * , (S, O, K,) aor.
gabuqa (S, O, TA) and
gabiqa , (TA,) inf. n. gaboqN; (O, TA;) and ↓ gb~qhu, inf. n. tagobiyqN; (TA;) He gave him to drink an eveningdraught, or what is termed a gabuwq. (S, O, K, TA.) laA A^agobiqu qabolahumaA A^aholFA walaA maAlFA, in a trad. respecting the companions of the cave [to which allusion is made in the Kur ix. 40], in which the verb is thus written by El-Yooneenee with kesr to the b, means I did not give to drink to any one [of family nor of cattle] the share [of the evening-draught] of milk of them two. (TA.)

2 gab~aqa see the next preceding paragraph. One says also gb~q AlA_ibila, and Alganama, He gave to drink to the camels, and the sheep or goats, in the evening: or he milked them in the evening: and Aln~aAqapa ↓ Agtbq he milked the she-camel after sunset. (TA. [See also 5.])

5 tgb~q *
He milked in the evening. (Lh, O, K. [See also what next precedes.]) ― -b2- And He drank in the evening. (TA. [See also what next follows.])

8 Agtbq * , (S, O, K,) inf. n. AigotibaAqN, (TA,) and mugotabaqN may be an inf. n. as well as a n. of place, (O, K,) He drank an evening-draught, or what is termed a gabuwq. (S, O, K. [See also what next precedes.]) ― -b2- And Agtbq labanahaA He drank her (a camel's) milk in the evening. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2.

gaboqapN *
A single case of the evening-drink, or of what is termed gabuwq. (TA.)

gabaqapN *
A string, or cord, (IDrd, O, K,) or a plaited thong (EaraqapN), (IDrd, O,) which is tied to the transverse piece of wood upon the hump of the bull [in the TA of the camel, or, accord. to the T, of the bull,] when he [draws the plough that] turns over the ground for cultivation, or is used for the drawing of water [to irrigate land in the manner expl. voce saAniyapN], in order that the piece of wood may be firm. (IDrd, O, K.)

gaboqaAnu * , applied to a man, and gaboqaY [for which the CK has gaboqaA='u], applied to a woman, (O, K, TA,) epithets similar to SaboHaAnu and SaboHaY, (O,) irregularly formed, for faEolaAnu is not to be formed from AifotaEala nor from tafaE~ala, (TA,) Who has drunk an evening-draught, or what is termed a gayuwq. (K.)

gabuwqN *
An evening-draught; i. e. a draught, drink, or potation, [and particularly of milk, but also applied to one of water, and of wine, &c.,] that is drunk in the evening, or the last, or latter, part of the day. (S, O, K. [See also SabuwHN.]) See an ex. in a verse of Khuzaz Ibn-Lowdhán cited voce ka*aba. One of the Arabs said to a companion of his, A_ino kunota kaA*ibFA fa$aribota gabuwqFA baAridFA [If thou be tying, then mayest thou drink a cold evening-draught]; meaning, may there not be milk for thee, so that thou shalt drink water not mixed with anything; this being called by him gbwq by way of comparison: or meaning, may that be to thee in the place of gbwq. (TA.)
And one says, laqaytuhu *aA gabuwqK [lit. I met him at a time of drinking the evening-draught], meaning, in the evening; a phrase used only adverbially; like *aA SabuwHK: (TA:) and *aAta Algabuwqi [which has a similar meaning]. (T in art. *uw.) ― -b2- Also, and with p, A she-camel whose milk one drinks in the evening: or, accord. to Lh, that is milked after sunset: epithets like SabuwHN and SabuwHapN. (TA.)
mugotabaqN * an inf. n. [of 8, q. v.]: and also a n. of place [signifying A place in which one drinks the draught termed gayuwq]. (O, K.)

1 gabanahu * , (S, MA, Msb, K,) aor.
gabina , (Msb, K,) inf. n. gabonN (S, MA, Msb, K, KL) and gabanN, or the former is [the inf. n. used in this case, i. e.] in selling [and the like], and the latter is in judgment, or opinion, (K, agreeably with a positive statement in the S,) He cheated, deceived, overreached, or defrauded, him, (S, MA, K, KL, TA,) in selling; (S, MA, K, TA;) he endamaged him, or made him to suffer loss or damage or detriment, (Msb, KL, TA,) in selling, (KL, TA,) &c., (KL,) or in the price, or otherwise: (Msb:) [or] he overcame him in selling and buying. (Msb.) And gubina He was cheated, or deceived [&c. in a purchase]: (S, K, TA:) and ↓ Angbn [in like manner signifies] he became [cheated or endamaged or] overcome in selling and buying. (Msb.) And it is said that gabana fiY AlbayoEi, inf. n. gabonN, signifies He was unmindful, or inadvertent, [or perhaps gabana is here a mistranscription for gubina, signifying thus, and therefore meaning he was made to suffer loss,] in selling or in buying. (TA.) And one says also, gubina Alr~ajulu A^a$ad~a AlgabanaAni [The man was cheated or deceived &c. with the utmost degree of cheating &c.]. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) gabonN yasiyrN [A petty overreaching or endamaging] is one of which the rate is such as has been estimated [as allowable by custom] by one estimator, not by every one: and gabonN faAHi$N [An exorbitant overreaching or endamaging] is one of which the rate is such as has not been estimated [as allowable by custom] by any one. (Dict. of Technical Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans.) [Algubonu waAlgabanu mentioned by Freytag as occurring in the Fákihet el-Khulafà, and expl. by him as meaning “ Fraus omnimoda, ” should, I doubt not, be Algabonu waAlgabanu, the two inf. ns. mentioned in the first sentence above.] ― -b2- gabanahu, aor.
gabina , inf. n. gabonN, signifies also He passed by him (i. e. a man) inclining, or leaning, [or bending down, so as as to elude his observation, i. e.] so that he [the latter] did not see him, and was not cognizant of him. (TA.) ― -b3- [And it is said in the TA that gayanuwA Aln~aAsa means None but they obtained it: whence it appears that fiyhi or the like has been omitted after Aln~aAsa: with this addition, the phrase may be rendered, they overreached, or prevented, the other people in respect of it, by obtaining it themselves.] ― -b4- h`*aA yagobinu Eaqolaka, said to a man whom another had cheated (gabana) in a sale, means This [man] attributes defect, or imperfection, to thy intellect. (TA.) ― -b5- qado gabanuwA xabarahaA, and gabinuwA, aor. of the former verb
gabuna , and of the latter
gabana , i. e. lamo yaEolamuwA EilomahaA [meaning They have not know her case or state or condition, or her qualities], (ISh, K, ast; TA,) is a phrase relating to a she-camel, of which it is said that she is what one would desire a she-camel to be as a beast for riding and in generousness of race, but she is ↓ magobuwnapN, [i. e.] one of which the qualities are not known to be as above mentioned. (ISh, TA.) ― -b6- gabanota raA^oyaka [if not a mistranscription for gabinota (see gabina raA^oyahu in what follows)] means Thou hast lost, and forgotten, thy judgment, or opinion. (TA.) ― -b7- gabina Al$~ay^ao and fiY Al$~ay^o, aor.
gabana , inf. n. gabonN and gabanN, signify He forgot the thing: or he was unmindful, neglectful, or heedless, of it; (K, TA;) and ignorant of it: (TA:) or he made a mistake in respect of it; (K, TA;) as in the saying, gabina ka*aA mino Haq~ihi Einoda fulaAnK [he made a mistake in respect of such a thing, of his right, or due, to be required at the hand of such a one]. (TA.) ― -b8- gabina raA^oyahu, inf. n. gabanN (S, Msb, K) and gabaAnapN, (S, * K,) means He was, or became, deficient in his judgment, or opinion: (S:) or he was, or became, weak [therein]: (K:) or his intelligence, or sagacity, and his sharpness, or acuteness, of mind, went away: (Msb:) the parsing of this phrase has been [fully] expl. voce safiha [q. v.]. (S.) -A2- gabana Alv~awoba, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) inf. n. gabonN, (K,) from magobinN [q. v.], (Msb,) He folded, or doubled, the garment, (T, Mgh, Msb, K, * TA,) it being [too] long. (T, TA,) and then sewed it; (Mgh, Msb;) like xabanahu [q. v.] (S, Mgh) and kabanahu. (Mgh.) And gabana Ald~alowa He folded, or doubled, [the edge of] the leathern bucket, to shorten it. (TA: but only the inf. n. of the verb thus used is there mentioned.) ― -b2- And gabana Al$~ay^o He hid, or concealed, the thing in the magobin [or armpit or groin or the like]; (TA;) as also ↓ Agtbnhu. (K, TA.) gabana AlT~aEaAma is like xabanahu [i. e. He concealed, kept, or stored, wheat, or food, for a time of dearth, or adversity.] (S.)
3 gaAobana see 6, first sentence.
5 tagab~ana see 10.

6 tagaAbunN * signifies Mutual gabon [i. e. cheating or endamaging or overcoming in selling and buying: and ↓ mugaAbanapN signifies the same; or mutual endeavoring to cheat &c: see 3 in art zbn]. (S, MA, K, KL, TA.) Hence, yawomu Alt~agaAbuni [in the Kur lxiv. 9], an appellation of The day of resurrection; because the people of Paradise will then overreach (tagobinu) the people of Hell, (S, K, TA,) by the state of enjoyment in which the former will become and the punishment which the latter will experience; or, as El-Hasan says, because the former will attribute defect, or imperfection, to the intellects of the latter by reason of the preferring infidelity to faith. (TA.) ― -b2- And tgAbn lh [i. e. lahu, but this, I think, is probably a mistranscription for bihi,] signifies taqaAEada [i. e. tqAEd bihi, meaning He did not pay him his due,] Hat~aY gubina [so that he was cheated or endamaged or overcome]. (TA.)
7 A_inogabana see 1, second sentence.
8 A_igotabana see 1, last sentence but one.
10 Astgbnhu * and ↓ tgb~nhu [app. signify He esteemed him gabiyn, i. e. weak in judgment, and therefore liable to be cheated or endamaged]. (TA in art. zbn: see 10 in that art.)
gabanN * [mentioned above as an inf. n.,] Weakness: and forgetfulness. (K.) -A2- And What is cut off from the extremities of a garment, and thrown down, or let fall. (TA.)

gabiynN *
Weak in his judgment, or opinion; (S, K, TA;) and in intellect, and in religion; (TA;) and ↓ magobuwnN signifies the same. (K, TA.)
gabaAnapN * [mentioned above as an inf. n. (see gabina raA^oyahu),] Weakness of judgment, or opinion. (S.)

gabiynapN * [The act of cheating, deceiving, overreaching, or defrauding; or of endamaging; in selling or the like;] a subst. (S, Msb, K) from [the inf. n.] gabonN, like $atiymapN from $atomN, (S,) [or] from gabanahu (Msb, K) used in relation to selling, (K,) or in relation to a price &c. (Msb.)

gaAbinN *
Remiss, or languid, in work. (K.)

magobinN * sing. of magaAbinu, (Mgh, Msb, K,) which signifies The A^arofaAg, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the A=baAT, (Mgh, Msb, K,) [i. e. the groins and the armpits, and the like; (see rafogN;)] or the places of flexure, or creasing, of the skin: the sing. is expl. by Th as signifying any part upon which one folds his thigh. (TA.)
magobuwnN * pass. part. n. of 1 signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art. [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- See also gabiynN. ― -b3- magobuwnapN applied to a she-camel: see 1, latter half.

1 gabiYa * , aor. yagobaY, inf. n. gabFA and gabaAwapN, [the latter of which is the more common,] He had little [or no] intelligence. (Msb.) ― -b2- And gabiYa Al$~ay^o (S, K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] gabaY,) or AlA^amora, (Msb,) and gabiYa Eani Al$~ay^o (S, K) or Eani AlA^amori, (Msb,) aor. as above, (S,) inf. n. gabaAwapN (S, K) and gabFA, (K,) He did not understand (S, Msb, K) the thing (S, K) or the affair. (Msb.) And gabiYa Eani Alxabari He was ignorant of the information. (Msb.) ― -b3- And in like manner, EabiYa EalaY~a Al$~ay^ou, inf. n. gabFA, [The thing was not understood, or not known, by me; or] I knew not the thing: (S:) [or] gabiYa Al$~ay^ou minohu i. e. xafiYa [the thing was hidden from him], (K, TA,) so that he did not know it: (TA:) and gabaA is used in the dial. of Teiyi for gabiYa in the sense of xafiYa: (A and TA in art. gbs:) or it is for gab~a, like
taqaD~aY for taqaD~aDa. (S in that art. [See gubayosN: and see also gabiyapN, in art. gbY.])
5 tgb~Ahu * : see 10.

6 tgAbY *
i. q. tagaAfala, (S, MA, TA,) i. e. He was, or he feigned himself, unmindful, &c. (MA.) So in the phrase tgAbY Eanohu: (TA: [see tagaAfala and tagaf~ala:]) and one says tgAbAhu [also, app. in the same sense]. (IAar, TA in art. Em$.)
10 AstgbAhu * and ↓ tgb~Ahu [app. He esteemed him unintelligent, or one having little intelligence] (TA in art. zbn: see 10 in that art.)
fiyhi gabowapN * and ↓ gubuw~apN and ↓ gubiy~N In him is unmindfulness, forgetfulness, neglectfulness, heedlessness, or inadvertence. (K.)

[
gabaApN *
Stupidity. (Freytag, from El-Meydánee.)]

gabaA='N *
Low, or depressed, ground. (K, TA.) And A thing that is hidden, or concealed, from one. (TA.) ― -b2- And Earth, or dust, that is put over a thing to conceal it from one. (TA.) [See also art. gbY.]

gabiY~N *
Having little, (S, Msb,) or no, (K,) intel-ligence: (S, Msb, K:) or one who does not understand deceit, or guile, and the like: (T, TA:) or unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent: (TA:) and ignorant: (Msb:) pl. A^agobiyaA='u (IAth, Msb, TA) and A^agobiyaA='N: (IAth, TA:) accord. to J and others, (TA,) it belongs to this art.; (S, TA;) but Aboo-'Alee derives it from $ajarapN gaboyaA='u, [see A^agobaY in art. gbY,] as though his ignorance hid from him to whom it is applied what is plainly apparent to others. (TA.) ― -b2- [And A hunter, or sportsman, concealing himself. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
gubiY~N * : see gabowapN.

gabaAwapN * an inf. n. of gabiYa [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- huwa *uw gabaAwapK means He is one to whom things, or affairs, are unapparent, or obscure; or from whom they are hidden, or concealed. (TA.)
gubuw~apN * : see gabowapN.
A^agobaY * : see the next article.

2 gb~Ahu Eani Al$~ay^oi * , (TA,) inf. n. tagobiyapN, (K, TA,) He covered, veiled, or concealed, (K, * TA,) him, or it, from the thing. (TA.) ― -b2- And gb~Y Albiy^ora He covered the head [or mouth] of the well, and then put over it earth, or dust. (TA.) -A2- gb~y $aEarahu, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) He shortened his hair: (K, * TA:) of the dial. of 'Abd-el- Keys, and sometimes used by others: (TA:) and he eradicated it (K, TA) at once. (TA.)
4 Agbt Als~amaA='u * , inf. n. A_igobaA='N, The sky rained such rain as is termed gaboyap [q. v.]. (AZ, S.)

gaboyapN *
A rain that is not copious, (S, K,) but exceeding such as is termed bago$ap [q. v.]: (S:) or a vehement shower (K, TA) of rain: (TA:) pl. gabayaAtN. (S.) ― -b2- [And app. (assumed tropical:) A shower of arrows.] $ar~u AlgabayaAti gaboyapu Aln~aboli which seems clearly to mean (assumed tropical:) The worst of showers is the shower of arrows] is a saying mentioned by As. (TA.) ― -b3- Also An abundant pouring of water: ― -b4- and likewise (assumed tropical:) of siyaAT [i. e. stokes of the whip, or lashes]: (K, TA:) thought by ISd to be thus termed as being likened to the gabayaAt of rain. (TA.) ― -b5- And, as being likened to the rain thus termed, (tropical:) A running after another running: [but] A'Obeyd says, it is like a leap in pace or going. (S. [In three copies of the S, I find Algaboyapu kaAlwavobapi fiY Als~ayori as the explanation given by A'Obeyd: in one of my copies of the S, Algaboyapu kaAlz~uboyapi: and in the TA, Algayobapu kAlzbyp fY Alsyr: I have followed the first of these readings, as I cannot doubt its being the right.]) ― -b6- Also Dust of the earth. that has risen, or that has spread, or diffused itself; (K, TA;) as also ↓ gabaA='N; thus correctly; but in [some of] the copies of the K gibaA=', like kisaA='; [and accord. to other copies gabFA;] it is like dust in the sky: or, as some say, it is the earth, or dust, with which the head [or mouth] of the well is stopped up, upon the corer. (TA.) [See also art. gbw.] -A2- One says also, jaAw^uwA EalaY gaboyapi Al$~amosi, meaning gayobatihaA [i. e. They came at, or in the time of, the setting of the sun]: (K, TA;) in which instance it is thought by ISd to be formed by transposition. (TA. [See also 1 in art. gbw.])
gabaA='N * : see the next preceding paragraph: ― -b2- and see also art. gbw.

guSonN A^agobaY * , and $ajarapN gaboyaA='u, A branch, and a tree, tangled, confused, or dense. (K.) -A2- Audoxulo fiY Aln~aAsi faA_in~ahu A^agobaY laka means [Enter thou among the people, for it will be] most concealing for thee. (TA.)

samaA='N mugobiyapN *
A sky raining such rain as is termed gabiyap [q. v.] (AZ, S.)

mugab~aApN *
i. q. mugaT~aApN: so in the saying, Hafara mugab~aApF [He dug a pitfall which he afterwards covered over with earth]: and [hence] one says, dafana liY fulaAnN mugob~aApF vum~a HamalaniY EalayohaA [lit. Such a one covered over a pitfall for me, then urged me to go upon it], meaning (assumed tropical:) such a one caused me to fall in [or by means of] a stratagem that he had concealed. (TA.) -A2- Also i. q. mufaw~aApN [A land (A^aroDN) abounding with fuw~ap i. e. madder]. (TA.)

1 gat~ahu * , (S, K,) aor.
gatu3a , inf. n. gav~N, (TK,) He fatigued, or wearied, him, (kad~ahu,) biAlA^amori [by, or with, the affair]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And He forced him to do a thing against his will, so that he afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, him. (TA.) And you say, gat~a Ald~aAb~apa $awoTFA A^awo $awoTiyoni or wearied, the beast by urging it to run a heat, or two heats. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Also He grieved him; (K, TA;) and afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, him. (TA.) And gut~a He was grieved [&c.]. (Sh, TA.) ― -b4- And He overcame him, or silenced him, biAlkalaAmi [by speech, i. e. by what he said]. (K, TA.) [Hence] it is said in a trad. respecting prayer, yaA mano laA yaguv~uhu duEaA='u Ald~aAEiyna O Thou whom the praying of those who pray does not overcome. (TA.) And [hence, perhaps,] one says, gav~a AlD~aHika (aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) He concealed laughter, (S, K, TA,) by putting his hand, or his garment, over his mouth. (TA.) ― -b5- Also He squeezed his throat, or throttled him: (K:) and he squeezed his throat for the period of an breath, or of two breaths, or, as some say, more than that. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the mission [of Mohammad], faA^axa*aniY jiboriylu fagat~aniY And Gabriel took me, and squeezed me vehemently, so that I experienced distress as when one is forcibly plunged into water: inf. n. gat~N: and gaT~N signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b6- gat~ahu fiY AlmaA='i, (S, K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) is syn. with gaT~ahu; (S, K, TA:) meaning He immersed, or plunged, him, or it, into the water. (TA.) ― -b7- And one says, gat~ahumu A@ll~`hu biAlEa*aAbi, inf. n. as above, God plunged them. or may God plunge them, with consecutive plungings, into punishment. (TA.) ― -b8- And gat~a, aor. and inf. n. as above, He took successive draughts, keeping the vessel to his mouth. (AZ, TA.) And gat~a AlmaA='a, (K, TA,) and gat~a fiY AlA_inaA='i, (TA.) He drank, taking draught after draught, or gulp after gulp, without removing the vessel from his mouth. (K, TA.) ― -b9- And gat~a Al$~ay^oa Al$~ay^oa He made the part of the thing to follow another part thereof, (K, TA,) whether in drinking or in speaking [&c.] (TA.) ― -b10- ― -b11- It is said in a trad. respecting Mohammad's pool, yagut~u fiyhi miyzaAbaAni i. e. Two spouts were pouring forth into it with an uninter rupted pouring: or it is said to mean, two spouts were running into it with a murmuring sound; accord. to which latter explanation we must read yagit~u: and some say that it is ygT~. (Az., L, TA.) [See also another reading voce Eab~a.] ― -b12- And one says, gat~ahu biju$amihi He threw his breast upon him. (TA in art. j$m.) -A2- gat~a, aor.
gati3a , It was, or became, bad, or corrupt; said of food; and likewise of speech. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) [See also gav~a.]
2 gat~t AlT~aEaAma * , inf. n. tagotiytN He made the food bad, or corrupt; as also ↓ Agt~hu. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.)
4 A^agota3a see what next precedes.
gt~N * [inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- And] The interval between two draughts, or gulps, while the vessel is kept to the mouth. (TA.)

1 gatima * , aor.
gatama , inf. n. gatamN, He had an impotence, or an impediment, or a difficulty, in his
speech, or utterance; and a barbarousness, or vitiousness, therein, especially in speaking Arabic; i. e., a want of clearness, perspicuousness, distinctness, chasteness, or correctness, therein. (Msb.) -A2- gatama, said of food (TaEaAm), It was, or became, wholesome, or beneficial. (TA.)

4 Agtm Alz~iyaArapa * , (K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] Agotatama,) He visited much, so as to weary. (K, TA.) One says, laA tugotimi Alz~iyaArapa fatumil~a [Do not thou visit much, so as to weary]. (TA.) ― -b2- And they said, kaAna AlEaj~aAju yugotimu Al$~iEora i. e. El-'Ajjáj used to make poetry cause much wearying: and it is said in the A, A^agotama A=lu AlEaj~aAji Alr~ajoza i. e. The family of El- 'Ajjáj recited much poetry of the metre termed rajaz; and he among them. (TA.)

8 Agttm *
He suffered from indigestion (K, TA) in consequence of much eating; and became affected by what is termed ↓ gatom [app. meaning heat of the stomach so intense as to take the breath] arising from the distress occasioned by repletion. (TA.)

gatomN *
Intense heat that almost takes away the breath. (S, K.) A rájiz says, (S,) namely, Mes'ood Ibn-Keyd [?] El-Fezáree, (TA,) describing camels, (S in art. fl,)
Har~aqahaA HamoDu bilaAdi fil~i
wagatomu najomK gayori musotaqil~i
[The pasturage termed HmD of tracts of country not rained upon and not having fresh herbage rendered them thirsty, and the intense and almostsuffocating heat of a star not high (above the horizon), i. e. not having become high so as to be concealed by the rays of the sun]; i. e. [a star] not high (gayori murotafiEK) because of the constancy of the heat attributed to it [at the time of its auroral rising]; the heat becoming intense only at the time of the [auroral] rising of Al$~iEoraY, [meaning Sirius, the star to which allusion is here made,] which is in [correctly after] AljawozaA='. (S. [See Al$~iEoraY.]) ― -b2- See also 8.

gutomN *
Thick pieces [or clots or lumps] of milk. (TA.)

gutomapN *
An impotence, or an impediment, or a difficulty, in speech, or utterance; and a barbarousness, or vitiousness, therein; i. e. a want of clearness, perspicuousness, distinctness, chasteness, or correctness, therein; meaning, in speaking Arabic; syn. EujomapN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)

gutomiY~N * : see A^agotamu. ― -b2- Hence, applied to milk, [and so, accord. to Reiske, as stated in Freytag's Lex., ↓ A^agotamu,] Thick; the pouring forth of which is without any sound. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- And One who is heavy in spirit: from gutomN signifying as expl. above. (TA.)

HiyaADu gutayomK * , like zubayor, (so in copies of the K,) [or HyAD gutayoma, for it is] a proper name for Almaniy~apu, (TA,) meaning Death, (K, TA,) like $aEuwbu, imperfectly decl. [as being a proper name and of the fem. gender]; so says Z; and, accord. to Lh, Algutayomu signifies the same, but ISd says, “ I know it not save as from him. ” (TA.) One says, A^aworadahu HiyaADa gutayom [He brought him to death]: and in like manner, waqaEa fiY A^aHowaADi gutayom [He fell into death], expl. by Lh as meaning he died. (TA.)

A^agotamu * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ gutomiY~N, (S, * K, * TA,) [and ↓ A^agotamiY~N, occurring in the fAkhp AlxlfA=', p. 151, 1. 18, as mentioned by Freytag, who explains it as meaning “ barbarus, ”] One who does not utter anything with clearness, perspicuousness, or distinctness, or with chasteness, or correctness; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) i. q. A^aEojamu: (TA:) fem. of the first, gatomaA='u, applied to a woman: (Msb, TA:) pl. of the first gutomN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and A^agotaAmN, (Mgh,) or this latter is pl. of the second. (TA.) ― -b2- See also gutomiY~N.
A^agotamiY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.
magotuwmN * , Burned by the heat. (TA.)

1 gav~a * , aor.
gavi3a ; and gav~a, (originally gaviva, TA) aor.
gava3a ; (S, O, K;) said of flesh-meat; (S, O;) and gav~at; said of a $aAp [i. e. sheep or goat]; (S, O, Msb;) inf. n. gavaAvapN and guvuwvapN, (S, O, K,) or gav~N; (Msb;) and ↓ Agv~, (K,) or Agv~t, (S, O,) or both; (TA;) It was, or became, lean, or meagre: (S, O, K:) or gav~at, said of a $Ap, it was, or became, weak. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] gav~a AlHadiyvu (tropical:) The talk, or discourse, was, or became, [meagre, or] bad, or corrupt; (S, A, O, K;) as also ↓ Agv~. (S, K.) [See gav~N.] ― -b3- And laA yagiv~u Ealayohi $ay^oN (assumed tropical:) [Nothing is bad in his opinion; so that] he does not say of anything that it is bad, and therefore leave it. (S, K.) And maA yagiv~u Ealayohi A^aHadN (assumed tropical:) [No one is to be disregarded in his opinion; so that] he does not leave any one unasked by him. (T, A, O, K.) And gav~ato EalayonaA mak~apu falaA bud~a lanaA mino xuruwjK (assumed tropical:) [Mekkeh has become unpleasing (as though insipid) to us, so that there is for us no avoiding going forth]. (A.) ― -b4- And gav~a, (S, O, K,) aor.
gavi3a , inf. n. gav~N and gaviyvN, (S, O,) is said of a wound, meaning It flowed with thick purulent matter, as also ↓ Agv~, (S, O, K,) and with dead flesh. (S and O in explanation of the former verb.)

2 gv~vt AlA_ibilu * , (El-Umawee, O, TA,) inf. n. tagoviyvN, (El-Umawee, O, K,) The camels became fat (El-Umawee, O, K, TA) by little and little: (O, K, TA:) [or became somewhat fat; for] one says, gav~a baEiyriY vum~a gav~ava My camel became lean; then he became somewhat fat. (A, TA.)

4 A^agova3a see 1, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, Agv~ fiY manoTiqihi (tropical:) He [was meagre in his diction; or] spoke badly, or corruptly. (S, TA.) And Agv~ fiY kalaAmihi (assumed tropical:) He said that in which was no good. (A, Msb.) -A2- And Agv~ All~aHoma He bought the flesh-meat lean. (S, O.)

entryFree.key: A^atagav~avu maA A^anaA Ealayohi Hat~aY A^atasam~ana

div2.entryFree: 5 A^atagav~avu maA A^anaA Ealayohi Hat~aY A^atasam~ana * means (assumed tropical:) I do what is of an inferior kind that I may find much; as also ↓ A^asotagiv~uhu: (A, TA:) or A^atagav~avu Hat~aY A^asotasomina, meaning (assumed tropical:) I deem my doing to be little that I may obtain thereby much recompense. (O.)

8 Agtv~t Alxayolu * (as also Agtf~t and Agtb~t, O) The horses found, or lighted upon, somewhat of the [herbage called] rabiyE, (O, K, TA,) and became fat in consequence thereof after having been lean. (TA.)

10 Astgv~ AljuroHa *
He extracted from the wound the thick purulent matter therein, (S, K,) and the dead flesh, and treated it curatively. (S.) -A2- See also 5.

R. Q. 1 gavogava * , (O,) inf. n. gavogavapN, (K,) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (O, K,) in a place. (O.) -A2- [And it seems to signify also He washed clothes without an implement of the kind called miqoSarap (q. v.): for ― -b2- ] gavogavapN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Weak fighting, without a weapon: (O, K:) likened to the gavogavap of the garment, or piece of cloth, [which is] when it is washed with the hands [app. meaning with the hands only]. (O.)

gav~N *
Lean, or meagre; (S, A, O, K;) as also ↓ gaviyvN; (S, O, K;) both applied to flesh-meat; and the former, with p, to a $aAp [i. e. sheep or goat]: (S, O:) pl. givaAvN. (MA.) ― -b2- Hence, i. e. as being likened to flesh-meat thus termed, kalaAmN gav~N (assumed tropical:) Speech, or language, that is [meagre,] without grace, or beauty. (Ham p. 757.) One says, fiY AlkalaAmi Algav~u waAls~amiynu (assumed tropical:) [In speech, or the speech, is what is meagre and what is vigorous; or] what is good and what is bad [or rather what is bad and what is good]. (Msb.) And Hadiyvukumo gav~N wasilaAHukumo rav~N (assumed tropical:) [Your talk, or discourse, is meagre, or bad, and your weapons are old and worn out]. (A.) And qawomN gavavapN (assumed tropical:) [A people, or party, meagre, or bad, in speech: gavavapN being pl. of gav~N, like as bararapN is of bar~N]. (A. [The meaning that I have given is there indicated by the context.])

guv~apN *
A lean, or meagre, $aAp [i. e. sheep or goat]. (TA.) [See also gav~N.] -A2- And A sufficiency of the means of subsistence: (O, K:) like guf~apN and gub~apN. (O.)
Algavivu * and ↓ AlguvaAgivu The lion. (O, K.)
gavaAvN * [if not a mistranscription for the inf. n. gavaAvapN] Leanness, or meagreness, of a camel [&c.]. (A, TA.)
gaviyvN * : see gav~N: -A2- and see what here follows.

gaviyvapN * , (S, O,) or ↓ gaviyvN, (A, K,) The thick purulent matter, (S, A, O, K,) and dead flesh,
(S, O,) of a wound. (S, A, O, K.) ― -b2- And [hence, probably,] the former word, (assumed tropical:) A corrupt, or disordered, state of mind. (S, A, O, K.) So in the saying, labisotuhu EalaY gaviyvapK fiyhi [meaning (assumed tropical:) I consorted with him (see labisa) notwithstanding a corrupt, or disordered, state of mind in him]. (S, O, L, TA. [In a copy of the A, lasotu EalaY gaviyvapK, meaning (assumed tropical:) I am not in a corrupt, or disordered, state of mind: but the former, I doubt not, is the right reading.]) -A2- Also A palm-tree (naxolapN) that produces ripe dates without sweetness. (O, K.) ― -b2- And Foolish, or stupid, in whom is no good: (O, K:) or foolish, or stupid: and also one who speaks that in which is no good. (TA.)
AlguvaAgivu * : see Algavivu.

1 gavarati AlA^aroDu biAln~abaAti *
i. q. maA^adat (thus in the JK [app. meaning The land became flourishing and fresh with herbage]): or maAdat (thus in the O and K [i. e. without '; but the former, I think, is evidently the right: the meaning which I have given may be from gavarN, q. v., and therefore tropical: and it may be inferred from what here follows that the verb is correctly, or originally, gavorat, fem. of ↓ gavoraY]). The epithet applied to such land is ↓ mugavoriyapN. (JK, O, K.)

4 Agvr *
It (the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov [&c.]) exuded what is termed mugovuwr [q. v.]; (K;) as also Agfr. (TA.) ― -b2- See also Eay~ara, last sentence.

11 AgvAr~ *
It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) had much gavar i. e. nap, or villous substance, (K, TA,) and wool. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1 gavoraY * : see the first paragraph.

Q. Q. 2 tamagovara *
He gathered mugovuwr [q. v.]. (K.) You say, xaraja Aln~aAsu yatamagovaruwna, like yatamagofaruwna, The people went forth to gather magaAviyr [pl. of mugovuwrN]. (TA.)
gavarN * The nap, or villous substance, of a garment, or piece of cloth; (K, TA;) and the wool thereof. (TA.)

gavorapN *
Abundance: (TA:) [and particularly] abundance of herbage, and of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; ampleness [thereof] (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A portion of property. (TA.)

guvorapN *
A dust-colour inclining to xuDorap [which here app. means a dingy ash-colour]: (S, TA:) or, as some say, [simply] dust-colour: (TA:) or it is like duskiness (gubo$apN) mixed with redness. (K, TA.)
gavarapN * : see A^agovaru, last sentence.
gavaAri * , or gavaAru, accord. to the CK guvaArN: see A^agovaru.
Algawovaru * and Algavawovaru: see A^agovaru, former half.

gayovarapN *
A threatening. (K.) ― -b2- And Fight, or conflict; and commotion, or tumult: so in the saying, tarakotu Alqawoma fiY gayovarapK and gayovamapK [I left the people, or party, in fight, &c.]: (As, TA:) or, accord to IAar, it means the treading, or trampling, of the people, or party, one upon another, (mudaAwasapu Alqawomi baEoDihimo baEoDFA,) in fight, or conflict: you say, bayona Alqawomi gayovarapN $adiydapN [Among the people, or party, is a vehement treading, &c.]. (S, TA.) -A2- See also A^agovaru, last sentence, in two places.

A^agovaru * , (S,) and [the fem.] gavoraA='u, (K,) Dustcoloured: (K, TA:) or of a dingy, or dusky, colour: (TA:) or of a dingy, or dusky, colour: (TA:) or [of the colour termed guvorap, which is] nearly the same as dust-coloured. (S, K, TA.) 'Omárah says,
Hat~aY A@kotasayotu mina Alma$iybi EimaAmapF
gavoraA='a A^agofiru lawonahaA bixiDaAbi
[Until I attired myself with a dusky turban of hoariness, the colour of which I concealed with hair-dye]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^agovaru is applied as an epithet to a ram That is not red [or brown] nor black ner white; (IAar, TA;) meaning of a dusky, or dingy, colour. (TA.) And it is so applied to a wolf. (IAar, TA.) And AlA^agovaru signifies The wolf; (TA;) as also AlA^agobaru. (TA in art. gbr.) ― -b3- And [in like manner] AlgavoraA='u signifies The hyena, or female hyena; (K, TA;) because of its colour: (TA;) as also ↓ gavaAri, (O, K, TA,) like qaTaAmi, (O, TA,) determinate; (K, TA;) [accord. to the CK guvaArN, which is wrong;] and accord. to IAar ↓ gavaAru, imperfectly declinable. (TA.) ― -b4- And AlA^agovaru signifies also The lion; and so ↓ Algavawovaru: (K:) or the latter, as also ↓ Algawovaru, the lion that is in a confused, or perplexed, case. (O.) ― -b5- And A certain bird, (K, TA,) having confused, or disordered, plumage, (TA,) long in the neck, (K, TA,) in the colour of which is guvorap [q. v.], and which is of the aquatic kind. (TA.) ― -b6- A^akalatohumu AlgavoraA='u [which may be rendered The hyena, or female hyena, devoured them] means (assumed tropical:) they perished.
