(Z, TA.) ― -b7- gavoraA='u applied to [garments of the kind called] A^akosiyap [pl. of kisaA='N] (K, TA) and qaTaAy^if [pl. of qaTiyfapN] and the like, and to an EabaA='ap, (TA,) signifies Having much wool (L, K, TA) and nap, or villous substance. (L.) ― -b8- AlA^agovaru also signifies The [green substance that overspreads stale water, called] TuHolub. (S, TA.) ― -b9- Also (assumed tropical:) The ignorant man: and the stupid man: likened to the hyena, or female hyena, which is one of the most stupid of beasts, and of which one of the appellations is AlgavoraA='u. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b10- And AlgavoraA='u and Alguvoru, (S, K, TA,) which latter is the pl. of AlA^agovaru, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) The low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid, or the refuse, or rabble, of mankind; as also ↓ Algavorapu, (S, K, TA,) said to be originally ↓ Algayovarapu, (S, TA,) which signifies the same: (S, K, TA:) and gavoraA='u is also expl. as meaning a mixed assemblage of people (K, TA) of the low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid, or of the refuse, or rabble, of mankind; (TA;) and so ↓ gayovarapN: (AZ, TA:) or a mixed assemblage of people of various tribes: or the unknown common people: or the commonalty, or generality, of men. (TA.)
migovarN * : see what next follows.
migovaArN * : see what next follows.

mugovuwrN * (S, M) and ↓ migovarN (Yaakoob, S, K) and ↓ migovaArN (TA) [A sort of manna;] a thing [or substance] which is exuded by the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov, (S, K,) and by the EurofuT, (S,) and the vumaAm, and the Eu$ar, (K,) resembling gum, and sweet, (S,) like honey: (S, K:) it is eaten; (TA;) and sometimes it flows upon the ground, like dibos: and it has an unpleasant smell: mugovuwrN is a dial. var. of mugofuwrN [q. v.]: (S, TA:) the pl. is magaAviyru. (K.)

A^aroDN mugavoriyapN * : see 1. ― -b2- wajada AlmaA='a mugavoriyFA Ealayohi means He found the water to be thronged: (K, TA:) or, accord. to Sgh, (TA,) you say, wajadotu AlmaA='a mugavoriyFA biAlwirodi I found the water to be thronged by the coming thereto. (O, TA.)

div2.head: gvw and gvY
div2.entryFree:
1 gavaA AlwaAdiY * , (Msb, K,) aor. yagovuw, (Msb,) inf. n. gavowN; (Msb, K;) and gavaY, aor. yagoviY, inf. n. gavoyN; (K;) the latter mentioned by IJ, but the former is that which is [commonly] known to the lexicologists; (TA;) The valley, or water-course, was, or became, full of guvaA=' [q. v.]: (Msb: [and the like is indicated in the K:]) or had in a abundance of camels' or similar dung (baEor) and leaves and reeds or canes. (TA.) ― -b2- gavaA All~aHomu, inf. n. gavowN, The flesh-meat was bad by reason of its leanness. (IKtt, TA.) ― -b3- gavati Aln~afosu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. tagoviY, (S, Msb,) inf. n. gavoYN and gavayaAnN; (S, Msb, K;) and, accord. to Lth, gaviyat, aor. tagovaY, inf. n. gavFA, but Az says that this is post-classical; (TA;) i. q. xabuvat; (S, K, TA;) and jaA$at; (TA;) i. e. [The soul, or stomach, heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; or] became agitated so that the person nearly vomited, by reason of a mixture pouring forth to the mouth of the stomach: (Msb, TA:) or, as some say, gavayaAnN signifies a flowing of the mouth which sometimes, or often, occasions vomiting. (TA.) ― -b4- gavati Als~amaA='u biAls~aHaAbi, (K, TA,) aor. tagoviY, (TA,) The sky was, or became, clouded, or covered with clouds: (K, TA:) or began to be so. (TA.) -A2- gavaA Als~ayolu AlmarotaEa, aor. yagovuwhu, inf. n. gavowN; thus accord. to J, [in the S,] but accord. to the K and ISd, gavaY, mentioned in art. gvY; and in [some of] the copies of the K, AlmarobaEa is erroneously put for AlmarotaEa; (TA;) The torrent drew [or washed] together the pasture, and deprived it of its sweetness; as also ↓ AgvAhu. (S, K.) ― -b2- And hence, by way of comparison, (TA,) gavaY AlkalaAma, aor. yagoviyhi; (K, TA;) and gaviyahu, aor. yagovaAhu; (K, * TA;) the former verb of the class of ramaY, and the latter of the class of raDiYa; inf. n. gavoYN;
(TA;) (tropical:) He mixed, or put together confusedly, the speech, or language. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And gavaY AlmaAla, and Aln~aAsa, He beat the cattle, and the people, and dealt blows among them. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- gaviyati AlA^aroDu biAln~abaAti The land became abundant in herbage: (K, TA:) or began to be so. (TA.) ― -b5- And gaviYa $aEoruhu, inf. n. gavFY, His hair became matted, or compacted together: mentioned in art. gvY by IKtt: perhaps a dial. var. of EaviYa, with the unpointed E; mentioned before. (TA.)
4 A^a1o2a3a see the preceding paragraph, latter half.

guvaA='N * (S, Msb, K) and guv~aA='N (S, K) The rubbish, or small rubbish, or particles of things, or refuse, and scum, and rotten leaves mixed with the scum, (Zj, S, * Msb, * K, TA,) borne upon the surface (S, Msb, TA) of a torrent: (Zj, S, Msb, K, TA:) or dried-up [or decayed] and broken pieces [or leaves and stalks] of herbage, that are seen upon a torrent: so in the Kur lxxxvii. 5: [see A^aHowaY in art. Hw:] (TA:) pl. A^agovaA='N. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, maAluhu guvaA='N waEamaluhu habaA='N wasaEoyuhu xafaA='N (assumed tropical:) [His property is as rubbish borne by a torrent (see Kur xxiii. 43), and his work is as motes that are seen in the rays of the sun (see Kur xxv. 25), and his labour, or earning, is a thing that is unapparent]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] guvaA='u Aln~aAsi (assumed tropical:) The low, or vile, and the refuse, of mankind. (TA.)

AlA^agovaY *
The lion. (K.)
1 gud~a * and gad~a , said of a camel: see 4.
2 gud~ida * : see 4. -A2- gad~ada, inf. n. tagodiydN, He took his [gud~ap, i. e.] lot, portion, or share. (K.)

4 A^agad~a * (S, A, O, L, Msb, K) and A^ugid~a, (O, L, K,) and ↓ gud~a, (Az, O, L, K,) this last heard by Az from the Arabs, (L,) [in the CK ↓ gad~a, but (though the phrase gud~ato A_ibiluhumo occurs there afterwards) gud~a may be less correct than gad~a, for the part. n. of the former was disallowed by As,] and ↓ gud~ida, (Az, O, K,) He (a camel) had the disease termed gud~ap [q. v.]; (Az, S, O, L, Msb, K;) or had gudad [pl. of gud~apN] between the flesh and the skin. (L.) ― -b2- Hence, (A,) A^agad~a signifies also (tropical:) He (a man, As, S, A, O) was, or became, angry, (As, S, O, L,) or swollen by reason of anger, as though he were a camel having the disease termed gud~ap: (A:) and A^agad~a Ealayohi he was angry with him; (K;) or he swelled against him and was angry with him. (L.) ― -b3- And A^agad~a Alqawomu The people, or party, had their camels affected with the disease termed gud~ap. (S, O, L, K.)
gadN * : see art. gdw.

gud~apN * (IDrd, S, O, L, Msb, K) and ↓ gudadapN (S, O, L, K) [A ganglion; i. e.] any hard lump in the tendinous parts; (L, K;) [a lump of] flesh arising from disease, between the skin and the flesh, which may be made to move about: (Msb:) and any small nodous lump (Euqodap) in the body (IDrd, O, L, K) of a man, (IDrd, O, L,) surrounded by fat: (IDrd, O, L, K:) pl. gudadN [properly pl. of gud~apN, and also a coll. gen. n. of which gudadapN is the n. un.]: (S, O, L, Msb, K:) gud~apN [is applied in the present day to a ganglion: and a bubo: and a wen: and all these may be meant by its being said that it] also signifies a [swelling such as is termed] siloEap, (L, K,) overspread by fat. (L.) ― -b2- And gud~apN signifies likewise The plague, or pestilence, (TaAEuwn,) in camels; (As, S, O, L, K;) as also ↓ gadadN: (K:) or the same in camels as the TAEwn in man: (Msb:) it attacks them in the groins, and seldom do they recover from it: (L:) or it is only in the belly; (K, TA;) and when it extends to the camel's naHor [or part where he is stabbed, or stuck, when he is slaughtered], and to his groin, or arm-pit, the epithet daAbirN [so in the TA, but in the O daAriy^N, which I believe to be the right reading,] is applied to him: so says IAar: (TA:) or it is also in the fat parts; (Lth, O, L;) and between the flesh and the skin. (L.) ― -b3- And What is between the fat and the hump [of the camel]. (K.) -A2- Another signification of gud~apN is A part, or portion, of property; (L, K;) as in the saying, Ealayohi gud~apN mino maAlK [He owes a part, or portion, of some property]: (L:) pl. gadaAy^idu, (L, K,) and, in some of the copies of the K, gidaAdN. (TA.) And [these two pls.] gadaAy^idu and gidaAdN signify also Lots, portions, or shares: (L, K:) thus, accord. to Fr, the former of them means in a verse of Lebeed cited and expl. voce EadiydapN; but the reading better known is EadaAy^idu: accord. to Az, gadaAy^idu in this instance signifies redundances. (L.)
gadadN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
gudadapN * : see gud~apN. ― -b2- [The pl.] gadadaAtN is expl. by AHeyth as signifying Redundances of fatness: and redundances of goodly [fur, such as is termed] wabar. (L.)
gaAd~N * : see mugid~N, in two places.
mugad~N * : see the paragraph here following.

mugid~N * A camel having the disease termed gud~apN; (As, Az, S, O, L, K;) as also ↓ mugad~N (L) and ↓ magoduwdN, (Az, L, K,) or this is not said, (As, O, K,) but it was heard by Az from the Arabs, (O, L,) and ↓ mugad~adN (Az, L) and ↓ gaAd~N: (O, L, K:) mugid~N, without p, is also applied to a she-camel: and its pl. is magaAd~u: (L:) the pl. of ↓ gaAd~N is gidaA*N. (O, L, K. *) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) An angry man: (As, S, L:) or swollen by reason of anger, (A, L,) as though he were a camel having the disease termed gud~ap. (A.) One says, raA^ayotu fulaAnFA mugid~FA and ↓ musomagid~FA (tropical:) I saw such a one swollen with anger. (L.)
mugad~adN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
migodaAdN * (assumed tropical:) A man, (S, O, L, K,) and a woman, (O, L, K,) much, or often, in anger: (S, O, L, K:) or always angry: (O, K:) or angry in disposition or nature. (O, L.)
magoduwdN * : see mugid~N.
musomagid~N * : see mugid~N.

1 gadarahu * , (K,) and [more commonly] gadara bihi, aor.
gadira (S, M, IKtt, Msb, K) and
gadura ; (M, IKtt, K;) and gadira, aor.
gadara , (Lh, K,) but ISd doubts the correctness of this last; (TA;) inf. n. gadorN, (S, Msb, K,) of gadara; (S, Msb, TA;) and gadarN (TA, and so in the CK in the place of gador,) and gadaraAnN, (K, TA,) which are both of gadira; (TA;) He acted perfidiously, unfaithfully, faithlessly, or treacherously, to him; (M, K;) he broke his compact, contract, covenant, or the like, with him; (Msb;) he neglected the performance, or fulfilment, of his compact, &c., with him: (S:) gadorN is the contr. of wafaA='N, (K,) or of wafaA='N biEahodK: (M:) or it signifies the being remiss in a thing, and neglecting it. (B.) -A2- gadara, aor.
gadira , (T, O, K,) inf. n. gadorN, (T, O,) He drank the water of the gadiyr [q. v.]: (T, O, K:) and, accord. to the K, gadira, he drank the water of the sky; but this is a sheer mistake, occasioned by a misunderstanding of a saying in the T; here following: (TA:) Az says that gadara meaning as expl. above should accord. to analogy be gadira, like kariEa meaning “ he drank the karaE, ” i. e. the water of the sky: (O, TA:) moreover, a distinction is strangely made in the K between the water of the gadiyr and the water of the sky. (TA.) -A3- gadarato waladahaA, said of a woman, is like dagaratohu [q. v.]. (TA.) -A4- gadira, [aor.
gadara , inf. n. gadarN,] He remained, or lagged, behind; as also ↓ tgd~r, accord. to As, who cites the following verse of Imra-el-Keys:
Ea$iy~apa jaAwazonaA HamaApa wasayorunaA
A^axuw Aljahodi laA nalowiY EalaY mino tagod~araA
[In the evening when we passed beyond Hamáh, and our journeying was laborious, we not waiting for such as lagged behind]: but accord. to one relation it is taEa*~ara, which means [the same, or] “ held back, or withheld himself, for a cause rendering him excused. ” (TA.) You say gadira Eano A^aSoHaAbihi He remained, or lagged, behind his companions. (TA.) And gadirati Aln~aAqapu Eani AlA_ibili, (S, K,) and Al$~aApu Eani Alganami, (S,) The she-camel remained, or lagged, behind the other camels, (S, K,) not coming up to them, (TA,) and so the sheep, or goat, behind the other sheep, or goats. (S.) And gadara fulaAnN baEoda A_ixowatihi Such a one remained after the death of his brothers. (TA. [But gadara, here, is app. a mistake for gadira, unless both forms be allowable.]) -A5- gadira All~ayolu; (K;) or gadirati All~ayolapu, aor.
gadara , inf. n. gadarN; and ↓ A^agodarat;
(S;) The night became dark: (K:) or became intensely dark. (S.) -A6- gadirati Alganamu, (K,) inf. n. gadarN, (TA,) The sheep, or goats, became satiated in the place of pasture in the first of the growth thereof. (K.) -A7- gadirati AlA^aroDu The land abounded with gadar [q. v.]. (K.)

2 gd~r *
He cast men, or made them to fall, into what is termed gadar [q. v.]; and ↓ Agdr may signify the same. (O.)

3 gAdrhu * , inf. n. mugaAdarapN (S, K) and gidaArN; (K;) and ↓ Agdrhu; (S, K;) He left him, or it; (S, K;) he left him, or it, remaining. (K.) It is said in the Kur xviii. 47, laA yugaAdiru SagiyrapF walaA kabiyrapF It will not leave, or omit, or it will not fall short of, (TA,) a small sin nor a great sin. (Jel.) And in a trad., yaA layotaniY guwdirotu maEa A^aSoHaAbi nuHoSi Aljabali Would that I had [been left behind, and had] suffered martyrdom with the people of the foot of the mountain of Ohud, who were slain there, and the other martyrs: said by Mohammad. (A 'Obeyd.) [See also a verse of 'Antarah cited voce mutarad~amN; and another, of Kutheiyir, voce EasobN.] ― -b2- Agdr also signifies He left behind. (TA.) You say Aln~aAqapa ↓ Agdr, and Al$~aApa, He (the pastor) left the she-camel behind the other camels, and the sheep, or goat, behind the other sheep, or goats. (S.) And lahu *`lika fiY qalobiY mawad~apF i. e. [Such a one aided me, and that] left remaining [in my heart a love for him]. (Lh, TA.)
4 A^agodara see 3, in four places: -A2- and see also 1: -A3- and 2.
5 tagad~ara see gadira.

10 Astgdr *
It (a place) had in it pools of water left by a torrent or torrents. (K.) ― -b2- And Aisotagodarato hunaAka gudurN Pools of water left by a torrent or torrents became formed there. (S.)

gadarN * ; pl. guduwrN: see gudorapN, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, A^aloqati Aln~aAqapu gadarahaA The she-camel cast forth what her womb had left remaining in it of blood and foul matter [after her bringing forth]. (TA.) And A^aloqati Al$~aApu guduwrahaA The ewe, or she-goat, cast forth the water and blood and other remains in her womb after bringing forth. (TA.) ― -b3- And fiY Aln~ahori gadarN In the river, or rivulet, is slime remaining when the water has sunk into the earth. (TA.) -A2- gadarN signifies also A place such as is termed Zalif [app. as meaning hard, and that does not show a footmark, or rugged and hard], abounding with stones: (S, O, TA:) or a place abounding with stones, difficult to traverse: (TA:) or any difficult place, through which the beast can hardly, or in nowise, pass: (K:) or soft ground, in which are [trenches, or channels, such as are termed] laxaAqiyq: (TA:) or burrows, (Lh, S, K, TA,) and banks, or ridges, worn and undermined by water, (Lh, TA,) and uneven laxaAqiyq in the ground: (Lh, S, K, TA: [and the like is also said in the TA on the authority of As:]) and stones (K, TA) with trees; thus accord. to AZ and IKtt: (TA:) and anything that conceals one, and obstructs his sight: pl. A^agodaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, maA A^avobata gadarahu, meaning maA A^avobatahu fiY Algadari [How firm is he in traversing the rugged and hard and stony place! &c.]: this is said of the horse: and also (assumed tropical:) of the man when his tongue is firm in the place of slipping and of contention or litigation: (S, TA:) or, accord. to Lh, it means (assumed tropical:) how firm, or valid, is his argument, or plea, and how seldom does harm in consequence of slipping and stumbling befall him! or, accord. to Ks, how firm is what remains of his intellect or understanding! but ISd says that this explanation did not please him. (TA.) And farasN vabotu Algadari A horse firm, or steady, in the place of slipping. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) And rajulN vabotu Algadari (tropical:) A man firm, or steadfast, in fight, or conflict, (S, K, TA,) or in altercation or disputation, or in speech, (S accord. to different copies,) or and in altercation or disputation, (K, TA,) and in speech; (TA;) and also in everything that he commences. (K, TA.) And accord. to Ibn-Buzurj one says, A_in~ahu lavabotu Algadari, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is strong in talking or discoursing, with men, and in contending, or disputing, with them. (L.) [See also vabotN.]

gadirN * [part. n. of gadira]. ― -b2- See gaAdirN, last sentence but one. -A2- And see also gaduwrN. -A3- You say also layolapN gadirapN and ↓ mugodirapN (S, K) meaning A dark night; (K;) as also ↓ gadoraA='u: (IKtt, TA:) or an intensely-dark night, (S,) in which the darkness confines men in their places of alighting or abode, and their shelter, so that they remain behind: or, as some say, such a night is termed ↓ mugodirapN because it casts him who goes forth therein into the gdr [i. e. gadar]. (L, TA.)
gudaru * and gudarN: see gaAdirN, in six places: -A2- and for gudarN, see also gadiyrN.
gadorapN * [an inf. n. un., signifying An act of perfidy. unfaithfulness, faithlessness, or treachery]: see two exs. voce gaAdirN.

gudorapN * and ↓ gidorapN, (K,) or ↓ gidarapN, (ISk, Az, TA,) and ↓ gadarapN and ↓ gadarN, (Lh, TA,) and ↓ gudaArapN, with damm, (K,) or ↓ gidaArapN, (as written in the L,) A portion that is left, or left remaining, of a thing; (K, * TA;) a remain, remainder, remnant, relic, or residue: (Lh, ISk, Az, L:) the pl. of gudoArapN is gudoraAtN (K) [and accord. to analogy gudaraAtN and guduraAtN] and app. gudarN; (TA;) and that of ↓ gidarapN [or ↓ gidorapN] is gidarN and gidaraAtN; (ISk, Az;) and that of ↓ gadarN is guduwrN. (TA.) You say, EalaY mina AlS~adaqapi ↓ fulaAnK gidarN Such a one owes arrears of the poor-rate. (ISk.) And EalaY baniY fulaAnK mina AlS~adaqapi ↓ gadarapN and ↓ gadarN The sons of such a one owe an arrear of the poor-rate. (Lh, L.) And mino maraDK ↓ bihi gaAdirN In him is a relic of disease; like gaAbirN. (TA.)
gidorapN * , and the pl. gidarN: see gudorapN, in three places.
gadarapN * : see gudorapN, in two places. gidarapN, and the pl. gidarN: see gudorapN, in three places.

gadoraA='u *
Darkness. (K.) ― -b2- See also gadirN. -A2- A^aroDN gadoraA='u Land abounding with places of the kind termed gadar. (IKtt, TA.)
gadaAri * : see gaAdirN.

gaduwrN * : see gaAdirN, in two places. -A2- Also A she-camel that remains, or lags, behind the other camels: (K, TA:) in some of the copies of the K gaduwrapN, with p; but the former is the right. (TA.) And gabirapN gamorapN ↓ naAqapN gadirapN A she-camel that remains, or lags, behind the other camels, in being driven. (Lh.)

gadiyrN *
A pool of water left by a torrent: (A 'Obeyd, S, M, K:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufaAEilN, from gaAdarhu, or mufoEalN, from A^agodarahu; or, as some say, of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN; (S;) because it is unfaithful to those who come to it to water, failing when much wanted: (S, * TA:) but it is a subst.; [not an epithet; or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, and only used as a subst.:] you do not say h`*aA maA='N gadiyrN: (Lh:) or a place in which rain-water stagnates, whether small or large, not remaining until the summer: (Lth:) or a river: (Msb:) [but this is extr.:] pl. [of pauc. A^agodirapN, (occurring in a verse cited voce A_il~aA, &c.,) and of mult.] gudoraAnN (S, Msb, K, TA) and gudurN (S, Nh, L, TA,) which last is sometimes contracted into gudorN: (TA:) in the K, the last pl. is said to be of the measure of SuradN; [i. e. ↓ gudarN;] but this is inconsistent with what is said in other lexicons, as shown above: and it is also said in the K that gudarN signifies the same as gadiyrN, in the sense first given above; but it appears that this is a pl. of gudorapN; and that, in the K, we should read, for waAlgadiyru, kaAlgadiyri, and place this before, instead of after, its explanation. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) A piece of herbage; (TA;) as also ↓ gadiyrapN: pl. gudoraAnN: (K, TA;) this is the only pl. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, (TA,) (tropical:) A sword; (K, TA;) like as it is called luj~N. (TA.) ― -b4- And ↓ gadiyrapN also signifies A she-camel left by the pastor (S, K) behind the other camels; and in like manner, a sheep, or goat. (S.)
gudaArapN * or gidaArapN: see gudorapN.

gadiyrapN * : see gadiyrN, last two sentences. -A2- Also A portion, or lock, or plaited lock, of hair, hanging from the head; syn. *uw^aAbapN: (S, K:) accord. to Lth, every EaqiySap is a gadiyrap; and the gadiyrataAni are the two portions, or locks, or plaited locks, of hair (*aw^aAbataAni) which fall upon the breast: (TA:) pl. gadaAy^iru: (S, K:) or gdAy^r pertain to women, and are plaited; and DafaAy^ir, to men. (TA.) -A3- gadiyrapu AlHaAy^iki means The hollow, in the ground, in which the weaver puts his legs, or feet: also called Alwahodapu. (Mgh in art. whd.)
gad~aArN * : see gaAdirN; the first and third, in two places.
gad~iyrN * : see gaAdirN; the first and third, in two places.
gad~aArapN * : see gaAdirN; the first and third, in two places.

gaAdirN * and ↓ gudarN [respecting which see below] (S, K) and ↓ gaduwrN and ↓ gad~aArN and ↓ gid~iyrN (K) are epithets applied to a man [and signifying, the first, Perfidious, unfaithful, faithless, or treacherous; or acting perfidiously, &c.; and the rest, very perfidious, &c.]: (S, K:) and ↓ gaduwrN and ↓ gad~aArN and ↓ gad~aArapN are epithets applied to a woman [and signifying as above]: (K:) but ↓ gudar is mostly used in calling to a man and reviling him: (S:) you say to a man, yaA gu*aru [O very perfidious man]; (S, K;) and in like manner, ↓ yaA magodaru, and ↓ yA magodiru, and ↓ yaA A@bona magodarK, and ↓ yA Abn magodirK, all determinate; (K, TA;) and to a woman, ↓ yA gadaAri, like qaTaAmi: (K:) [accord. to some, ↓ gudar is only used in this manner, and is therefore without tenween; for] it is said that rajulN gudaru is not allowable, because gudaru is determinate: but Sh says rajulN gudarN, writing it, says Az, with tenween, contr. to what Lth says; and this is correct; a word of the measure fuEal being imperfectly decl. [only] when it is a determinate subst., like Eumaru and zufaru: and IAth says that gudaru is altered from its original form, which is gaAdirN, for the sake of intensiveness: (TA:) in the pl. [sense] you say yaAla gudara, (S,) or yaA lagudara, [for yaA A=la gudara, (see the letter l, and see A=lN, in art. Awl,)] like yaA lafujara. (TA.) It is said in a trad., ↓ yaA gudaru ↓ A^alasotu A^asoEaY fiY gadoratika [app. meaning, O thou very perfidious: am I not striving, or labouring, in respect of thine act of perfidy, to rectify it?]. (S: but in one copy, gudoratika.) And in another trad., relating to El-Hodeybiyeh, wahalo ↓ yaA gudaru A_il~aA biA@loA^amosi ↓ gasalota gadorataka [O thou very perfidious: and didst thou wash away thine act of perfidy save yesterday?]: said by 'Orweh Ibn-Mes'ood to El-Mugheereh. (TA.) And in another trad., ↓ Aijoliso gudaru [Sit thou, O very perfidious]; for yaA gudaru: said by 'Áïsheh to El-Kásim. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ↓ sinuwna gad~aArapN (tropical:) Years in which is much rain and little herbage; from [the inf. n.] Algadoru; i. e. that excite people's eager desire for abundance of herbage, by the rain, and then fail to fulfil their promise. (TA.) ― -b3- [And ↓ gadirN is app. syn. with gaAdirN; for] gadirapN occurs in a trad. applied to land (A^aroD), as though meaning (assumed tropical:) Not producing herbage bountifully; or giving growth to herbage, and then soon becoming blighted, or blasted; wherefore it is likened to the gaAdir, who acts unfaithfully. (TA.) -A2- See also gudorapN, last sentence.
magodar * and magodir: see gaAdirN, each in two places.
layolapN mugodirapN * : see gadirN, in two places.

1 gadafa lahu fiY AlEaTaA='i * , (aor.
gadufa , inf. n. gadofN, TK,) He was profuse to him in giving. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

4 Agdft qinaAEahaA *
She (a woman, S) let down, or let fall, her [head-covering called] qnAE upon her face. (S, K.) 'Antarah says,
A_ino tugodifiY duwniY AlqinaAEa faA_in~aniY
Tab~N biA^axo*i AlfaArisi Almusotaloy^imi
(S,) i. e. If, O my beloved, thou let down before me the head-covering, meaning if thou veil thyself from me, I am expert in capturing the mail-clad horseman: then how should I lack power to capture thee? (EM p. 236.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Agdf All~ayolu (tropical:) The night let down its curtains [of darkness]. (S, K.) ― -b3- And Al$~abakapa EalaY AlS~ayodi He (a sportsman, or fowler, or the like,) let fall the net upon the object, or objects, to be captured. (S, K.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad., A_in~a qaloba Almuw^omini A^a$ad~u A@rotikaADFA mina Al*~anobi yuSiybuhu mina AlEuSofuwri Hiyna yugodafu bihi (S, TA,) i. e. [Verily the heart of the believer is more vehemently agitated in consequence of the offence that he purposes than the sparrow] when the net is made to cover it, whereupon it struggles to escape: (TA:) or mina AlxaTiyoy^api [i. e. in consequence of the sin that he is tempted to commit]. (So in the O, instead of min Al*nb ySybh.) ― -b4- Agdf bihaA (assumed tropical:) He compressed her, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K,) i. e., a woman: (Ibn-'Abbád, O:) or, as in the A, he went in to her. (TA.) ― -b5- Agdf said of the sea [app. from the same verb said of the night] (tropical:) It became confusedly agitated in its waves; expl. by the words AiEotakarato A^amowaAjuhu. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) He slept. (AA, TA in art. sdf.) ― -b7- And, accord. to Lh, (O,) Agdf said of the circumciser (O, K, TA) of a boy (O) means He cut off entirely the prepuce; (O, K, TA;) like A^asoHata; (O, TA;) but ISd holds that the latter has this meaning, and the former means he left somewhat thereof: (TA:) one says to the circumciser, laA tugodifo walaA tusoHito, (O, TA,) but this means Leave not thou much of the skin, nor cut off entirely. (TA.)

8 Agtdf minohu *
He (a man, O) took from him (another man, O) much. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And Agtdf Alv~awoba He cut the garment, or piece of cloth. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

12 Aigodawodafa *
It (the night) came with its darkness. (TA.)

gadafN *
A state of ease, and plentifulness, or ampleness: so in the saying, Alqawomu fiY gadafK mino Eayo$ihimo (O, K *) or maEiy$atihimo (TA) [The people, or party, are in a state of ease, &c., in respect of their means of subsistence]: thus in the O and TS: but in the L, mn mEy$thm ↓ fY gudAfK. (TA.)

gudofapN *
A thing in the form of the [head-covering called] qinaAE, worn by the women of the Arabs of the desert. (TA.)
gidofapN * The apparel of the king. (TA.)

gudaAfN * The crow, (S, O, K, TA,) or, as some say, the large crow, (TA,) of the summer, or hot season: (S, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to some, in an absolute sense, the crow: (TA:) or the large crow that is full in the wings: (JK:) or the black crow: (MA:) pl. gidofaAnN. (S, O.) ― -b2- And A vulture having abundant plumage (S, O, K) is sometimes thus called: (S, O:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b3- And Long, (S, O, K, TA,) abundant, (TA,) black hair. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b4- Also A black wing. (S, K, TA.) And Anything intensely black is termed gudaAfN, and ↓ A^asowadu gudaAfiY~N. (TA.) -A2- See also gadafN.
gudaAfiY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

mgdf * , [app. mugodifN, or perhaps taken from a mistranscription for mugodiqN,] as an epithet applied to means of subsistence (Eayo$N), signifies Smooth and ample. (TA.) [Freytag mentions mugad~afN and mugad~aqN, each having the fem. with p, as signifying Copious, applied to rain: both from the “ Fákihet el-Khulafà, ” p. 141, l. 3; where the word is mgdqp, evidently mugodiqap, and rhyming with muTobiqap.]

1 gadiqati AlEayonu * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
gadaqa , inf. n. gadaqN, (Msb,) The spring, or source, abounded with water; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Agdqt, inf. n. A_igodaAqN. (Msb.) And gadiqa AlmaTaru, inf. n. as above; (Msb;) and ↓ Agdq, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. A^igodaAqN; (Msb;) and ↓ Aigodawodaqa; (K;) and ↓ gayodaqa; (Abu-l-'Omeythil, TA;) The rain was, or became, copious. (O, Msb, K, TA.) And gadiqato sanatunaA [Our year was, or became, rainy]. (O.) And gadiqa, aor. and inf. n. as above, There was abundance of rain, or dew, or moisture, or of water, in the place. (Zj, TA.) ― -b2- gadaqN is also used in relation to herbs, or herbage, as meaning The being plentifully irrigated, or flourishing and fresh, juicy, or moist. (En-Nadr, AHn, TA.) ― -b3- And you say, gadiqati AlA^aroDu, and ↓ Agdqt, meaning The land abounded, or became abundant, with herbage, or with the produce of the earth. (TA.) ― -b4- And gadaqati AlA^aroDu, aor.
gadiqa , being of the class of Daraba, The land became moistened by abundant water. (Msb.)
4 A^agodaqa see the preceding paragraph in three places.
12 A_igodawodaqa see 1, second sentence.
Q. Q. 1 gayodaqa * : see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) He (a man, Ibn-'Abbád, O) had much saliva; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA;) or, accord. to the L, much slaver. (TA.)

gadaqN * [an inf. n.: and used in the sense of the part. n. ↓ gadiqN, meaning] Abundant, or copious; applied to water; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) not restricted to rain; (TA;) as also ↓ mugodiqN and ↓ mugodawodiqN, both applied to rain, and the latter [or both] applied to water [in general]; and ↓ gayodaAqN likewise, applied to water, and, as AA
says, to rain: or gadaqN is applied to rain as meaning abundant, or copious, [so as to be] general in its extent. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [lxxii. 16], lawi A@sotaqaAmuwA EalaY A@lT~ariyqapi laA^asoqayonaAhumo maA='F gadaqFA [If they should go on undeviatingly in the way which they are pursuing, we would water then with abundant water]; (O, TA;) to try them thereby; the Tryqp here being that of infidelity; so says Th, and in like manner Fr; but others say that it is that of the right direction: (TA:) 'Ásim Ibn-Abi-n-Najood read ↓ gadiqFA. (O, TA.) In the saying, in a trad., Aall~`hum~a A@soqinaA gadaqFA ↓ mugodiqFA, the last word is used as a corroborative [the meaning being O God, water us very abundantly]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also gayodaAqN.

gadiqN * : see gadaqN, in two places. You say also EayonN gadiqapN A spring, or source abounding with water. (Msb.) And A^aroDN gadiqapN Land that is moist and irrigated in the utmost degree; abounding with water. (TA.) And Eu$obN gadiqN Herbs, or herbage, plentifully irrigated, or flourishing and fresh, juicy, or moist. (En-Nadr, AHn, TA.)
EayonN gudayoqapN * : see EayonN, near the end of the paragraph.
gayodaqN * : see each in two places in the next paragraph.
gayodaqaAnN * : see each in two places in the next paragraph.

gayodaAqN * : see gadaqN. ― -b2- [Hence,] Eayo$N gayodaAqN A life ample in its means, or circumstances; plentiful; as also ↓ gayodaqN: and mina ↓ humo fiY gadaqK AlEayo$i and gayodaAqK [They are in an ample, or a plentiful, state of life]. (TA.) And EaAmN gayodaAqN A year abounding in herbage, fruitful, or plentiful; and so sanapN gayodaAqN, without p [to the latter word]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A_in~ahu lagayodaAqu AljaroYi and AlEadowi Verily he is wide-stepping in respect of running. (TA.) ― -b4- And $ad~N gayodaAqN A vehement running. (TA.) ― -b5- gayodaAqN applied to a horse signifies TawylN [app. meaning Long-bodied]. (O, K.) ― -b6- And, applied to a man, (S, O, TA,) Generous; (S, O, K, TA;) bountiful; large, or liberal, in disposition; munificent; (TA;) and so ↓ gayodaqaAnN; (K, * TA;) or this, some say, signifies abundant, ample, as applied to anything. (TA.) ― -b7- Also, and ↓ gayodaqN, (S, O, K,) and ↓ gayodaqaAnN, (O, K,) Soft, or tender; applied to a youth, or young man; (S, O, K;) and to youth, or youthfulness, (O, K,) as also gdAqY [app. a mistranscription for ↓ gayodaAqiY~N]: (TA:) and it is said that gayodaAqN applied to a boy signifies that has not attained to puberty. (TA.) ― -b8- And gayodaAqN signifies also The young one of the [lizard called] Dab~, (AZ, S, O, K,) after the state in which it is termed HisolN [q. v.]. (AZ, S, O.) ― -b9- And [the pl.] gayaAdiyqu signifies Serpents. (S, O, L, K.)
gayodaAqiY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mugodiqN * : see gadaqN, in two places. [mugod~aqN mentioned by Freytag as signifying “ copious, ” applied to rain, is a mistake: see the last paragraph of art. gdf.]
mugodawodiqN * : see gadaqN, first sentence.

1 gadaA * , (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yagoduw, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. Euduw~N (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and gadowN (M, TA, and so accord. to the CK instead of guduw~N [which is the only inf. n. commonly known]) and gudowapN, (K,) He went, or went away, in the time called gudowap, (Mgh, Msb,) i. e. [the early part of the morning,] the period between the prayer of daybreak and sunrise: this is the primary signification: (Msb:) or i. q. bak~ara [he went forth early in the morning; in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise]; so in the phrase gadaA Ealayohi [he went forth early in the morning, &c., to him, or it]; (K;) as also ↓ AgtdY: (S, * K:) and ↓ gAdAhu signifies the same as gadaA Ealayohi; (S;) or the same as baAkarahu [which is syn. with bak~ara Ealayohi as expl. above; and signifies also, like bak~ara Ealayohi, he hastened to it, or to do it, at any time, morning or evening]: (ISd, K, TA:) Alguduw~u is the contr of Alr~awaAHu [inf. n. of raAHa]. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [lxviii. 22], A^ani A@goduwA EalaY Harovikumo [Saying, Go ye forth early, &c., to your land's produce]: and the saying of a poet,
waAlT~ayoru fiY wukunaAtihaA ↓ waqado A^agotadiY
[And sometimes, or often, I go forth early, &c., while the birds are in their nests]. (TA.) ― -b2- Afterwards, by reason of frequency of use, it became employed as meaning He went, or went away, or departed, at any time. (Mgh, * Msb, TA.) Hence the saying, (Mgh, Msb,) of the Prophet, (Msb,) in a trad., (Mgh,) Augodu yaA A^unayosu, (Mgh, Msb,) meaning Depart then, O (??) (Msb.) ― -b3- [Freytag bas erroneously assigned to it another meaning, i. e. “ Nutrivit ” misled by his finding tagoduwo put for tago*uw in art. TlY in the CK.] ― -b4- gadiYa: see 5.
2 gad~ayotuhu * , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tagodiyapN, (Msb, K,) I fed him with the meal called gadaA=' [q. v.]. (S, * Msb, K.)
3 gaAodawa see 1, first sentence. One says, A^anaA A^uEaAdiyhi waA^uraAwiHuhu expl. in the first paragraph of art. rwH.

5 tgd~Y * [He ate the meal called gadaA=', q. v.; properly,] he ate in the first part of the day; (S, Msb, * K;) as also ↓ gadiYa, (IKtt, K, TA,) inf. n. gadFA. (TK: but in the TA written gdA'.) When it is said to thee, tagad~a [Eat thou the gadaA='], thou sayest, maA biY mino tagad~K [I have no desire for eating the gadaA=']; and not maA biY gadaA='N, for [the] gadaA=' is the meal itself. (S, Msb. See also 5 in art. E$w.) tagad~aY fiY ramaDaAna means tasaH~ara [i. e. He ate the meal, or drank the draught of milk, called saHuwr, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And tagad~ati AlA_ibilu means The camels pastured in the first part of the day. (AHn, TA.)
8 A_igotadawa see 1, first and second sentences. [10. AstgdY accord. to Freytag is syn. with tagad~aY; but for this I do not find any authority.]

gadN * , meaning The morrow, the day next after the present day, (Msb,) is originally ↓gadowN, (S, Msb, K,) the w being elided, (S, Msb,) without any substitution, (S,) and the d being made a letter of declinability. (Msb.) And one says gadFA meaning [I will do such a thing, &c.,] tomorrow: and baEoda gadK the day after to-morrow. (MA.) See also gadaApN. ― -b2- And its signification has been extended so that it is applied to a remote time that is expected, (Msb, TA,) and to a near time. (Nh, TA.) ― -b3- It is not used in its complete form except in poetry: (Nh, TA:) Lebeed, (S, TA,) or Dhu-r-Rummeh, (TA,) has thus used it in his saying,
wamaA Aln~aAsu A_il~aA kaAld~iyaAri waA^aholuhaA
balaAqiEu ↓ bihaA yawoma Hal~uwhaA wagadowFA
[And mankind are no other than the like of dwellings, the occupants thereof being in them daring the day in which they have alighted in them, and to-morrow they are vacant]: (S, TA:) or, accord. to the M, one says, h`*aA Eaduka and ↓ h`*aA gadowuka [This is thy morrow]. (TA.) ― -b4- It has no diminutive. (Sb, S, in art. Ams.)
gadowN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in there places.

gadaApN * : see gudowapN, in four places: though [properly] fem., and not heard as made mase., it may be made mase. if meant to be understood as signifying the “ first part of the day: ” (IAmb, Msb:) it is originally gadawapN, because its pl. is gadawaAtN. (IHsh, TA.) One says, ↓ A=tiyka gadaApa gadK [I will come to thee in the early part of the morning, &c., of to-morrow]. (S, TA.) biA@logadaApi waA@loEa$iY~i in the Kur [vi. 52 and xviii. 27] means After the prayer of daybreak and [after] the prayer of [the period of the afternoon called] the EaSor: or, accord. to some, [it means in the morning and the evening, or rather in the forenoon and the afternoon, for they say that] it denotes constancy of religious service: Ibn-'Ámir and Aboo-'Abd-erRahmán Es-Sulamee read waA@loEa$iY~i ↓ biA@logudowapi; but the former is the common reading; and A 'Obeyd says, we think that they read thus following the handwriting, for it is written in all the copies of the Kur-án with w like AlS~alawp and Alz~akawp, and this is not an indication of the reading [which they have adopted], as the w in AlSlwp and Alzkwp is not pronounced [otherwise than as an] of prolongation except that it requires the fet-hah that follows to be uttered with a somewhat broad sound]. (TA.) ― -b2- huwa A@bonu gadaAtayoni means He is a son of two days [i. e. he is two days old]. (TA.) ― -b3- The dim. is ↓ guday~apN: (TA:) or this is the dim. of ↓ gudowapN: (EM p. 56:) one says, A^arokabu
A_ilayohi guday~apF [I will ride to him, or it, in a short period of an early part of a morning, &c.]: and one says also, ↓ *atayotuhu guday~aAnaAtK [I came to him, or it, in short periods of early parts of mornings, &c.]; an anomalous [pl.] dim. like Eu$ay~aAnaAt; both of which are mentioned by Sb. (TA.)

gadowapN *
A journey in the first part of the day: [an inf. n. un. of gadaA:] opposed to rawoHapN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph. ― -b3- And see gadaA='N.

gudowapN * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) and ↓ gadowapN, said by MF to be well known, and ↓ gidowapN, said by him to be rare, or disapproved, (TA,) The early part of the morning; the first part of the day; (K;) or the period between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ gadaApN, and ↓ gadiy~apN, (K, TA,) the last [in the CK gadoyapi, but correctly] a dial. var. of gudowapN, like DaHiy~apN a dial. var. of DaHowapN: (IAar, TA:) or ↓ gadaApN is syn. with DaHowapN [meaning the early part of the forenoon, after sunrise; accord. to some, when the sun is yet low; or, accord. to others, when the sun is somewhat high]: (Msb:) [it may therefore be generally rendered morning, before, or after, sunrise:] the pls. are gudFY, which is pl. of gudowapN; (S, Msb, TA;) and gadawaAtN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) which is pl. of ↓ gadaApN; (S, Msb, TA;) and ↓ guduw~N, (K, TA,) which is a pl. of gudowapN, formed by rejecting the p [of the sing.], or, accord. to the M, an anomalous pl. of ↓ gadaApN, or, as J says, [in the S,] referring to the phrase biA@logaduw~i waA@loA=SaAli, in the Kur [vii. 204 and xiii. 16 and xxiv. 36], biAlguduw~i there means biAlgadawaAti, and is a verb [i. e. an inf. n.] used to denote the time, as [is TuluwE] in the saying TuluwEa Al$~amosi meaning fiY waqoti TuluwEi Al$ms; (TA;) and gadiy~aAtN, (IAar, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, gadayAtN,]) which is pl. of ↓ gadiy~apN; (TA;) and gadaAyaA, (K, TA,) which is likewise a pl. of ↓ gadiy~apN, accord. to IAar, and, if so, regularly formed from gadaAyiwu, in the same manner as has already been expl. in the case of Ea$aAyaA [pl. of Ea$iy~apN, q. v. voce Ea$iY~N]; by some said to be a pl. of gudowapN, but this has been controverted by IHsh in the Expos. of the “ Kaabeeyeh ” and by its commentator ['AbdEl-Kádir] El-Baghdádee; (TA;) or gadaAyaA is not used except in conjunction with Ea$aAyaA; (K, TA;) one says, A_in~iY laA=tiyhi biAlgadaAyaA waAlEa$aAyaA [Verily I come to him in the early parts of mornings and in the late parts of evenings], for the purpose of conformity. (S, TA.) Zj says that when gudowap means The bukorap [or early part of the morning, &c.,] of the present day, or of a particular day, it is imperfectly decl.: and AHei says that it is thus accord. to the opinion commonly obtaining, as is also bukorap, each as being a generic proper name, like A^usaAmapu; and that when you mean to generalize, you say, gudowapN waqotu na$aATK [An early part of a morning is a time of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness]; and when you mean to particularize, laA^asiyran~a All~ayolapa A_ilaY gudowapa [I will assuredly journey to-night until the early part of the morning]: (TA:) [in the latter case also] one says, A^atayotuhu gudowapa [I came to him in the early part of the morning of this, or of a particular, day]; gdwp being here imperfectly decl. because it is determinate, like saHara; but it is of those adv. ns. that may be used otherwise than as adv. ns.: you say, siyra EalaY farasika gudowapa and gudowapF [i. e. Journeying was performed on thy horse, or mare, in the gudowap of this, or of a particular, day, and in a gudowap,] and gudowapN and gudowapN [i. e. the journey of the gudowap of this, or of a particular, day, and the journey of a gudowap, was performed (lit. was journeyed) on thy horse, or mare, gudowapu and gudowapN being for. masiyrapu gudowapa and masiyrapu gudowapK, like as $ahorN in the Kur xxxiv. 11 is for masiyrapu $ahorK]; what is with tenween, of these, being indeterminate, and what is without tenween being determinate. (S. [In one of my copies of the S, siro is put in the place of siyra: that the latter is the right is shown by the addition of gudowapu and gudowapN; for each of these must be what is termed naAy^ibN Eano faAEilK i. e. a substitute for an agent.]) See also gadaApN, in two places.
gidowapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

gadawiY~N * : see gadiY~N. ― -b2- Also Whatever [offspring] is in [any of] the bellies of pregnant animals (AO, K, TA) of camels and of sheep or goats: (AO, TA:) or peculiarly of sheep or goats; (K, TA;) thus in the dial. of the Prophet: (TA:) or it [virtually, in a trad. mentioned in what follows,] means the selling a camel, or other [animal], for what the stallion begets: or the selling a sheep for the offspring begotten by the ram: (K:) in all of which senses ga*iY~N and ga*awiY~N are [said to be] syn.: (K in art. g*w:) or gadawiY~N, (TA,) or ga*awiY~N, or, as some relate a verse of El-Farezdak in which it occurs, gadawiY~N, (S in art. g*w,) means the selling a thing for the offspring begotten by the ram [or, as appears from what follows, by the stallioncamel] in that year: gadawiY~N being a rel. n. from gadN: as though they rendered one desirous by saying, “ Our camels will bring forth and we will give thee to-morrow (gadFA): ” (S in art. g*w, and TA:) what is thus termed is forbidden in a trad.: a man used to buy, for a camel or a she-goat or money, what was in the bellies of pregnant animals; and this is a hazardous proceeding, and was therefore forbidden. (Nh, TA.) See also art. g*w. ― -b3- And see Eadawiy~apN, in art. Edw.

gadoyaAnu *
Eating the meal called gadaA=': (S, K: *) fem. gadoyaA, of the measure faEolaY, applied to a woman; (S;) or gadoyaA='u: (so in copies of the K:) they are originally with w [in the place of the Y], on the ground of preference, as is said in the M: and gadoyaAnapN is mentioned by Z, as applied to a woman, coupled with Ea$oyaAnapN. (TA.)

gadaA='N * The morning-meal, that is eaten between daybreak and sunrise; i. e. the meal, or repast, of the gudowap; (K;) or of the gadaAp; (Msb;) the meal, or repast, that is the contr. of the Ea$A=': (S:) [it may therefore be rendered breakfast: but it is now commonly applied to dinner, which is eaten soon after the prayer of noon, and which is a lighter repast than the Ea$aA=', i. e. supper:] Algdwp [app. ↓ Algadowapu] as meaning AlgadaA='u is vulgar: (TA voce Ea$owapN:) the pl. of gadaA='N is A^ago*iyapN. (K.) And The [meal, or the draught of milk, called] saHuwr is thus termed; because it is to the person fasting the like of what it is to him who is not fasting. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The pasture of camels in the first part of the day. (TA.)
gu*uw~N * : see gudowapN.

gadiY~N *
Of, or relating to, the morrow; the rel. n. from gadN; as also ↓ gadawY~N; (S, K;) the latter allowable. (S.) ― -b2- See also Eadawy~apN, in art. Edw.
gadiy~apN * : see its syn. gudowapN, in three places.
guday~apN * : and see gadaApN, last sentence.
guday~aAnaAtN * : see gadaApN, last sentence.

AlgaAdiY *
The lion: (K, TA:) because he goes forth in the early part of the morning against the prey. (TA.)

gaAdiyapN *
A cloud that rises (S, K) in the SabaAH (S) or in the gudowap (K) [i. e. in the first part of the day]: or a rain of the [period of the morning called] gadaAp: (K, TA:) thus says Lh: the pl. is gawaAdK. (TA.) [See a verse in the Ham p. 429.]

magodFY * and ↓ magodaApN [A place to which people go, or to which they return, in the period of the morning called gudowap; opposed to maraAHN and maraAHapN]. ― -b2- [Hence] one says, maA taraka fulaAnN mino A^abiyhi magodFY walaA maraAHFA, and walaA maraAHapF ↓ magodaApF, expl. in art. rwH. (S in art. rwH, and K in the present art.)
magodaApN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 ga*~a * , aor.
ga*i3a (S, O, L, K, &c.) and
ga*u3a , (K,) but the former aor. only is known, (MF,) inf. n. gad~N, (S, O, L,) It (a wound) flowed with what was in it; as also ↓ Ag*~: (K:) or flowed with thick purulent matter; (S, O;) as also ↓ Ag*~ [and gav~a] and Agv~: (O, L:) or flowed with purulent matter, thick or thin: (Az, O, L:) or became swollen: (Lth, L, K:) or this is a mistake; the true signification being that next preceding. (Az, O, L.) You say, tarakotu juroHahu yagi*~u [I left his wound flowing with thick, or thin, purulent matter]. (S.) ― -b2- Also It (a vein) flowed with blood without stopping; (O, L;) and so ↓ Ag*~. (L.) ― -b3- [And, accord. to Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd, He delayed, or loitered, and remained behind, in (fiY) a journey.] -A2- And gad~ahu He diminished, or impaired, to him; or made him to
lose; syn. naqaSahu; (O, K;) as also minohu ↓ ga*oga*a. (O, K.) You say, maA ga*a*otuka $ayoy^FA i. e. maA naqaSotuka [I did not diminish to thee, &c., or I have not diminished to thee, &c., aught]. (O.)

4 Ag*~ * : see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Ag*~ fiY Als~ayori, (S, * O, * L, K,) inf. n. A_igo*aA*N; (S, O, L;) and Ag*~ Als~ayora; (L, K;) He hastened in the pace or journeying; (S, O, L, K;) and he hastened the pace or journeying. (L, K.) ― -b3- And Abu-l-Hasan Ibn-Keysán thinks, from the use of the phrase sayorN mugi*~N, that one says also, Ag*~ Als~ayoru, meaning The pace, or journeying, was quick. (L.)
R. Q. 1 ga*oga*a * : see 1, last sentence but one.

R. Q. 2 taga*ogada *
He leaped, sprang, or bounded. (O, K.)

ga*iy*apN *
Thick purulent matter (S, O, L, K) of a wound; as also gaviyvapN. (S, O, L.) Yaakoob says that the * of the former is a substitute for the v of the latter; (L;) and so says Ibn-es-Seed. (TA.)

gaA*~N * [act. part. n. of 1, q. v.: as such signifying A vein incessantly bleeding. (L.) ― -b2- Also A recrudescence (Earab [inf. n. of Eariba], so in the O, in copies of the K garab, and in the CK garob, [app. a mistranscription suggested by another explanation of gaA*~N which will be found in what follows,]) in any part of the body. (L, K.) AZ says, what we call AlEarabu, the Arabs term AlgaA*~u. (O.) One says of a camel that has had a gall on the back which has healed but is, or becomes, moist [or exuding], bihi gaA*~N [He has a gall which has healed but is moist, or constantly discharging, or exuding]. (S, O, L.) ― -b3- And A vein, or duct, in the eye, [also called garobN,] which flows incessantly. (L, K.) In this sense, and in that immediately preceding, it is a subst. like kaAhilN and gaAribN. (L.) -A2- And AlgaA*~u signifies AlHis~u: one says, qaTaEa A@ll~`hu gaA*~a fulaAnK i. e. His~ahu [app. meaning May God cause to cease the sound of such a one]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O)

AlgaA*apu *
The part that is in a state of commotion, [or that pulses,] of the top of the head of a [young] child; as also AlgaA*iyapu [which belongs to art. g*w]. (IAar, K, TA.)

A^aga*~u *
More, or most, or very, quick, and brisk, or sprightly. (L.)

sayorN mugi*~N *
A quick pace or journeying: a phrase like layolN naAy^imN. (L. [See also 4: and see an ex. voce muri*~N, in art. r*.])
mugaA*~N * A camel that loathes water. (S, O, L, K.)

1 ga*awotuhu * , (S, Msb, K, TA,) aor. A^ago*uwhu, (Msb,) inf. n. ga*owN, (K,) I fed him, or nourished him, (S, Msb, K, TA,) [for instance,] a child, (S, TA,) with milk; (S, Msb, TA;) and ga*ayotuhu signifies the same, unknown by J, and therefore disallowed by him, (K and TA in art. g*Y,) but known by ISd: (TA in that art.;) and so ↓ ga*~ayotuhu, (S, * Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. tago*iyapN, (S, TA,) [but, accord. to SM.] in an intensive sense. (TA.) And ga*aAhu AlT~aEaAmu, aor. and inf. n. as above, The food [nourished him, or] had an agreeable, a wholesome, or a beneficial, effect upon him, and sufficed him; namely, a child. (Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence,] gu*uw bilibaAni Alkarami (tropical:) [They were fed, or nourished, by sucking the milk of generosity; meaning they derived generosity from their parents]. (TA.) -A2- ga*aA bawolahu, and ga*aA bihi, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a camel) interrupted his urine; (K, TA;) as also ↓ g*~Ahu, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. tago*iyapN. (S, TA.) And ga*aA Alkalobu biga*FY [or biga*FA] The dog emitted urine in repeated discharges. (TA.) -A3- ga*aA, said of urine, It became interrupted: (S, K, TA:) the verb being intrans. as well as trans. (TA.) ― -b2- And, (S, M, K, TA,) aor. yago*uw, inf. n. ga*owN and ga*awaAnN, (M, TA,) It flowed; (S, M, K, TA;) said of water, (S,) or, as some say, of anything, [or] of water or blood or sweat. (TA.) [Thus,] as IKtt says, the verb has two contr. significations. (TA.) It flowed with blood; (S, K;) aor. as above, inf. n. ga*owN; (S;) said of a vein; as also ↓ g*~Y, inf. n. tago*iyapN. (S, K.) And It flowed continually; aor. as above; said of a wound. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He went quickly. or swiftly; (S, M, K, TA,) aor. as above, inf. n. ga*owN and ga*awaAnN; said of a horse. (TA.)

2 ga*~awa see the preceding paragraph, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] Aln~aAru tuga*~aY biAlHaTabi (tropical:) [The fire is fed with firewood]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Alt~ago*iyapu signifies also Alt~arobiyapu [app. as meaning The rearing a child &c. though it also means “ the feeding, or nourishing ”]: (S, K:) or in an intensive sense. (TA.) -A2- See, again, 1, in two places.
5 tg*~Y * quasi-pass. of 2: (Msb, K: *) see 8. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says of a man, xayoruhu yataga*~aY kul~a yawomK (tropical:) His goodness increases every day. (TA.)

8 Agt*Y *
He was, or became, fed, or nourished; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ tg*~Y. (Msb, K.) You say, Agt*Y bihi He was, or became, fed, or nourished, with it; (S, Msb;) namely, food, and beverage, (S,) or milk. (Msb.)

10 Astg*Ahu *
He threw him down on the ground with vehemence. (K.)

ga*FA * or ga*FY [accord. to different copies of the K, the former agreeable with a general rule, though the latter is said in the TA to be the right,] The urine of the camel, (K, TA,) and of the dog. (TA. [See 1.])

ga*awaAnN * [an inf. n. of ga*aA said of water, and of a horse, and hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) Swift: (TA:) or brisk, lively, or sprightly, and swift; applied to a horse: (S, K, TA: [see also ga*awaAnN:]) or that interrupts his urine, or emits it in repeated discharges, (yago*uw bibawolihi,) when he runs. (TA.) ― -b2- And (applied to a man, TA) (assumed tropical:) Long-tongued, or clamorous and foul-tongued; foul, unseemly, or obscene [in speech]: fem. with p: (K, TA:) the latter, applied to a woman, expl. by Fr as signifying faAHi$apN [i. e. foul, &c., as above]. (TA.)
ga*awiY~N * : see ga*iy~N, in four places: ― -b2- and see also Eadawiy~apN, in art. Edw.

gi*aA='N *
Aliment, or nutriment; consisting of food and of drink; (S, Msb;) the means of the growth, or increase, and of the sustenance, or support, of the body: (K:) pl. A^ago*iyapN. (KL.) [One says rajulN Hasanu Algi*aA='i A man good in respect of food: i. e., who feeds on good food: and say~iy^u Algi*aA='i bad in respect of food: who feeds: a bad food.] ― -b2- It is also applied, by the poet Eiyoob Ibn-'Abáyeh. to (assumed tropical:) The water for irrigation of palm-trees. (TA.) -A2- Also pl. of ga*iY~N. (S, &c.)

ga*iY~N *
A lamb, or kid; syn. saxolapN; (S, Msb, K;) or, as some say, a lamb (Hamal); (Msb:) and the pl. is gi*aA='N: (S, Msb, K:) and syn. with gadawiY~N in senses expl. in art. gdw: as also ga*awiY~N: (K:) or ga*iY~u AlmaAli and ↓ ga*awiy~uhu signify the younglings of cattle, such as lambs or kids and the like; (S, Msb;) accord. to Khalaf El-Ahmar, (S,) or IF; so that they are of camels and of him and of sheep or goats: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, ↓ ga*awiY~N is syn. with bhym [an evident mistranscription for bahom, q. v.]: and signifies such as is fed: (TA:) and he was told, he says, by an Arab of the desert, of Belhujeym, that the ↓ ga*awiY~ is the lamb (Hamal), or the kid, that is (??) with the milk of its mother, but with another's milk; accord. to which explanation it is different from the ga*iy~; and so it is accord. to A(??) as IF says, some imagine Alga*awiY~u to be from Alga*iY~u, which signifies the saxolap [as expl. in the beginning of this paragraph]. (Msb, TA.) The dim. of ga*iY~N is ↓ gu*aY~N. (S.) ― -b2- See also Eadawiy~apN, in art. Edw.
gu*aY~N * dim. of ga*iY~N, q. v. (S.)

gaA*iY maAlK * (assumed tropical:) A good manager or tender [of cattle]: (K, TA:) as though he fed them. or reared them. (TA.) -A2- And AlgaA*iY signifies also Teh wound that will not cease to bleed. (TA.)

AlgaA*iyapu *
A certain vein; (K, TA;) so called because of its flowing with blood. (TA.) ― -b2- And The part that is in a state of commotion, [or that pulses,] of the top of the head of a [young] child. as long as it continues soft; for when it becomes hard, and becomes bone, it is termed yaA^ofuwx: pl. AlgawaA*iY: mentioned by AZ: (TA:) also called AlgaA*~apu. (IAar, K in art. g*.)

Algayo*aA * , of the measure fayoEalN [when indeterminate], from ga*aA “ it flowed, ” occurring in a
trad. as meaning The clouds, is said by Z to be the only word of this measure having the final radical letter infirm except AlkayohaA, [which I do not find in its proper art.,] meaning “ the large, or bulky, ” she-camel [like kahaApN and kayohaApN]. (TA.)
1 ga*ayotuhu * : see 1 (first sentence) in art. g*w.

1 gar~ahu * , aor. yagur~u, inf. n. guruwrN (Fr, S, Msb, K) and gar~N, (Az, K,) which latter is preferable to the former, [though less common,] because the inf. n. of a trans. verb is scarcely ever of the measure fuEuwlN, (Az,) and gir~apN (Lh, K) and gararN, (IKtt, TA,) He (the devil, TA) deceived him; beguiled him; (S, K;) made him to desire what was vain, or false. (K.) You say gar~atohu Ald~unoyaA The world deceived him, or beguiled him, by its finery, or show, or pomp. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [lxxxii. 6], maA gar~aka birab~ika What hath deceived thee, and led thee into error, so that thou hast neglected what was incumbent on thee to thy Lord? (Aboo-Is-hák:) or what hath deceived thee respecting thy Lord, and induced thee to disobey Him, and to feel secure from his punishment? (TA:) or what hath deceived thee, and emboldened thee to disobey thy Lord? (Bd. [But see bi as syn. with Eano.]) maA gar~aka bifulaAnK signifies [What hath deceived thee, and emboldened thee against such a one? or] how is it that thou art emboldened against such a one? (As, S, Msb, TA.) [See also 4.] And mano gar~aka bifulaAnK, (TA,) and mino fulaAnK, (S, TA,) Who hath made thee to pursue a course without being rightly directed, or a course not plain, (mano A^awoTaA^aka Eu$owapF, S, TA,) with respect to such a one, (S,) or with respect to the case of such a one? (TA. [See again 4.]) [Also gur~a mino fulaAnK, i. e. gur~a guruwrFA SaAdirFA mino fulaAnK, He was deceived by such a one; he was deceived with deceit proceeding from such a one. See gariyrN, as syn. with magoruwrN.] And gar~a fulaAnN fulaAnFA Such a one exposed such a one to perdition or destruction [app. by deceiving him]. (TA. [See also 2, and 4.]) Also Such a one acted with such a one in a manner resembling the slaying with the edge of the sword. (TA. [See 3 in art. ETw.]) -A2- gar~a faroxahu, (S, O, K,) aor.
garu3a , (S, O,) inf. n. gar~N (S, O, K) and giraArN, (O, K, [or the latter is inf. n. of gaAr~a only,]) It (a bird, S, O, K, * or a pigeon, TA) fed its young one with its bill: (S, O, K:) and A^unovaAhu ↓ gAr~, (As, S, K,) inf. n. giraArN (S) or mugaAr~apN, (TA,) he (the [collared turtle-dove called] qumoriY~) fed his female with his bill. (As, S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, in a trad., kaAna yagur~u Ealiy~FA (O, TA) biAlEilomi (TA) (assumed tropical:) He (the Prophet) used to nourish 'Alee with knowledge like as the bird feeds its young one. (O, TA. *) And one says, gur~a fulaAnN mina AlEilomi maA lamo yugar~uhu gayoruhu (assumed tropical:) Such a one has been nourished, and instructed, with that wherewith other than he has not been nourished, and instructed, of knowledge. (TA.) -A3- gar~a, aor. yagir~u, (S, Msb,) with kesr; (S;) or gar~a, see. pers. garirota, aor. yagar~u; (K, TA;) inf. n. garaArapN; (S, Msb, K;) He (a man, S, Msb, or a youth, or young man, K) was inexperienced in affairs; (S, K;) he was ignorant of affairs; negligent, or heedless, of them. (Msb.) You say kaAna *`lika fiY garaAratiY waHadaAvatiY, i. e. fiY gir~atiY, That was in [the time of] my inexperience and youth. (S.) [See also 8.] ― -b2- And gar~a, (K,) see. pers. garrota, (IAar, T, TA,) aor. yagar~u, with fet-h, (IAar, T, K,) inf. n. garaArapN, (IAar, T, TA,) He acted in a youthful or childish manner: (IAar, T, TA:) or he so acted after having soundness of judgment, produced by experience. (Sgh, K.) But this is at variance with what J cites from Fr, in art. $d, that the aor. of an intrans. verb of this class of the measure faEala, should be of the measure yafoEilu, with kesr to the E. (TA.) -A4- gar~a, (IAar, IKtt, K,) in one place written by IAar garira, to show that it is of the measure faEila, and that the sec. pers. is garirota, (TA,) aor. yagar~u, (IAar, IKtt, K,) inf. n. gararN (IAar, K) and gur~apN, (IAar, IKtt, K,) or the latter, as ISd thinks, is not an inf. n., but a subst., (TA,) and garAarapN, (K,) He (a horse, IAar, IKtt, and a camel, IAar) had what is termed a gur~ap upon his forehead: (IAar, IKtt:) it (his face) had what is so termed: (K:) it (his face) became white. (IAar, K. *) ― -b2- gar~a, aor. yagar~u, He (a man) became eminent, or noble. (TA.) ― -b3- And gur~apN signifies also A grape-vine's quickly becoming tall. (K.) -A5- See also R. Q. 1. -A6- gar~a Ealayohi AlmaA='a He poured upon him, or it, the water: like qar~a. (TA.) And gur~a fiY HawoDika Pour thou into thy watering-trough. (TA.) And gur~a fiY siqaAy^ika Fill thou thy skin by putting it into the water and throwing the water into it with thy hand, not abstaining until thou fillest it: thus as related by Az accord. to the usage of the desert-Arabs. (TA.)

2 gr~r binafosihi * , (S, K, TA,) and bimaAlihi, (TA,) inf. n. tagoriyrN and tagir~apN, (S, K,) He exposed himself, (K, TA,) and his property, (TA,) to perdition, or destruction, or loss, (K, TA,) without knowing it: (TA:) he endangered, jeoparded, hazarded, or risked, himself, (S, TA,) [and his property,] and was negligent, or heedless, of the end, issue, or result, of an affair. (TA.) [See also 1.] -A2- guz~ira He (a horse) was marked with a gur~ap [i. e. a star, or blaze, or white mark, on the forehead or face]: you say bima gur~ira farasuka With what kind of gur~ap is thy horse marked? and the owner answers, With a $Aadixap, or with a watiyrap, &c. (Mubtekir El-Aarábee, TA.) -A3- gar~arato vaniy~ataA AlgulAamK The central incisors of the boy showed their points for the first time: (S:) or gr~r AlgulAamu the first of the teeth of the boy showed its point; as though the gur~ap, i. e. whiteness, of his teeth appeared: and gar~arato A^asonaAnu AlS~abiY~i the teeth of the boy were disposed to grow, and came forth. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) gar~arati AlT~ayoru The birds desired, or endeavoured, to fly, and raised their wings. (K, TA.) -A4- gr~r Alqirobapa (Sgh, K, TA) and Als~iqaA='a (TA) He filled the water-skin. (Sgh, K, TA.)

3 gAr~t Aln~aAqapu * , (As, ISk, S, K,) aor. tugaAr~u, inf. n. giraArN, (ISk, S,) The she-camel became scant of milk: (As, S, K:) or deficient in milk: (TA:) or she took fright, and drew up her milk, (ISk, S,) after yielding milk freely: (ISk, TA:) or the she-camel, having yielded milk abundantly on her teats' being stroked, and not being promptly milked, drew up her milk, and would not yield it plentifully until it collected again in her udder in the interval before the next period of milking. (Az.) [This signification of the verb is said in the TA to be tropical: but I rather think it to be proper; as the next is derived from it.] ― -b2- gAr~at Als~uwqu, aor. tugaAr~u, (AZ, S,) inf. n. giraArN, (AZ, S, K,) (tropical:) The market became stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic; (AZ, S, K;) contr. of dar~at. (AZ, S.) ― -b3- [See also giraArN, below.] -A2- gAr~ A^unovaAhu, said of the qumoriY~: see 1.

4 Agr~hu *
He, or it, emboldened him, or encouraged him; [by deceiving him;] syn. A^ajosarahu: so says AHeyth; and he cites the following verse:
A^agar~a hi$aAmFA mino A^axiyhi A@boni A^um~ihi
qawaAdimu SaA^onK yas~arato warabiyEu
meaning [The teats of sheep that have yielded abundance of milk and of young, and spring herbage, i. e.] the abundance of his sheep and their milk, have emboldened Hishám against his brother, the son of his mother, [to pursue a wrong course towards him, and] to forsake him, thinking himself in dependent of him: the poet makes qwAdm to belong to sheep, whereas they properly belong to the udders of camels, using the word metaphorically. (TA.) [But I incline to think that the A^a in A^agar~a is the interrogative particle, and that its explanation is A^ajas~ara, with the same particle; and the more so as I have not found any authority, if this be not one, for A^ajosara in the sense of jas~ara: so that the meaning of the verse is, Have the teats, &c.? and it shows that gar~ahu minohu, not A^agar~ahu, means jas~arahu Ealayohi, like gar~ahu bihi. See 1.] ― -b2- Also He caused him to fall into peril, danger, jeopardy, hazard, or risk. (TA.) [But perhaps this meaning is also derived from a misunderstanding of the verse quoted above. See again 1.]

8 Agtr~ *
He became deceived, or beguiled; (S, K;) made to desire what was vain, or false; (K;) bi$aYo'K by a thing. (S.) [See also 10.] ― -b2- He was negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, heedless, or unprepared; (S, K;) he thought himself secure, and therefore was not on his guard. (Msb.) [See again 10.] -A2- Agtrahu He, or it, came to him when he was negligent, inadvertent, heedless, or unprepared; (T, S, TA;) as also ↓ Astgr~hu: (T, K, TA:) or he sought to avail himself of his negligence, inadvertence, heedlessness, or unpreparedness; as also Agtr~bihi. (TA.)

10 Astgr~ *
i. q. Agtr~ [which see in two places: but in what sense, is not said]: (K, TA:) said of a man. (TA.) -A2- Astgr~hu: see Aigotar~ahu.

R. Q. 1 garogara * , (IKtt,) inf. n. garogarapN, (K,) He gargled with water; (IKtt, K;) and in like manner with medicine; (IKtt;) made it to reciprocate in his throat, (IKtt, K,) not ejecting it, nor suffering it to descend easily down his throat; (IKtt;) as also ↓ tagarogara. (K.) ― -b2- garogarati Alqidoru The cooking-pot made a sound in boiling. (TA.) And grgr All~aHomu The flesh-meat made a sound in broiling. (K.) [See an ex. in a verse of El-Kumeyt cited voce maroDuwfapN.] ― -b3- grgr He gave up his spirit, [app. with a rattling sound in the throat,] at death; (K;) as also ↓ gar~a. (TA.) ― -b4- grgr biSuwotihi He (a pastor) reiterated his voice in his throat. (S.) -A2- garogarahu He slaughtered him by cutting his throat with a knife. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- He pierced him in his throat with a spear-head (IKtt, K.) -A3- And garogarapN signifies also The breaking of the bone of the nose, and of the head of a flask or bottle. (K.)

R. Q. 2 tagarogara * : see R. Q. 1. ― -b2- tgrgr Sawotuhu fiY Haloqihi His (a pastor's) voice became reiterated in his throat. (S.) ― -b3- tgrgrt Eayonuhu biAld~amoHi The water came and went repeatedly in his eye. (TA.)

gar~N * , (S, O, K, TA,) with fet-h, (S, O, TA, [in the CK erroneously said to be with damm,]) A crease, wrinkle, ply, plait, or fold, (S, O, K, TA,) in skin, (O, * S,) accord. to Lth, from fatness, (TA,) or in a skin, (K,) and in a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, O, K;) syn. kasorN, (S, O,) or kasorN matavan~K, (K,) and makosirN: (S, * O:) pl. guruwrN. (S, TA.) [Hence,] guruwru Alfaxi*ayoni The furrows [or creases or depressed lines] between the muscles of the thighs. (TA.) And guruwru Al*~iraAEayoni The duplicatures [or creases] between the [sinew's called] HibAal [pl. of HabolN q. v.] of the fore arms. (TA.) And gar~u AlZ~ahori The duplicature [or crease] of the maton [or flesh and sinew next the backbone]: or, as ISk says, gar~u Almatoni signifies the line of the mtn. (TA.) And guruwru Alqadami The creases of the foot. (TA.) And one says, Tawayotu Alv~awoba EalaY gar~ihi I folded the garment, or piece of cloth, according to its first, or original, folding. (S, O, TA. [In the TA said to be tropical; but for this I see no reason.]) And hence Tawayotuhu EalaY gar~ihi meaning (assumed tropical:) I left him as he was, without making known his case: a saying proverbially used in relation to one who is made to rely upon his own opinion. (Har p. 233. [In Freytag's Arab Prov., ii. 38, it is not well rendered nor well explained.]) Hence also the saying of 'Áïsheh, respecting her father, mentioned in a trad., farad~a na$ara AlA_isolaAmi EalaY gar~ihi i. e. (assumed tropical:) And he reduced what was disordered of El-Islám to its [primitive] state [of order]: (O:) meaning that he considered the results of the apostacy [that had commenced], and counteracted the disease thereof with its [proper] remedy. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A fissure, or cleft, in the earth or ground. (K.) ― -b3- And A rivulet: (IAar, TA:) or a narrow steam of water in land: (K, TA:) so called because it cleaves the earth: pl. guruwrN. (TA.) ― -b4- guruwrN signifies also The streaks, or lines, of a road. (TA.) ― -b5- And Algar~aAni signifies Two lines by the two sides of the lower part of the Eayor [or ridge in the middle of the iron head, or blade, of an arrow &c.]. (AHn, TA.) ― -b6- See also giraArN, last sentence. ― -b7- Also, the sing., The extremity of a tooth: pl. as above. (O.) -A2- And The food wherewith a bird feeds its young one with its bill: (K, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b2- Its pl. is used in a verse of 'Owf Ibn-Dhirweh in relation to the journeying of camels, in the phrase AiHotasaY guruwra Eiydiy~aAtihaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) He jaded their Eiydy~aAt [an appellation given to certain excellent she-camels]; as though he supped their guruwr. (TA.)

gir~N *
Inexperienced in affairs; (S, K;) ignorant of affairs; negligent, or heedless, of them; (Msb;) applied to a man, (S, Msb,) or to a youth, or young man; (K;) as also ↓ gaAr~N (Msb) and ↓ gariyrN; (S, K;) and applied to a young woman; as also gir~apN and ↓ gariyrapN (S, K:) or these three epithets, applied to a girl, signify young, inexperienced in affairs, and not knowing what woman know of love: (A'Obeyd:) the pl. of gir~N is A^agoraArN (S) and giraArN; (TA;) and of ↓ gariyrN, A^agor~aA='u (S, K) and A^agir~apN [which is a pl. of pane.] (K.) [And gir~apN is also used as a pl.] Paradise says, yado xuloniY gir~apu Aln~aAsi The simple, of mankind, who prefer obscurity. and discard the affairs of the present world, and provide themselves for the world to come, enter me. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- Also Youthful, or childish, in conduct: applied to a man, and to a girl, or young woman. (IAar, T.) ― -b3- And One who submits to be deceived. (K.)

gur~apN *
Whiteness: clearness of colour or complexion. (L, TA.) So in the phrase gur~apF ↓ A^agar~u [app. meaning More, or most. fair-complexioned]; occurring in a trad. applied to virgins: or the phrase is ↓ gir~apF ↓ A^agar~u, meaning more, or most, remote from the knowledge of evil. (L.) ― -b2- [A star, or blaze, or white mark, on the forehead or face of a horse;] a whiteness on the forehead of a horse, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) above the size of a diroham; (S, Msb;) or of the size of a drhm; (Mgh;) as also ↓ gurogurapN: (S, K:) or it is a general term [for a star or blaze], including different kinds, as the quroHap and the $imoraAx and the like: or, if round, it is termed watiyrapN; and if long, $aAdixapN: or as, ISd thinks, the space itself, of the face, that is occupied by whiteness; not the whiteness: pl. gurarN. (TA.) [See also A^agar~u.] ― -b3- In a dog, A white speck, or a small white spot, above each of the eyes: so in a trad., in which it is said that the black dog having two such marks is to be killed. (TA.) -A2- Also (tropical:) The first, or commencement, of the month; (Msb;) the night, of the month, in which the new moon is first seen: (K:) so called as being likened to the gur~ap on the forehead of a horse: (AHeyth:) pl. gurarN: (AHeyth, Msb:) which is also applied to the first three nights of the month. (A'Obeyd, S, Msb.) One says katabotu gur~apa Al$~ahori ka*aA I wrote on the first of the month thus. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) The first, or commencement, of El-Islám; (TA;) and of anything. (S.) ― -b3- The whiteness of the teeth; and the [first that appears] of them. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The head app. when first appearing] of a plant. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) [The sight, or spectacle, or] whatever appears to one, of light, or daybreak: you say thereof, badato gur~atuhu [The sight, or spectacle, thereof appeared]. (K.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) The aspect of the new moon: (K:) because of its whiteness: (TA:) or the phasis of the moon in the first night of the month]. (TA in art. hl.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) The face of a man: (K:) or his aspect; syn. TaloEap. (TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) [And The forehead of a man. So used, as opposed to qafFA, in the Life of Teemoor, 170, ed. Mang., cited by Freytag; and so used in the present day; but whether in classical times I know not.] ― -b9- taTowiylu Algur~api. in performing the ablution termed waDuwo', means (assumed tropical:) The washing of the fore part of the head with the face, and the washing of the side of the neck: or, as some say the washing of somewhat of the fore arm and of the shank with the hand and the foot. (Msb) ― -b10- And gur~ahN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A noble, or an (??) man, (K,) or a chief, or lord, (S,) of a people (S, K:) pl. gurarN. (S.) ― -b11- And (tropical:) The best. (K.) and chiefest, (TA,) of goods. or household furniture: (K:) pl. as above: (TA:) the best of anything: (S:) the best, (Mgh,) or most precious and excellent, (Aboo-Sa'eed,) of property ; as, for instance, a horse, and an excellent camel, (Aboo-Sa'eed, Mgh.) and camels, (TA.) and a male slave. (Aboo-Sa'eed. S. Mgh, Msb, K.) and a female slave, (S, Msb, K,) or a clever female slave: (Aboo-Sa'eed, Mgh:) its application to a slave, male or female, [among articles of property,] is most common. (TA.) It has this last signification (a male or female slave) in a trad. in which it relates to the compensation for the destroying of a child in the womb: (TA:) as though this term were applied, by a synecdoche, to the whole person; (S;) the word properly signifying the “ face; ” in like manner as the terms raqabapN and raA^osN are employed: (Mgh:) Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-Alà is related to have said that it there means a white male slave or a white female slave: but this is not a condition accord. to the doctors of practical law; for they hold the term to mean a male or female slave whose price amounts to the tenth part of the whole price of blood: (IAth:) or to the twentieth part thereof: (K, T:) or it means a slave of the best sort. (Mgh.) The Rájiz says,
kul~u qatiylK fiY kulayobK gur~aho
Hat~aY yanaAla Alqatolu A=la mur~aho
Every one slain in retaliation for Kuleyb is as a slave, until the slaying reach the family of Mur-
rah. (TA.) ― -b12- Also (assumed tropical:) Goodness, and righteous conduct: so in the saying, A_iy~aAkumo waAlmu$Aar~apa faA_in~ahaA tadofinu Algur~apa watuZohiru AlEur~apa [Avoid ye contention, or disputation, for it hides goodness, &c., and manifests what is disgraceful]. (TA.) -A3- [It is also an inf. n.: see 1, latter part.]

gir~apN *
Negligence; inattention; inadvertence, or inadvertency; inconsiderateness; heedlessness; or unpreparedness: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) [pl. gir~aAtN and girarN: see an ex. of the former in a verse cited voce $afaEa, and exs. of both in a verse cited voce daraY.] It is said in a prov., Algir~apu tajolibu Ald~ir~apa Inadvertence brings the means of subsistence: (TA:) or paucity of milk causes to come abundance thereof: applied to him who gives little and from whom much is hoped for afterwards. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 179: and see also girAarN.]) [Hence,] EalaY gir~apK [On an occasion of negligence, &c.; unexpectedly]. (K in art. ErD; &c.) [And Eano gir~apK In consequence of inadvertence: see an ex. in a verse cited voce zalaqN.] Also Inexperience in affairs. (S.) gir~apN and garaArapN signify the same. (A'Obeyd.) [The latter is an inf. n.: see 1.] See also gur~apN, second sentence. ― -b2- gir~apN biA@ll~`hi means Boldness against God. (Mgh.) -A2- [See also gir~N.]
gur~aY * : see A^agar~u, near the end.

gararN *
Peril; danger; jeopardy; hazard; or risk. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., nahaY Eano bayoEi Algarari He (Mohammad) forbade the sale of hazard, or risk; (S, Mgh, Msb;) of which it is unknown whether the thing will be or not; (Mgh;) such as the sale of fish in the water, and of birds in the air: (S, Mgh:) or, accord. to 'Alee, in which one is not secure from being deceived: (Mgh:) or of which the outward semblance deceives the buyer, and the intrinsic reality is unknown: (TA:) or that is without any written statement (Euhodap), and without confidence. (As, Mgh.) ― -b2- HabolN gararN means gayoru mawovuwqK bihi [i. e., app., A bond, or compact, in which trust, or confidence, is not placed]. (TA.) -A2- See also gariyrN.

giraArN *
Paucity of milk of a camel: (K:) or deficiency thereof. (S.) [See 3.] It is said in a prov., respecting the hastening a thing before its time, sabaqa dir~atuhu giraArahu [lit., His abundant flow of milk preceded his paucity thereof]: (As:) or sabaqa dir~atahu giraAruhu [lit., his paucity of milk preceded his abundance thereof; agreeably with an explanation of Z, who says that it is applied to him who does evil before he does good: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 613: and see also gir~apN]. (So in my copies of the S.) ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) Paucity of sleep. (As, A'Obeyd, S.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] in prayer, (tropical:) A deficiency in, (K,) or an imperfect performance of, (S,) the bowing of the body, and the prostration, (S, K,) and the purification. (K.) And in salutation, The saying (in reply to Als~alaAmu Ealayokumo) waEalayokumo, not waEalayokumu Als~alaAmu: (T, TA:) or the saying salaAmN Ealayokumo (K) or salaAmN Ealayoka (M) [without Al prefixed to slAm: as though it were a deficient form; but it is the form specially sanctioned by the Kur-án]: or the replying by saying Ealayoka, not Ealyokumo. (K.) This is said in explanation of a trad., lAa giraAra fiY SalaApK walaA tasoliymK [There shall be no deficiency in prayer, nor in salutation]: but accord. to one relation, it is lA grAr fY SlAp wlA tasoliyma, meaning, that the person praying shall not salute nor be saluted: in the former case, tslym is an adjunct to SlAp: in the latter, it is an adjunct to grAr, so that the meaning is, There shall be no deficiency nor salutation in prayer. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) Little sleep (S, K) &c. (K.) El-Farezdak uses the expression nawomuhun~a girAarN Their sleep is little. (TA.) ― -b5- And particularly (assumed tropical:) Littleness of consideration; denoting haste. (TA.) You say, A^ataAnaA EalaY girAarK (assumed tropical:) He came to us in haste. (S.) And laqiytuhu giraArFA (assumed tropical:) I met him in haste. (TA.) ― -b6- And maA A^aqamotu Einodahu A_il~aA giraArFA (assumed tropical:) [I remained not at his abode save] a little while. (TA.) And labiva giraAra $ahorK He (a man, S) tarried the space of a month. (S, O, TA.) And layota Alyawoma giraAru $ahori i. e. [Would that the day were] of the length of a month. (So in some copies of the S, and in the O: in other copies of the S, labiva Alqawomu giraAra $ahorK [like the phrase immediately preceding].) ― -b7- And, accord. to As, giraArN signifies A way, course, mode, or manner. (S, O, TA.) One says, ramayotu valaAvapa A^asohumK EalaY giraArK waAHidK [I shot three arrows] in one course. (S, O, TA.) And waladato fulaAnapu valaAvapa baniyna EalaY giraArK, (S,) or EalaY giraArK waAHidK, (TA,) i. e. [Such a woman brought forth three sons,] one after another, (S, TA,) without any girl among them. (TA.) And banaY Alqawomu buyuwtahumo EalaY giraArK waAHidK [app. The people, or party, reared their tents, or, perhaps, their houses, in one line, or according to one manner]. (S, O.) ― -b8- Also The model, or pattern, according to which iron heads (S, K) of arrows (S) are fashioned, (S, K,) in order to their being made right. (K.) One says, Daraba niSaAlahu EalaY giraArK waAHidK (S, TA) i. e. [He fashioned his arrow-heads according to] one model, or pattern. (TA.) ― -b9- And The Had~ [app. meaning point, or perhaps the edge of the iron head or of the blade,] of a spear and of an arrow and of a sword: [see also *ubaAbN:] and ↓ gar~N also signifies the Had~ of a sword: (K, TA:) or AlgiraAraAni signifies the two sides of the [arrow-head called] miEobalap: (AHn, TA:) or the two edges of the sword: [see, again, *ubaAbN:] and giraArN, the Had~ of anything that has a Had~: (S, O:) and the pl. is A^agir~apN. (S.)

garuwrN *
Very deceitful; applied in this sense as an epithet to the present world; (Msb;) or what deceives one; (K;) such as a man, and a devil, or other thing; (As, TA;) or such as property or wealth, and rank or station, and desire, and a devil: (B, TA:) and ↓ guruwrN signifies a thing by which one is deceived, of worldly goods or advantages: (S:) or the former signifies the devil, specially; (Yaakoob, S, K;) because he deceives men by false promises and by inspiring hopes; or because he urges a man to do those things which are causes of his being loved but which are followed by that which grieves him: (TA:) and this last sense it has, accord. to ISk, in the Kur xxxi. 33 and xxxv. 5: (S:) also the present world; (K;) as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: and this sense is assigned to it by some as used in the passages of the Kur-án to which reference has just been made. (TA.) [It is masc. and fem., agreeably with analogy.] -A2- Also A medicine with which one gargles: (S, K:) a word similar to laduwdN and laEuwqN and saEuwTN (S) and safuwfN. (TA.)

guruwrN *
