False, or vain, things; vanities: (Zj, K:) as though pl. of gar~N, inf. n. of gar~ahu: (Zj:) or pl. of ↓ gaAr~N; (Zj, K;) like as $uhuwdN is pl. of $aAhidN, and quEuwdN of qaAEidN: (Zj:) or what is false, or vain; a deception; a thing by which one is deceived. (AZ.) See also garuwrN.

gariyrN *
Deceived; beguiled; made to desire what is vain, or false; (A'Obeyd, K;) and so ↓ magoruwrN. (K.) And you say likewise, minoka ↓ A^anaA gararN, in the sense of magoruwrN [I am deceived by thee]. (TA.) And ↓ magoruwrN signifies also A man who marries to a woman in the belief that she is free, and finds her to be a slave. (TA.) ― -b2- See also gir~N, in three places. ― -b3- It is said in a prov., A^anaA gariyruka mino h`*aA AlA^amori, meaning I am one possessing knowledge in this affair so that when thou askest me of it I will inform thee respecting it without being prepared for it and without consideration: so says AZ: and Z says the like; i. e. I [am one who] will answer thee if thou ask me unexpectedly respecting this affair by reason of the soundness of my knowledge of the true state of the case: or [it means I am a deceived informant of thee respecting this affair; for] as As says, the meaning is, thou art not deceived by me, but I am the person deceived; the case being this, that false information came to me, and I acquainted thee with it, and it was not as I told thee; I having only related what I had heard. (TA.) And one says, A^anaA gariyruka minohu i. e. I caution thee [or I am thy cautioner] against him; (K, TA:) [i. e.,] mino fulaAnK [against such a one]; (S, O;) meaning, as Aboo-Nasr says in the “ Kitáb el-Ajnás, ” [that] there shall not happen to thee, from him, that whereby thou shalt be deceived; (S, O, TA;) as though he said, I am thy surety, or sponsor, for that. (AM, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence, app., it is said that] gariyrN signifies also A surety, sponsor, or guarantee. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And Eayo$N gariyrN (tropical:) A life in which one is not made to be in fear: (S, K, TA:) like Eayo$N A^abolahu: (TA:) pl. gur~aAnN. (K.) ― -b6- Hence, perhaps; or from Algir~apu [app. as meaning “ inexperience ”], which is sometimes approved; (Har p. 607;) or because it [sometimes] deceives; (TA;) gariyrN also signifies (tropical:) Good disposition or nature. (S, O, K, TA.) One says of a man when he has become old, and evil in disposition, A^adobara gariyruhu waA^aqobala hariyruhu
(tropical:) His good disposition has regressed, or departed, and his evil disposition has advanced, or come: (S, Meyd, O, TA:) or what deceived and pleased has gone from him, and what is disliked on his part, of evilness of disposition &c., has come. (Meyd.)

giraArapN * , (S, Msb, K,) not garaArapN, (K,) for the latter is vulgar, (TA,) A sack, syn. juwaAliqN, (K,) for straw &c., (S,) resembling what is called EidolN: (Msb:) [J says,] I think it is an arabicized word: (S:) pl. garAay^iru. (S, Msb.)

gaAr~N *
Deceiving; beguiling; causing to desire what is vain, or false; a deceiver. (TA.) ― -b2- See also guruwrN. -A2- And Negligent; inattentive; inadvertent; inconsiderate; heedless; unprepared. (S, K.) See also gir~N.

garogarapN *
A sound with which is a roughness, (K,) like that which is made by one gargling with water. (TA.) ― -b2- The sound of a cooking-pot when it boils. (K.) ― -b3- The reciprocation of the spirit in the throat. (S.) ― -b4- A word imitative of the cry of the pastor (K, TA.) and the like. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1.]
gurogurapN * : see gur~apN: ― -b2- and see A^agar~u.

A^agar~u *
More, or most, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, heedless, or unprepared. (Mgh.) See also gur~apN, second sentence. -A2- And White; (S, K;) applied to anything: (K:) pl. gur~N (TA) and gur~aAnN (S) [and perhaps gurarN, as in an ex. voce *irowapN: but see what is said of this pl. in a later part of this paragraph]. You say rajulN A^agar~u Alwajohi A man white of countenance. (TA.) And qawomN gur~aAnN, (S,) and gur~N, (TA,) White people. (S.) And AimoraA^apN gar~aA='u A woman [white of countenance: or] beautiful in the front teeth. (TA voce far~aA='u.) See, again, gur~apN, second sentence. And AlA^ay~aAmu Algur~u The days of which the nights are white by reason of the moon; which are the 13th and 14th and 15th; also called AlbiyDu. (TA.) And yawomN A^agar~u muHaj~alN: see art. Hjl. And All~ayolapu Algar~aA='u (assumed tropical:) The night of [i. e. preceding the day called] Friday. (O.) ― -b2- Also A horse having a gur~ap [i. e. a star, or blaze, or white mark, on the forehead or face]: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or having a gur~ap larger than a diroham, in the middle of his forehead, not reaching to either of the eyes, nor inclining upon either of the cheeks, nor extending downwards; it is more spreading than the quroHap, which is of the size of a drhm, or less: or having a gur~ap of any kind, such as the quroHap or the $imoraAx or the like: (L, TA:) and in like manner a camel having a gur~ap: (IAar:) fem. gar~aA='u. (Msb, K.) [See an ex. in a prov. cited voce bahiymN: and another (from a trad.) voce muHaj~alN.] ― -b3- [Hence] Algar~aA='u (assumed tropical:) A certain bird, (K, TA,) black, (TA,) white-headed: applied to the male and the female: pl. gur~N; (K, TA;) which is also expl. in the K as signifying certain aquatic birds. (TA.) ― -b4- And A^agar~u, (K, TA,) applied to a man, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) One whose beard occupies the whole of his face, except a little: (K, TA:) as though it [his face] were a [horse's] gur~ap. (TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Generous; open, or fair, or illustrious, in his actions; (K;) applied to a man: (TA:) eminent; noble; as also ↓ gurogurapN: (S, K:) or fair-faced: or a lord, or chief, among his people: (Msb:) pl. gur~N, (T, M,) accord. to the K gurarN, but the former is more correct, (TA,) and gur~aAnN. (T, M, K.) And ↓ gur~aY signifies (assumed tropical:) A woman of rank, eminence, or nobility, among her tribe. (Sgh, K, TA.) ― -b6- yawomN A^agar~u means (tropical:) An intensely hot day: (K, TA: afterwards expl. in the K as meaning [simply] a hot day: TA.) and in like manner one says haAjirapN gar~aA='u, and ZahiyrapN gar~aA='u, (K, TA, expl. by As as meaning, white by reason of the intense heat of the sun, TA,) and wadiyqapN gar~aA='u. (K, TA.) ― -b7- And sanapN gar~aA='u (assumed tropical:) A year in which is no rain. (L in art. $hb.)
magoruwrN * : see gariyrN, in two places.

mugaAr~N * (S, K) and mugaAr~apN (TA) A she-camel having little milk: (S, K:) or having lost her milk by reason of some accident or disease; as some say, on disliking her young one, and rejecting the milker: (TA:) or taking fright, and drawing up her milk, (ISk, S,) after yielding it freely: (TA:) pl. magaAr~u, (S, K,) imperfectly decl. [being originally magaAriru]. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) (tropical:) A niggardly, or tenacious, hand: (K:) but accord. to the A and the TS, you say rajulN mugaAr~u Alkaf~i, meaning a niggardly, or tenacious, man. (TA.)

1 garaba * , aor.
garuba , (TA,) inf. n. garobN, (K, TA,) He, or it, went, went away, passed away, or departed. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And He retired, or removed, (K, * TA,) Eani Aln~aAsi [from men, or from the people]. (TA.) ― -b3- And garaba, (S, K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) and ↓ gr~b; (A, TA;) and ↓ tgr~b; (K, TA;) He, or it, became distant, or remote; or went to a distance. (S, A, K, TA.) One says, Augorubo Ean~iY Go thou, or withdraw, to a distance from me. (S.) ― -b4- And garaba and ↓ gr~b He, or it, became absent, or hidden. (K.) The former is said of a wild animal, meaning He retired from view, or hid himself, in his lurking-place. (A.) ― -b5- And garabati Al$~amosu, (S, Msb, TA,) aor.
garuba , (Msb,) inf. n. guruwbN (S, Msb, TA) and magoribN [which is anomalous] and mugayoribaAnN [which is more extr.], (TA,) The sun set: (S, Msb, TA:) and garaba Aln~ajomu The star set. (TA.) -A2- garobN [app. as an inf. n. of which the verb is garaba] signifies also (assumed tropical:) The being brisk, lively, or sprightly. (K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The persevering (K, TA) in an affair. (TA.) ― -b3- garabati AlEayonN, inf. n. garobN, The eye was affected with a tumour such as is termed garobN [q. v.] in the inner angle. (TA.) -A3- garuba, aor.
garuba , inf. n. garaAbapN or gurobapN and gurobN, said of a man: see 5. ― -b2- garuba, (K, TA,) inf. n. garaAbapN, said of language, (A, TA,) It was strange, or far from being intelligible; difficult to be understood; obscure. (A, * K, TA.) And in like manner, you say, garubati Alkalimapu [which also signifies The word was strange as meaning unusual]. (A, TA.) -A4- gariba, aor.
garaba , (K, TA,) inf. n. garabN, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, black. (K, TA.) -A5- garibato said of a ewe or she-goat, She was, or became, affected with the disease termed garabN meaning as expl. below. (S.) -A6- See also garabN in another sense.

2 gr~b * , inf. n. tagoriybN: see 1, in two places: and 4, likewise in two places: ― -b2- and see also 5. ― -b3- Also He went into the west: (TA in this art.:) he directed himself towards the west. (TA in art. $rq.) One says, gar~ibo $ar~iqo [Go thou to the west go thou to the east: meaning go far and wide]. (A, TA.) [See also 4.] -A2- He made, or caused. him, or it, to be, or become, distant, remote, far off, or aloof: (Mgh:) he removed, put away, or put aside, him, or it; as also ↓ Agrb. (TA.) ― -b2- And gr~b, (Msb,) inf. n. as above, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He banished a person from the country, or town, (S, * Mgh, * Msb, TA,) in which a dishonest action had been committed [by him]. (TA.) ― -b3- And He divorced a wife. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- And gr~bhu Ald~ahoru, and gr~b Ealayohi, Fortune left him distant, or remote. (TA.) -A3- tagoriybN signifies also, accord. to the K, The bringing forth white children: and also, black children: thus having two contr. meanings: but this is a mistake; the meaning being, the bringing forth both white and black children: the bringing forth either of the two kinds only is not thus termed, as Saadee Chelebee has pointed out. (MF, TA.) -A4- Also The collecting and eating [hail and] snow and hear-frost; (K;) i. e., guraAb. (TA.) -A5- See also garabN.

4 A_igoraAbN * signifies The going far into a land, or country; as also ↓ tagoriybN. (K.) And you say, AlkilaAbu ↓ gr~bt The dogs went far in search, or pursuit, of the object, or objects, of the chase. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also 5. ― -b3- And Agrb signifies He made the place to which he cast, or shot, to be distant, or remote. (A.) ― -b4- Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) He (a horse) ran much: (K:) or Agrb fiY jaroyihi, said of a horse, (A, TA,) he exceeded the usual bounds, or degree, in his running: (A:) or he ran at the utmost rate. (TA.) ― -b5- And Agrb fiY AlD~aHiki, (A, K,) and ↓ Aisotagoraba fiyhi, (S, A, * K, *) and ↓ Ausotugoriba (K, TA) i. e. fY AlD~Hk, and DaHikFA ↓ Aisotagoraba occurring in a trad. and Ealayohi AlD~aHiku ↓ Aisotagoraba, and Agrb AlD~aHika, (TA,) He exceeded the usual bounds, or degree, in laughing; (A, K, TA;) or he laughed [immoderately, or] violently, or vehemently, and much: (S, TA:) or i. q. qahoqaha [q. v.]: (TA:) or Agrb signifies he laughed so that the guruwb [or sharpness and lustre &c.] of his teeth appeared: (L, TA:) or Agrb fY AlDHk means he exceeded the usual bounds, or degree, in laughing, so that his
eye shed tears [which are sometimes termed garob]. (Har p. 572.) In the saying, in a certain form of prayer, ↓ A^aEuw*u bika mino kul~i $ayoTaAnK musotagoribK [I seek protection by Thee from every devil &c.], the meaning of mstgrb is thought by El-Harbee to be exorbitant in evilness, wickedness, or the like; as though from AlAisotigoraAbu fiY AlD~aHiki: or it may mean sharp, or vehement, in the utmost degree. (TA.) ― -b6- And Agrb, (S, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He did, or said, what was strange, or extraordinary. (S, Msb, K.) You say, takal~ama faA^agoraba He spoke, and said what was strange, and used extraordinary words: and yugoribu fiY kalaAmihi [He uses strange, or extraordinary, words in his speech]. (A, TA.) ― -b7- Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He came to the west. (K, TA.) [See also 2.] -A2- Agrb also signifies He had a white child born to him. (TA.) ― -b2- And A_igoraAbN signifies Whiteness of the groins, (K, TA,) next the flank. (TA.) You say, of a man, Agrb meaning He was white in his groins. (TK.) -A3- See also garabN. -A4- Agrb as trans.: see 2. ― -b2- A_igoraAbN said of a rider signifies His making his horse to run until he dies: (K:) or, accord. to Fr, one says, AErb EalaY farasihi meaning “ he made his horse to run: ” [or AErb farasahu has this meaning: (see 4 in art. Erb:)] but he adds that some say Agrb. (O in art. Erb.) ― -b3- And Agrb, (S, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) He filled (S, K, TA) a skin, (S, TA,) and a watering-trough or tank, and a vessel. (TA.) Bishr (Ibn-Abee-Kházim, TA) says,
wakaA^an~a ZuEonahumu gadaApa taHam~aluwA
↓ sufunN takaf~aA^u fiY xaliyjK mugorabi
[And as though their women's camel-vehicles, on the morning when they bound the burdens on their beasts and departed, were ships inclining forwards (or moving from side to side like the tall palm-tree) in a filled river (or canal)]. (S.) ― -b4- Hence, (TA,) A_igoraAbN signifies also Abundance of wealth, and goodliness of condition: (K, TA:) because abundance of wealth fills the hands of the possessor thereof, and goodliness of condition fills [with satisfaction] the soul of the goodly person. (TA.) [Therefore the verb, meaning He was endowed (as though filled) with abundance of wealth and with goodliness of condition, is app. A^ugoriba; not (as is implied in the TK) A^agoraba: the explanation of the verb in the TK is, his wealth was, or became, abundant, and his condition was, or became, goodly.] ― -b5- One says also (of a man, S) A^ugoriba (with damm, K) meaning His pain became intense, or violent, (As, S, K, TA,) from disease or some other cause. (TA.) ― -b6- And A^ugoriba Ealayohi, accord. to the K, signifies A foul, or an evil, deed was done to him; and [it is said that] A^ugoriba bihi signifies the same: but in other works, [the verb must app. be in the act. form, for] the explanation is, he did [to him] a foul, or an evil, deed. (TA.) ― -b7- And A^ugoriba said of a horse, His blaze spread (S, K) so that it took in his eyes, and the edges of his eyelids were white: and it is used in like manner to signify that they were white by reason of what is termed zaraqN [inf. n. of zariqa, q. v.]. (S, TA.) See its part. n., mugorabN.

5 tgr~b * : see 1, third sentence. ― -b2- tgr~b and ↓ Agtrb are syn., (S, Msb, K,) signifying He became [a stranger, a foreigner; or] far, or distant, from his home, or native country; (S, * Msb, K;) [he went abroad, to a foreign place or country;] and so ↓ garuba, aor.
garuba , inf. n. garaAbapN, (Msb,) or gurobapN (MA) [and app. gurobN, this last and gurobapN being syn. with tagar~ubN and AigotiraAbN, and being like qurobapN and qurobN inf. ns. of qaruba]; and binafosihi ↓ gar~aba, (Mgh, * Msb,) inf. n. tagoriybN; (Msb;) and ↓ A^agoraba, (Aboo-Nasr, S,) or this last signifies he entered upon Algurobap [the state, or condition, of a stranger, &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b3- And tgr~b signifies also He came from the direction of the west. (K.)
8 Agtrb * : see 5. ― -b2- Also He married to one not of his kindred. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., AigotaribuwA walaA tuDowuwA (TA) [expl. in art. DwY].

10 A_isotagoraba see 4, in four places. -A2- Astgrbhu He held it to be, or reckoned it, gariyb [i. e. strange, far from being intelligible, difficult to be understood, obscure; or extraordinary, unfamiliar, or unusual; and improbable]. (MA.)

garobN * [an inf. n. of garaba, q. v., in several senses. ― -b2- As a simple subst.,] Distance, or remoteness; and so ↓ garobapN. (A, K.) Aln~awaY ↓ garobapu [in one of my copies of the S gurobap] means The distance, or remoteness, of the place which one purposes to reach in his journey. (S, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence, used as an epithet, Distant, or remote.] You say nawFY garobapN [in one of my copies of the S gurobapN] A distant, or remote, place which one purposes to reach in his journey. (S, A. *) And daAru fulaAnK garobapN The house, or abode, of such a one is distant, or remote. (TA.) And daraAhimu garobapN Distant money [so that it is not easily attainable]. (TA.) And EayonN garobapN A far-seeing eye: and A_in~ahu lagarobu AlEayoni Verily he is far-seeing; and of a woman you say garobapu AlEayoni. (TA.) -A2- And Algarobu is syn. with ↓ Almagoribu, (S, M, Msb, K,) which latter is also pronounced ↓ Almagorabu, with fet-h to the r, but more commonly with kesr, (Msb,) or accord. to analogy it should be with fet-h, but usage has given it kesr, as in the case of Alma$oriqu; (TA;) [both signify The west;] Algarobu is the contr. of Al$~aroqu; (M, TA;) and ↓ Almagoribu [is the contr. of Alma$oriqu, and] originally signifies the place [or point] of sunset, (TA,) as also Al$~amosi ↓ magoribaAnu; (K;) and is likewise used to signify the time of sunset; and also as an inf. n.: (TA:) and ↓ AlmagoribaAni signifies the two places [or points] where the sun sets; i. e. the furthest [or northernmost] place of sunset in summer [W. 26 degrees N. in Central Arabia] and the furthest [or southernmost] place of sunset in winter [W. 26 degrees S. in Central Arabia]: (T, TA:) between these two points are a hundred and eighty points, every one of which is called magoribN; and so between the two points called Alma$oriqaAni. (TA.) -A3- garobN signifies also The first part (S, K) of a thing (K) [and particularly] (assumed tropical:) of the run of a horse. (S.) ― -b2- And The Had~ [or edge] (S, K) of a thing, as also ↓ guraAbN, (K,) or of a sword and of anything; (S;) and thus [particularly] the ↓ guraAb of the faA^os [or adz, &c.]. (S, K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Sharpness (S, A, Msb, TA) of a sword, (TA,) or of anything, such as the faA^os [or adz, &c.], and of the knife, (Msb,) and (Msb, TA) (assumed tropical:) of the tongue: (S, A, Msb, TA:) and [as meaning (assumed tropical:) sharpness of temper or the like, passionateness, irritability, or vehemence,] of a man, (TA,) and of a horse, (S, TA,) and of youth: (A, TA:) [from the same word signifying the “ edge ” of a sword &c.: whence the saying, A^arohifo garoba *ihonika lamaA A^aquwlu (mentioned in the A and TA in art. Arhf) meaning (tropical:) Sharpen the edge of thine intellect for what I say:] and ↓ garobapN signifies the same. (TA.) And Vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, of men; syn. $awokapN. (TA.) [And hence, app., (assumed tropical:) Briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: and (assumed tropical:) perseverance in an affair: see the first paragraph.] ― -b4- Also, [used as an epithet,] (assumed tropical:) Sharp, applied to a sword [and the like], and to a tongue. (TA.) And, applied to a horse, (assumed tropical:) That runs much: (S, K:) or that casts himself forward, with uninterrupted running, not desisting until he has gone far with his ride. (TA.) -A4- And A large dalow [or leathern bucket], (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) made of a bull's hide, (Mgh, TA,) with which one draws water on the [camel, or she-camel, called] saAniyap [q. v.]: (Msb:) of the masc. gender: pl. guruwbN. (TA.) So expl. in the following words of a trad.: A^axa*a Ald~alowa Eumaru faA@sotaHaAlato garobFA ['Omar took the dlw, and it became changed into a grb]; i. e. when he took the dlw to draw water, it became large in his hand: for the conquests in his time were more than those in the time of Aboo-Bekr. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- And A [camel, or any beast, such as is called] raAwiyap, (K, TA,) upon which water is carried. (TA.) ― -b3- And accord. to the K, A day of irrigation: but [this is app. a mistake: for] Az says that Lth has mentioned the phrase fiY yawomi garobK, meaning thereby in a day in which water is drawn with the [large bucket called] garob, [for irrigation,] on the [camel, or she-camel, called] saAniyap. (TA.) -A5- And Tears (K, TA) when they come forth from the eye: (TA:) or guruwbN signifies tears; (S;) and is pl. of garobN. (TA.) A poet says,
maA laka laA ta*okuru A^um~a Eamoriw
A_il~aA liEayonayoka guruwbN tajoriY
[What aileth thee, that thou dost not mention Umm-'Amr but thine eyes have tears flowing?]. (S, TA.) And it is said of Ibn-'Abbás, in a trad., kaAna mivaj~FA yasiylu garobFA i. e. (tropical:) [He was an eloquent orator, flowing with] a copious and uninterrupted
stream of knowledge, likened to garob as meaning “ tears coming forth from the eye. ” (TA.) ― -b2- And A flowing, (masiylN, K,) or vehement flowing, (AinohilaAlN, A, K,) in one copy of the K AinohimaAlN [which means a flowing], (TA,) of tears from the eye: (A, K:) and a single flow (fayoDapN) of tears, and of wine. (K.) ― -b3- And A certain vein, or duct, (EiroqN,) in the channel of the tears, (S, Mgh,) or in the eye, (A, K,) that flows [with tears] uninterruptedly; (S, A, Msb, K;) like what is termed naAsuwrN. (S, Mgh.) One says of a person whose tears flow without intermission, baEayonihi garobN. (As, S, Mgh.) And [the pl.] Alguruwbu signifies The channels of the tears. (S.) ― -b4- Also The inner angle of the eye, and the outer angle thereof. (S, A, K.) ― -b5- And A tumour in the inner angles of the eyes; (Mgh, K;) as also ↓ garabN. (Mgh.) ― -b6- And A pustule (bavorapN) in the eye, (K, TA,) which discharges blood, and the bleeding of which will not be stopped. (TA.) ― -b7- And Abundance of saliva (K, TA) in the mouth; (TA;) and the moisture thereof, i. e., of saliva: (K:) pl. guruwbN. (TA.) And The place where the saliva collects and remains: (K, TA:) or the garob in a tooth is the place where the saliva thereof collects and remains: (TA:) or garobN, (TA,) or its pl. guruwbN, (S, TA,) signifies the sharpness, and maA=' [meaning lustre], (S, TA,) of the tooth, (TA,) or of the teeth: (S, TA:) accord. to the T and M and Nh and L, guruwbu AlA^asonaAni signifies the places where the saliva of the teeth collects and remains: or, as some say, their extremities and sharpness and maA=' [which may here mean either water or lustre]: or the maA=' that runs upon the teeth: (TA:) or their maA=', and shining whiteness: (A, TA:) or their fineness, or thinness, and sharpness: or guruwbN signifies the sharp, or serrated, edges of the fore teeth: it is also, as pl. of garobN, expl. as signifying the maA=' of the fam [by which may be meant either the water of the mouth or the lustre of the teeth, for Alfamu properly signifies “ the mouth ” and metonymically “ the teeth ”], and the sharpness of the teeth: and accord. to MF, as on the authority of the Nh, [but SM expresses a doubt as to its correctness,] it is also applied to the teeth [themselves]. (TA.) [See also $anabN, in two places.] -A6- A^aSaAbahu sahomu garobK and ↓ sahomu garabK, and sahomN garobN and ↓ sahomN garabN, (S, Msb, * K,) the second of which, i. e. ↓ sahomu garabK, accord. to IKt, is the most approved, (MF,) mean An arrow of which the shooter was not known [struck him]: (S, Msb, K:) or, accord. to some, shm garob signifies an arrow from an unknown quarter; shm ↓ garab, an arrow that is shot and that strikes another. (TA.) -A7- And garobN signifies also A certain tree of El-Hijáz, (K, TA,) green, (TA,) large, or thick, and thorny, (K, TA,) whence is made [or prepared] the kuHayol [i. e. tar] with which [mangy] camels are smeared: [or it is a coll. gen. n., for] its n. un. is with p: so says ISd: kHyl is qaTiraAn, of the dial. of El-Hijáz: and he [app. ISd] says also, the A^abohal [q. v.] is the same as the garob, because qTrAn is extracted from it. (TA.) Hence, as some say, (K, TA,) the trad., (TA,) laA yazaAlu A^aholu Algarobi ZaAhiriyna EalaY AlHaq~i [The people of the grb will not cease to be attainers of the truth, or of the true religion]: (K, TA:) or the meaning is, the people of Syria, because Syria is [a little to the] west of El-Hijáz: or the people of sharpness, and of vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess; i. e. the warriors against unbelievers: or the people of the bucket called garob; i. e. the Arabs: or the people of the west; which meaning is considered by Iyád and others the most probable, because, in the relation of the trad. by Ed-Dárakutnee, the word in question is Almagorib. (L, TA.)
gurobN * : see gurobapN.

garabN *
Silver: or a [vessel such as is termed] jaAm of silver; (S, K;) [i. e.] a [drinking-cup or bowl such as is termed] qadaH of silver. (L, TA.) A poet says,
fadaEodaEaA sur~apa Alr~akaA='i kamaA
daEodaEa saAqiY AlA^aEaAjimi AlgarabaA
cited in the S as being by El-Aashà but it is said in the L, IB says, this verse is by Lebeed, not by El-Aashà, describing two torrents meeting together; meaning, And they filled the middle of the valley of Er-Rehà, also, but less correctly, called Er-Rikà, like as the cup-bearer of the AEAjm [or foreigners] fills the silver qadaH with wine: the verse of El-Aashà in which [it is said that] garab occurs as meaning “ silver ” is,
A_i*aA A@nokab~a A^azoharu bayona Als~uqaApi
taraAmawoA bihi garabFA wanuDaAraA
i. e. When a white wine-jug is turned down so as to pour out its contents [among the cup-bearers], they hand it, i. e. the wine in the cups, one to another [while it resembles silver or gold]: (L, TA:) garabFA is here in the accus. case as a denotative of state, though signifying a substance: [and so nuDaAraA:] but it is said that garabN and nuDaArN signify species of trees from which are made [drinkingcups or bowls such as are termed] A^aqodaAH [pl. of qadaHN]: and it is said in the T that nuDaArN signifies a species of trees from which are made yellow A^aqodaAH. (TA.) ― -b2- [In explanation of the last of the applications of garabN mentioned above, it is said that] it signifies also A species of trees (T, S, ISd, TA) from which are made white [drinking-cups or bowls of the kind termed] A^aqodaAH; (T, TA;) called in Pers. A_isbiydo daAr [or A_isoPiydaAr]: (S:) [generally held to mean the willow; like the Hebr. עֲרָבִים; or particularly the species called salix Babylonica: a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (ISd, TA.) [Avicenna (Ibn-Seenà), in book ii. p. 279, mentions a tree called grb, but describes only the uses and supposed properties of its bark &c., particularizing its Samog; whence it appears that he means the garob, not the garab.] ― -b3- It also signifies A [vessel of the kind termed] qadaH [perhaps such as is made from the species of trees above mentioned]: (K, TA:) and its pl. is A^agoraAbN. (TA.) ― -b4- And Gold. (K.) ― -b5- And Wine. (S, K.) ― -b6- And The water that drops from the buckets between the well and the watering-trough or tank, (S, K,) and which soon alters in odour: (S:) or any water that pours from the buckets from about the mouth of the well to the wateringtrough or tank, and that soon alters in odour: or the water and mud that are around the well and the watering-trough or tank: (TA:) and (as some say, TA) the odour of water and mud: (K:) so called because it soon alters. (TA.) [Hence] one says, lA tgrb, [thus in the TA, so that it may be ↓ lA tagorubo or ↓ lA tugar~ibo or ↓ lA tugoribo,] meaning Spill not thou the water between the well and the watering-trough or tank, so as to make mud. (TA.) -A2- Also A certain disease in sheep or goats, (S, K,) like the saEaf in the she-camel, in consequence of which the hair of the xuroTuwm [i. e. nose, or fore part of the nose,] and that of the eyes fall off. (S.) ― -b2- And [A colour such as is termed] zaraq [q. v.] in the eye of a horse, (K, TA,) together with whiteness thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- See also garobN, latter half, in five places.
gurubN * : see gariybN.
garobapN * : see garobN, former half, in three places.

gurobapN * (S, K) and ↓ gurobN (K) [as simple substs. The state, or condition, of a stranger or foreigner: but originally both are, app., inf. ns. of garuba, like qurobapN and qurobN of qaruba, signifying] the being far, or distant, from one's home, or native country; (K;) i. q. AigotiraAbN (S, K) and tagar~ubN. (K.) -A2- Also, the former, Pure, or unmixed, whiteness. (IAar, TA.) [See mugorabN.]

garobiY~N * [Of, or relating to, the west, or place of sunset; western]: see gaAribN. ― -b2- [Also,] applied to trees ($ajarN), Smitten, or affected, by the sun at the time of its setting. (K.) [Respecting the meaning of its fem. in the Kur xxiv. 35, see $aroqiY~N.] -A2- And A sort of dates: (K:) but accord. to AHn, the word is guraAbiY~N [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The [sort of] nabiy* that is termed faDiyx [i. e. a beverage made from crushed unripe dates without being put upon the fire]: (K, TA:) or [a beverage] prepared only from fresh ripe dates; the drinker of which ceases not to possess selfrestraint as long as the wind does not blow upon him; but if he goes forth into the air, and the wind blows upon him, his reason departs: wherefore one of its drinkers says,
A_ino lamo yakuno garobiy~ukumo jay~idFA
fanaHonu biA@ll~`hi wabiA@lr~iyHi
[If your gharbee be not excellent, we (put our trust) in God and in the wind]. (AHn, TA.) ― -b3- And A certain red Sibog [i. e. dye, or perhaps sauce, or fluid seasoning]. (K.)

garobiybN *
One of the most excellent kinds of grapes; (K;) a sort of grapes growing at Et-Táïf, in-
tensely black, of the most exceuent, and most delicate, and blackest, of grapes. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce EajiybapN.] ― -b2- Applied to an old man, Intensely black [app. in the hair]: or whose hair does not become white, or hoary: (TA:) or, so applied, who blackens his white, or hoary, hair with dye: (K, TA:) occurring in a trad., in which it is said that God hates such an old man: pl. garaAbiybu. (TA.) ― -b3- A^asowadu girobiybN means Intensely black: but if you say garaAbiybu suwdN, you make the latter word a substitute for the former; because a word corroborative of one signifying a colour cannot precede; (S, K;) nor can the corroborative of any word: (Suh, MF:) or, accord. to Hr, garaAbiybu suwdN [in the Kur xxxv. 25], relating to mountains, means Streaks having black rocks. (TA.)

guraAbN *
A certain black bird, (TA,) well known; (K, TA;) [the corvus, or crow;] of which there are several species; [namely, the raven, carrioncrow, rook, jackdaw, jay, magpie, &c.:] and it was used as a proper name, which, as is said in a trad., he [i. e. Mohammad] changed, because the word implies the meaning of distance, and because it is the name of a foul bird: (TA:) the pl. [of mult.] is girobaAnN (S, Msb, K) and gurobN (K) and (of pauc., S) A^agoribapN (S, Msb, K) and A^agorubN; (Msb, K;) and pl. pl. garaAbiynu. (K.) When the Arabs characterize a land as fertile, they say, waqaEa fiY A^aroDK laA yuTay~aru guraAbuhaA (tropical:) [He lighted upon a land of which the crow will not be made to fly away; because of its abundant herbage: see also Tay~ara]: and wajada vamarapa AlguraAbi (assumed tropical:) [He found the fruit of the crow]; because that bird seeks after and chooses the most excellent of fruits. (TA.) They also say, TaAra guraAbu fulaAnK (tropical:) [The crow of such a one flew away], meaning the head of such a one became white, or hoary. (A, TA. [See also a similar phrase below.]) Also, fulaAnN A^aboSaru mino guraAbK [Such a one is more sharp-sighted than a crow]: and A^aHo*aru [more cautious]: and A^azohaY [more proud]: and A^a$oA^amu [more inauspicious]: &c.: they say that this bird is more inauspicious than any other inauspicious thing upon the earth. (TA.) In the phrase ↓ guraAbN gaAribN, the epithet is added to give intensiveness to the signification. (TA.) guraAbu Albayoni has been expl. in art. byn. ― -b2- AlguraAbu is the name of (assumed tropical:) One of the southern constellations, [i. e. Corvus,] consisting of seven stars [in the enumeration of Ptolemy], behind AlbaATiyap [which is Crater], to the south of Als~imaAku AlA^aEozalu [i. e. Spica Virginis]. (Kzw.) ― -b3- A^agoribapu AlEarabi is an appellation of (assumed tropical:) The blacks [lit. crows] of the Arabs; the black Arabs: (K, TA:) likened to the birds called Agrbp, in respect of their complexion: (TA:) in all of them the blackness was derived from their mothers. (MF, TA.) The A^agoribap in the Time of Ignorance were 'Antarah and Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh (asserted to have been a Mukhadram, TA) and Aboo-'Omeyr Ibn-El- Hobáb and Suleyk Ibn-Es-Sulakeh (a famous runner, TA) and Hishám Ibn-'Okbeh-Ibn-AbeeMo'eyt; but this last was a Mukhadram: and those among the Islámees, 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Khá- zim and 'Omeyr Ibn-Abee-'Omeyr and Hemmám [in the CK Humám] Ibn-Mutarrif and Munteshir Ibn-Wahb and Matar Ibn-Abee-Owfà and Taäbbata-Sharrà and Esh-Shenfarà and Hájiz; to the last of whom is given no appellation of the kind called “ nisbeh, ” (K, TA,) in relation to father, mother, tribe, or place. (TA.) ― -b4- rijolu AlguraAbi signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain herb, called in the language of the Barbar A_iToriylaAl, (K, TA,) and in the present day zir~u AlA^axil~api, (MF,) resembling the $ibiv~ [q. v., variously written in different copies of the K,] in its stem and in its jum~ap [or node whence the flower grows] and in its lower part, or root, except that its flower is white, and it forms grains like those of the maqoduwnis [app. scandix cerefolium or apium petroselinum], (K, TA,) nearly: (TA:) a drachm of its seeds, bruised, and mixed with honey (K, TA) deprived of its froth, (TA,) is a tried medicine for eradicating [the species of leprosy which are called] the baraS and the bahaq, being drunk; and sometimes is added to it a quarter of a drachm of EaAqiro qaroHaA, (K, TA,) which is [commonly] known by the name of Ewd AlqrH [i. e. Euwdu AlqaroHi, both of these being names now applied to pyrethrum, i. e. pellitory of Spain, but the latter, accord. to Forskål (Flora Ægypt. Arab. p. cxix.), applied in El-Yemen to the cacalia sonchifolia, or to a species of senecio]; (TA;) the patient sitting in a hot sun, with the diseased parts uncovered: (K, TA:) [see also rijolN: now applied to the chelidonium hybridum of Linn., chelidonium dodecandrum of Forsk.: (Delile's Floræ Ægypt. Illustr. no. 502:) in Bocthor's Dict. Français-Arabe, both the names of rjl AlgrAb and ATrylAl are given to the plants called cerfeuil (or chervil) and corne de cerf (or buck'shorn plantain, also called coronopus).] ― -b5- Also (i. e. rijolu AlguraAbi) A certain mode of binding the udder of a camel, (S, K,) tightly, (S,) so that the young one cannot suck; (K;) nor will it undo. (TA.) [Hence] one says, Sur~a Ealayohi rijolu AlguraAbi, meaning (tropical:) The affair was, or became, difficult, or strait, to him: (A, * K:) or his life, or subsistence, was, or became, so. (TA.) [And in like manner one says also A^aSar~a, accord. to the TA: but this I think doubtful; believing that A^aSar~a is a mistranscription for Sar~a, meaning that one says also Sar~a Ealayohi rijola AlguraAbi i. e. He bound him with a bond not to be undone, or that would not undo; or he straitened him. See, again, rijolN; and a verse there cited as an ex.] -A2- AlguraAbaAni signifies The two lower extremities of the two hips, or haunches, that are next to the upper parts of the thighs: (K, TA:) or the heads, and highest parts, of the hips, or haunches: (TA:) or two thin bones, lower than what is called the faraA$ap [or, app., faraA$, q. v.]: (K, TA:) or, in a horse and in a camel, the two extremities of the haunches, namely, their two edges, on the left and right, that are above the tail, at the junction of the head of the haunch, (As, S, TA,) where the upper parts of the haunch, on the right and left, meet: (TA:) or the two extremities of the haunch that are behind the qaTaAp [or fore part of the croup]: (IAar, TA:) pl. girobaAnN: Dhu-r-Rummeh says, referring to camels,
taqaw~aba Eano girobaAni A^aworaAkihaA AlxaToru
meaning taqaw~abato girobaAnuhaA Eani AlxaTori [The prominences of their haunches were excoriated from the lashing with the tails], the phrase being inverted, for the meaning is known; (S in this art.;) or taqaw~aba may be for qaw~aba [i. e. the saying means the lashing with the tails excoriated the prominences of the haunches]: (S in art. xTr:) or girobaAnN signifies the haunches themselves, of camels: and is employed [by a synecdoche] to signify camels [themselves]: (IAar, TA:) and [the sing.] guraAbN is also expl. as meaning the extremity of the haunch that is next the back. (L, TA.) ― -b2- guraAbN signifies also The whole of the back of the head. (K, TA.) You say, $aAba guraAbuhu The hair of the whole of the back of his head became white, or hoary. (TA. [See a similar phrase above in this paragraph.]) ― -b3- See also gurobN, former half, in two places. -A3- And A bunch of bariyr [or fruit of the A^araAk, q. v.]: (K:) or a black bunch thereof: pl. girobaAnN: (TA:) or girobaAnu Albariyri signifies the ripe fruit of the A^araAk. (S.) -A4- And Hail, and snow, (K, TA,) and hoar-frost: from mugorabN signifying the “ dawn; ” because of their whiteness. (TA.)
guruwbN * pl. of garobN [q. v.]. ― -b2- [Golius assigns to it the meaning of wihaAdN, which he renders “ Depressiores terræ; ” as on the authority of J: but I do not find this in the S.]

gariybN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ gurubN (S, K) and ↓ gariybiY~N (AA, TA) signify the same, (S, K, TA,) [A stranger, or foreigner;] one far, or distant, from his home, or native country; (Msb;) a man not of one's own people: (TA:) a man not of one's own kindred; an alien with respect to kindred; (S in explanation of the first;) pl. of the first gurabaA='u; (S, TA;) and gurobN [also] is a pl. of gariybN, like as qurobN is of qariybN: (TA in art. zlf:) fem. of the first gariybapN; pl. garaAy^ibu. (L, TA.) A^a*aAEato gazolahaA fiY AlgaraAy^ibi, a phrase used by a poet, means She distributed her thread among the strange women: for most of the women who spin for hire are strangers. (L, TA.) And one says wajohN kamiroA=pi Algariybapi [A face like the mirror of her who is a stranger]: because, the gariybap being among such as are not her own people, her mirror is always polished; for she has none to give her a sincere opinion respecting her face. (A.) And laA^aDoriban~akumo Daroba gariybapi AlA_ibili (tropical:) [I will assuredly beat you with the beating of the strange one of the camels] is a saying of El-Hajjáj threatening the subjects of his government; meaning, as a strange
camel, intruding among others when they come to water, is beaten and driven away. (IAth, TA.) And [hence] qidoHN gariybN means (assumed tropical:) [An arrow, without feathers or head,] such as is not of the same trees whereof are the rest of the arrows. (TA.) ― -b2- gariybN signifies also Language that is strange; [unusual, extraordinary, or unfamiliar;] far from being intelligible; difficult to be understood; or obscure. (Msb, TA.) Hence, muSan~afu Algariybi [The composition on the subject of the strange kind of words &c.]. (A, TA.) [Hence also AlgariybaAni The two classes of strange words &c., namely, those occurring in the Kur-án, and those of the Traditions.] And kalimapN gariybapN A word, or an expression, that is [strange, &c., or] obscure: (A, TA:) gariybapN applied to a word [and often used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant] is opposed to faSiyHapN: and its pl. is garaAy^ibu. (Mz 13th nwE.) ― -b3- [And hence it often signifies Improbable.] ― -b4- Applied to a trad., it means Traced up uninterruptedly to the Apostle of God, but related by only one person. of the taAbiEuwna or of those termed A^atobaAEu Alt~aAbiEiyna or of those termed A^atobaAEu A^atobaAEi Alt~aAbiEiyna. (KT.) -A2- [The fem.] gariybapN, in a verse of Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee, as some relate it, is expl. by Skr as meaning Black; syn. sawodaA='u. (TA voce Eaziyzapu [q. v. It is perhaps used by poetic license for girobiybapN, fem. of girobiybN.])

gariybapN * fem. of gariybN [q. v.] ― -b2- [Hence, as a subst.,] Algariybapu signifies (tropical:) The hand-mill: so called because the neighbours borrow it, (A, K, TA.) and thus it does not remain with its owners. (A, TA.)

guraAbiY~N *
A sort of dates. (AHn, K, TA. [See also garobiY~N.]) In some copies of the K, for tmr is put vmr: the former is the right. (TA.)
gariybiY~N * : see gariybN.

gaAribN * [The western side of a mountain &c.]. You say, h`*aA gaAribu Aljabali and ↓ garobiy~uhu [This is the western side of the mountain], and [in the opposite sense] h*A $aAriqu Aljabali and $aroqiy~uhu. (TA in art. $rq.) -A2- Also The kaAhil [or withers], (A, K, TA,) of the camel; (TA;) or the part between the hump and the neck; (S, A, Msb, K, TA;) upon which the leading-rope is thrown when the camel is sent to pasture where he will: (Msb:) pl. gawaAribu. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, (S, &c.,) Haboluki EalaY gaAribiki [Thy rope is upon thy withers]; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) used (Msb, TA) by the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance (TA) in divorcing; (Msb, TA;) meaning (tropical:) I have left thy way free, or open, to thee; (TA;) go whithersoever thou wilt: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) originating from the fact of throwing a she-camel's leading-rope upon her withers, if it is upon her, when she pastures; for when she sees the leading-rope, nothing is productive of enjoyment to her. (As, S, TA.) ― -b3- AlgaAribaAni signifies The fore and kind parts of the back [and of the hump]: and baEiyrN *uw gaAribayoni, A camel whereof the part between the gArbAn [or fore and kind parts] of the hump is cleft; which is mostly the case in the baxaAtiY~, whose sire is the faAlij [or large twohumped camel of Es-Sind] and his dam Arabian. (TA.) ― -b4- And gaAribN signifies also The fore part of the hump: thus in the following saying, in a trad. of Ez-Zubeyr: famaA zaAla yafotilu fiY Al*~irowapi waAlgaAribi Hat~aY A^ajaAbatohu EaAy^i$apu A_ilaY Alxuruwji i. e. (assumed tropical:) [And he ceased not to twist the fur of] the upper part and the fore part of the hump [until 'Áïsheh gave him her consent to go forth]; meaning, he ceased not to practise guile with her, and to wheedle her, until she gave hun her consent: originating from the fact that, when a man desires to render a refractory camel tractable, and to attach to him the nose-rein, he passes his hand over him, and strokes his gArb, and twists its fur, until he has become familiar: (L, TA:) or gaAribN signifies the upper portion of the fore part of the hump. (Lth, TA.) ― -b5- Also (tropical:) The upper part of a wave: (Lth, TA:) gawaAribu AlmaA='i means (tropical:) the higher parts of the waves of water; (S, K, TA;) likened to the gwArb of camels: (S, TA:) or the higher parts of water. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The highest part of anything. (Msb, TA.) -A3- See also guraAbN, first quarter.

magoribN * and magorabN: see garobN, first quarter, in four. places. You say, laqiytuhu magoriba Al$~amosi (K, TA) and ↓ magoribaAnahaA (K, * TA) and magoribaAnaAtihaA (TA) and ↓ mugayoribaAnahaA (S, K) and mugayoribaAnaAtihaA (S, * K) I met, or found, him, or it, at sunset. (K, TA.) [It is said that] ↓ mugayoribaAnN is a dim. formed from a word other than that which is its proper source of derivation; being as though formed from ↓ magoribaAnN. (S, L. [Hence it seems that this last word as given above was unknown to, or not admitted by, the authors of these two works.]) ― -b2- magoribN signifies also Anything [meaning any place] that conceals, veils, or covers, one: pl. magaAribu, which is applied to the lucking-places of wild animals. (Az, TA.)

mugorabN * : see 4, latter half. ― -b2- Also White; (S, K;) as an epithet applied to anything: or that of which every partis white; and this is the ugliest kind of whiteness. (K.) And White in the edges of the eyelids; (S, K;) as an epithet applied to anything: (S:) a camel of which the edges of the eyelids, and the iris of each eye, and the hair of the tail, and every part, are white: (IAar, TA:) and a horse of which the blaze upon his face extends beyond his eyes. (TA.) And EayonN mugorabapN An eye which is blue [or gray], and of which the edges of the lids, and the surrounding parts, are white: when the iris also is white, the ↓ A_igoraAb is of the utmost degree. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The dawn of day: (K, TA:) so called because of its whiteness. (TA.)

EanoqaA='u mugoribN * (A, K) and mugoribapN and mugoribK, and AlEanqaA='u Almugoribu, (K,) A certain bird, of which the name is known, but the body is unknown: (A, K:) or a certain great bird, that goes far in its flight or they are words having no meaning [except the meanings here following]. (A, L, K.) [See also art. Enq.] ― -b2- Calamity, or misfortune. (K.) TaArato bihi EanoqaA='u mugoribN means Calamity, or misfortune, carried him off, or away. (TA.) [See, again, art. Enq.] ― -b3- And The summit of an [eminence of the kind called] A^akamap: (K:) or AlEanoqaA='u Almugoribu signifies the summit of an A^akamap on the highest part of a tall, or long, mountain so says Aboo-Málik, who denies that it means a bird. (TA.) ― -b4- And [The people, or the woman,] that has gone far into a land, or country, so as not to be perceived nor seen: (K:) thus is expl. in the T AlEanoqaA='u Almugoribu, as transmitted from the Arabs, with the p suppressed in like manner as it is in liHoyapN naASilN meaning “ an intensely white beard. ” (TA.)
magoribaAnN * ; pl. magoribaAnaAtN: see garobN, first quarter: and see also magoribN, in two places.

[
magoribiY~N * and magorabiY~N, or, accord. to some, the former only, but the latter is now common, Of the west; western: now generally meaning of the part of Northern Africa west of Egypt or of North-Western Africa: as applied to a man, its pl. is magaAribapN.]

$aA^owN mugar~ibN * and mugar~abN [A term, or limit, &c.,] distant, or remote. (S.) ― -b2- And xayarN mugar~ibN Fresh, or recent, information, or news, from a foreign, or strange, land or country. (TA.) One says, halo jaA='akumo mugar~ibapu xabarK Has any information, or news, come to you from a foreign, or strange, land or country? (Yaakoob, S, TA:) and halo mino mugar~ibapi xabarK (A'Obeyd, A, Msb, TA) and mugar~abapi xabarK (A'Obeyd, Msb, TA) Is there any information from a distant place? (A;) or any occasion of such information? (Msb;) or any new information from a distant land or country? or, accord. to Th, mgr~bp xbr means new, or recent, information. (TA.) [See an ex. voce junubN: and see also muqar~ibN.] ― -b3- Almugar~ibuwna, mentioned in a trad., (Hr, Nh, K, TA,) in which it is said, A_in~a fiykumo mugar~ibiyna, (Hr, Nh, TA,) is expl. [app. by Mohammad] as meaning Those in whom the jinn [or demons] have a partnership, or share: so called because a foreign strain has entered into them, or because of their coming from a remote stock: (Hr, Nh, K, TA:) and by the jinn's having a partnership, or share, in them, is said to be meant their bidding them to commit adultery, or fornication, and making this to seem good to them; so that their children are unlawfully begotten: this expression being similar to one in the Kur xvii. 66. (Nh, TA.) ― -b4- And mugar~ibN signifies also One going, or who goes, to, or towards, the west. (S.) [See an ex. voce mu$ar~iqN.]
mugayoribaAnN * ; pl. mugayoribaAnaAtN: see magoribN, in two places.
musotagoribN * : see 4, former half.

Q. 1 garobalahu * , (S, MA, O, K,) inf. n. garobalapN, (TA,) He sifted it; (MA;) i. q. naxalahu; (K;) namely, flour, &c., (S, O,) or earth, or mould. (MA.) ― -b2- And [hence, app.,] He dispersed it, or scattered it. (Sh, TA.) ― -b3- And He cut it, or severed it; syn. qaTaEahu: (S, O, and so in the CK:) or he cut it in pieces; syn. qaT~aEahu. (So in several copies of the K and in the TA.) ― -b4- And grbl Alqawoma He slew, and crushed [lit. ground], the people, or company of men. (K.) Hence the saying, in a trad., kayofa bikumo A_i*aA kunotumo fiY zamaAnK yugarobalu Aln~aAsu fiyhi (O, * TA) i. e. [How will it be with you when ye shall be in a time when men] shall be slain, and crushed? (TA:) or the meaning is, when the best of them shall be taken away and the worst of them shall remain; like as is done by the sifter of wheat? (O, TA:) or, in the opinion of Suh, as he says in the R, when they shall be searched to the utmost, and pursued one after another? agreeably with the saying of Mek- hool Ed-Dimashkee, daxalotu Al$~aA^oma fagarobalotuhaA garobalapF Hat~aY lamo A^adaEo EilomFA A_il~aA Hawayotuhu [I entered Syria, and searched it to the utmost in such a manner that I left not a science but I acquired it]. (TA.) ― -b5- And gurobila Alqatiylu The slain man became swollen, or inflated, and raised his legs. (TA.)

garobaAlN * [A sieve;] a certain thing well known; (S, O;) the thing with which one sifts: (K:) pl. garaAbiylu. (O.) ― -b2- And (O, K, TA) hence, as being likened thereto in respect of its circular shape, (TA,) A tambourine: (O, K, TA:) whence the trad., A^aEolinuwA Aln~ikaAHa waA@DoribuwA Ealayohi biA@logirobaAli [Publish ye the marriage, and beat for it the tambourine]. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) One who makes known what has been told him, in a malicious, or mischievous, manner, so as to occasion discord, or dissension. (K, TA.)

girobiylN * a word said to signify A sparrow: occurring in the saying, in a trad. of Ibn-EzZubeyr, A^atayotumuwniY faAtiHiY A^afowaAhikumo kaA^an~akumu Algirobiylu [Ye came, or have come, to me opening your mouths as though ye were the sparrow]. (TA.)

mugarobalN * [Sifted. ― -b2- And hence, app.,] Dispersed, or scattered. (TA.) ― -b3- And The low, base, vile, or mean, (K, TA,) of men; as though he had come forth from the girobaAl [or sieve]. (TA.) ― -b4- And Slain and swollen or inflated. (A'Obeyd, S, O, K.) ― -b5- And mulokN mugarobalN Dominion passing away. (O, K.)

1 gariva * , aor.
garava , (S, A, O, K,) inf. n. garavN, (S, O,) He hungered: (S, A, O, K:) or, as some say, in the slightest degree: and some say, vehemently. (TA.) -A2- And accord. to Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, one says, garivuwA biA_ibili fulaAnK, meaning They took the camels of such a one wrongfully: and a man says to another, wayolaka garivota biY watarakota Haq~aka [app. meaning Woe to thee: thou hast wronged me, and hast left, or neglected, thy right]. (O.)
2 gr~v * , (S, A, O,) inf. n. tagoriyvN, (S, A, O, K,) He made hungry; made to hunger. (S, A, O, K.) You say, gr~v kilaAbahu He made his dogs hungry. (S, O.)

garovaAnu *
Hungry: [or, accord. to some, in the slightest degree: and accord. to some, vehemently: (see the verb:)] you say qawomN garovaY [using the fem., i. e. a hungry people or party], (S, A, * O, K,) and garaAvaY, (S, O, K,) and also with kesr to the v [i. e. garaAvK] accord. to a copy of the S, (TA,) and giraAvN: (S, A, O, K:) the fem. is garovaY; (S, A, O, K;) pl. giraAvN. (S, O, K.) And you say AimoraA^apN garovaY Alwi$aAHi, meaning (tropical:) A woman slender in the waist: (S, A, O, K:) because she does not fill her w$AH [q. v.] which is therefore as though it were hungry. (S, O.)
1 garida * : see the next paragraph, in three places.

2 gr~d * , inf. n. tagoriydN, It (a bird) sang, or warbled, or uttered its voice; as also ↓ garida: (As, L:) it, or he, (a bird, S, A, K, and a man, S, as is implied in a verse there cited, and L,) prolonged its, or his, voice, and singing, and modulated it sweetly, or warbled; (Lth, S, A, Msb;) and so ↓ garida, inf. n. garadN; (S, L, Msb;) and ↓ tgr~d: (S:) or raised its, or his, voice, and prolonged it, modulating it sweetly, or warbling; (L, K;) as also ↓ garida, aor.
garada ; and so ↓ tgr~d, and ↓ Agrd: (K:) and it (a pigeon) cooed: it (the [bird called] muk~aA=') whistled: it (the cock) crowed: it (the fly) buzzed, or hummed: he (the ass) uttered a hoarse, or rough, sound; as also ↓ tgr~d. (L.) gr~d is trans. as well as intrans.; or it may be rendered as though trans. by the suppression of the preposition [li]. (L.)
4 A^agorada see 2. -A2- A^agoradaniY, said of a turtle-dove, means It gladdened me by its cooing. (ElHejeree, L.)
5 tagar~ada see 2, in three places.

10 Astgrd Alr~awoDu Al*~ubaAba *
The meadows, or gardens, by their luxuriance (naEomap, as in the L and in some copies of the K, in other copies of the K nagomap, TA), excited the flies to buzz, or hum. (L, K.)

Q. Q. 3 AigoranodaAhu * , (K,) and AigoranodaY Ealayohi, (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. AigorinodaA='N, (AZ, S,) He overcame him; (A'Obeyd, K;) he set upon him, or assailed him, or overcame him, with reviling and beating and violence; (AZ, A'Obeyd, S, K;) like AigolanotaY (AZ, A'Obeyd, S,) and AisoranodaY. (TA. [See the last of these verbs, in art. srd, and the verse there cited.])
garodN * : see girodN. -A2- Also A [booth of reeds, or canes, &c., such as is called] xuS~, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

girodN * : see garidN. -A2- Also, (Ks, AHn, S, K,) and ↓ girodapN, (AHn, K,) or girodN and girodapN are like tibonN and tibonapN [the former a coll. gen. n. and the latter its n. un.], (S,) and ↓ garodN (Fr, AHn, S, K) and ↓ garodapN, (AHn, K,) or garodN and garodapN are like tamorN and tamorapN [the former a coll. gen. n. and the latter its n. un.], (S,) and ↓ garadN (K) and ↓ garadapN, (AHn, L,) [or this last is the n. un. of that next preceding it, which is a coll. gen. n.,] and ↓ garaAdN (AA, K) and ↓ garaAdapN, (AHn, K,) or this last is the n. un. of that next preceding it, [which is a coll. gen. n.,] (AA, L,) and ↓ mugoruwdN, (Fr, AHeyth, K,) with damm, (K,) of the measure mufoEuwlN, which is a measure very rare, (Fr, AHeyth, TA,) or this is ↓ magoruwdN, (L, and thus in my copies of the S,) with fet-h to the m, accord. to As, (L,) A species of kamoA^ap [or truffles]: (Ks, AHn, S, K:) or small kmA^p: or bad kmA^p: (AHn, L:) pl. (of girodN, S, or of garodN, Fr, S) giradapN, (Fr, S, K,) like as qiradapN is of qirodN, (S,) or jibaA^apN of jabo'N, (Fr, S,) [or, accord. to some, this is a quasi-pl. n., (see jabo'N,)] and (of both of these, S) giraAdN, (S, K,) like as *iy^aAbN is pl. of *iy^obN, and kilaAbN of kalobN, (S,) and (of magoruwdN [or mugoruwdN], S) magaAriydu. (S, K.)
garadN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

garidN * (Lth, As, S, L, Msb, K) and ↓ girodN, (M, L, K,) which is thought by ISd to be a contraction of the former, (L,) and ↓ mugar~idN (L, K) and ↓ gariydN, (L, TA,) or ↓ giroyadN, (TA,) and ↓ gir~iydN [which has an intensive signification], applied to a bird, (As, S, A, K,) and to a man, (L,) Singing, warbling, or uttering the voice: (As, L:) or prolonging the voice, and the singing, and modulating it sweetly, or warbling: (Lth, S, L, Msb:) or raising the voice, and prolonging it, modulating it sweetly, or warbling. (L, K.) [See also 2.]
garodapN * and girodapN and garadapN: see girodN.
garaAdN * and garaAdapN: see girodN.
gariydN * , or giroyadN: see garidN.

gar~aAdN * an appellation applied by the people of El-'Irák to A maker of [the booths called] A^axoSaAS [pl. of xuS~N, with which garodN is syn.], and of [the fabrics of reeds, or canes, called] HaraAdiY~ [pl. of HurodiY~N or Hurodiy~apN]. (O.)
gir~iydN * : see garidN.

Agrwd * and Agrwdp [i. e. A^ugoruwdN and A^ugoruwdapN, in measure like A^usoluwbN and A^uHoduwvapN,] A song or a singing [or a warbling, of a bird, &c.]: pl. A^agaAriydu. (Har p. 445.) One says TaAy^irN musotamolaHu AlA^agaAriydi [A bird whose songs, or warblings, are esteemed sweet]. (A.)
mugar~idN * : see garidN.
mugoranodK * act. part. n. of Q. Q. 3 [q. v.]. (S.)
magoruwdN * and mugoruwdN: see girodN.

A^aroDN magoruwdaA='u *
Land abounding with [the species of truffles called] girod: (K:) or having in it magaAriyd [pl. of maugoruwdN]. (O.)

rawoDN musotagoridN *
Luxuriant meadows or gardens [that excite the flies to buzz, or hum: see 10]. (TA.)

1 garaza * , aor.
gariza , (S, K,) inf. n. garozN, (S,) He pricked a thing with a needle, (S, K,) and with a stick or the like. (K in art. nxs.) ― -b2- He inserted a needle into a thing; as also ↓ gr~z: (TA:) he stuck, (TA,) or fixed, (Msb, TA,) a thing, (Msb,) or a stick, (TA,) into the ground; (Msb, TA;) he inserted and fixed a stick into the ground; (Mgh;) he planted a tree; [like garasa;] (TA;) with the same aor., (Msb,) and the same inf. n.; (Mgh, Msb;) as also ↓ Agrz. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence,] garaza rijolahu fY Algarozi, (S, K,) or fiY Alr~ikaAbi, (A,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) (tropical:) He put his foot into the garoz, (S, K,) or stirrup; (A;) as also ↓ Agtrz [alone, from garozN meaning a kind of stirrup]. (A, K.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] garazati AljaraAdapu; and ↓ gr~zt, (TA,) or gr~zt bi*anabihaA, inf. n. tagoriyzN; (S;) The locust stuck her tail into the ground to lay her eggs. (S, TA.) ― -b5- And hence, A^aqaAma biA^aroDinaA wagaraza *anabahu (tropical:) [He stayed. or abode, in our land, and remained fixed, or] did not quit it. (A and TA in art. *nb.) ― -b6- guriza and ↓ gur~iza are also said of anything when one means It was tucked up ($um~ira) into a thing. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of El-Hasan, Dufura raA^osihi ↓ waqado gar~aza, i. e., And he had twisted [the locks or plaits of] his hair, and inserted its extremities into its roots. (TA.) -A2- gariza, aor.
garaza , (Sgh, K,) inf. n. garozN, (TK,) (tropical:) He obeyed the Sultán after having been disobedient to him: (Sgh, K:) as though he laid hold of his garoz [or stirrup] and went with him. (TA.) -A3- garazato, (S, A, K,) aor.
garuza , (S,) inf. n. giraAzN (A, K) and garozN, (K,) She (a camel, S, A, K, and a sheep or goat, and an ass, TA) had little milk; her milk became little. (S, K.)

2 gar~aza see 1, in four places. -A2- gr~z Aln~aAqapa He abstained from milking the she-camel: (A:) and gr~z Alganama he ceased to milk the ewes or she-goats, desiring that they should become fat: (TA:) and gur~izati Aln~aAqapu, inf. n. tagoriyzN, the she-camel was left unmilked: or her udder was dashed with cold water in order that her milk might cease: or she was left unmilked once between two milkings: (K:) this is when her milk has withdrawn: (TA: [see also 2 in art. gzr:]) or tagoriyzN signifies the sprinkling a she-camel's udder with water, then daubing the hand with earth or dust and slapping the udder, so that the milk is driven upwards, then taking her tail and pulling it vehemently, and slapping her with it, and leaving her; whereupon she goes away for a while at random. (AHn, TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Atà, that he was asked respecting the tgryz of camels; and answered, “ If it be for emulation, [to make them more fat than those of other men,] no; but if from a desire of putting them in a good state for sale, yes: ” and IAth says that the tgryz thereof may mean them increase, or offspring, (nitaAj,) and fatness; from garozu Al$~ajari [the planting of trees]; but that the more proper explanation is that before given [which appears to be one of the explanations here preceding]. (TA.)
4 A^agoraza see garaza. -A2- Agrz AlwaAdiY The valley produced the plant called garaz. (K, TA.)

8 A_igotaraza see garaza. ― -b2- Agtrz Als~ayoru (tropical:) The journeying, or time of journeying, (Als~ayoru, K, or Almasiyru, S,) drew near: (S, K:) or his journeying, or time of journeying, drew near: (TA:) from garozN [meaning a kind of stirrup]. (S, TA.) [But the reading adopted by the author of the TA is app. Als~ayora; agreeably with what I find in a copy of the A, Aigotarazota Als~ayora, expl. by danaA masiyruka.] ― -b3- It is said in a trad., that a man asked him [meaning, app., Mohammad,] respecting the most excellent warring against unbelievers, and that he was silent respecting at until Aigotaraza fiY Aljamorapi Alv~aAlivapi, i. e., (assumed tropical:) He entered upon [the period of] the third jamorap: [meaning, that the most excellent is when the weather has become hot; because warring is then the most arduous: see jamorapN:] like as the foot of the rider enters into the garoz [or stirrup]. (TA.)

garozN * The stirrup (S, Mgh, K) of the camel's saddle, (S, Mgh,) made of skin, (S, K,) sewed; (TA;) that of iron [or brass] or wood being called rikaAbN; (S;) the camel's stirrup: (Msb:) IAar says that it is to the she-camel like the HizaAm to the horse: but others say, that it is to the camel like the rikaAb, to the mule. (TA.) You say, Ailozamo garoza fulaAnK [lit. Keep thou to the stirrup of such a one; meaning,] (tropical:) keep thou to the commands and prohibitions of such a one. (K, TA.) And Au$odudo yadayoka bigarozihi (tropical:) Cleave thou to him, (A, K,) and leave him not. (A.) And it is said in a trad., Aisotamosiko bigarozihi, meaning, (tropical:) Cling thou to him, and follow what he says and does, and disobey him not; like as one lays hold upon the stirrup of the rider and goes with him. (TA.) -A2- Also sing. of guruwzN, which signifies Sprigs ingrafted upon the branches of the grape-vine. (K.)

garazN *
A species of panic grass (vumaAm), (K, TA,) small, growing upon the banks of rivers, having no leaves, consisting only of sheaths (A^anaAbiyb) set one into another; and it is of the plants called HamoD: or, as some say, the [kind of rush called] A^asal: and spears are so called as being likened thereto: As says, it is a plant which I have seen in the desert, growing in plain, or soft, tracts of land: (TA:) or its growth is like that of the [sweet rush called] A_i*oxir; of the worst of pasture: (K, TA:) AHn says, it is an unwholesome pasture; for when the she-camel that pastures upon it is slaughtered, the garaz is found in her stomach separate from the water, not diffused: and it does not beget the cattle strength: the n. un. is with p: it has been erroneously mentioned as being called Earaz, with the unpointed E (TA.)

garozapN *
A single puncture; syn. xarozapN. (TA in art. xrz.)

gurozapN * [i. q. xurozapN; q. v.: see Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 626: in the present day applied to A stitch: expl. by Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, as signifying “ sutura seu consutio vestis, quæ densioribus fit punctorum interst(??) ” the pl. is gurazN; not gurozN, as in the Lex. of Golius.)

gariyzapN *
Nature: or natural, native, innate, or original, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; idiosynerasy; [of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN; as though signifying a disposition, &c., implanted by the Creator;] syn. TabiyEapN, (Lh, S, Msb, K,) and qariyHapN, (S,) and sajiy~apN, (TA.) and A^aSolN; (Lh, TA;) whether good or bad; as, for instance, courage, and cowardice: pl. garaAy^izu. (TA.)

[
gariyziY~N *
Natural, native, or innate.]

jaraAdapN gaArizN *
A locust that has stuck her tail into the ground to lay her eggs; as also gaArizapN, and ↓ mugar~izapN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying, maA TalaEa Als~imaAku qaT~u A_il~aA gaArizFA *anabahu fiY barodK [(assumed tropical:) Es-Simák has never risen aurorally unless in conjunction with cold]; meaning Als~imaAku AlA^aEozalu, a well-known star in the sign of Libra, [a mistake for Virgo, for it is Spica Virginis, the Fourteenth Mansion of the Moon,] which rises with the dawn on the 5th of Tishreen el-Owwal, [or October O. S., nearly agreeing with my calculation, accord. to which it rose aurorally in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of October O. S.,] (A, * TA.) when the cold commences. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also the saying,] huwa gaArizN raA^osahu fiY sinatihi (tropical:) He is ignorant, (Sgh, K,) and departs from the care of himself which is incumbent on him and pertaining to him. (Sgh, TA.) -A2- Also gaArizN A she-camel, (S, K,) [and a ewe or a she-goat,] and an udder, (TA,) having little milk: (S, K, TA:) or a she-camel that has drawn up her milk from her udder: (As, S:) pl. gur~azN (TA) [and gawaArizu, for] you say also ganamN gawaArizu. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] EuyuwnN gawaArizu (tropical:) Eyes that shed no tears. (AZ, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] gaArizN applied to a man, (tropical:) [Parum seminis habens; and hence,] that seldom indulges in nikaAH: pl. gur~azN. (TA.)
tagoriyzN * , sing. of tagaAriyzu, (K,) which signifies Offsets of palm-trees, &c., that have been transplanted. (Kt, S, K.)

magorizN * The place of growth, [or of insertion,]
(A^aSol,) of a feather, and the like, [such as a tooth, and also of the neck,] and of a rib, and of the udder; [of which last, and of the neck, and the like, it means the base, which is also termed ASl:] pl. magaArizu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] The place in which the locust lays its eggs. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also the saying,] AuTolubi Alxayora fiY magaArizihi (tropical:) [Seek thou good in the persons in whom it is naturally implanted]; as also fY magaArisihi. (A, TA.)

waAdK mugorizN *
A valley in which is the plant called garaz. (K, TA.)

manokibN mugar~azN *
A shoulder-joint stuck close to the kaAhil [or withers]. (TA.)
jaraAdapN mugar~izapN * : see gaArizN, first sentence.

1 garasahu * , aor.
garisa , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. garosN, (S, Msb,) He planted it, or fixed it in the ground; (A, K;) namely, a tree; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Agrshu, (Zj, A, K,) inf. n. A_igoraAsN. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] garasa fulaAnN EinodiY niEomapF (tropical:) Such a one established, or settled, in my possession, a benefaction, or boon. (TA.) And garasa AlmaEoruwfa (tropical:) He did good, or what was beneficent or kind. (IKtt, TA.)
4 A^agorasa see the preceding paragraph.

garosN * , [originally an inf. n.,] i. q. ↓ magoruwsN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) i. e., A tree planted; [and used as a subst., meaning a set;] (A, K;) as also ↓ girosN, (A,) and ↓ giraAsN: (Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^agoraAsN and [of mult.] giraAsN (K) [and accord. to general analogy guruwsN: see Eu$uqN]. And A twig that is plucked from a garden and then planted: (TA:) and giraAsN, (S, A,) which is its pl., (A,) shoots, or offsets, of palm-trees, which are cut off from the mother-trees, or plucked forth from the ground, and planted; (S, K;) as also ↓ gariysapN: (TA:) or ↓ this last signifies one of such shoots or offsets from the time when it is put into the ground until it takes hold: (IDrd, K: *) or a palm-tree when it first grows: (S, K:) or a palm-tree recently planted: (A:) and the same word also signifies a grape-vine when first planted: (TA:) and a date-stone that is sown: (Abu-lMujeeb and El-Hárith Ibn-Dukeyn:) and its pl. is garaAy^isu (A, TA) and giraAsN, which latter is extr. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^anaA garosu yadika and yadika ↓ girosu (tropical:) [I am the creature of thy hand]: and naHonu garosu yadika and A^agoraAsu yadika (tropical:) [We are the creatures of thy hand]; garosN being an inf. n. [used in the sense of a pass. part. n. both sing. and pl. agreeably with a general rule]; and A^agoraAsN being pl. of girosN in the sense of magoruwsN. (A.) And fulaAnN garosu niEomatihi (tropical:) [Such a one is the creature of his (another's) beneficence]. (TA.)

girosN * : see garosN, in two places. -A2- Also The membrane that encloses the child; syn. ma$iymapN: (IAar, S in art. $ym:) or the membrane, or thin skin, that comes forth with the child from the belly of its mother: (Az, TA:) or that is upon, or over, the head of the new-born child: (A:) or what comes forth upon, or over, the face: (TA:) or what comes forth with the child, resembling mucus: or the membrane, or thin skin, that is upon, or over, the face of the young one of a camel at the birth, and which, if left upon it, kills it: (S, K:) pl. A^goraAsN. (K.)

giraAsN * The act of planting trees. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] h`*aA masoqaTu raA^osihi wamakaAnu giraAsihi (tropical:) [This is the place of his birth, (lit., of the falling of his head,) and the place of his plantation]. (A.) -A2- The time of planting: (S, K:) or this is termed waqotu AlgiraAsi, (A,) or zamanu AlgiraAsi. (Msb.) -A3- See also garosN [of which it is a syn. and a pl.]. ― -b2- Accord. to Kr, Abundance of the trees called EurofuT. (TA.)
gariysapN * : see garosN, in two places. ― -b2- gariysapu is a proper name for The female slave [as being planted in a family]. (Sgh, K.)

magorisN *
A place of planting: pl. magaArisu. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, metaphorically, (tropical:) A woman, or wife. (Har p. 502.) ― -b3- [Hence also the saying,] AuTolubi Alxayora fiY magaArisihi (tropical:) [Seek thou good in the persons in whom it is naturally implanted]; as also, fiY magaArizihi. (A and TA in art. grz.)
magoruwsN * : see garosN.

1 gariDa * , aor.
garaDa , (S, K,) inf. n. garaDN, (S, A, K,) He was vexed, or disquieted by grief, and by distress of mind; he was grieved, and distressed in mind: he was disgusted; he turned away with disgust. (S, A, K.) You say, gariDa minohu He was vexed by, or at, him, or it, and disquieted by grief, and by distress of mind; he was grieved, and distressed in mind, by him, or it: (Mgh in art. grD, and TA:) he was disgusted with it, or at it; he turned away from it with disgust: (Mgh:) and he feared him, or it. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TK: but the first and second mention only the inf. n. of the verb in this last sense.) And gariDa biAlmuqaAmi, aor. and inf. n. as above, [He was vexed, &c., by continuance, stay, residence, or abode, in a place: he was disgusted with it, or at it.] (S.) And A_i*aA faAtahu AlgaraDu fat~ahu AlgaraDu i. e. AlD~ajaru [When the object of aim, or endeavour, escapes him, so that he cannot attain it, vexation, or disquietude by grief, and by distress of mind, or disgust, crushes him]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (A,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (A, TA,) He yearned, or longed: (S, A, K:) or he yearned, or longed, vehemently, or intensely: (TA:) A_ilayohi for him, or it: (S:) or A_ilaY liqaAy^ihi for meeting with him: the verb in this sense being made trans. by means of AlY because it imports the meaning of Ai$otaAqa and Han~a [which are made trans. by the same means]: (A, TA:) [for] accord. to Akh, gariDotu A_ilayohi signifies gariDotu mino h`w^ulA='i A_ilayohi [I turned with vexation, or disgust, from these, to him, or it]; because the Arabs connect the verb [with its objective complement] by means of all these particles [mentioned above; namely, b and mn and AlY]. (S.) Mbr reckons garaDN, as meaning both “ being disgusted ” and “ yearning ” or “ longing, ” among words having contrary significations; and so does Ibn-Es-Seed; (MF;) and in like manner, IKtt. (TA.) [Perhaps these derive the latter meaning from garaDN signifying “ a butt, ” or “ an object of aim, ” &c.] -A2- garaDa Eanohu, (TA,) [in the TK garaDahu,] inf. n. garoDN, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) He (a man, TA) refrained, forbore, abstained, or desisted, from him, or it; left, relinquished, or forsook, him, or it. (Ibn-'Abbád, * K, * TA.) -A3- garuDa, aor.
garuDa , inf. n. giraDN, It (a thing) was fresh, juicy, moist, not flaccid. (S, K.) -A4- garaDa Al$~aYo'a, aor.
gariDa , (K,) inf. n. garoDN; (TA;) and ↓ gr~Dhu, (K,) inf. n. tagoriyDN; (TA;) He plucked the thing while it was fresh, juicy, moist, or not flaccid: or he took it (A^axa*ahu, in some copies of the K ja*~ahu, which is a mistake, TA) while it was so. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He did the thing hastily, or hurriedly, before its time; syn. A^aEojalahu Eano waqotihi. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TS, K. *) ― -b3- garaDa Als~axola, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) and ↓ gr~DhA; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He weaned the lambs, or kids, before their time. (ISk, S, K.) ― -b4- garaDato siqaA='ahaA, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) (assumed tropical:) She (a woman, S) churned, or agitated, the contents of her milk-skin, and when its butter had formed in little clots but had not collected together, she poured out the milk, and gave it to people to drink. (ISk, S, K. *) ― -b5- garaDotu lahu gariyDFA (tropical:) I gave him to drink fresh milk. (TA.) ― -b6- garaDotu lilD~ayofi gariyDFA (tropical:) I fed the guests with food that had not been kept through the night: so in the A: but in the K, lahumo ↓ A^agoraDa gariyDFA (tropical:) he kneaded for them fresh dough, and did not feed them with food that had been kept through the night. (TA.) -A5- garaDahu, aor.
gariDa , [inf. n. garoDN,] also signifies He filled it, namely, a vessel, (S, K,) and a skin, and a wateringtrough; (TA;) and so ↓ AgrDhu. (K.) ― -b2- And He stopped short of filling it completely. (S, K. [See also 2.]) Thus it has two contr. significations. (S, K.) A rájiz says,
laqado fadaY A^aEonaAqahun~a AlmaHoDu
waAld~aA^oZu Hat~aY maA lahun~a garoDu
(S, TA,) i. e. Verily the mHD and the dA^Z [the pure milk and the fatness and fulness so that there is no deficiency in their skins] have ransomed them from being slaughtered and sold. (TA.) [But see garoDN below.] ― -b3- Also, aor.
gariDa , inf. n. garoDN, He broke it (i. e. a thing) without separating it. (TA.) -A6- garaDa AlbaEiyra, (S,) or Aln~aAqapa, (K,) [aor.
gariDa , as appears from the word magoriDN, for otherwise, by rule, it would be magoraDN,] inf. n. garoDN, (K,) He bound the garoD upon the camel; (S;) as also
↓ AgotirDhu; (TA;) or he bound the she-camel with the guroDap, (K,) or garoD; (TA;) as also ↓ A^agoraDahaA; (K;) and in like manner, garaDa Albagiyra biAlgaroDi. (TA.)

2 gr~D * , inf. n. tagoriyDN, He ate fresh flesh-meat. (K.) ― -b2- See also garaDa, in two places. -A2- One says also, gar~iDo fiY siqaAy^aka Fill not thy skin [completely; leave a portion unfilled in thy skin]. (S.) ― -b2- And fulaAnN baHorN laA yugar~aDu i. e. [Such a one is a sea] that will not become exhausted. (S, A, TA.) -A3- And gr~D signifies also tafak~aha, (K, TA.) [meaning He affected jesting, or joking, for it is] said in the I. to be from AlfukaAhapu signifying AlmuzaAHu. (TA.)
3 gArD A_ibilahu * (tropical:) He brought his camels to the watering-place early in the morning; in the first part of the day. (A, O, K.)

4 AgrDhu *
He made him to be vexed, or disquieted by grief, and by distress of mind; to be grieved, and distressed in mind: he made him to be disgusted; to turn away with disgust. (S.) -A2- See also 1, latter half, in two places. -A3- AgrD Aln~aAqapa: see 1, last sentence. -A4- AgrD He (a man) hit, or attained, the garaD [i. e. the butt, or object of aim, &c.]. (IKtt.)

5 tgr~D * , (K, TA,) thus in the O, on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád; but accord. to the Tekmileh, ↓ AngrD; (TA;) said of a branch, It broke without breaking in pieces: (K, TA:) or, accord. to the L, the latter signifies It bent and broke without becoming separated. (TA.)
7 A_inogaraDa see what next precedes.

8 AigotaraDa * : (so in a copy of the A: [and if this be correct, the primary signification seems to be It (a thing) was plucked, or taken, while it was fresh, juicy, moist, or not flaccid: quasi-pass. of garaDa in the first of the senses assigned to it as a trans. v. above:]) or AugotariDa: (so in the JK and TA: [and if this be correct, it is app. formed by transposition from AugotuDira:]) (tropical:) He died in his fresh state; (JK;) [i. e.] he died a youth, or a young man: [the latter reading seems to be the right, for it is said to be] similar to AuHotuDira [evidently a mistranscription for AuxotuDira]. (A, TA.) -A2- AgtrD Al$~aYo'a He made the thing his garaD [i. e. butt, or object of aim, &c.]. (TA.) -A3- AgtrD AlbaEiyra: see 1, last sentence.

garoDN * and ↓ guroDapN The appertenance of a camel's saddle of the kind called raHol which is like the HizaAm of the saroj (S, K) and the biTaAn of the qatab; (S;) i. e. girth, or fore girth, (taSodiyr,) thereof; (S;) the HizaAm of the raHol: (A:) pl. of the former, A^agoraADN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, K) and A^agoruDN [also a pl. of pauc.] (IB) and guruwDN [a pl. of mult.]: and of the latter, ↓ guroDN, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] (S, K,) like as busorN is of busorapN, (S,) and guruDN. (S, K.) [Hence the saying of Mohammad,] guroD shall not be bound [upon camels by pilgrims] except to three mosques; the sacred mosque [of Mekkeh], and my mosque [of ElMedeeneh], and the mosque [El-Aksà] of Beytel-Makdis [or Jerusalem]. (TA.) -A2- garoDN also signifies (accord. to some, in the verse cited in the first paragraph, S, TA) The place of what thou hast left (mawoDiEu maA tarakotahu, not mA' [i. e. not maA='K] as written in the S [and K], TA,) and not put into it anything: (S, K, TA:) and is said by some to be like the A^amot [q. v.] in a skin. (TA.) ― -b2- And A state of folding. (AHeyth, K.) And A man's having folds (guruwD) in the body when he has been fat and then has become lean. (Sgh, K.) And you say, Tawayotu Alv~awoba EalaY guruwDihi i. e. guruwrihi [I folded the garment, or piece of cloth, according to its first, or original, foldings.] (Ibn- 'Abbád, Z, Sgh, K.)
EuroDN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

garaDN *
A butt, a mark, or an object of aim, at which one shoots, or throws; (S, O, Msb, K;) a thing that thou settest up (maA A^amovalotahu) to shoot or throw at: (IDrd:) pl. A^agoraADN. (Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., laA tat~axi*uwA $ayoy^FA fiyhi Alr~awHu garaDFA [Ye shall not take a thing in which is the vital principle as a butt]. (TA.) And hence one says, Aln~aAsu A^agoraADu Almaniy~api (assumed tropical:) [Mea are the butts of destiny, or of death]: and jaEalotaniY garaDFA li$atomika (assumed tropical:) [Thou madest me, or hast made me, a butt for thy reviling]. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) An object of aim or endeavour or pursuit, of desire or wish, or of intention or purpose: (Msb:) a scope; or any end which one endeavours, or seeks, or intends, or purposes, to attain: (B:) an object of want, and of desire: (TA:) the advantage, or good, which one seeks, or endeavours, or purposes, to attain, or obtain, from a thing: so much used in this tropical sense as to be, in this sense, conventionally regarded as proper. (MF.) You say, garaDuhu ka*aA (tropical:) His object of aim or endeavour or pursuit, &c., is such a thing: (Msb:) or his object of want, and of desire, is such a thing (TA.) And faEala ligaraDK SaHiyHK (tropical:) He did, or acted, for a just, or right, object of aim &c. (Msb.) And fahimotu garaDaka (assumed tropical:) I understood, or have understood, thine object of aim &c., or thine intention; syn. qaSodaka. (S.) [See another ex. voce gariDa, of which it is also the inf. n.]

gariDN * , when followed by mino, Vexed, or disquieted by grief, and by distress of mind; grieved, and distressed in mind: disgusted; or turning away with disgust. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, when followed by A_ilaY, Yearning, or longing: (S, TA:) or yearning, or longing, vehemently, or intensely. (TA.)
guroDapN * : see garoDN.

gariyDN * A thing that is fresh, juicy, moist, or not flaccid: (S, A, K:) also applied to flesh-meat. (S.) [See also 1, in three places, in the latter half of the paragraph.] ― -b2- Fresh, or juicy, dates. (TA.) ― -b3- Rain-water; as also ↓ magoruwDN: (S, K:) because of its freshness. (S, TA.) ― -b4- Water to which one comes early in the morning; in the first part of the day. (TA.) ― -b5- See also A_igoriyDN, in two places. ― -b6- Also Any new, or novel, song. (IB, TA.) ― -b7- And hence, A singer; because of his performing new, or novel, singing: (IB, TA:) or a singer who performs well, (K, TA,) and is of those who are well known; and so called because of his gentleness, or softness. (TA.)

warada AlmaA='a gaAriDaA * (assumed tropical:) He came to the water early in the morning; in the first part of the day. (S, K. *) And A^aworada A_ibilahu gaAriDFA (assumed tropical:) He brought his camels to the watering-place early in the morning; in the first part of the day. (TA.) And A^atayotuhu gaAriDFA I came to him in the first part of the day. (TA.)

A_igoriyDN * The spadix of a palm-tree: syn. TaloEN; (S, K;) which some call A_igoriyDapN; (TA:) as also ↓ gariyDN: (S, K:) or the spadix of a palm-tree (TaloE) when it bursts from its kaAfuwr [i. e. spathe, or envelope]: (IAar:) or what is in the interior of the TaloEap [or spathe of a palm-tree]: (Th:) or the thing [i. e. the spathe] from which the spadix of the palm-tree (TaloE) bursts: (Ks, A) to which a woman's garment is likened. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Anything white and fresh or juicy or moist, as also ↓ gariyDN: (S, K:) or anything white like milk.
