gasaAqN * and ↓ gas~aAqN, (S, O, K, TA,) occurring in the Kur [xxxviii. 57 and] lxxviii. 25, accord. to different readings, (S, O, TA,) The ichor, or watery matter, (O, TA,) and thick purulent matter, (TA,) that will flow and drip (O, * TA) from the skins of the inmates of the fire [of Hell]: (O, TA:) or the washings of them: or their tears: (TA:) or, as some say, the latter of the words has the first of these meanings: (O, TA:) and the former word signifies cold, (O,) or intensely cold, (TA,) that burns by reason of its coldness (O, TA) like the hot wind: (TA:) or, accord. to Lth, stinking: (O, TA:) the latter word is expl. by I'Ab and Ibn-Mes'ood as signifying intense cold: (TA:) or both signify cold and stinking. (S, O.)

gasiyqaAtN *
Intensely red; [applied to she-camels;] thus expl. by Skr as occurring in a verse of Sakhr [?] El-Hudhalee. (TA.)
gas~aAqN * : see gasaAqN: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following, near the end.

AlgaAsiqu * signifies The night; (Zj, TA;) and [hence] wamino $ar~i gaAsiqK A_i*aA waqaba (in the Kur [cxiii. 3], S, O) means [And from the mischief] of the night when it cometh in; (S, O, K;) accord. to El-Hasan (S, O) El-Basree: (O:) or the beginning of the night; as El-Hasan is related to have said: (TA:) or the night when the $afaq [or redness in the horizon after sunset] disappears: (S, O, K:) and the night is said to be so called because it is colder than the day: (O, TA:) [for] AlgaAsiqu signifies [also] the cold (AlbaAridu) [like AlgasaAqu] (TA:) or what is meant in the verse of the Kur-án cited above is the accident in the night: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or AlgaAsiqu signifies the moon; (K;) and this is said to be meant in the verse of the Kur-án; (S, TA;) so the Prophet is related to have said to Áïsheh; i. e. the verse means, [the mischief of] the moon when it is eclipsed: (Th, O, * TA:) or what is meant in that verse is, Alv~uray~aA [i. e. the asterism called the Pleiades] when it sets [aurorally (see vuray~aA)], because diseases and pestilences are frequent at that period. (O, K, TA,) and become removed at that period of its [auroral] rising [in the opposite season of the year], (O, TA,) as is related in a trad. (TA:) or the sun when it sets: or the day when it enters upon the night. or the serpent called AlA^asowad when it smites, or turns over: or, accord. to Sub. Iblees when he suggests evil: (TA:) or, accord. to I'Ab and several others, from the mischief of the *akar when it becomes erect; (K, TA:) a strange explanation: and ↓ Algas~aAqu is like AlgaAsiqu; [but in what sense or senses is not said;] each is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (TA.) ― -b2- gaAsiqN also signifies Flowing; applied by a poet in this sense to a source, or spring; and having to relation to darkness. (Sh. TA.)

1 gasalahu * , (S, MA, O, Msb, K,) aor.
gasila , (Msb, K,) inf. n. gasolN, (S, MA, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) and gusolN is the subst, (S, Msb,) or a subst. (Mgh, K, TA) from AlAigotisaAlu, (Mgh, TA,) or, as some say. the latter is the inf. n. and the former is the subst., (MF, TA,) He washed it; with water (biAlmaA='i): (MA:) gasolu Al$~Yo'i signifies the removing of dirt, or filth, and the like thereof, from the thing, by making water to run over it. (Mgh.) You say, gasala Aljiloda kul~ahu [He washed the skin, all of it], and Almay~ita [the dead body]: and ↓ gs~l has the like, but an intensive, meaning. (Msb.) See also 10. ― -b2- waA@gosiloniY bimaA='i Alv~aloji waAlbaradi [lit. And wash Thou me with the water of snow and of hail], in a trad. relating to [forms of] prayer, means (assumed tropical:) and cleanse Thou me from sins. (TA.) And one says, gasala A@ll~`hu Hawobataka i. e. (assumed tropical:) May God cleanse thee from thy sin. (TA.) ― -b3- maA gasaluwA ruw^uwsahumo mino yawomi Aljamali [lit. They did not wash their heads &c., as one does in cleansing himself from impurity,] means maA faraguwA and maA taxal~aSuwA [i. e., app., (assumed tropical:) they did not become free from the consequences of the Day of the Camel (the famous engagement between the forces of 'Alee and those of Áïsheh)]. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says of a horse, gusila, like EuniYa, meaning He sweated; [or became suffused with sweat;] (Sh, O, K;) as also ↓ Aigotasala (K.) [See an ex. of the former in a verse cited in art. Edw, conj. 3.] ― -b5- gasala AlmaroA^apa signifies (tropical:) He compressed the woman (jaAmaEahaA); (Az, Mgh, O, TA;) like EasalahaA, with E; (Az, Mgh, TA;) much or little; (TA;) and ↓ gas~alahaA signifies the same: (Mgh, O, TA:) or both signify he did so much. (K.) It is said in a trad., (Mgh, O, TA,) respecting [preparation for the prayers of] Friday, (Mgh,) mano gasala waA@gotasala, as some relate it, or, as others relate it, wAgtsl ↓ mn gas~ala; the latter of which is said to mean Whose compresses his wife [before his going to the mosque]; (Mgh, O;) and El-Kutabee says that most hold this to be the meaning; i. e., lest he should see in his way anything that might divert his heart [from devotion]; (Mgh;) [and then washes himself;] and Az held gasala, without teshdeed to be correct (Mgh, O) in this sense: (Mgh:) or the meaning accord. to the reading of gs~l is, whose performs the [ablution termed] wuDuw'o fully, washing every member [of those that are to be washed] three times, (Mgh, O,) and then washes himself for the [prayers of] Friday; (Mgh;) and accord. to IAmb, it means whose washes himself after AljimaAE and then washes himself for the [prayers of] Friday; (O:) accord. to the K, ↓ Alt~agosiyla signifies the exceeding the ordinary bounds in washing the members: (TA:) he who explains as meaning the causing a woman to become under the obligation of performing a total ablution, biA^ano waTiy^ahaA, says what is improbable, and departs from the authorities respecting it. (Mgh.) ― -b6- One say, also, gasala AlfaHolu Aln~aAqapa, meaning (tropical:) The stallion covered the she-camel much. (K, TA.) [See also 4.] ― -b7- And gasala, aor.
gasila . (K, TA,) inf. n. gasolN, (TA,) (tropical:) He beat, and caused to suffer pain, (K, TA,) biAls~awoTi [with the whip]. (TA.)
2 gas~ala see the preceding paragraph, in four places
4 Agsl * [said of a stallion, and intrans.,] (assumed tropical:) He covered much, or often; syn. A^akovara AlD~iraAba (Fr, O, K.) [See also 1, last explanation but one.]
7 Angsl * said of a thing is quasi-pass. of gasalahu [i. e. it signifies It became washed, or washed off]. (O, TA.) [See gisoliynN.]

8 Agtsl * (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K) He washed [himself, i. e.] his whole person, (Mgh,) biAlmaA='i [with water]. (S, Mgh, O, K.) And Agtsl lilojumoEapi [He washed himself for the prayers of Friday]. (IAmb, O.) ― -b2- And Agtsl biAlT~iybi He daubed, or smeared, himself, or did so copiously, so as to cause a dripping, (taDam~axa, Lh, TA,) or he sprinkled himself, (tanaD~axa, K,) with perfume. (Lh, K.) ― -b3- Agtsl said of a horse: see 1.

10 A_isotagosala It is said in a trad., AlEayonu Haq~N faA_i*aA A@sotugosilotumo ↓ faA@gosiluwA [The evil eye is a truth; so when ye are asked to wash, wash ye]: i. e., when he who was smitten by the eye of any one demanded [the performance of what is here meant], he brought to
the smiter therewith a bowl in which was water, and he [the latter] would put his hand into it, and rinse his mouth [with some of it], then spit it out into the bowl; then he would wash his face in it; then he would put in his left hand, and pour upon his right hand; then he would put in his right hand, and pour upon his left hand; [then he would put in his left hand (a clause omitted in my original),] and pour upon his right elbow; then he would put in his right hand, and pour upon his left elbow; then he would put in his left hand, and pour upon his right foot; then he would put in his right hand, and pour upon his left foot; then he would put in his left hand, and pour upon his right knee; then he would put in his right hand, and pour upon his left knee; then he would wash what is termed daAxilapu AlA_izaAri [expl. in art. dxl]: and he would not put the bowl upon the ground: then he would pour that used water upon the head of the person smitten with the eye, from behind him, with one pouring; and he would be cured, with the permission of God. (TA.)

gasolN * inf. n. of gasalahu: (S, MA, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) or, accord. to some, this and ↓ gusolN have one and the same meaning; and the saying that this is the case is ascribed to Sb: (Msb:) or, as some say, the latter is the inf. n., and the former is the subst. (MF, TA.) See also the next paragraph.

gusolN * the subst. from gasalahu [i. e. a subst. signifying A washing]: (S, Msb:) or a subst. (IKoot, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) from AlAgtsAl, (IKoot, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and [as such] signifying a complete washing [of oneself, i. e.] of the whole person: (IKoot, T, Mgh, Msb, TA:) it is in consequence of janaAbap [q. v.], and of childbirth, and for [the prayers of] Friday, and is the washing of the dead; but in other cases, the word ↓ gasolN, with fet-h, is used: (Ham p. 30:) and one says ↓ gusulN as well as gusolN, (S, O,) the former being a dial. var. of the latter: (TA:) El-Kumeyt says, describing a wild ass,
taHota AlA^alaA='api fiY nawoEayoni mino gusulK
baAtaA Ealayohi bitasojaAlK wataqoTaAri
[Beneath the (tree called) A^alaA='ap, in two sorts of washing that continued during the night upon him with much pouring and much dropping]; meaning that the water that was upon the tree poured upon him at one time; and at one time, that of the rain: (S, TA:) the pl. of gusolN is A^agosaAlN. (Msb.) See also gasolN. ― -b2- And see gasuwlN.

gisolN *
A preparation for washing the head, consisting of xiTomiY~ [or marsh-mallows] and other things (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) of a similar kind, (Mgh, Msb, K,) [with water,] as [leaves of] the [species of lote-tree called] sidor, (Msb,) and Tiyn, (TA,) or Tiynapu Alr~aA^osi, [meaning fullers' earth, which is often used in the bath and elsewhere instead of soap,] (Mgh,) and A^u$onaAn [or potash]: (TA:) [and app. any wash for the head:] and ↓ gisolapN signifies the same: (Mgh, K:) and also (this latter) leaves of the myrtle: and perfume; syn. TiybN: and what a woman puts into her hair on the occasion of combing and dressing it: (K:) gisolapN muTar~aApN being myrtle [-leaves] rendered fragrant with aromatic perfumes, used in combing and dressing one's hair: one should not say gasolapN. (S, O.) IAar cites the following verse (S, O) of 'Abd-Er-Rahmán Ibn-Dárah El-Ghatafánee, (O,)
fayaA layola A_in~a Algisola maA dumoti A^ay~imFA
EalaY~a HaraAmN laA yamas~uniYa Algisolu
[And, O Leylà, (layola being a contraction of layolaY, but in the O it is yA jumolu O Juml,) verily the wash for the head, as long as thou remainest husbandless, shall be unlawful to me: the wash for the head shall not touch me]: i. e. I will not need the wash for the head by my jimaAE of other than her: [he says thus] in eager desire of taking her in marriage. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also gasuwlN. -A2- And see also gusalapN.
rajulN gasilN * (assumed tropical:) A man who compresses his wife much. (TA.) [See also gusalapN.]
gusalN * : see gusalapN.
gusulN * : see gusolN.

gasolapN * [A single act of washing: pl. gasalaAtN]. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, banawoA h`*ihi Almadiynapa bigasalaAti A^ayodiyhimo (assumed tropical:) [They built this city] by means of their earnings. (TA.)

gisolapN * : see gasuwlN: ― -b2- and see also gisolN. ― -b3- EalaY wajohihi gisolapN means His face is beautiful, with no fat, or fatness, upon it. (TA.) ― -b4- A^abuw gisolapa is an appellation of The wolf: (O, K:) and so Abw Eisolapa, with E. (TA.)

gusalapN * (S, Mgh, O, K) and ↓ gusalN and ↓ gasiylN and ↓ gis~iylN and ↓ migosalN (O, K) and ↓ gisolN, (K,) all, except the last, mentioned by Fr, (O, TA,) applied to a stallion [camel], (tropical:) That covers much: (Fr, Mgh, * O, K, TA:) or that does so much without impregnating: (Ks, S, K, TA:) and in like manner applied to a man. (K.) [See also gasilN.]

Algisoliynu * : see AlgusaAlapu. ― -b2- Algisoliynu (in the Kur [lxix. 36], TA) What is washed off of the flesh and the blood of the inmates of the fire [of Hell]; (Akh, S, O;) [for] what comes forth from any wound, or sore, when it is washed, is termed gisoliyn: (TA:) what is washed off from the bodies of the unbelievers, in the fire: (Msb:) or what flows from the skins of the inmates of the fire, (K, TA,) such as thick purulent matter &c.; thus expl. by Fr and Seer; (TA;) as though it were washed from them: (Sb, TA:) accord. to Mujáhid, a certain food of the inmates of the fire; and El-Kelbee says that it is what the fire has cooked, of their flesh, and has fallen off, and is eaten by them: (TA:) and, (K,) accord. to Ed-Dahhák, (O, TA,) a species of trees in the fire; (O, K, TA;) and so he says of AlD~ariyEu: (O, TA:) and, (K,) accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) what is intensely hot: (O, K, TA:) the Y and n are augmentative. (S, O, Msb.)

gasuwlN * (S, O, K) and ↓ gas~uwlN (O, K) and ↓ gusolN (Mgh, K) and ↓ gisolN and ↓ gisolapN (IAth, K) Water with which one washes himself; (S, Mgh, O, K;) as also ↓ mugotasalN, occurring [in this sense] in the Kur xxxviii. 41: (S:) or the words preceding this signify water little in quantity, with which one washes himself: (TA:) and xiTomiY~ [or marsh-mallows], (K, TA,) and A^u$onaAn [or potash (see also gaAsuwlN)], and the like thereof, and certain of the [plants termed] HamoD: (TA:) or gasuwlN signifies a thing [or substance] with which the hand is washed, such as A^u$onaAn &c.: (Har p. 86:) or, accord. to the M, anything with which one washes a head or a garment and the like. (TA.) [See also the pl. gasuwlaAtN voce daluwkN.]

gasiylN *
i. q. ↓ magosuwlN [i. e. Washed]; (S, O, Msb, K;) applied to a thing, (S, O,) and to a dead body; (Lh, Msb, TA;) and the former is also applied as an epithet to a fem. n., as is also gasiylapN; (S, O, K;) or this last is used after the manner of substs., like naTiyHapN and *abiyHapN; not as is said in the S [and O] after the manner of epithets: (IB, TA:) the pl. of gasiylN is gasoliY and gusalaA='u; (Lh, K, TA;) and the pl. of gasiylapN [and app. of gasiylN used a fem. epithet] is gasaAlaY or gusaAlaY. (K accord. to different copies.) Han- dhaleh Ibn-er-Ráhib was called gasiylu AlmalaAy^ikapi [The washed of the angels], because he died a martyr on the day of Ohod, and the angels washed him, (S, O, Msb,) accord. to the Prophet, who said that he saw them washing him. (O.) ― -b2- See also gusalapN. ― -b3- [It is now used as meaning Clothes, or the like, put together to be washed.]

AlgusaAlapu * , (S, O, Msb,) or gusaAlapu Al$~aYo'i, (K,) That with which one has washed the thing: (S, O, Msb:) or the water with which the thing is washed. (K.) [Hence the latter often signifies The infusion of the thing; i. e. the liquid in which the thing has been steeped, and which is impregnated with its virtues.] ― -b2- Also, the latter, What is extracted from the thing by washing. (K.) ― -b3- And AlgusaAlapu also signifies What is washed from the garment and the like; and so ↓ Algisoliynu. (K.)

gasowiylN *
A certain plant, growing in places that exude water and produce salt: (O, K:) said by IDrd to be a species of trees. (O.)
gas~aAlN * [A washer of clothes, and also of the dead: fem. with p]. (TA.) [See also gaAsilN.]
gas~uwlN * : see gasuwlN.
gis~iylN * : see gusalapN.

gaAsilN *
A washer of the dead. (Msb.) [See also gas~aAlN.] -A2- And A species of trees. (TA.)

gaAsuwlN *
i. q. A^u$onaAnN [i. e. Potash: and the plant from which it is prepared; kali, or glasswort; or mesembryanthemum nodiflorum (Forskål, Flora Ægypt. Arab. pp. lxvii. and 98), a species of glasswort]. (TA.) [See also gasuwlN.]

magosilN * (S, O, Msb, K) and magosalN [which is anomalous] (S, O, K) and ↓ mugotasalN (K) A place in which the dead are washed: (S, O, Msb, K) pl. of the first (S, Msb) and second (S) magaAsilu: (S, Msb:) and one says also magosialu AlmawotaY. (S, O, Msb. *)

migosalN *
A thing [i. e. vessel] in which (so in the M, in the K with which,) a thing is washed. (TA.) -A2- See also gusalapN.

magosuwlN * : see gasiylN. ― -b2- Hence one says, kalaAmuhu magosuwlN, meaning (assumed tropical:) His speech, or language, is devoid of nice, or subtile, expressions or allusions; as though it were washed from such; or deserving to be washed and obliterated: or it may mean (tropical:) trimmed, or pruned. (TA.)

mugotasalN *
A place in which one washes himself: (O, Msb, TA: *) dim. ↓ mugayosilN: and pl. magaAsiylu [which, if correct, is anomalous]. (TA.) ― -b2- And it is said to signify also what is called in Pers. HwD masiyn [or HawoD misiyn app. meaning A tank, or the like, of copper]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- See also magosilN. ― -b4- And see gasuwlN.
mugayosilN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 gasama *
It (the night) was, or became, dark; (As, S, K;) as also ↓ Agsm, (JK, K,) like A^agosaY. (JK.)
4 A^agosama see what precedes.

gasamN * The darkness (S, ISd, TA) of night; (ISd, TA;) like gasaqN: (S, TA:) or blackness: (Kr, K:) and (K) accord. to En-Nadr, (S,) the confusedness, or blending, of the darkness: (JK, S, K:) and the first rising of the dawn. (JK.) ― -b2- And Dust, or dust rising, or spreading, like smoke; syn. habowapN and gabarapN (K) or guborapN [which sometimes signifies the same as gabarahN]. (CK.)
gusamN * ; see A^agosaAmN.

layolN gaAsimN *
Dark night. (TA.)
fiY Als~amaA='i A^agosaAmN * and ↓ gusamN In the sky are portions of clouds. (K.)

div2.head: gsw and gsY
div2.entryFree: 1 gasaA All~ayolu * , (S, K,) aor. yagosuw, (S,) inf. n. gusuw~N; (S, K; accord. to some copies of the K gasowN;) and gasaY, aor. yagosiY; (IJ, TA;) and gasiYa, aor. yagosaY, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. gasFA; of which last form, ga$iYa is a dial. var.; (TA;) The night was, or became, dark; as also ↓ AgsY. (S, K.) [See also EasaA.]

4 A^a1o2a3a see what precedes. ― -b2- AgsY also signifies He (a man) entered upon the time of, or a little after, sunset. (TA.) ― -b3- And A^agosi mina All~ayoli Journey thou not in the first part of the night, until its darkness depart. (TA.) -A2- And AgsAhu All~ayolu The night enveloped him in its darkness. (Sgh, K.)

1 ga$~ahu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
ga$u3a , (S, Msb,) inf. n. ga$~N, (Msb, TA,) or gi$~N, with kesr, (S,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb, K,) He acted towards him, or advised or counselled him, dishonestly, or insincerely: (A. Msb, K:) and he dressed up to him an affair [in false colours]: (Msb:) or he acted towards him with dissimulation: pretended to him the contrary of what he conceived in his mind: (A, K:) but this is a needless addition, for it is the same as the first explanation (TA:) as also ↓ g$~$hu, (K,) inf. n. tago$iy$N: (TA) or this latter has an intensive signification: it is said to be derived from ga$a$N, signifying “ a turbid drinking-place, ” (TA:) It is said in the story of Umm-Zara, accord. to one relation, ↓ laA tamolaA^u bayotanaA tago$iy$FA, said by some to be from Algi$~u, and by others to be from [a usage of] Altg$y$ as signifying Aln~amiymapu [app. here meaning the embellishing speech with falsehood]: but accord. to the approved relation, it is [tago$iy$FA] with the unpointed letter. (IAth.) [See art. E$.] ― -b2- [Also He made it to seem what it was not; falsified it; counterfeited it; adulterated it: so as used often by post-classical authors; and so, probably, in classical times also; see its pass. part n., below.] -A2- ga$~a Sadoruhu, aor.
ga$i3a , [inf. n., probably. gi$~N, q. v.,] His bosom concealed enmity and violent hatred; or bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (TA,)
2 ga$~a3a see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

4 Ag$~hu * , inf. n. A_igo$aA$N, He made him to fall into dishonest, or insincere, conduct, or advice or counsel; into dissimulation; or the pretending the contrary of what he conceived in his mind. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^ago$a$otuhu Eano HaAjatihi I prevented him from obtaining the object of his want; syn. A^aEojalotuhu. (IKtt, K.)
8 A_igota$a3a see the next paragraph, in two places.

10 Astg$~hu * (S, K) and ↓ Agt$~hu (K, TA) He reckoned him, or deemed him, dishonest, or insincere, in action, or advice or counsel; contr. of AisotanoSaHahu (S, K) and AinotaSaHahu; (K;) or, [which means the same,] i. q. Ead~ahu gaA$~FA: (TA:) or he imagined in him dishonest, or insincere, conduct, or advice or counsel; dissimulation; or the pretending the contrary of what he conceived in his mind. (K.) A poet says,
laka naASiHN ↓ A^ayaA rub~a mano tagota$~uhu
wamusotanoSaHK biAlogayobi gayoru A^amiyni
[O man, many a one whom thou reckonest dishonest in action, or advice, is honest therein to thee; and (many a) one who is reckoned honest in action, or advice, in that which is beyond the reach of perception, is not faithful]. (TA)

ga$~N * , (K, TA,) of the measure faEolN, or it may be originally of the measure faEilN, (TA,) applied to a man, (K, TA,) i. q. EaZiymu Al$~arahi [i. e. Very greedy]; not EZym Als~ur~api, as in some copies of the K; nor EZym Al$~ir~api, as in other copies: a rájiz says,
layosa biga$~K ham~uhu fiymaA A^akalo
[He is not one who is very greedy; whose care, or solicitude, is in respect of what he has eaten]. (TA)

gi$~N *
Dishonest, or insincere, conduct, or advice or counsel: (Msb, K:) and the embellishment of an affair [with false colours]: (Msb:) or dissimulation; pretence of the contrary of what one conceives in his mind. (K.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- And Rancour, malevolence, malice, or (??) (K.) ― -b3- [Also Adulterating alloy in coin (See HumolaAnN.) ― -b4- And Adulterated, or counterfeit, coin. (See zagalN.)]

ga$a$N *
A turbid drinking-place: (Az, IAmb, Sgh, TA:) Alkadiru Alma$uwbu in the K is a mistake: the right explanation of Alga$a$u being Alma$orabu Alkadiru, which is that given by Az and IAmb and Sgh. (TA.)
ga$aA$N * : see the next paragraph.

gi$aA$N * , applied to a drinking ($urobN), Little in quantity, (K, TA,) because of turbidness: (TA: [in which it is said to be applied in like manner to a day, ywm; but I think that this is a mistranscription for nawomN, i. e. sleep:]) or hasty. or not wholesome; (K, TA;) because the water is not clear. (TA.) -A2- And The beginning of the darkness: and the end thereof. (K.) -A3- naqiytuhu gi$aA$FA, (T, S, K,) and ↓ ga$aA$FA, (K,) I met, or found, him, or it, in haste; (T, S, K:) and so ElY g$A$: (T, TA:) or at sunset; (Lth, K;) but Az disallows this: (TA:) or in the night; (K;) which is nearly the same as what Lth says. (TA.)

gaA$~N *
Acting, or advising or counselling, dishonestly, or insincerely; or acting with dissimulation; pretending the contrary of what one conceives in his mind: [see its verb;] pl. gi$a$apN and [quasipl. n., like as SaHaAbapN is of SaAHibN,] ga$aA$apN (TA.)

$aYo'N mago$uw$N * [A thing made to seem what it is not; falsified; counterfeited; adulterated]; (S, K;) a thing that is not pure; not genuine; or not unadulterated. (K.) You say, TaEaAmu fulaAnK mago$uw$N A^aEolaAhu yaAbisN waA^asofaluhu maro$uw$N [The wheat of such a one is made to seem what it is not: it upper part is dry, and its lower part is sprinkled]. (A.) And labanN mago$uw$N Milk mixed with water. (Mgh, Msb.) And fiD~apN mago$uw$apN Silver mixed with copper or brass. (TA.)

1 ga$omN * signifies The acting, or treating, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (S, K:) or the taking another's property wrongfully, &c., or by force: and the taking a course, in journeying [&c.], at random, without direction and without knowledge. (JK.) One says of a governor, ga$ama Alr~aEiy~apa, aor.
ga$ima , [accord. to the TK, the aor. of the verb in the sense here following is
ga$uma , but this I think a mistake,] inf. n. ga$omN, He struck, or beat, with vehemence, the people under his government, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, and took [from them] what he could. (TA.) And ga$ama Aln~aAsa He asked whom he could of the people. (Z, TA.) And ga$ama AlA^umuwra He performed affairs, or the affairs, [in a random manner,] confusedly, without discrimination. (Ham p. 37: by implication.) ― -b2- And ga$amahu, aor.
ga$ima , He smeared him [i. e. a camel] with tar so that he left nothing [or no part of him] without tar, pouring it upon what was sound thereof and what was diseased thereof: and ↓ ga$amN [perhaps as an inf. n., but accord. to the TK it is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is ga$omN,] signifies the act of so smearing. (K.) ― -b3- And ga$ama (tropical:) He collected firewood by night, cutting whatever he could get, without consideration, (K, TA,) or, as in the A, without discrimination. (TA.)
ga$amN * : see the preceding paragraph. -A2- Also Blackness [of night: app. a dial. var. of gasamN; or, perhaps, a mistranscription]. (Ham p. 163.)

ga$uwmN * A man who strikes, or beats, people vehemently, [and wrongfully, (see 1,)] and takes [from them] everything that he can get; as also ↓ ga$~aAmN and ↓ gaA$imN [except that the first and second are app. intensive epithets and the last is a simple part. n.]: and it is likewise applied to a fem., as, for ex., to a hand (yadN): and to a striking, or beating, (DarobN,) [app. as meaning wrongful,] as is also ↓ ga$amo$amN. (TA.) [One says,] AlHarobu ga$uwmN [War is wrongful], because it reaches other than the committer of a crime, or an offence deserving punishment. (S.) ― -b2- Also A she-camel that will not be turned back from her course, or way. (R, TA.)
ga$iymN * , meaning [Ignorant of affairs,] not knowing anything, is a word of the vulgar. (TA.)
gu$uwmiy~ahN * , meaning Ignorance of affairs, is a word of the vulgar, like that next preceding. (TA.)
ga$~aAmN * : see ga$uwmN.
gaA$imN * : see ga$uwmN.

ga$amo$amN * : see migo$amN. Accord. to some, it signifies One who acts with much wrongfulness, injustice, injuriousness, or tyranny. (Ham p. 104.) ― -b2- naAqapN ga$amo$amapN A she-camel strong, resisting, or indomitable, in spirit. (IJ, TA.) And ga$amo$amN is applied to a he-camel as meaning haAy^ijN [i. e. Excited by lust]. (Meyd in explanation of the prov. here following.) ― -b3- ga$amo$amN yuga$~iY Al$~ajara, i. e. This, or it or he, is a torrent [wild in its course,] that overwhelms the trees, so that it crushes them and uproots them, sayolN preceded by h`*aA or huwa being meant to be supplied, is a prov. applied to a man who cares not what wrong he does. (Meyd.) ― -b4- See also ga$uwmN.
A_in~ahu la*uw ga$amo$amapK * and ga$amo$amiy~apK Verily he is one who possesses boldness, or daringness, and penetrative energy. (K.)

A^ago$amu * [More, and most, wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical: &c.: see 1]. A^ago$amu mina Als~ayoli [More wild in course than the torrent] is a proverb. (Meyd.) -A2- IAar cites a verse in which it is applied to a plant as meaning Dry and old; but accord. to one relation of that verse, the word is A^aEo$am. (TA.)

migo$amN * One who goes at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, without consideration, whom nothing will turn from that which he desires, (S, K,) by reason of his courage; (S;) as also ↓ ga$amo$amN: (S, K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Riyásh, one who performs affairs [in a random manner,] confusedly, without discrimination: or, as some say, one who, when the road is unapparent to him, goes at random, without direction and without knowledge. (Ham p. 37.)

div2.head: g$w and g$Y
div2.entryFree:
1 ga$iyahu * , aor. yago$aY, inf. n. ga$aAwapN, It covered, or concealed, him, or it; (TA;) as also ↓ tg$~Ahu. (MA.) And one says, ga$aAniY All~ayolu, i. e. ga$iyaniY [The night covered me, or concealed me: or the meaning may be that which next follows]. (JK.) ― -b2- ga$iyahu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) is said of an event (A^amorN), [and of heat, (S and K in art. dgm,) and of cold, (K in that art.,) and of an affection of the mind or body, and of various things, sometimes in like manner of a man, and of a company of men,] in a similar sense; and so ↓ tg$~Ahu; (K, TA;) both signifying It came upon, [or invaded, so as to surprise, and so as to over-whelm, properly meaning] as a thing that covered, him, or it. (K, * TA.) Hence, in the Kur [liii. 16], A_i*o yago$aY A@lsi~dorapa maA yago$aY [When there was coming upon the lote-tree so as to cover it, or overspread it, what was so coming]. (TA.) And in the same [xx. 81], faga$iyahumo mina A@loyam~i maA ga$iyahumo [And there came upon them so as to overwhelm them, of the sea, what so came upon them]. (TA.) And in the same [viii. 11], A_i*o yago$aAkumu [followed by A@Aln~uEaAsu, i. e. When it (drowsiness) was coming upon you, or overcoming you]; accord. to one reading; other readings being yugo$iykumu and yuga$~iykumu [followed by A@ln~uEaAsa]. (TA.) See also gaA$iyapN, in three places. ― -b3- [A somewhat similar signification of ga$iyahu will be found below.] ― -b4- One says of the night, yago$aY biZulomatihi kul~a maA bayona Als~amaA='i waAlA^aroDi [It covers, or conceals, with its darkness, everything that is between the heaven and the earth]. (Jel in xcii. 1.) And [hence it is said that] ga$iYa All~ayolu means The night was, or became, dark; as also ↓ Ag$Y. (Msb, TA.) ― -b5- [And ga$iyahu, and ga$iYa baSarahu and ↓ g$~Ahu, signify It, i. e. light (Dawo'N), came upon him, and upon his eye, with an overpowering effect, so as to obscure, or dazzle, his sight.] ― -b6- ga$iyahu also signifies jaA='ahu (S) or A^ataAhu (Mgh, Msb, K) [which have two meanings, i. e. He came to him, and he did it; both, perhaps, here meant, for both are well-known meanings of ga$iyahu]; and, thus used, the aor. is as above, (TA,) and the inf. n. is ga$ayaAnN, (S, TA,) or gi$oyaAnN, (so in one of my copies of the S,) or the subst. is ↓ gi$oyaAnN, (Msb,) with kesr, (Mgh, Msb,) syn. with A_itoyaAnN. (Mgh.) You say, ga$iYa fulaAnFA He came to such a one; syn. A^ataAhu; as also ga$aAhu, aor. yago$uwhu. (K.) ― -b7- [Hence,] ga$iyahaA, (S, MA, Msb, K,) inf. n. ga$ayaAnN or gi$oyaAnN, (accord. to different copies of the S,) or the latter and ga$oYN, (MA,) or ↓ gi$oyaAnN is the subst. in this case also, (Msb,) and syn. with A_itoyaAnN, metonymically used in the sense of jimaAEN, (Mgh, Msb,) (tropical:) He compressed her; (S, MA, Msb, K;) namely, a woman; (MA, K;) as also ↓ tg$~AhA. (MA, Msb, TA.) ― -b8- And ga$iYa A_ilayohi maHojarFA He did to him (A^ataY A_ilayohi) a forbidden action. (TA in art. Hjr.) [Hence,] ↓ gi$oyaAnu AlmaHaArimi [The doing of forbidden things]. (Mgh and Msb and K in art. rhq.) And ga$iYa Al$~aYo'a He occupied himself with the thing, engaged in it, or personally managed or conducted it; syn. laAbasahu and baA$arahu. (JM.) [And ↓ tg$~Y has a similar meaning; for it is said that] Alt~aga$~iY and Alga$oYu primarily signify AlA_itoyaAnu and AlmulaAbasapu: and they took an extended range in using the former, so that one said, biAlEadoli ↓ taga$~aAhumo or biAlojawori [app. meaning He ruled them with equity or with injustice]. (Ham p. 27.) [And one says, yago$aY AlHuruwba (see Ham p. 27), meaning He plunges into wars, or battles: see mugaAmisN, and its verb.] ― -b9- One says also, ga$iyahu biAls~awoTi, (K, in which it is said to be like raDiyahu, and so accord. to some copies of the S, the phrase in these being ga$iyatu Alr~ajula biAls~awoTi,) or bihi ↓ ga$~aAhu, (accord. to other copies of the S, the verb in these being written ga$~ayotu, and thus accord. to an explanation of qan~aEa raA^osahu biAls~awoTi in art. qnE in the K,) He struck him (i. e. a man, S) with the whip; he flogged him. (S, K.) -A2- gu$iYa Ealayohi, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. ga$oYN, (S, Mgh, * K,) or gu$oYN, (MA,) or both, (Msb,) and ga$ayaAnN, (K, TA, and so in some copies of the S,) or gi$oyaAnN, (so in other copies of the S,) and ↓ ga$oyapN, (S, Mgh,) or this last is an inf. n. of un., (Msb,) or it is the subst., (K,) He swooned, i. e. became senseless: (MA, PS:) or i. q. A^ugomiYa Ealayohi [q. v.]: (K, TA:) or Alga$oYu, or Algu$oYu,
is a state of inertness (taEaT~ul, Mgh, Msb) of the motive and sensitive faculties, (Mgh,) or of the motive faculties and of the sensitive will, (Msb,) on account of the weakness of the heart, (Mgh, Msb,) and the soul's becoming drawn together thereto by a cause that suppresses it (yuxofiyhi) within so that it finds not a place of passage, and of the causes thereof is a strangling [or stifling], or hurtful, cold repletion, or vehement hunger, (Mgh,) or vehement pain, (Mgh, Msb,) or cold, or excessive hunger, (Msb,) or an evil affection in some associate, or participating, organ, such as the heart and the stomach: (Mgh:) some say that it is the same as AlA_igomaA='u [for which see its proper art.]; (Mgh, Msb;) thus say the scholastic theologians: (Mgh:) others (the physicians and the lawyers, Mgh) make a difference between these two terms. (Mgh, Msb.)

2 ga$~ayotu Al$aYo'a * , (S, Msb,) inf. n. tago$iyapN, (S,) I covered the thing; put a cover, or covering, upon it, or over it. (S, Msb.) One says, ga$~aY A@ll~`hu EalaY baSarihi, inf. n. as above; and ↓ Ag$Y; (K, TA;) i. e. God put a covering upon, or over, his eyes. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) it is said in the Kur [xxxvi. 8], fahumo laA yuboSiruwna ↓ faA^ago$ayonaAhumo And we have put a covering over them [so that they shall not see]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [See a usage of the inf. n. voce $iynN.] ― -b3- g$~Ahu said of light; see 1, former half. ― -b4- See also 4. ― -b5- g$~Ahu biAls~awoTi: see 1, latter half. ― -b6- One says also, ga$~ayotuhu sayofFA, or sawoTFA, [in my original g$yth, without any syll. sign, but app. as I have written, for I do not find any instance of ga$iYa as doubly trans., meaning I equipped him with a sword, or a whip,] like the saying kasawotuhu sayofFA, or Eam~amotuhu. (TA.)

4 Ag$Ahu A_iy~aAhu * and ↓ g$~Ahu He made it to cover it; or to be a cover, or covering, upon it, or over it. (MA, * TK, and Bd * and Jel * in vii. 52, &c.) ― -b2- And [hence,] both signify He made it, i. e. an event (A^amor), to come upon, [or invade, so as to surprise, or so as to overwhelm, properly meaning] as a thing that covered, him, or it. (K, * TA,) Both of these verbs are used in this sense in the Kur-án accord. to different readings in vii. 52 and xiii. 3, and likewise (as mentioned in the first paragraph of this art., q. v.,) in viii. 11. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, the former, He made him, or it, to come to him. (S, MA, TA.) ― -b4- See also 2, in two places. ― -b5- [Hence,] Ag$Y All~ayolu: see 1, former half.
5 ta1a2~a3a see 10: ― -b2- and see also 1, first and third sentences: ― -b3- and again, near the middle, in three places.

10 Astg$Y vawobahu * , (T, K, [agreeably with phrases in the Kur xi. 6 and lxxi. 6,]) and (K) bivawobihi, (S, K,) and bihi ↓ tg$~Y, (S,) [see an ex. of the latter verb in a verse of El-Khansà cited in the first paragraph of art. rEY, where it is trans. without a preposition,] He covered himself with his garment (S, K) in order that he might not see nor hear: (K: [in the CK, yusomaEa and yuraY are put for yasomaEa and yaraY:]) accord. to Er-Rághib, Aisotago$awoA viyaAbahumo means they put their garments as a covering over their ears; and is a phrase denoting the refusing to hearken; or, as some say, an allusion to running, like the phrase $am~ara *ayolFA, and A^aloqaY vawobahu. (TA.)
ga$FA * The whiteness of the head [or face], of a horse and of other animals, denoted by the epithet A^ago$aY [q. v.]. (S.)
ga$owN * The nabiq [generally meaning the fruit of the lote-tree called sidor; but sometimes the tree thus called itself]: (K:) accord to the M, [the n. un.] ga$owapN signifies a sidorap. (TA.)
ga$owapN * and gi$owapN and gu$owapN: see gi$aAwapN.

ga$oyapN * an inf. n. of the verb in the phrase gu$iYa Ealayohi, (S, Mgh,) or the subst, thereof, (K,) or the inf. n. un. thereof [signifying A swoon]. (Msb.) See 1, last sentence. ― -b2- ga$oyapu Almawoti is The clouding (lit. covering) of the understanding that befalls a man on the occasion of death. (TA.) ― -b3- And ga$oyapu Hum~aY signifies A touch, or slight attack, of fever. (TA.)
gu$oyapN * : see gi$aAwapN.
gi$oyaAnN * : see 1, near the middle, in three places.

gi$aA='N *
A cover, or covering; syn. giTaA='N: (S, Msb:) or it differs from the giTaA=' in being of clothing or the like: (TA in art. gTw) and gi$aAwapN [q. v.] signifies the same: (Msb;) [the pl. of the former is A^ago$iyapN and A^ago$aA='N; the former regular; and the latter, (which occurs in this art. in the TA in an explanation of gawaA$K, pl. of gaA$iyapN.) like A=daAmN as pl. of A_idaAmN.] The gi$aA=' of the heart is The cover, or covering, thereof; (K, TA;) the qamiyS thereof, likewise mentioned in the K as being called the ↓ gaA$iyap; a covering of skin, (i. e. the pericardium,] the removal of which therefrom causes death; and also called the ↓ gi$aAwap, this being expl. as meaning the skin of the heart: (TA:) and so of the horse's saddle; (K, TA;) which is a covering of skin or other material: (TA:) [see also gaA$iyapN:] and so of the sword; (K, TA.) which is its gilaAf [a term applied to its scabbard, and also to a case, or covering, enclosing the scabbard, or enclosing the scabbard with its appertenances] (TA;) and so of other things. (K.)

gi$aAwapN * (S, ISd, K) and ga$aAwapN and gu$aAwapN (ISd, K) and ↓ ga$owapN and gi$owapN and gu$owapN (S, K) and ↓ gaA$iyapN and ↓ gu$oyapN and ↓ gu$aAyapN and gi$aAyapN (K) signify A covering upon the eyes (S, K) and upon the heart: (K:) you say, EalaY baSarihi gi$aAwapN &c. [Upon his eyes is a covering, or film, app. used only in a tropical sense], (S, K,) and EalaY qalobihi [upon his heart], (K:) thus the first of these words signifies. in relation to the eyes, in the Kur [ii. 6 and] xlv. 22, in relation to the heart, Az says that it is a [sort of] covering of rust (mino TabaEK [also termed rayon]). (TA.) See also gi$aA='N, in two places.
gu$aAyapN * and gi$aAyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

gaA$iyapN * : see gi$aA='N and gawaA$K .gi$aAwapN is its pl. (TA:) occurring in the Kur vii. 39, meaning A^agomaA='N, (K, TA,) i. e. A^ago$aA='N [or Coverings, a pl. of gi$aA='N]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also [The covering, like gi$aA='N, q. v.], of the horse's saddle. (S.) ― -b3- And (S,) of the [camel's saddle called] raHol, (K,) it is The iron that is above the muw^ax~arap or [hinder part], (S, K, TA,) also called the daAmigap [q. v.]. (Az TA.) ― -b4- Also The skin with which the jafon [or scabbard] of a sword is covered, from the lower part of its $aArib [q. v.] to its naEol [or shoe of iron, or silver, at the lower end of the scabbard]: or the covering that is put upon the hilt, consisting of [the skins called] A^asofaAn [pl. of safanN, q. v.]: (K. [for A^asofaAn, which is the reading in the M, some copies of the K have A^asofaAr:]) or the first part, of the sword, of what is next to thee [when holding the hilt]: and sometimes it signifies its gimod [or scabbard], also. (Ham p. 22.) ― -b5- AlgaA$iyapu (in the Kur lxxxviii. I, TA) means The resurrection; (S, K, TA;) because it will overwhelm (↓ tago$aY) with its terrors; (S, TA;) or because it will come upon mankind as a thing covering them, (↓ tago$aY Alxaloqa,) so as to include them universally: (TA:) and, (K, TA,) some say, (TA,) the fire of Hell); (K, TA;) because it will cover, or overspread, (↓ tago$aY,) the faces of the unbelievers. (TA.) (In like manner also,] gaA$iyapN mina AlEa*aAbi means Punishment that is general, or universal, in its extent. (TA.) ― -b6- And gaA$iyapN signifies also A calamity, or misfortune. (TA.) ― -b7- And A cer tain disease that attacks in the jawof [i. e. belly, or chest]. (As, S, K.) One says, ramaAhu A@ll~`hu bigaA$iyapK [May God smite him, or afflict him, with a gaA$iyap]. (As, S.) ― -b8- Also Petitioners that come to one (K, TA) seeking, or demanding, or asking, gifts: (TA:) and visiters, and friends, that come to one time after time; (K, TA;) and that resort to one (TA:) a man's resorters; such as guests; and hangers-on, or seekers of favours; servants [or dependants]; and others. (Har pp. 95 and 467.)

A^ago$aY * , applied to a horse, (S, K,) and to other than a horse, (S,) Whose whole head, as distinct from his body, is white; like A^aroxamu: (S:) or whose face is covered by whiteness: (K:) or having a blaze covering his face, and wide: (M, TA;) fem. ga$owaA='u, applied to a goat. (S, K.)

mago$iY~N Ealayohi *
Swooning; i. e. senseless; (MA, PS;) having the affection denoted by the phrase gu$iYa Ealayohi [q. v.]. (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K.)

1 gaS~a * , (Msb, MF,) sec. pers. gaSiSota, (S, Msb, K,) and gaSaSota, (Msb, K,) the latter extr.,
(TA, [see 1 in art. ED,]) aor. yagaS~u, (S, Msb, K,) when the sec. pers. of the pret. is gaSiSota, (Msb,) and yaguS~u, (Msb, TA,) when the sec. pers. of the pret. is of the other form mentioned above, (Msb,) inf. n. gaSaSN, (S, K,) or gaS~N, (Msb,) or the former when the aor. is yagaS~u, and the latter when the aor. is yaguS~u, (TA,) His throat, or fauces, became choked, or obstructed, (S, K, MF,) by food: (S, Msb, MF:) [as also, app., ↓ AigotaS~a:] accord. to some of those skilled in the science of lexicology, you say gaS~a when it is by food, and $ariqa when it is by beverage, [or by the spittle, and water, and the like, (see art. $rq,)] and $ajiYa when it is by a bone, and jariDa when it is with spittle; but every one of these is sometimes used in the place of any other: (MF:) and [thus] you say also, gaS~a biAlmaA='i, meaning, his throat, or fauces, became choked, or obstructed, by the water; or the water stopped therein, and he was hardly able to swallow it. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] gaS~a biriyqihi [lit., His throat, or fauces, became choked by his spittle;] meaning, (tropical:) he died. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, also, gaS~a biAlgayoZi (tropical:) [He was, or became, choked with wrath, or rage]. (Msb.) ― -b4- [And gaS~a, alone, seems to signify (assumed tropical:) He became grieved, or disquieted in mind; like as does $ajiYa (q. v.): and it seems to be indicated in the CK that ↓ AgtS~ signifies the same: see guS~apN.] ― -b5- [Hence also,] gaS~ato binaA AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land became straitened [as though it were choked] by us. (TA.) And gaS~a Almajolisu biA^aholihi (assumed tropical:) [The sitting-place became straitened, or choked, or choked up, by its people]; as also ↓ AgtS~. (TA.)

4 AgS~hu * , (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. A_igoSaASN, (TA,) He (a man, S, Msb) caused his throat, or fauces, to be choked, or obstructed, (S,) by food; (Msb;) syn. A^a$ojaAhu [which has the above-mentioned meaning and also another to he found below]. (TA.) [And It (food &c.) choked him.] ― -b2- Hence, AgS~hu biAlgayoZi (tropical:) [He (a man) caused him to become choked with wrath, or rage]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AgS~hu biriyqihi [lit., He caused his throat, or fauces, to become choked by his spittle;] meaning, (assumed tropical:) He caused him to become grieved, or disquieted in mind; (A, TA;) [like A^a$ojaAhu: and it seems to be indicated in the CK that AgS~hu without any addition signifies the same: see guS~apN.] ― -b4- [Hence also,] AgS~ EalayonaA AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) He made strait to us the land. (K, TA.)
8 A_igotaSa3a see 1, in three places.

guS~apN *
A thing lying across in the throat, or fauces, so as to cause a choking, or an obstruction, thereof; (IDrd, A, * K;) a thing by which one has his throat, or fauces, choked, or obstructed; (TA;) food by which one has his throat, or fauces, choked, or obstructed; (Msb;) i. q. $ajFA; (S, K;) [which has another meaning that will be found below; and both these meanings may be intended by it in the S; but in the K, the latter only seems to be intended; for there, between it and the explanation which is here first given, we find intervening the pl., and also, in the CK, the words waqado AagoSaSotuhu fAgotaS~a;] a thing by which one is choked ($ajFA yugaS~u bihi, Lth, JK, TA) in the Haroqadap [meaning the head of the windpipe], (Lth, TA,) or in the throat, or fauces: (JK:) pl. guSaSN. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [lxxiii. 13], waTaEaAmFA *aA guS~apK (TA) And food that sticks fast, (Bd,) or by which one is choked, (Jel,) in the throat, or fauces. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) Choking wrath or rage. (Msb.) ― -b3- [And (assumed tropical:) Grief, or disquietude of mind; a signification often occurring; and app. intended by the explanation $ajFA in the K. See what is said on this point above.] ― -b4- Hence also, guSaSu Almawoti [The chokings, or strangulations, of death: the deathrattles: or (assumed tropical:) the agonies of death]. (TA.)
gaS~aAn * : see what next follows.

gaAS~N * A man having his throat, or fauces, choked, or obstructed, (S, Msb, * K,) by food; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ gaS~aAn. (S [in two copies of which it is written gaS~aAnu], K [in two copies of which it is written gaS~aAnN], Msb [in my copy of which, as well as in the TA, it is without any final syll. sign].) ― -b2- And [hence,] gaAS~N biAlqawomi (assumed tropical:) An abode, or a place of alighting, filled [and as it were choked up] with the company of men; (S, A, K;) and in like manner a mosque; as also ↓ mugotaS~N. (A.)
mugotaS~N * : see what next precedes.

1 gaSabahu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
gaSiba , (Msb, K,) inf. n. gaSobN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) and ↓ AgtSbhu; (S, Msb, K;) He took it wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously; (S, A, Mgh, K;) or by force; (Mgh, Msb;) minohu and Ealayohi [i. e. from him], both meaning the same. (S.) AlgaSobu repeatedly occurs in the traditions, signifying The taking another's property wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or by violence. (L.) But as employed in law, it means The taking property that has a price and is forbidden, without the permission of its owner, without stealthiness: therefore it does not rightly apply in the case of an animal that has died a natural death or not been slaughtered according to the law, because it is not property; nor in the case of the free person, in like manner; nor in the case of the wine of the Muslim, because it has not a price; nor in the case of the property of him with whom one is at war, because it is not forbidden; the saying “ without the permission of the owner ” precludes the trust, or deposit; and the saying “ without stealthiness ” excludes theft. (KT.) ― -b2- One says also, gaSabotuhu maAlFA and gaSabotu minohu maAlFA I took property from him [wrongfully, &c., or] by force. (Msb.) ― -b3- And gaSabahaA nafosahaA (Msb, TA) and nfshA ↓ AgtSbhA (Msb) (tropical:) He violated her; forced her; had connection with her against her will; (TA;) or constuprated her by force. (Msb.) ― -b4- And gaSaba fulaAnFA EalaY Al$~aYo'i (K, TA) and ↓ AgtSbh (TA) He compelled such a one by force to do the thing. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And gaSaba Aljiloda, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He removed from the skin its hair and its fur by plucking and peeling, without subjecting it to the process termed EaTonN, in the tan, and without A_igomaAl [i. e. burying it] in moist earth, (K, TA,) or [soaking it in] urine [to loosen the hair and fur], and without folding it up: so Az heard it expl. by the Arabs. (TA.)
3 gASbhu A_iy~aAhu * , accord. to Freytag, signifies He took it from him by violence: but for this he has not named any authority.]

8 A_igotaSaba see 1, in three places. ― -b2- One says also, of a woman, AugotuSibato nafosahaA, meaning (tropical:) She was constuprated by force; (A, Mgh, Msb;) as also AugotuSibato EalaY nafosihaA. (Msb.)
gaSobN * and ↓ magoSuwbN A thing taken wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, (S, Mgh,) or by force: (Mgh, Msb:) the former originally an inf. n. (Msb.)
gaASibN * One taking, or who takes, a thing wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, (TA,) or by force: pl. guS~aAbN. (Msb.)
magoSuwbN * : see gaSobN. ― -b2- magoSuwbN lahu and minohu A man from whom a thing has been taken [wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or] by force. (Msb.)

1 gaSanahu * , aor.
gaSina , (K, TA,) inf. n. gaSonN, (TA,) He drew it to him, or towards him; namely, a guSon [or branch]: (K, TA:) from El-Kanánee. (TA.) ― -b2- And He took it; namely, a thing: (K, TA:) or he cut it off: (S, K:) or it signifies also he cut it off, namely, a guSon, and took it. (TA.) ― -b3- And gaSana fulaAnFA Eano HaAjatihi, (K, TA,) aor.
gaSina and
gaSuna , (TA,) He turned, or turned away, and withheld, such a one from the object of his want: (K, TA:) Az says that it was thus read to him by El-Mundhiree in the “ Nawádir ” of IAar; but that, accord. to Sh, it is [gaDana, i. e.] with D; and this is correct: (TA:) the former is a mistake. (TA in art. gDn.)
2 gaS~ana see the next paragraph.

4 AgSn Al$~ajaru * , (A in art. fr$,) inf. n. A_igoSaAnN, The trees put forth branches. (KL.) ― -b2- And AgSn, and ↓ gS~n, said of a bunch of grapes (Eunoquwd), It was, or became, large (kabura, thus in some of the copies of the K, in other copies kavura, but the former is the right, TA) in its berries: (K:) or somewhat large therein. (TA.)

guSonN *
A branch from the stem [or from another branch] of a tree; of the slender thereof as well as of the thick: (K:) [sometimes signifying a twig, or shoot:] pl. [of pauc.] A^agoSaAnN and [of mult.] guSuwnN and giSanapN. (S, K.)
guSonapN * [A branchlet; and a small twig or shoot;] a small guSon. (K.)
A^agoSanu * A bull having a whiteness in his tail. (K.)

1 gaD~a Tarofahu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaguD~u, (Msb, * TA,) [and yagoDuDo may be used, in the dial. of El-Hijáz, instead of its contracted form yaguD~a,] imp. guD~a, (S, A,) in the dial. of Nejd, (S,) and AugoDuDo, in the dial. of El-Hijáz, (S,) inf. n. gaD~N (Msb, K) and giDaADN, with kesr, (A, K,) and gaDaADN and gaDaADapN, with fet-h, (K,) He lowered his eye, or eyes; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also gaD~a mino Tarofihi; (Msb;) [the mn being redundant, accord. to some; but see what is said on this point below:] and he contracted his eye, or eyes; syn. kasarahu; [so as to wrinkle the lids;] or he blinked; i. e. he contracted his eyelids, or drew them near together, and looked: [this signification is very common:] and he contracted (kasara) his eye, or eyes, and looked towards the ground, not opening his eye [or eyes]: and sometimes it indicates a state of abasement. (TA.) Also gaD~a alone, inf. n. gaDaADapN, He contracted his eyelids; like A^agoDaY: he looked languishingly. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 30], qulo lilomuw^ominiyna yaguD~uwA mino A^aboSaArihimo, in which some of the grammarians hold mn to be redundant; but the meaning is obvious, i. e. [Say thou to the believers] that they shall abridge their look, or view, from what is prohibited to them: (Sgh:) or that they shall restrain somewhat of their look, or view. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He bore with forgiveness and silence what was disagreeable, or hateful, or evil. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- gaD~a Sawotahu, (Msb,) or mino Sawotihi, (S, TA,) or both, (Msb,) in like manner signifies He lowered his voice. (S, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxi. 18], waA@goDuDo mino Sawotika, (S, A,) i. e. And lower thy voice: or diminish the loudness of thy voice. (TA.) ― -b4- gaD~a mino lijaAmi farasihi He lowered the rein of his horse, in order to lessen his sharpness of temper. (A, TA. *) ― -b5- gaD~a minohu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaguD~u, (S, TA,) inf. n. gaD~N (Msb, TA) and gaDaADapN, (Msb,) He lowered and lessened his estimation, dignity, or rank: (S, K, TA:) or he detracted from his reputation; or attributed or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, fault, or the like: (Msb:) and, inf. n. gaDaADapN, he disdained it, or scorned it; as also minohu ↓ AgtD~. ('Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, TA.) ― -b6- Also gaD~ahu, (K,) aor. as above, inf. n. gaD~N, (TA,) He lessened it, diminished it, or made it defective or deficient; (K, TA;) and so ↓ gaDogaDahu, (K,) inf. n. gaSogaDapN. (TA.) You say gaDaDotu Als~iqaA='a I lessened, diminished, or made defective or deficient, [the contents of] the skin. (Msb.) And AlmaA='a ↓ gaDogaDotu I lessened, &c., the water. (S.) And ↓ fulaAnN baHorN laA yugaDogaDu Such a one is a sea, or great river, that will not be lessened, &c.: (S:) or that will not become exhausted. (Har p. 418.) [See also R. Q. 1 below, and R. Q. 2.] And [you make the former verb doubly trans., saying,] maA gaDaDotuka $ayoy^FA I have not abridged thee, deprived thee, or defrauded thee, of anything. (TA.) And laA A^aguD~uka dirohamFA I will not abridge thee, deprive thee, or defraud thee, of a dirhem. (TA.) You also say, gaD~a mina Al$~aEari He shortened the hair. (M in art. qSr.) And [in like manner] one says, gaD~a mino raA^osihi, i. q. Tam~a raA^osahu. (K voce Tam~a, q. v.) ― -b7- Also He broke it (i. e. a branch, or stick, or the like,) but did not break it thoroughly; (L, K, TA;) and so ↓ gD~Dhu. (L, TA.) ― -b8- And gaDaDotuhu also signifies I withheld, restrained, or prevented, it; whatever it were. (S.) [Hence the phrase in the Kur xxiv, 30, accord. to an explanation given above.] You say gaD~a AlEa*ola, or AlmalaAmapa, aor. as above, inf. n. gaS~N, He withheld blame. (Lth.) And you say to a rider, in asking him to stop a little where you are, guD~a saAEapF, (TA,) and AugoDuDo liY saAEapF, (A, TA,) i. e. Restrain for me thy beast, and stop, or pause, where I am, a while. (A, TA.) -A2- gaD~a, [first pers. gaDaDotu,] aor. yagiD~u; (Msb;) or the first pers. is gaDiDotu and gaDaDotu, (S, K,) and the aor. of each is yagaD~u; (K;) or, accord. to the T, some say gaDiDota, aor. tagaD~u, and some say gaDaDota, aor. tagaD~u: (IB, TA;) but the latter of these requires consideration; (TA;) inf. n. guDuwDapN (IAar, S, K) and gaDaADapN; (S, K;) or the former only, accord to Alee Ibn- Hamzeh; but the saying baDaADapN and buDuwDapN, to denote the quality of that which is termed baD~N, strengthens what J says [in the S] with respect to gaDaADapN; (IB;) It (a thing) was, or became, fresh, juicy, sappy, moist, not flaccid. (S, Msb:) or flourishing and fresh; or luxuriant: (IAar:) or beautiful and bright: (K:) and gaD~ato, aor. tagiD~u and tagaD~u, inf. n. gaDaADapN and guDuwDapN, said of a woman, (tropical:) she was, or became, fine-skinned, or thin-skinned, so that the blood appeared [through the skin]. (Lh, TA.)

2 gD~D * : see 1, latter half. -A2- Also, inf. n. tagoDiyDN, He ate what is termed gaD~, (K, TA,) i. e. the TaloE [or spadix of a palm-tree]: (TA:) or he became thin-skinned, and plump, and soft, or tender: (O, K:) or he became affected with languor and abasement; (K, TA;) or, as in the Tekmileh, with softness, or tenderness. (TA.)

7 AngD~ AlT~arofu *
i. q. AnogamaDa: (S, TA:) [or the former more probably signifies The eye, or eyes, became contracted: and the latter, the eye, or eyes, became closed.]
8 A_igotaDa3a see 1, near the middle.

R. Q. 1 gaDogaDahu * , inf. n. gaDogaDapN: see 1, near the middle, in three places. -A2- EaDogaDa [inf. n. as above] is also intrans. (TA.) See R. Q. 2. ― -b2- It likewise signifies It (for instance a sea, or a large river, TA) became scanty, or little in quantity, and sank into the earth, or disappeared in the earth; or became scanty, or little in quantity; or decreased: (K, TA:) or went away. (TA.) In the TS, the inf. n. is expl. by gayoZ, which is an abominable mistake for gayoD. (TA.) ― -b3- And gaDogaDapN also signifies A man's speaking indistinctly. (TA.) ― -b4- And The boiling of a cooking-pot. (IKtt, TA.)

R. Q. 2 tgaDogaDa *
It (water, and a sea, or great river, S) decreased, diminished, lessened, or became defective, or deficient; (S, K;) as also ↓ gaDogaDa, (TA,) inf. n. gaDogaDapN. (Msb.) You say, maAta fulaAnN bibiTonatihi lamo yatagaDogaDo minohaA $aYo'N Such a one died with his property abundant, (S,) or complete; nothing thereof having been given away by him; a prov. relating to the death of the niggard. (A 'Obeyd.) And 'Amr Ibn-El-'As said, alluding to the death of Ibn-'Owf. xarajota mina Ald~unoyaA bibiTonatika walamo tatagaDogaDo minohaA $ayoy^FA, meaning Thou hast died with thy religion unimpaired: (A 'Obeyd:) i. e. he had not been occupied with any office of authority or administration where by his recompense might be diminished. (Az.) You say also maTarN laA yatagaDogaDu Rain that will not cease (TA.)

gaD~N *
Fresh; juicy; sappy: moist; not flaccid; (S, Msb, K;) applied to a thing, (S, Msb,) whatever it be; (TA;) as also ↓ gaDiyDF. (S. K,) Hence the trad. mano sar~ahu A^ano yaqoraA^u AlquroA=na gaD~FA kamaA nazala faloyaqoraA^o qiraA='apa A@boni A^am~i EabodK [He who is rejoiced or pleased, to read the Kur-an freshly, who as it descended, let him read according to the reading of Ibn-Umm-'Abd]. (TA.) ― -b2- A calf recently born: pl. giDaADN. (K.) ― -b3- Anything (S) beautiful and bright; (S, K;,) as (assumed tropical:) youth, and the like: (S;) or gaD~N applied to youth, and gaD~apN applied to a woman, (tropical:) i. q. baD~N and baD~apN thinskinned, or fine-skinned, and plump: &c. j: (A:) or the latter, applied to a woman, (tropical:) thin-shinned, or fine-skinned, so that the blood appears [though the skin]; (Lh:) and ↓ gaDiyDapN also is thus applied like gaD~apN. (TA.) You say also, $aYo'N baD~N gaD~N, and ↓ baAD~N gaAD~N A thing fresh, &c., and beautiful and bright; [in a flourishing condition;] not changed, or altered [for the worse]. (TA.) And nabotu gaD~N A [fresh and flourishing and] tender plant. (TA.) And Zil~N gaD~N (assumed tropical:) Shade which the sun has not reached; like a plant which the sun has not reached. (TA.) ― -b4- The spadix of a palm-tree; syn. TaloEN; as also ↓ gaDiyDN: (IAar:) or both signify a tender TaloE: (K:) or a tender TaloE when it appears: (TA:) or the latter, a TaloE when it appears: (As, S:) or the same, fruit when it first comes forth. (TA.)
guD~apN * : see gaDaADapN. -A2- Also A sufficiency of the means of subsistence; like gub~apN. (TA in art. gb.)

gaDiyDN * , applied to an eye, or eyes, (Tarof,) Lowered: (A, TA:) contracted: having the lids contracted, or drawn near together, and so looking: contracted, and looking towards the ground: (TA:) languishing: (K, TA:) and so ↓ magoDuwDN, in all these senses: (TA:) and the former, so
applied, [and app. the latter also,] having the eyelids relaxed, or flaccid. (TA.) You say, ZaboYN gaDiyDu AlT~arofi A gazelle having languishing eyes. (S.) And A_in~aka lgaDiyDu AlT~arofi naqiY~u AlZrofi, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Verily] thou art faithful, not treacherous; by AlZ~arof being meant wiEaAw^uhu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Lowered and lessened in estimation, dignity, or rank: (see gaD~a minohu:)] defective or deficient [in good qualities]; (K;) and, in consequence thereof, (TA,) low, mean, or vile: (A, K:) pl. A^agiD~apN (K) and A^agiD~aA='u. (TA.) ― -b3- Lessened; diminished; made defective or deficient. (TA.) -A2- See also gaD~N, in three places.

gaDaADapN * , [an inf. n., of which the verb is not mentioned in senses agreeing with those here following,] (S, A, K,) and ↓ gaDiyDapN and ↓ magaD~apN (IAar, K) and ↓ guD~apN, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K,) A defect, an imperfection, a fault, a vice, or the like: and lowness, meanness, or vileness: (S, A, Mgh, K:) and the first, [or all,] languor, or want of power. (TA.) You say, layosa Ealayoka fiY h`*aA AlA^amori gaDaADapN There is not, or will not be, charged against thee, in, or with respect to, this affair, lowness, &c.; or any defect, &c.; (S, TA;) or languor, or want of power. (TA.) And ↓ maA A^aradotu bid`lika gaDiyDapa fulaAnK, and ↓ magaD~atahu, I desired not, or meant not, thereby, to attribute any defect, imperfection, fault, vice, or the like, to such a one. (IAar.)
gaDiyDapN * : see gaDaADapN, in two places.
gaAD~N * : see gaD~N.
magaD~apN * : see gaDaADapN, in two places.
magoDuwDN * : see gaDiyDN.

1 gaDiba Ealayohi * , (S, Msb, K,) [aor.
gaDaba ,] inf. n. gaDabo (S, Msb, K *) and magoDabapN, (S, K, *) He was angry with him; (MA, K, * PS, &c.;) and ↓ tgD~b Elyh signifies the same. (Msb.) [See AlgaDabu below.] And gaDiba mino laA$aYo'K i. e. [He was angry] for nothing; meaning, for no cause. (Msb. [lA$Y', in a case of this kind, is regarded as one word, and is therefore as above, not laA $aYo'i: see p. 1626, third col.]) ― -b2- gaDiba lahu (meaning He was angry with another person for his sake, or on his account, TA) is said when the person [on whose account the anger is excited] is living: and gaDiba bihi, when he is dead: (S, A, Msb, K:) so says El-Umawee, and El-Ahmar says the like. (S.) ― -b3- [And you say, gaDiba fiY A@ll~`hi He was angry for the sake of God.] ― -b4- And gaDibati Alfarasu EalaY All~ijaAmi (tropical:) The mare champed upon the bit. (TA.) Abu-n-Nejm says,
tagoDabu A^aHoyaAnFA EalayA ll~ijaAmi
kagaDabi Aln~aAri EalaY AlD~iraAmi
(tropical:) [She champs, sometimes, upon the bit, like the fierce burning of the fire upon the quickly-kindling fragments of firewood]. (A, TA.) [See also 5, last sentence.] -A2- guDiba, like EuniYa [pass. in form]; and gaDiba; (K, TA;) the former of which is the more usual; (TA;) He had the disease termed guiDaAb [q. v.]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And gDbt Eayonuhu, with fet-h and kesr [i. e., app., gaDibato; or “ with fet-h and kesr ” may be a mistranscription for “ with damm and kesr, ” so that the verb may be guDibato; His eye had in it what are termed guiDaAb]. (TA.)

3 gaADabotuhu *
I made him angry, he also making me angry. (K.) ― -b2- And I broke off from him, or quitted him, in anger, or enmity. (S, K.) *ahaba mugaADibFA, in the Kur [xxi. 87], means He went away, breaking off from his people, or quitting them, in anger, or enmity. (S.)

4 AgDbhu *
He angered him, or made him angry. (S, * Msb, * K.)

5 tgD~b *
He became angered or angry: (S:) or he was angry somewhat after [having been so] somewhat. (Ham p. 522.) See also 1, first sentence. ― -b2- And tgD~bt Alqidoru (tropical:) The cooking-pot boiled fiercely EalaY All~aHomi [upon the flesh-meat]. (TA.)

gaDobN * (S, K) Red (S) intense in redness: (S, K:) you say A^aHomaru gaDobN: so says ISk: (S:) or gaDobN signifies A^aHomaru gaDobN (K) i. e. red that is dense, or deep: (TK:) or A^aHomaru [i. e. red], applied to anything: and galiyZN [i. e. thick, &c.]. (TA.) -A2- Also, and ↓ gaDobapN, A hard rock (K, TA) set, or fixed, in a mountain, and differing therefrom: (TA:) or the latter signifies thus: or a hard, round, rock. (O.) -A3- And AlgaDobu signifies The lion: and the bull: as also [in the latter sense, or perhaps in both senses,] ↓ AlgaDuwbu. (K.)

gaDabN * an inf. n. of gaDiba [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) AlgaDabu is The contr. of Alr~iDaY: (K, TA:) it is variously defined: some say that it is a state of excitement of the blood of the heart for the purpose of revenge: some say that pain on account of anything reparable is gaDab; and for anything irreparable, A^asaf: some say that it [is a passion which] includes all that is evil; wherefore the Prophet, to a man who asked of him a precept, said, laA tagoDabo: and some say that AlgaDab is [a passion] accompanied by an eagerness to obtain revenge; and Algam~ is accompanied by despair of obtaining it: (TA: [see also gayoZN:]) there is a gaDab that is commended, and a gaDab that is discommended; the former being that which is for the sake of religion and truth, or right; and the latter being that which is in a wrong case: and the gaDab of God is his disapproving of the conduct of him who disobeys Him, and whom He will therefore punish. (Ibn- 'Arafeh, TA.)
gaDibN * : see gaDobaAnu.

gaDobapN *
A single fit of gaDab [or anger]. (O.) -A2- See also gaDobN. ― -b2- Also An [eminence of the kind termed] A^akamap. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And A baxaSap (K, TA, in the CK baxoSap), or protuberance [of flesh], above, or beneath, the eyes, in the form of a flatulent tumour, (TA,) or in the upper eyelid, produced by nature: (K, TA:) so in the M. (TA.) ― -b4- And A thing resembling a daraqap, (K, TA,) i. e. a shield, (TA,) of the hide of the camel, (K, TA,) one part of which is folded over another. (TA.) ― -b5- And A [garment of the kind called] jub~ap made of the hides of camels, and worn for fighting. (O.) ― -b6- Also The skin of a mountain-goat advanced in age. (K.) The skin of a fish. (K.) The skin of the head. (K.) And The skin of the part between the horns of a bull. (K.) ― -b7- And A patch of the small-pox: so in the saying, A^aSobaHa waAHidapF mina AljudariY~i jiloduhu gaDobapF [His skin became one patch of the small-pox]: (O:) like gaDonapN. (S in art. gDn.)
guDabapN * : see gaDobaAnu.

gaDobaY * fem. of gaDobaAnu [q. v.]: (S, Msb, K:) and pl. thereof. (S.) [See also gaDuwbN.] -A2- It is also said by J, (K, TA,) and [before him] by EzZejjájee, and also [after him] by ISd, (TA,) to be a name for A hundred camels, and not to have tenween, nor the article Al: but this is a mistake for gaDoyaA. (K, TA.)
Alquw~apu AlgaDabiy~apu * [The irascible faculty]. (KT, in explanation of Alt~ahaw~uru.)

gaDobaAnu * (S, Msb, K) [and, in the dial. of BenooAsad, as is implied by the fem. in that dial. mentioned in what follows, gaDobaAnN,] and ↓ gaDibN and ↓ gaDuwbN [which is both masc. and fem.] and ↓ guDub~N (K) and ↓ guDub~apN (S, K) and ↓ gaDub~apN and ↓ gaDab~apN, (K,) or the last, accord. to MF, is ↓ guDabapN, (TA,) are epithets applied to an angry man: (K:) [the first seems often to signify simply Angry, like gaDibN; but accord. to SM,] all these epithets signify quickly, or soon, angry [as guDub~apN is said in the S to signify, on the authority of As]: (TA:) the fem. of the first word is gaDobaY, (S, Msb, K,) and (in the dial. of Benoo-Asad, S) gaDobaAnapN, (S, K,) which is seldom used; (K;) and gaDuwbN is also used as a fem. epithet [as stated above], (K,) and has an intensive signification: (TA:) pl. (of the first word, Msb) giDaAbN (Msb, K) and (likewise of the first) gaDobaY (S) and guDaAbaY (S, K) and gaDaAbaY. (Msb, K.)
guDub~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.
guDub~apN * and gaDub~apN and gaDab~apN: see gaDobaAnu.

giDaAbN * and guDaAbN Motes (qa*FY) in the eye: (K, TA:) or, as in one copy of the K, [and in the O,] in the eyes. (TA.) ― -b2- And A certain disease; (K, TA;) or so the latter word; (O;) an eruption in the skin; but not small-pox: (TA:) or (so accord. to the TA, but in the CK “ and ”) small-pox. (K, TA.)

gaDuwbN * : see gaDobaAnu. ― -b2- Also Stern, or austere,
in look, or countenance; applied to a woman: (S, O, K:) and in like manner applied to a she-camel: (O, K:) or thus applied to a she-camel: and also signifying a company of women. (TA.) ― -b3- And A malignant serpent. (O, K.) ― -b4- See also gaDobN.
guDaAbiY~N * A man (TA) perturbed (kadirN) in social intercourse and in comportment. (K. [For waAlmuxaAlafapi in some copies of the K, I read waAlmuxaAlaqapi, as in other copies.])

AlA^agoDabu *
The part between the penis and the thing. (K.)

magoDuwbN Ealayohi * [An object of anger]. By AlmagoDuwbi Ealayohimo in the Kur [ch. i. last verse], are meant The Jews. (O, TA.) -A2- magoDuwbN also signifies Having [the disease called giDaAb, i. e.] the smallpox. (O, TA.)

1 gaDura * , aor.
gaDura , inf. n. gaDaArapN, It (anything) was, or became, soft, or tender. (TA. [See also the inf. n. below; and see the part. n., gaDiyrN; and gaDirN.]) ― -b2- And gaDira, aor.
gaDara , inf. n. gaDarN, He (a man) became rich, wealthy, or abounding in property. (Msb.) You say, gaDira biAlmaAli, (K. TA,) and in like manner, biAls~aEapi waAlA^aholi, aor.
gaDara , inf. n. gaDarN and gaDaArapN: (TA;) as also guDira, like EuniYa; (IKtt, TA;) He (a man, TA) had abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; (K, TA;) [or he was, or became, rich in wealth and family;] after having been poor. (K, TA.) -A2- gaDarahu A@ll~`hu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
gaDura , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. gaDorN, (Msb, K,) God made him to be rich, wealthy, or abounding in property: (Msb:) to enjoy a pleasant life: (S:) or to have abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (K, TA.) -A3- gaDira, with kesr, said of a place, It had in it red clay or earth: so says Az. (O.) -A4- gaDara Eanohu, aor.
gaDira , (S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. gaDorN [and ↓ magoDarN likewise, accord. to a verse of Ibn-Ahmar as cited in the O and TA, but accord. to the reading of that verse in my copies of the S, it is ↓ magoDirN, app., if correct, a n. of place]; as also gaDira; (TA;) He turned aside or away, or deviated, from it, or him; (S, O, K, TA;) and so ↓ tgD~r. (O, K.) One says, maA gaDarotu Eano SawobiY I did not deviate from my course. (TA.) ― -b2- gaDara Ealayohi, (K. TA,) aor.
gaDira , inf. n. gaDorN, (TA,) i. q. EaTafa (K, TA) [app. as meaning He turned against him, for it is added] and maAla. (TA.) ― -b3- And maAgaDara Eano $atomiYa He did not hold back, or refrain, from reviling me. (TA.) -A5- And gaDarahu, (S, K, TA,) aor.
gaDira , inf. n. gaDorN, (TA,) It, or he, withheld, or prevented, him. (S, K, TA.) One says, A^aradotu A^ano A=tiyaka fagaDaraniY A^amorN [I desired to come to thee, and] an affair withheld, or prevented, me. (TA.) -A6- And gaDara Al$~aYo'a He cut off the thing, (K, TA,) lahu [for him]. (TA.) You say, gaDara lahu mino maAlihi He cut off a portion for him from his property. (K.) -A7- And gaDara Aljiloda He tanned well the skin. (TA.)

2 Hamala famaA gaD~ara *
He charged, and was not cowardly, and did not fall short of what was requisite. (TA.)
5 tagaD~ara see the first paragraph.

8 AugotuDira *
he died being a youth, or young man, in a sound state: (K, TA:) like AuxotuDira. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. grD.]

Q. Q. 1 gaDowara *
He (a man, TA) was angry. (O, K.)
maA naAma liguDorK * is expl. as meaning He hardly, or scarcely, slept; but is said to be with E and S, and has been thus mentioned before [in art. ESr]. (TA.)

gaDirN * : see gaDiyrN. ― -b2- One says also Eayo$N gaDirN maDirN An easy and a plentiful life: (K, * TA:) mDr being here an imitative sequent to EDr. (TA.) ― -b3- And gaDiru Aln~aASiyapi applied to a man, (O, K,) and gaDirapu Aln~aASiyapi applied to a beast (d~aAb~ap), (O, Msb, K,) Blest, fortunate, or abounding in good or advantage or utility. (O, Msb, K.) -A2- See also gaDoraA='u, in two places.

gaDorapN *
A certain plant. (K, TA.) Hence the prov. yaA^okulu gaDorapF wayarobiDu HajorapF [He eats ghadrah, and lies down aside]. (TA. [See also HajorapN.])

gaDoraA='u * : see gaDaArapN, in six places. -A2- Also Earth, or land, (A^aroDN, K,) or a piece, or portion, of clay or earth, (TiynapN, S, Msb,) good, or fertile. (Tay~ibapN, K,) green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour: (xaDoraA='u EalikapN: S, Msb, K:) and land in which is clay, or soil, of a good kind, without sand, or without salt earth; (K, TA;) as also ↓ gaDiyrapN or ↓ gaDirapN, accord. to different copies of the K, the latter accord. to the L. (TA:) or, accord. to IAar, ↓ gaDirN [in the TA gaDoraA='u, which is a mistranscription,] signifies a place having in it red clay or earth. (O.) One says, A^anobaTa fulaAnN biy^orahu fiY gaDoraA='a(S, TA) i. e. Such a one produced the water of his well by digging in land of soft and good earth of which the water was sweet. (TA.) ― -b2- And Land in which palm-trees will not grow until it is dug, (K, TA,) the upper part thereof consisting of white [soft stones, like dry pieces of clay, such as are termed] ka*~aAn. (TA.)

gaDaArN * Clay that is cohesive, and A^axoDar [i. e. green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour], (K,) or (O) of a good kind, without sand, or without salt earth; (O, K;) and so ↓ gaDaArapN: (K:) or the latter signifies such clay itself: (Sh, O:) and the former signifies baked clay (Sh, O, K, TA) made of gaDaArap, (Sh, O,) green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour, (A^axoDaru, O, TA,) which is suspended upon a human being as a preservative from the [evil] eye. (O, K, * TA. *)

gaDowarN *
Sticky clay, (K, TA,) that adheres to the foot, which will hardly, or in nowise, go into it [app. by reason of its compactness]. (TA.) -A2- And A species of trees [or plants], (K, TA,) dustcoloured, that grow large: n. un. with p, (TA.) And (TA) A certain plant, (S, O, TA,) resembling the vumaAm [or panic grass], (TA,) or of the species of A^asal [or rushes], not beneficial, nor causing increase in the cattle; (AHn, O;) it is said that the cattle pasturing upon it do not form fat thereby, (O, TA, *) and that it does not dissolve in their stomachs: (O:) n. un. with p. (AHn, O.)

gaDiyrN *
Soft, or tender; (TA;) applied to a plant, or herbage; as also ↓ gaDirN, and ↓ gaADirN; (O, TA;) all in this sense: (TA:) or so the first, applied to anything: (O, K, TA) or this signifies moist, juicy, or fresh: (AA, O:) and i. q. xaDiyrN [syn. with A^axoDaru i. e. green]. (K.) -A2- See also gaDoraA='u.

gaDaArapN * an inf. n., of gaDura and of gaDira. (TA.) [Used as a simple subst.,] Ease, comfort, and affluence; easiness of life: ampleness of the conveniences of life, or of the means of subsistence; plenty; (K, * TA;) prosperity; (TA;) plenty and prosperity; (S;) a plentiful and pleasant and easy state of life: (TA:) and ↓ gaDoraA='u signifies the same. (S.) One says, A_in~ahumo lafiY gaDaArapK mina AlEayo$i and mn AlEy$ ↓ fY gaDoraA='i, Verily they are in a plentiful and prosperous condition [of life]. (S.) Accord. to As, one should not say A^abaAda A@ll~`hu xaDoraA='ahumo, but ↓ AbAd All~`h gaDoraA='ahumo, meaning May God put an end to their prosperity, and their plentiful condition: (S:) but Ahmad Ibn- 'Obeyd says that both of these phrases mean may God destroy the collective body of them: and another says, their clay of which they were created. (TA. [See also xaDoraA='u, voce A^axoDaru.]) One says also, Eayo$K ↓ A_in~ahu lafiY gaDoraka and xaDoraA='i Eayo$K i. e. Verily he is in a plentiful condition of life. (TA.) And mino xayorK ↓ A_in~ahu lafiY gaDoraA='a [Verily he is in an ample state of prosperity]. (TA.) -A2- And, (O, K,) accord. to Lth, (O,) AlgaDaArapu is an appellation of The qaTaAp [or sand-grouse]; (O, K;) but As disapproved this: (O:) [or] the qaTaAp is called ↓ AlgaDoraA='u; and the pl. is AlgaDaAriY~u. (Msb.) -A3- See also gaDaArN. -A4- Of gaDaArapN meaning A certain utensil, IDrd says, I do not think it to be genuine Arabic: (O, TA:) it signifies a large [bowl such as is termed] qaSoEap: [app. from the Pers. gadaAraho:] pl. gaDaAy^iru. (Mgh.)

gaDaAriY~N *
A species of locust; also called the jaraAd mubaArak: a word of uncertain derivation. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also pl. of gaDoraA='u mentioned near the end of the next preceding paragraph. (Msb.)

AlgaDaw~ara *
The lion. (Sgh, K.)

gaADirN * : see gaDiyrN. -A2- Also Withholding, or preventing. (TA.) -A3- And A skin well tanned. (AHn, S, O, K.) -A4- And One who occupies himself early in the morning in the accomplishment of the objects of his want, or in his needful affairs. (AA, O, K.)
magoDarN * and magoDirN: see the first paragraph.
mugoDirN * : see the following paragraph.

magoDuwrN * A man enjoying a pleasant life: (S:) blest; fortunate; abounding in good, or advantage, or utility: (Msb, K:) or in a state of ease, comfort, and affluence; or of plenty, or prosperity; (O, K, TA;) and of happiness: (TA:) as also ↓ mugoDirN: (K, TA:) pl. of the former magaADiyrN, as well as magoDuwruwna. (TA.)
guDoruwfN * is syn. with guroDuwfN, (S and K &c. in art. grDf, q. v.,) in [all of] its meanings: (K:) pl. gaDaAriyfu. (O and TA in art. grDf.)

1 gaDafahu * , (S, O, K,) aor.
gaDifa , (K,) inf. n. gaDofN, (TA,) He broke it, namely, a branch, or stick, or the like, (S, O, K, TA,) and a thing, (TA,) but not thoroughly. (S, O, TA.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- And gaDafa A^u*unaha, (S, O, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, O,) He (a dog) relaxed his ear, and folded, or creased, it: (S, O, K, TA:) [see, again, 2:] or gaDafa A^u*unaha, inf. n. gaDofaAnN and gaDafaAnN, he (a dog) twisted his ear: and in like manner one says of the wind, [gaDafatohaA,] i. e. it twisted it. (TA.) And gDaf AlwisaAdapa He folded the pillow [so as to make creases in it]. (Ham p. 785. [But perhaps this is correctly ↓ gD~f: comp. its quasi-pass., 5.]) ― -b3- gaDafato said of [wild] she-asses, (O,) or of a she-ass, (K,) aor. as above, (O, TA,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) signifies A^axa*ati AljaroYa A^axo*FA [as though meaning They, or she, restrained the running, i. e. their, or her, running; agreeably with what here follows]: (O, K, TA:) gaDafa, [for gaDafa mina AljaroYi,] said of a horse &c., means he lessened, lit. took from, the rate of the running, (A^axa*a mina AljaroYi,) without reckoning: (L, TA:) Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee- 'Áïdh El-Hudhalee says,
yaguD~u wayagoDifona mino ray~iqK
(O, TA) meaning He (the ass) withholds somewhat of his running, (yakuf~u baEoDa jaroyihi,) and they (the she-asses) lessen, lit. take from, the [or rather a] first, or former, rate of their running, (yaA^oxu*ona A^axo*FA mino A^aw~ali jaroyihin~a,) without reckoning: (Skr: see Kosegarten's “ Carmina Hudsailitarum, ” p. 189:) Skr says, in explanation of the citation above from Umeiyeh, that gaDofN signifies the act of taking and lading out [with the hand] (A^axo*N and garofN); and on one occasion he says, the taking easily; [adding,] one says, gaDafa fulaAnN mino TaEaAmK lay~inK [Such a one took, or laded out with his hand, from soft food]. (TA.) -A2- gaDafa AlEayo$u, inf. n. guDuwfN, The life was soft, or easy, and plentiful. (TA.) -A3- gaDifa, [aor.
gaDafa , inf. n. gaDafN,] He (a dog, S) was, or became, relaxed, or flabby, in the ear. (S, K, TA.) And gaDifati AlA^u*unu, inf. n. gaDafN, is said to mean The ear was, or became, long and relaxed or flabby: or it advanced upon the face: or it retired towards the head: or its extremities folded upon the inner part thereof: or, in a dog, it turned towards the back of the neck: or it became folded, or creased, naturally. (TA.) [See also gaDafN, below: and see 7.] ― -b2- gaDifa All~ayolu: see 4.

2 gD~fhu * , inf. n. tagoDiyfN, He broke it. (TA.) [See also 1, first signification.] ― -b2- tagoDiyfN signifies also The making [a thing] to hang down. (O, K.) ― -b3- See also 1, third signification.

4 AgDf All~ayolu *
The night became dark and black; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ gaDifa, inf. n. gaDafN. (S.) ― -b2- AgDft Als~amaA='u The sky became clouded, and prepared to rain. (O, * K, * TA.) ― -b3- AgDft Aln~axolu The palm-trees had many branches, and bad fruit: (K, TA:) or became laden, or heavily laden, with fruit; or abounded therewith. (O, K, TA.) ― -b4- And AgDf AlEaTanu The usual abidingplace of camels, or cattle, or their place of lying down at, or around, the water or watering-trough, had many thereof. (K.)

5 tgD~f *
It broke, or became broken; as also ↓ AngDf. (TA.) ― -b2- And tagaD~ufN signifies The being, or becoming, creased, or wrinkled; (O, K, TA;) like tagay~ufN. (TA.) And tagaD~afa He, or it, inclined, and bent, and became folded, or creased, much, or in several places, syn. maAla, and tavan~aY, and takas~ara, (S, O, K, *) Ealayohi upon him, or it. (S, O.) And tgD~ft AlHay~apu The serpent twisted, or coiled, itself. (O, K.) ― -b3- ngD~ft Albiy^oru The sides of the well fell in ruins, or became demolished: (S, O, K:) the well collapsed, or broke down, EalaY fulaAnK upon such one, who had descended into it; (O;) as also ↓ AngDft. (O, K.) ― -b4- tgD~f EalayonaA All~ayolu The night covered us. (O, K.) ― -b5- tgD~ft EalayonaA Ald~unoyaA The world became abundant to us in its good things; and favourable to us. (O, K.)

7 A_inogaDafa see 5, in two places. ― -b2- AngDft A^u*unuhu His ear became folded, or creased, not naturally. (TA.) [See also 1, near the end.] ― -b3- AngDf AlD~abaAbu The DbAb [or thin clouds, like smoke,] overlay one another. (TA.) ― -b4- AngDfwA fiY AlgubaAri They entered into the dust, or raised and spreading dust. (S, O, K.)
gaDofN * : see gaDafN.
guDofN * [written by Golius guDufN]: see gaDafapN.
