gaDafN * [inf. n. of gaDifa (q. v.): and, as a simple subst.,] Laxness, or flabbiness, in the ear: (S, O, K:) or, as in the T, a laxness, or flabbiness, of the upper part [of each] of the two ears, upon, or over, the concha thereof, by reason of its width and its largeness: (TA:) Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee says, after citing a verse of Abu-n-Nejm, describing a lion, that it signifies a twisting, in the ear, backwards: accord. to ISh, it is, in the lion, a laxness, or pendulousness, of the upper eyelids, upon the eyes; arising from anger and pride: (O:) and he says that, accord. to some, it is, in the lion, abundance of the fur, and a folding, or creasing, of the skin. (TA.) And one says, [app. in relation to the lion,] ↓ fiY A^a$ofaArihi gaDofN and gaDafN [app. In the edges of his upper eyelids is a laxness, or pendulousness]; both meaning the same. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Softness, or easiness, and plentifulness, of life: (S:) like gaTafN. (O in art. gTf.) -A2- And A species of tree in India, exactly like the palm-tree, (Lth, O, K,) except that (K) its fruit-stones are divested of covering, without a liHaA=' [or pulpy pericarp], and from its lowest to its uppermost part it has green saEaf [or branches like those of the palm-tree], (Lth, O, K,) covered [thereby]: (Lth, O:) AHn says, it is a plant resembling the palm-tree exactly, (O, L, TA,) but not growing tall, (TA,) having many saEaf, and prickles, and [leaves such as are termed] xuwS, of the hardest sort, whereof are made large [receptacles of the kind called] jilaAl [pl. of jul~apN], that serve for sacks, goods being carried in them by land and by sea; (O, L, TA;) it produces from its head unripe dates of disagreeable flavour, not eaten; and, he says, of its xuwS are made mats like carpets, (L, TA,) called simaAm, pl. of sum~apN [q. v.], (L,) one of which may be spread for twenty years. (L, TA.) -A3- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

gaDafapN *
A certain bird: or a qaTaAp [or sandgrouse]: (IDrd, O, K:) or the qaTaAp termed juwniy~ap: pl. ↓ gaDafN [or rather this, if correct, is a coll. gen. n.]: J says that ↓ AlgaDafu [thus in the TA, but in my and other copies of the S ↓ AlguDofu, for which Golius appears to have found AlguDufu,] signifies AlqaTaA Aljuwnu; but IB says that it is correctly AlqTA AljuwniY~u. (TA. [See juwniY~N: and particularly what is said at the end of the paragraph thus headed.]) -A2- Also An [eminence of the kind called] A^akamap. (O, K, TA. [For Akmp, in this case, the TK has most strangely substituted Akmh, meaning A^akomahu, for it explains it as signifying “ blind from the birth; ” and this, though an obvious mistake, Freytag asserts to be the right reading and explanation.])
gaADifN * : see A^agoDafu, in two places. ― -b2- Also [applied to a man] Soft, or easy, and plentiful, in his circumstances. (S, O, K.)

A^agoDafu * , applied to a dog, Relaxed, or flabby, in the ear; pl. guDofN; (S, O, K;) occurring in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, cited voce Ea*abN; (O, TA;) and the fem. gaDofaA='u is applied [to a bitch, and] to an ear: (TA:) or a dog having the upper part of his ear folded, or creased, backwards; and ↓ gaADifN when it is forwards. (IAar, O, K.) And hence [the pl.] guDofN, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, is used as an appellation for Dogs of the chase. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a lion, Having the ear folded, or creased; (Hr, O, K;) denoting a quality that renders him more abominable: (Hr, O:) or relaxed, or pendulous, in the ears: (O, K:) or
whose upper eyelids are lax, or pendulous, upon his eyes, by reason of anger or pride; (K, TA;) so says ISh. (TA.) And accord. to Lth, A beast of prey whose upper part of his ear is folded, or creased, and the lower part thereof relaxed, or pendulous. (TA.) And the fem., gaDofaA='u, A she-goat whose extremities of her ears descend low, by reason of their length. (IA.) ― -b3- Also Anything bending, folding, or creasing, and relaxed, flabby, or pendulous: fem. as above. (TA.) And ↓ mugoDifN is like A^agoDafu, (TA.) ― -b4- And AlA^agoDafu is one of the names of The lion (TA.) ― -b5- sahomN A^agoDafu An arrow of which the feathers are thick; (S, O, K;) contr. of A^aSomaEu, (S, O.) ― -b6- layolN A^agoDafu A night that is dark (S, O, K) and black; (S, O;) covering with its dark ness. (TA.) ― -b7- Eayo$N A^agoDafu A soft, or an easy, and plentiful, life; as also ↓ gaADifN (S, O, K:) like A^agoTafu. (S and O in art. gTf) And sanapN gaDofaA='u A fruitful, or plentiful, year. (TA.)

mugoDifN * : see A^agoDafu, latter half. ― -b2- Applied to palm-trees (naxolN), Having many branches, and bad fruit; (O, TA;) thus without p; (O;) and also with p. (TA. [See also its verb.]) ― -b3- And vamarapN mugoDifapN A fruit that has become flaccid, but not completely ripe: (O:) or nearly, but not yet, ripe: (Sh, TA:) or whereof the goodness has not become apparent: or, accord. to AA, hanging upon its tree, flaccid. (TA.)

Q. 1 gaDofara *
He (a jade, or hackney, TA) was, or became, heavy, or sluggish. (K, TA.)
gaDofarN * : see the next paragraph; the former, in two places.
guDaAfirN * : see the next paragraph; the former, in two places.

gaDanofarN *
Big, thick, or rude, in body or person; (S, K;) as also ↓ gaDofarN, which is the original form; the n in the former being augmentative: (Az, TA:) or simply, big, thick, or rude: applied to a man: (Lth, TA:) or rude, or coarse, [in disposition or in make,] and big, or thick: (TA:) as also ↓ ganaDofarN and ↓ gaDofarN; (K;) applied to a man: (TA:) or big, or thick, (AA, TA.) in make, (TA,) and wrinkled; (AA, TA;) applied to a lion. (TA.) You say also A^u*unN gaDanofarapN, meaning, A big, or thick, fleshy, ear. (AO, L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlgaDanofaru The lion; (Lth, S, K;) as also ↓ AlguDaAfiru. (TS, K.)
gaDanofarN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 gaDanahu * , (S, K,) aor.
gaDina and
gaDuna , (K,) inf. n. gaDonN, (S,) He, or it, (a man, and a thing, S,) withheld, restrained, hindered, or diverted, him. (S, K.) One says, maA gaDanaka Ean~aA What withheld, hindered, or diverted, or has withheld, &c., thee from us? (S.) In the “ Nawádir ” of IAar, this verb, which is correctly thus, with D, is erroneously with S. (TA.) -A2- gaDanato biwaladihaA, and ↓ gaD~nt, She (a camel) cast her young one, or fœtus, in an imperfect state, (K, TA.) before the hair had grown upon it and its make had become [perfectly apparent. (TA. [See also xadajato.]) [This is what is meant in the S where, after the mention of a signification of ↓ Alt~agoDiyn which will be found below, it is said that this word signifies also Alr~ijaAEu (??) rajaEato, q. v.): hence, app., (though referring to the K as his authority,) Freytag has given to gD~nt, as said of a she-camel, besides the signification mentioned above, another, which is also assigned to rajaEato; (??) she falsely indicated her bring pregnant, by raising (??) &c.] -A3- See also 5, in form places: -A4- and see 4

2 gaD~anotuhu * , inf. n. tagoDiynN, I wrinkled, shrivelled, or puckered, it syn. of the inf. n. ta$oniyjN. (S.) One says. daxalotu Ealayohi fagaD~ana liY mino jabohatih [I went in to him and be wrinkled to me a portion of his (??)] (TA) ― -b2- See also 5 -A2- and see 1 in two places -A3- and 4

3 AlmagaADanapu * signifies mukaAsarapu AlEayonyoni [The contracting of the (??) as to wrinkle the lids], (S, K, TA,) by reason of (??), or suspicion. (TA.) One says, gaADana AlmaroA^apa, meaning gaAzalahaA bimukaAsarapi AlEayonayoni [i. e. He talked, or act, with the woman, in an amatory and enticing manner, with the contracting of the (??) so as to wrinkle the lids] (A. TA.)

4 AgDnt Als~amaA='u *
The sky rained continually; (S, TA;) as also gDnt [perhaps ↓ gaDanat, but more probably, I think, ↓ gaD~anat] (TA.) And gDnt Als~aHaAbapu [The (??) continually]. (S and TA in explanation of ray~amat.) ― -b2- And AgDn Ealayohi AlHum~aY The fever continued upon him persistently. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- AgDn Ealayohi All~ayolu The night became dark upon him. (TA.)

5 tgD~n *
It was, or became, wrinkled, shrivelled, or puckered; syn. ta$an~aja; (S, MA, TA;) as also ↓ gaDina, inf. n. gaDanN [and app. guDuwnN, like qubuwlN as an inf. n. of qabila. though this requires consideration, as will be shown by what follows]. said of the face as having this signification, or as signifying it was, or became, wrinkled and speckled; (MA;) [and so, perhaps, ↓ gD~n, for] AltgDyn [if not a mistranscription for Alt~agaD~unu], as also ↓ AlguDuwnu, is syn. with Alt~a$an~uju; and one says fiY jabohatihi ↓ rajulN *uw guDuwnK meaning takas~urK [i. e. a man having a wrinkling in his forehead; but guDuwn may be here used as pl. of gaDonN, and thus meaning wrinkles]: and ↓ gaDanN signifies a bending (tavan~K and talaw~K) of a branch or twig or the like. (TA.) One says also, tagaD~anati Ald~iroEu EalaY laAbisihaA The coat of mail became folded, [or it hung, or sat, with folds,] upon its wearer. (TA.)

gaDonN * and ↓ gaDanN A wrinkle, crease, fold, ply, plait. or pucker, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the skin, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and of anything, (Msb,) or in a garment, and in a skin, (K,) and in a coat of mail, (S, K,) &c. (S:) pl. guDuwnN, S Mgh, Msb, K,) occurring in a verse cited in art. $A^b (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, kaAna *`lika fiY guDuwni ka*aA [lit. That was within the folds, meaning in the midst, of such a thing, or such an affair or event]; like fiY A^avonaA='i k*A (TA in art. vnY ― -b3- guDuwnu AlA^u*uni means The places of fold the case; syn. mavaAniyhaA. K, TA. in the CK [erroneously] ??.) -A2- Also (i. p. ?? and ↓ ??. TA) Difficulty, distress, or trouble, and (??) or weariness. (K, TA.) The Arabs say (??) man, in threatening him, laA^uTiylan~a gaDonaka or ↓ gaDanaka i. e. [I will assuredly make] thy (??) &c., [to be long (AZ, A, TA)]

gaDanN * an inf. n. of gaDinu. (MA [See 5, in two places.]) ― -b2- See also gaDonN, in three places, ― -b3- gaDanu AlEayoni signifies The exterior, or apparent jilodap [app. meaning tunic i. e. the (??)] of the eye. (S, TA.)

gaDonahN * [A patch of the smallpox] One says of a person whose skin has became covered, or wholly covered, (A^ulobisa,) with the smallpox, A^uSobaHa jiloduhu gaDonapF waAHidapF [His skin has became (??) patch of the smallpox]: and some say gaDobap (S,)
giDaAnN * the subst from the verb in the phrase gaDanato biwaladihaA [i. e. a subst. signifying The (??) denoted by that phrase. q. v.] (K)
gaDiynN * A she-camel's young one or fœtus, cast in an imperfect state, before the hair has (??) upon it and its make has become [perfectly] apparent. (TA.)

A^agoDanu *
Contracting his eye so as to wrinkle the lids, naturally, or by reason of enmity, or (??) pride. (K.)

div2.head: gDw and gDY
div2.entryFree: 1 gaDaA * , aor. yagoDuw; and gaDaY, aor. yagoDaY: see 4; the former, in three places. -A2- gaDaA, (K, TA, aor. yagoDuw, thus in the M, (TA,) inf. n. guDuw~N. (K, * TK,) He, i. e. a man, [and app. it. i. e. a thing,] was, or became, such as is termed gaADK [q. v.]. (K, TA. [In the TK it is mentioned only as said of a thing but the context in the K indicates that it is said of a man, and app. of a thing also.]) -A3- [See also guDuw~N below] -A4- gaDiyati AlA_ibilu, inf. n. gaDFA, The camels had a complaint (M, K, TA) of their bellies (K, TA) from eating of the trees called gaDFA. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- And gaDiyati AlA^aroDu The land abounded with the trees called gaDFA. (IKtt, TA.)

4 AgDY * , (K,) inf. n. A_igoDaA='N, (S,) He contracted his eyelids; drew them near together; (S, K;) like gaD~a; (TA in art. gD;) [and] so AgDY Eayonahu; said of a man: (Msb:) or he closed his
eyelids upon his iris; so in the M; as also ↓ gaDaA, a dial. var. of AgDY, likewise mentioned by ISd; and ↓ gaDaY, aor. yagoDaY, is also a dial. var. thereof: (TA:) or he made one of his eyelids to cleave to the other, that he might not see a thing, by reason of shame: (Har p. 19:) or he put one of his eyelids upon the other from dislike of a thing. (Id. p. 492.) [See also 6.] ― -b2- Hence it is used in relation to forbearance: so that one says, A^agoDaY EalaY Alqa*aY He held, or refrained, notwithstanding annoyance, spontaneously, without being asked, or without constraint: (Msb, TA:) or AgDY EalaY qa*FY he bore annoyance patiently. (M, TA.) And AgDY Eanohu He feigned himself neglectful of it; [he closed his eyes from it;] he connived at it; as also AgmD Enh. (TA in art. gmD.) And [sometimes] AlA_igoDaA='u means The abstaining from proceeding to extremities. (Mgh in art. jwz.) ― -b3- Hence also, AgDY EalaY Al$~aYo'i He was silent respecting the thing; and so ↓ gaDaA, aor. yagoDuw. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And AgDY Eanohu Tarofahu means He closed, or turned away, from him, or it, his eye, or eyes; syn. sad~ahu [in the CK $ad~ahu], or Sad~ahu: (K, TA:) so in the M. (TA.) -A2- AgDY All~ayolu The night was, or became, dark; (S, Msb, K;) and covered everything (K, TA) with its darkness; from ISd; (TA;) as also ↓ gaDaA, aor. yagoDuw. (K, TA. [See also guDuw~N.])

6 tgADY *
He contracted, or put together, his eyelids, that he might not see an evil, or unseemly, thing. (Har p. 473. [See also 4.]) ― -b2- And [hence,] tgADY Eanohu i. q. tagaAfala [i. e. He was, or he feigned himself, unmindful, &c., of him, or it]: (K, TA:) like tagaAbaY Enh: mentioned by Az. (TA. [See, again, 4.])

gaDFA * , said by Th to be written [thus] with A but ISd says, I know not why this is; (TA;) [the latter, it seems, holding its last letter to be originally Y, not w;] A species of trees, (S, Msb, K,) well known, (K,) the wood of which is of the hardest of wood, and therefore there is hardness in its charcoal; (Msb;) it is of the plants of the sands, and has [sprigs, or foliage, of the kind termed] hadab [q. v.], like that called A^aroTFY; (TA;) and its fire is of long continuance: (Har p. 60:) [see also rimovN: Mr. Palgrave (in his Travels, i. 38,) describes it as a shrub believed by him to be peculiar to the Arabian Peninsula, “ of the genus Euphorbia, with a woody stem, often five or six feet in height, and innumerable round green twigs, very slender and flexible, forming a large feathery tuft, not ungraceful to the eye, while it affords some kind of shelter to the traveller, and food to his camels: ”] the sing. [or rather n. un.] is gaDaApN: (K:) and AHn says that sometimes gaDaAtN is a pl. [of the n. un.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, *iy^obu gaDFA [A wolf of trees, or shrubs, called gaDFA]; (S, K;) or, as in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà *iy^obu AlgaDaA; and such is the most abominable, or malignant, or noxious, of wolves; for he comes not into close proximity to men save when he desires to attack: or this means the wolf of the covert of trees: for ― -b3- gaDFA signifies also A covert of trees: (TA:) and a gayoDap [i. e. thicket; or collection of tangled, or confused, or dense, trees; &c.]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- A^aholu AlgaDaA is an appellation of the people of Nejd, (K, TA,) because of the abundance of [the trees called] gDA there. (TA.)

baEiyrN gaDK *
A camel having a complaint of his belly from eating of the trees called gaDFA: and A_ibilN gaDiyapN and gaDaAyaA [camels having such a complaint]; (S, K;) like ramivapN and ramaAvaY. (S.)

gaDoyaA * : see gaDoyaA='u. ― -b2- Also, (K, TA,) determinate, and imperfectly decl., like [its syn.] hunayodapu, (TA,) A hundred camels: (IAar, K, TA:) held by ISk to be so called as being likened to a place producing [an abundance of] gaDFA [i. e. the trees thus called]: AA has mentioned it with the article Al, saying that AlgaDoyaA signifies a hundred. (TA.)

gaDoyaA='u * A land (A^aroDN) abounding with the trees called gaDFA. (S, K.) ― -b2- And, as also ↓ gaDoyaA, A place in which is a collection of the trees called gaDFA; (K, TA;) a place where they grow. (TA.) ― -b3- And the former, Rugged land or ground. (TA.)

guDuw~N *
Intense darkness of the night. (IKtt, TA. [Perhaps in this sense an inf. n. of which the verb is gaDaA: see 4, last sentence.]) ― -b2- And The eating of the trees called gaDFA. (IKtt, TA. [App. in this sense an inf. n. of which the verb is gaDaA.]) -A2- And A state of muchness, abundance, copiousness, fulness, or completeness, or a thing. (K. [See also 1, second sentence.])

rajulN gaDiY~N Eani AlxanaA * or Eani AlfaHo$aA='i [A man who refrains from taking notice of that which is foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene,] may be from gaDaA; or it may be from A^agoDaY, similar to A^aliymN and wajiyEN; but the former derivation is the better. (TA.)
gaDawiY~N * a rel. n. from AlgaDaA [the trees thus called], and applied to a camel [app. as meaning That is fond of, or wont to feed upon, the trees called gaDFA]. (S.)

gaDoyaAnapN *
A herd of camels of generous race: (K, TA:) mentioned by Az, from AA. (TA.)

gaADK *
Dark; applied to night (layol); as also ↓ mugoDK, but this latter is rare: (S, Msb:) and so gaADiyapN, (S, K,) applied to a night (layolap): (S:) or, thus applied, accord. to Az, intensely dark. (TA.) ― -b2- And gaADiyapN signifies also Bright, or shining brightly; (S, K;) applied to a night, (thus in one of my copies of the S,) or to fire (naAr): (so in other copies of the S and in the TA:) thus having two contr. meanings. (S, K.) ― -b3- And Great; applied to a fire (nAr): a signification said by Az to be taken from the fire of the tree called gaDFA, which is of the best of firewood. (TA.) -A2- baEiyrN gaADK A camel that eats the trees called gaDFA: and A_ibilN gaADiyapN and gawaADK [camels that eat those trees]. (S, K.) -A3- $aYo'N gaADK A thing that is much in quantity, abundant, copious, full, or complete. (K.) ― -b2- And rajulN gaADK A man having food and clothing; or having a good state, or condition, in respect of food, and having clothing; sufficed, or satisfied. (K.)
mugoDK * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 gaT~ahu fiY AlmaA='i * , aor.
gaTu3a , (S, Msb, K,) and
gaTi3a , (K,) [the latter contr. to analogy,] inf. n. gaT~N, (S, Msb,) He immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him, or it, in the water: (S, Msb, K:) he made him to plunge, or dive, in, or into, the water: (S:) [Golius adds, as from Ibn-Maaroof, head-downwards; but it is not so in my copy of the KL:] and gat~ahu signifies the same. (TA in art. gt.) ― -b2- And gaT~ahu, inf. n. gaT~N, He pressed, or squeezed, him, or it, (EaSarahu,) vehemently; and i. q. kabasahu [q. v.]. (TA.) [And gat~ahu, q. v., has a similar meaning.] -A2- gaT~a, aor.
gaTi3a , inf. n. gaTiyTN, said of a he-camel, (S, Msb, K,) He brayed; syn. hadara: (K:) or he brayed, (hadara, AZ, S,) or made a sound, (Saw~ata, Msb,) in the $iqo$iqap [or bursa faucium]: when not in the $q$qp, it is termed hadiyrN: you say of the she-camel, tahodiru; not tagiT~u; (AZ, S, Msb;) because she has no $q$qp: (AZ, S:) or, as some say, he brayed, but not in the $q$qp. (L.) ― -b2- gaT~a, aor. as above, (Msb, K, *) and inf. n. as above (S, Msb, K *) and gaT~N, (TA,) said of a person sleeping, (S, Msb, K,) and of one strangled, or throttled, (S, K,) and of an animal slaughtered, (K,) He emitted a sound; (K;) in which sense it is also said of a lynx, and of a leopard, and of a bustard: (TA:) or snored, or snorted: (S, TA:) or sent back his breath up to his fauces so that it was heard by persons around him: (Msb:) or emitted a sound with his breath, reiterating his breath where he found not an easy passage [for it]. (TA.) ― -b3- gaT~ati Alburomapu The stone cooking-pot boiled audibly. (TA.) ― -b4- See also gat~a, near the end of the paragraph.

3 gAT~ HuwtFA *
He vied, or contended, with a fish in plunging, or diving. (JK in art. qms.)

6 tgAT~ Alqawomu *
The people, or company of men, vied, or contended, one with another, in plunging, or diving, (tamaAqaluwA,) in the water. (S.) And AlS~iboyaAnu yatagaAT~uwna fiY AlbaHori The children vie, or contend, one with another, in plunging, or diving, (yataqaAmasuwna,) in the sea or great river. (A in art. qms.)

7 AngT~ fiY AlmaA='i *
He (a man, TA) became immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, in the water; or he plunged, or dived, in the water. (S, Msb, TA.)

R. Q. 1 gaTogaTa AlbaHoru * [inf. n. gaTogaTapN] The
waves of the sea became high (Ealato), so in some copies of the K, or estuated (galato); so in other copies of the K, and in the L; (TA;) as also ↓ tagaTogaTa. (O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And gaTogaTati Alqidoru [The contents of the cooking-pot] made a sound: or boiled vehemently. (K.) ― -b3- And gaTogaTa Ealayohi, said of sleep, It overcame him. (L, K, TA.)
R. Q. 2 tagaTogaTa * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also It (a thing) became separated, or dispersed. (Sgh, K, TA.)

gaTaATN * The [bird called the] qaTaA [i. e. the sandgrouse]: (M, K:) or a species thereof, (S, K,) or, as some say, a species of bird not of the qTA, (TA,) dust-coloured in the backs and the bellies (S, K, TA) and the bodies, (S, TA,) black in the inner sides of the wings, (S, K, TA,) long in the legs and the necks, and slender, not collecting in flocks, two or three at most being found together: (S, TA:) n. un. with p: (S, K:) it is said that the qTA compose two species: the short in the legs, yellow in the necks, black in the primary feathers of the wings, of a white hue tinged with red (Suhob) in the tertials, are the kudoriy~ap and the juwniy~ap: and the long in the legs, white in the bellies, dust-coloured in the backs, wide in the eyes are the gTAT: AHát says that in the A^axodaEaAni [by which is here meant, as in some other instances, the places of the two veins so called in the neck] of the gaTaATap are what resemble two decorations, two lines, black and white; and it is slender, [but] exceeding the muk~aA=': accord. to Skr, it is a bird resembling the qTA. (TA.) -A2- See also the paragraph here following.

guTaATN * The commencement of the dawn: (S, K:) or a remaining portion of the blackness of the night: (S, * K:) or the commingling of the darkness of the last part of the night with the light of the first part of the day: (TA:) and (K) the saHar [or period a little before daybreak; as also ↓ gaTaATN. (Th, K, TA.)
gaTogaTapN * a word imitative of The cry of the [bird called the] qaTaA: (S, K:) ― -b2- and of The sound of the [vehemently-boiling] cooking-pot. (TA.)

qidorN mugaTogiTapN *
A cooking-pot vehemently boiling. (S.)

Q. 1 gaTorafa *
He (i. e. God) made persons to be [gaTaAriyf i. e. chiefs, &c., (pl. of giToriyfN,) or] noble. (Ham p. 793.) ― -b2- [And He treated (??)- lently, unjustly. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)] -A2- See also the next paragraph.

Q. 2 tagaTorafa *
He sought chiefdom, or lordship; [&c.;] from giToriyfN meaning say~idN. (O.) ― -b2- And He magnified himself, or was proud: (El-Ahmar, O, K:) [and so, app., ↓ gaTorafa, for] gaTorafapN and tagaTorufN and tagatorufN signify takab~urN: (S:) [or] he was proud, haughty, or self-conceited, in walk (IAar, O, K) especially. (IAar, O)

gaTorafapN * [app. an inf. n. of gaTorafa, q. v.; and, used as a simple subst., signifying Self-magnification, or pride: (see Q. 2:) or] pride, haughtiness, or self-conceit: and play, or sport; or such as is vain, or unprofitable. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
giToraAfN * : see giToriyfN, in two places.
guToruwfN * : see the following paragraph.
giTorawofN * : see the following paragraph.

giToriyfN * The hawk, or falcon; syn. baAzK: this is said to be the primary signification: (Ham p. 793:) or the young one thereof (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K:) or the hawk, or falcon, (baAzK,) that has been taken from its nest: as also ↓ giToraAfN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A say~id [i. e. chief, or lard, &c.]: (S:) or a say~id that is high-horn, or noble, (Lth, O, K,) or generous: said to be so called as being likened to the hawk, or falcon: (Ham ubi suprà:) and liberal, bountiful, generous, noble, and youthful: (ISk, O, K:) or a goodly, or comely, youth or young man. (TA:) and ↓ giToraAfN signifies the same: (ISk, O, K:) pl. gaTaArifapN (O, K, TA) and gaTaAriyfu and gaTaArifu. (TA.) Also Goodly, or beautiful; and so ↓ guToruwfN and ↓ giTorawofN: (Ibn- 'Abbád, O. K:) or the last of these signifies a youth, or young man, such as is Zariyf [i. e. excel-lent, or elegant in mind, manners, and address, or speech, and in person. &c.]. (AA, O, K.) ― -b3- Also The common fly: syn. *ubaAbN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) ― -b4- And EunuqN giToriyfN A wide neck. (O, TA.:) as also xiToriyfN (TA.)

1 gaTasahu * , (S, A, K,) aor.
gaTisa , (S, TA,) inf. n. gaTosN; (S;) or ↓ gT~shu, (Msb,) inf. n. tagoTiysN; (TA;) or both: (A. TA;) He immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him or it, in water. (S, A, Msb * K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ↓ gaT~asaniY fiY baHori A@noEumihi He overwhelmed me in the sea of his benefits, or favours]. (A.) -A2- gaTasa, aor.
gaTisa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. gaTosN, (Msb,) He, or it, became immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, in water or he immersed, or immerged himself, plunged, or dived, in water (Msb, * K) ― -b2- gaTasa fiY AlA_inaA='i He put his mouth into the vessel and so drank. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) -A3- gaTasato bihi All~ujamu Death took him away: (Sgh, K:) a dial. var. of EaTasato [q. v.]. (TA.)
2 gaT~asa see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

6 tgATsA *
They two vied, or contended, each with the other, in plunging, or diving, (A, K,) in water; (K;) syn. tamaAqalaA (A, K) and tagaAT~aA (A) and tagaAmasaA. (TA.) And tgATswA They vied, or contended, one with another, in plunging, or diving, in water; syn. tagaAT~uwA. (TA.) -A2- tgATs He feigned himself negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless, not being really so; (Sgh, K;) and tgAT$ is a dial. var. of the same: both are from Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer (TA.) You say, tgATs Eanohu He feigned himself negligent of it, &c.; (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA in art. gT$;) and [app. in like manner] tgATshu. (IAar, TA in art. Em$.)

gaT~aAsN *
One who dives to the bottom of water to fetch the shells that contain pearls, &c. (TA.)

layolN gaATisN *
Dark night: as also gaATi$N. (IDrd.)

magoTisN *
A place in which one plunges, or dives. (TA.)
magonaTiysN * and its variations, here mentioned in the S and L and K, see in art. mgnTs.

1 gaTa$a * , aor.
gaTi$a , (A, K,) inf. n. gaTo$N, (TK,) [or perhaps gaTa$N, q. v.,] It (the night) became dark; (A, K;) as also ↓ A^agoTa$a: (S, K:) or gaTa$N is syn. with sadafN; and hence All~ayolu ↓ AgT$ [app. meaning the night became dark, or black]. (As, A, TA.) [See gaTa$N, below.] -A2- gaTi$a, (S, TA.) [aor.
gaTa$a ,] inf. n. gaTa$N, (TA,) He had an affection resembling weakness of the sight, with a shedding of tears at most times. (S, TA.) And gaTi$a AlbaSaru [The eye, or sight, became weak, and affected with a shedding of tears at most times] and so ↓ AgTA$~, like AHmAr~ [in measure] (TA and Eayonuhu ↓ tgT~$t His eye became dark, or dim, (IDrd, K,) and weak-sighted. (IDrd.)
4 AgT$ * : see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AgT$wA They entered into, or upon, the darkness [of night]. (TA.) -A2- AgT$ A@ll~`hu All~ayola God made the night dark, (Fr. S, A, * K)
5 tagaT~a$a see 1. last sentence.

6 tgAT$ Eanohu *
He feigned himself negligent, or heedless, of it; (Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, K;) namely, a thing, or an affair; as also tgATs; (Aboo-Sa'eed;) and [app. in like manner] tgAT$hu: (IAar, TA in art. Em$:) or he feigned himself blind to it; either in the eyes or intellectually; syn. tEAmY. (TA.) You say also, mararotu bihi fatagaATa$a [I passed by him and he feigned himself heedless, or blind]. (A.)
11 A_igoTaAo$~a see 1, last sentence.

gaTa$N *
i. q. sadafN [app. meaning The darkness, or blackness, of night]: (As, A, TA:) Aboo-Turáb, (L,) or AZ, (TA,) makes it to be after the gaba$: (L, TA:) and ↓ guTaA$N also signifies the darkness and confusedness of night. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Weakness of sight, with a shedding of tears at most times: (K:) or an affection resembling this. (S, TA.)
gaTi$N * : see A^agoTa$u, in two places.

falaApN gaTo$aY * , (As, A 'Obeyd, Kr, S, A,) or gaTo$aA='u, (O, K,) if from gaTa$a All~ayolu. originally [and properly] like EamoyaA='u, but by poetic license it is made perfectly decl., [with tenween,] but if gaTo$aAnu occurred, as meaning “ dark, ” it would
be a fem., written [gaTo$aY,] with Y (O, TA,) or both forms, without and with medd, (TA,) A desert, or waterless desert, that is dark: (Kr:) or of which the ways through it are obscure; (As, A 'Obeyd,. A, TA;) where one cannot find the right way. (As, A 'Obeyd, S, K, TA.) You say, rakibonaA falaApF gaTo$aY wanaHonu karimaAlihaA EaTo$aY [We travelled upon a desert, or waterless desert, of which the ways through it were obscure, and we were like its sands thirsty]. (A.)
guTaA$N * : see gaTa$N.
gaATi$N * : see what next follows.

A^agoTa$u *
Dark; applied to night; as also ↓ gaATi$N and ↓ gaTi$N: [fem. gaTo$aA='u: see gaTo$aY:] and ↓ tagoTiy$N, an inf. n. [of gaT~a$a] used as an epithet, signifies the same, applied to sight. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A man having the affection of the eyes termed gaTa$N; (S, TA;) as also ↓ gaTi$N: (TA:) fem. of the former gaTo$aA='u. (S, TA.)
tagoTiy$N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

mutagaATi$N *
Feigning blindness to a thing. (S.) [See 6.]

gaTafN *
Ampleness of the means, or circumstances, of life: (S, O, K:) like gaDafN. (O.) -A2- And Length, and a folding, (O, K,) in the edges of the eyelids, (O,) or of the edges of the eyelids: (K:) or length, and then a bending [app. upwards] of the eyelashes: occurring in a trad., and, as some relate it, with E; but Er-Riyáshee knew not this, and thought it to be gaTaf: (TA:) or abundance of the hair of the eyebrow: (K:) said by ISh to be syn. with waTafN: (TA:) but by IDrd said to be the contr. of waTaf, and signifying paucity of the hair of the eyebrows: (O, TA:) and it is said to be sometimes used as meaning paucity of the eyelashes. (TA.) [See also gaDafN.]

[
gTfAn * , in a note to “ Abulf. Ann. ” i. 194, thought by Reiske to be the name of a bird, is app. a mistake for some word relating to the cry of the bird called gaTaAT.]

gaATuwfN *
A miSoyadap [or snare, trap, gin, or net]: a dial. var. of EaATuwfN [q. v.]. (TA.)

A^agoTafu * A life (Eayo$N) ample in its means, or circumstances: like A^agoDafu. (S, O.) -A2- And syn. with A^awoTafu in relation to the edges of the eyelids [Having what is termed gaTafN as meaning waTafN]. (TA.)

1 gaTalati Als~amaA='u * (JK, O, K) yawomanaA h`*aA, (JK, O,) and ↓ A^agoTalat, (JK, O, K,) The sky has [by its becoming overcast] concealed the light of the sun [in this our day]: (JK:) or its dajon [or shade of the clouds in a rainy day, or its abundant rain, or its covering of clouds full of moisture, and dark, but containing no rain,] has overspread. (O, K.) -A2- And gaTila All~ayolu, aor.
gaTala , (K, TA,) inf. n. gaTalN, (TA,) The darkness of the night became confused. (K, TA.)
4 A^agoTala see the preceding paragraph.

Q. Q. 1 gaToyala * , (O, K, TA,) with the T before the Y, (K, * TA,) He was, or became, abundant in his property, or cattle, and his dependents, or relations and household, or servants, (O, K, TA,) and his weal. (O, TA.) -A2- And gayoTala, (O, TA,) thus correctly in the following senses, accord. to the K gaToyala, but this is a mistake, (TA,) He made his traffic to be in beasts of the bovine kind, bulls or cows, (O, K, TA,) which are termed gayoTalN. (TA.) ― -b2- And gayoTala Alqawomu fiY AlHadiyvi The people, or party, pushed on, pressed on, or were copious or profuse, in discourse; or entered into it; and their voices became high: (K, * TA:) on the authority of El-Hejeree. (TA.) [Accord. to the K gaToyala, which is said in the TA to be a mistake.]

Q. Q. 4 AigoTaA^al~a *
It became heaped up, or it mounted, one part upon another: (A 'Obeyd, O, K, TA:) and so AigoZaA^al~a, mentioned by IKtt: (TA:) the former verb occurs in a verse of Hassán Ibn-Thábit, said of the sea. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And, said of the heat, It rose, or became raised. (R, TA.)

gayoTalN * is pl. of ↓ gayoTalapN, [or rather a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un.,] signifying Numerous dense or tangled trees: (S, O:) or the latter word signifies thus: (K:) or it (the latter) signifies also dense, or tangled, trees: (S, O:) or both signify thus: and also anything confused, or mixed: (Ham p. 213:) or the latter has this last meaning: and signifies also a collection of trees and of herbs; (AHn, TA;) and a collection of [the common tamarisks, called] TarofaA='; (K, TA;) as AHn says on one occasion. (TA.) ― -b2- And [the former, or perhaps both words,] The light of the dawn when mingling with the darkness of the night. (Ham p. 213 [q. v.].) ― -b3- And gayoTalu AlD~uHaY signifies Hayovu takuwnu Al$~amosu mino ma$oriqihaA kahayoy^atihaA mino magoribihaA waqota AlZ~uhori, (JK, O, and so in copies of the K,) or baEoda AlZ~uhori, (accord. to the text of the K in the TA,) or waqota AlEaSori: (so in some copies of the K, as mentioned in the TK:) [the last is evidently the right reading; and the meaning, The period of the earlier part of the forenoon, after sunrise, when the sun is distant from its place of rising like as it is from its place of setting at the time of the EaSor (q. v.): AlZhr is probably an old mistranscription.] -A2- Also Beasts of the bovine kind, bulls or cows. (TA.) [See also gayoTalapN, last explanation.] ― -b2- And The cat: (K, TA:) as also xayoTalN: on the authority of Kr. (TA.)

gayoTalapN * : see gayoTalN. ― -b2- Also A company, or collection, (Th, K, TA,) of men: (K, TA:) or the assembling of men, and their becoming in a dense, or confused, state. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And Darkness; as also ↓ gayoTuwlN; (K;) or the latter signifies confusedness of darkness; (IDrd, O;) or signifies also dense (lit. accumulated) darkness. (K. [The Arabs describe thick darkness as “ darknesses one above another: ” see Kur xxiv. 40.]) And The intricate and confused blackness of night: (S, O, K:) or gayoTalapu All~ayoli signifies the confusedness and denseness of the darkness [of night]: and the pl. is gayaATilu. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A confusion, or mixture, of cries or shouts or noises; (S, * O, * K;) and so ↓ gayoTuwlN: (IDrd, O, K:) gayoTalaAtN, pl. of the former, signifies clamours of men: and the sing., the numerous cries or shouts or noises, and the dust, of war, or battle. (TA.) ― -b5- And The overpowering influence of drowsiness: (O, K:) [or so gayoTalapu nuEaAsK: pl. gayaATilu:] one says, ray~avatohu gayaATilu Aln~uEaAsi meaning gawaAlibuhu [i. e. The overpowering influences of drowsiness retarded him, or made him late]. (A, TA.) ― -b6- And The means of happiness of the present world or state of existence: (K:) or gayaATilu Ald~unoyaA means those means of happiness: (O:) or this latter phrase means the consecutive means of happiness of the present world. (TA.) And The eating and drinking and rejoicing, with security. (Fr, O, K.) ― -b7- And AlgayoTalapu (accord. to Fr, as is said in the O and TA,) signifies AlmaAlu AlmuTogiY [as though most probably meaning Property that causes extravagance]: (O, K, TA:) [but from what SM remarks respecting it, I can only infer that he holds AlmuTogiY to be an epithet applied to the cow as signifying “ having a youngling, ” which is termed TagoyaA or TugoyaA, (like AlmuEojilu signifying “ having a calf, ” which is termed EijolN, and several other epithets of the same form,) and in like manner applied to a collective number of cows, though I do not find it mentioned in this sense; i. e., that he understands; and would explain, AlmaAlu AlmuTogiY as signifying The cattle, meaning cows, having younglings: but his derivation of it seems to be far-fetched; and perhaps he may have been led to assign this meaning to it by another explanation of gayoTalapN with which it is agreeable, and which will be found in the next sentence:] it is not [he says] from TagaA, aor. yaToguw, signifying A^asorafa fiY AlZ~ulomi, as it seems to be at first sight; but from Tagato said of the baqarap waHo$iy~ap, signifying SaAHato, the like of which is also said of the vawor. (TA.) ― -b8- gayoTalapN signifies also Such as has milk, of gazelles, or antelopes, and of beasts of the bovine kind [perhaps meaning of the wild species, i. e. bovine antelopes]; (S, O, K;) pl. gayaATilu: (S, O:) accord. to AO, the baqarap waHo$iy~ap [or bovine antelope]: (S, O:) Th says that it signifies the baqarap [or beast of the bovine kind, bull or cow], not particularizing the wild species. (TA.) [See also gayoTalN, last explanation but one.]
gayoTuwlN * : see gayoTalapN, first quarter, in two places.

guwTaAlapN *
i. q. rawoDapN [generally meaning A meadow]. (IAar, O, K.)

$ajarN mugoTay^il~N *
Dense, or tangled, trees. (JK.
[See also gayoTalN.]) And guSuwnN Soft, or tender, branches, (O, TA,) having dense leaves. (TA.)

giTam~N * A great sea, (S, K, TA,) abundant in water; (S, TA;) and ↓ giToyam~N, (K, TA,) like qiro$ab~u, (TA,) [in the CK gaTiyom,] signifies the same; as also ↓ gaTamoTamN: (K, TA:) one says baHorN giTam~N. (S.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A man large (S, K) in disposition (S) or dispositions; (K;) [i. e.] liberal, or bountiful: (TA:) one says rajulN giTam~N. (S.) ― -b3- And A numerous company, or collective body: (K, TA:) one says jamoEN giTam~N. (S, TA.) And ↓ EadadN giToyam~N, like qiro$ab~N, A large number. (TA.) [See also guTaAmiTN, in art. gTmT.]
giToyam~N * : see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
gaTamuTamN * : see the first paragraph.

gayoTam~N *
Thick milk. (K, TA.)

Q. 1 gaTomaTapN * [an inf. n. of which the verb is gaTomaTa] The dashing together of the waves of the sea; as also ↓ tagaTomuTN: (K:) you say, ↓ tagaTomaTa Ealayohi Almawoju The waves dashed together upon him so as to cover him. (TA.) ― -b2- And The sea's being great in the waves, and abundant in the water; as also giTomaATN; each an inf. n. (IDrd, K, TA: but omitted in the CK.) ― -b3- And The boiling of a cooking-pot: (K:) [or its boiling vehemently; for] you say, gaTomaTati Alqidoru meaning The cooking-pot boiled vehemently; as also ↓ tagaTomaTat: (TA:) and ↓ tagaTomuTN signifies also the sounding of the boiling of a cooking-pot. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And The sounding of a torrent in a valley. (K.)

Q. 2 tagaTomaTa * , and its inf. n.: see the preceding paragraph, in four places. ― -b2- The inf. n. signifies also The making, or sending forth, a sound (S, K) with which, (S,) or in which, (K,) is a roughness. (S, K.)
giTomaATN * (originally an inf. n., mentioned above: TA:) Waves (mawojN) dashing together. (K, TA.)

guTaAmiTN * (S, K) and ↓ gaTomaTiyTN (IDrd, K) The sound of the sea when the waves are great and the water is abundant: (so accord. to copies of the K:) or the sound of the boiling of the sea; (so [the former] in a copy of the S; TA;) or of the boiling of the cooking-pot, and of the waves of the sea: (so in other copies of the S: TA:) and ↓ the latter word, also, the sound of water. (IDrd, TA.) -A2- And baHorN guTaAmiTN and ↓ gaTawomaTN and ↓ gaTomaTiyTN A sea great in the waves, and abundant in the water. (K.) guTaAmiT is applied in a verse of Ru-beh to a number of men [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) Multitudinous]. (TA voce giToyam~N, by which it is followed.)
gaTawomaTN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
gaTomaTiyTN * : see guTaAmiTN, in three places. [Accord. to J, the m in the words of this article is augmentative.]

div2.head: gTw and gTY
div2.entryFree:
1 gaTaA Al$~aYo'a * , (K, TA,) first pers. gaTawotu, aor.
1a2u3a , (Msb,) inf. n. gaTowN; (TA;) and gaTaY Al$~aYo'a, (K, TA,) first pers. gaTayotu, aor.
1a2i3a (S, Msb,) inf. n. gaToYN; (S, TA;) and gaTaY Ealayohi; (K;) and ↓ gT~Ahu, (S, K,) inf. n. tagoTiyapN; (S;) or this has an intensive signification; (Msb;) [but it is very often used in the sense of gaTaAhu without teshdeed;] and ↓ AgTAhu; (Msb, K;) He, or it, covered, or concealed, the thing; (K and TA in explanation of all;) and came, or became, upon it, or over it. (K and TA in explanation of all except the first.) Ealayohi Almi$omalapa ↓ gaT~aY, a phrase used by Lh, is thought by [Sd to mean He covered [or enveloped] him with the [garment called] m$mlp, i. e. gaT~aAhu bihaA. (TA in art. $ml.) ― -b2- gaTaYa All~ayolu fulaAnFA means The night clad [or covered] such a one with its darkness; as also ↓ gT~Y (K.) [And the former is also said of the night as though intrans.; an objective complement being app. understood: thus,] gaTaY All~ayolu, (S, K,) aor.
1a2i3a (S, TA;) as also gaTaA, aor.
1a2u3a , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. gaTowN and guTuw~N; (K, TA;) signifies The night was, or became, dark: (S, K, TA;) [and Freytag states that ↓ AgTY is used in this sense in the Deewán of Jereer; like AgDY;] or covered, or concealed, everything with its darkness: (Msb:) or as some say, rose, and covered, and clad, everything. (TA.) ― -b3- Aall~`hum~a A@goTi EalaY qalobihi is a saying of the Arabs, meaning A^ago$i [i. e. O God, put Thou a covering upon, or over, his heart]. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says, gaTaAhu Al$~abaAbu. inf. n. gaToYN and guTiY~N, [but the latter I think doubtful, for it is of a measure extr. as that of an inf. n. of a trans. v.,] meaning A^alobasahu [i. e. Youthfulness, or young manhood, clad him, or invested him as with clothes]; as also ↓ gT~Ahu. (TA.) And [using the former v. as intrans., one says,] gaTaY Al$~abaAbu, (S, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Al$~Ab~u,]) aor.
1a2i3a , inf. n. gaToYN (S, K) and guTiY~N, thus in the S and accord. to ISd and IKtt and Sgh, but accord. to the K guToYN, (TA,) meaning AimotalaA^a [i. e. The sap, or vigour, of youth or young manhood became full, or mantled, in a person]. (S, * K, TA.) ― -b5- And gaTati Al$~ajarapu The tree had long branches, spreading over the ground, (K, TA,) so that it covered what was around it; (TA; mentioned in art. gTY;) like ↓ A^agoTat. (K, TA.) ― -b6- And gaTaA AlmaA='u, (S, K, TA,) and gaTaY, (TA,) The water rose, or rose high, (S, * K, TA.) and became abundant. (TA.) And gaTaA EalaY Al$~aYo'i is said of anything as meaning It rose, and became high, upon, or over, the thing. (S, TA.) And gaTayaAnu AlbaHori signifies The overflowing of the sea, or great river. (TA.) ― -b7- And gaTati Aln~aAqapu, (K, TA,) inf. n. gaToYN, (TA,) The she-camel proceeded in her course, (K, TA,) and stretched forth. (TA.) ― -b8- And faEala bihi maA gaTaAhu is mentioned in the M as meaning saA='ahu [i. e. He did to him that which occasioned evil to him; or that which displeased, grieved, or vexed, him]: but this may be a mistranscription, for EaZaAhu, which is mentioned in the K in this sense: or the two verbs may be dial. vars. (TA. [See also a similar explanation of gaTaAhu in the first paragraph of art. $rY.])
2 1a2~a3a see the preceding paragraph, in four places.
4 A^a1o2a3a see 1, in three places. ― -b2- AgTY Alkaromu The grape-vine had the sap running in it, (K, TA,) and increased. (TA.)
5 tgT~Y bihi * (S, MA) He was, or became, covered with it; [or he covered himself with it; namely, his garment [&c.]; (MA;) [and so ↓ AgtTY; for] AgtTY signifies the same as tgT~Y. (K.)
8 A_i1ota2a3a see what next precedes.

A_in~ahu la*uwgaTawaAnK *
Verily he is one possessing might, and power of resistance, in his people, or party; and possessing abundance [of defenders, or of the means of defence &c.]. (K.)

giTaA='N *
A cover, or covering; i. e. a thing by which, or with which, a thing or person is covered, or concealed: (Msb, K: *) or a thing by which or with which, thou art covered, or coverest thyself: (S:) or a thing by which, or with which, thou art covered or another thing is covered: so in the M: accord. to Er-Rághib, a thing that is put upon, or over, a thing, such as a Tabaq [meaning cover, or lid,] and the like thereof, like as the gi$aA=' is of clothing and the like thereof; (TA:) or the cover, or lid. of a cooking-pot or the like: (MA:) pl. A^ugoTiyapN: (Msb, TA;) it is [said to be] from the phrase gaTaYi All~ayolu. (Msb.) ― -b2- And it is metaphorically applied to denote (tropical:) Ignorance: whence [accord. to some] the saying in the Kur [l. 21], faka$afonaA Eanoka giTaA='aka fabaSaruka A@loyawoma HadiydN (tropical:) [But we have removed from thee thine ignorance; and thy sight, or thy mental perception, to-day, is sharp, or piercing: see HadiydN]. (TA.)

giTaAyapN *
A thing, of the stuffing of clothes, with which a woman has covered herself, (K, TA,) beneath her clothes, (TA,) such as the gilaAlap [q. v.] and the like: (K, TA:) [it is said that] the Y therein is substituted for w. (TA.)

gaATK * [act. part. n. of 1, Covering, or concealing, &c. ― -b2- And hence,] layolN gaATK Dark night: or night rising, and covering, and clothing, everything. (TA.) ― -b3- And $ajarapN gaATiyapN A tree having long branches, spreading over the ground, so that
it covers what is around it. (TA.) ― -b4- And maA='N gaATK Abundant water. (TA.)

gaATiyapN * [as a subst.] A grape-vine covering the ground: (IB in art. Ejb:) occurring in a verse cited in that art.: so called because of its high growth and its spreading: (TA in the present art.:) or a grape-vine having many nawaAmK, i. e. branches. (T and TA in art. nmY.)
magoTiY~N * A thing covered, or concealed, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, huwa magoTiY~N AlqinaAEi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He is obscure in respect of reputation. (TA.)

mugaT~aApN *
i. q. mugab~aApN [meaning A pitfall covered over with earth]. (TA in art. gbY, q. v.)

5 tgf~fhu *
He took the guf~ap [i. e. what was sufficient for his subsistence] thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

8 Agtf~t Alfarasu * , (S,) or Ald~aAb~apu, (O, K,) inf. n. AigotifaAfN, (S,) The mare, or the beast, obtained what was sufficient for its subsistence of the [herbage called] rbiyE; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ tgf~ft: (TA:) or [in the K “ and ”] acquired somewhat of fatness: (S, O, K:) each of these meanings is mentioned as on the authority of Ks: (S:) AZ mentions the phrase Agtf~t AlmaAlu, (S,) or Agtf~ AlmAl, (O,) and says that the meaning is [the cattle obtained] middling pasture, and middling fatness. (S, O.) And AigotifaAfN signifies also The taking [with the mouth] fodder, or provender. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. gv.] -A2- Aigotafafotuhu I gave him somewhat, little in quantity. (O, K.)

gaf~N *
Such as has become dry of the leaves of ruTob [or juicy herbage (in the CK raTob)]: (O, K:) as also qaf~N. (TA.)

guf~apN *
A sufficiency of the means of subsistence: (S, O, K:) like guv~apN and gub~apN. (O in art. gv.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce TabaEN. ― -b2- And A thing [or portion of pasture or fodder] that a camel takes with his mouth in haste. (Sh, O, K.) ― -b3- And Old, and wasted or withered, such as is the worst, of pasture or herbage. (TA.) ― -b4- And A portion remaining of the contents of a vessel and of an udder. (TA.) ― -b5- And The mouse; because it is sufficient food for the cat. (IDrd, * O, * K.)

gafiyfapN *
Such as is beautiful and bright, in full maturity and in blossom, of herbs, or leguminous plants. (K.)

jaA='a EalaY gif~aAnihi *
He came at the time thereof: (O, K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) or (K) it is correctly Eif~aAnihi, with the unpointed E (O, K,) originally A_if~aAnihi. (O.)

1 gafarahu * , aor.
gafira , (K,) inf. n. gaforN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He covered, veiled, concealed, or hid, it; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e., anything. (TA.) This is the primary signification. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence] gafar Al$~ayoba biAlxiDaAbi He covered, or concealed, the white, or hoary, hair with dye; (K;) as also ↓ A^agofarahu. (TA.) ― -b3- And gafara AlmataAEa, (S, K,) fiY AlwiEaA='i, (K,) He put the goods, or utensils, into the bag, or receptacle, and concealed them; (K;) as also ↓ Agfrhu. (K.) ― -b4- [Hence also] gafara lahu *anobahu, (S, Msb, * K,) aor.
gafira , (K,) inf. n. magofaripN, (S, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and guforaAnN and gaforN (S, Msb, K) and gufuwrN (Lh, K) and gafiyrN and gafiyrpN, (K,) He (God) covered, his sin, crime, or offence; (K;) forgave it; pardoned it; (Msb, K;) as also *anobahu ↓ Agtfr, (S,) or Agtfr lahu maA SanaEa he forgave him what he had done: (Msb:) or guforaAnN and magofirapN, on the part of God, signify the preserving a man from being touched by punishment: and sometimes gafara lahu signifies [he forgave him, or pardoned him: and also] he forgave him, or pardoned him, apparently, but not really; and thus it is used in the Kur xlv. 13, accord. to the B. (TA.) As an ex. of the last of the inf. ns. mentioned above on the authority of the K, the following saying, of a certain Arab, is cited: A^asoA^aluka Algafiyraho waAln~aAqapa Algazyiraho waAlEiz~a fiY AlEa$iyraho faA_in~ahaA Ealayoka yasiyraho [I beg of Thee (O God) forgiveness, and a she-camel abounding in milk, and might among the kinsfolk, or in the tribe, for they are to Thee things easy]. (TA.) [See also the paragraph commencing with gafiyrapN.] ― -b5- In the following saying of Zuheyr, the verb is used tropically:
A^aDaAEato falamo tugofaro lahaA gafalaAtuhaA
meaning [She lost her young one, and] her acts of negligence with respect to her young one were not forgiven her, by the wild beasts, so they ate it. (TA.) ― -b6- ↓ gafara AlA^amora biguforatihi, (S, * K,) and ↓ bigafiyratihi, (K,) aor.
gafira , (S,) [lit. He covered the affair with its cover,] means (assumed tropical:) he rectified the affair with that wherewith it was requisite that it should be rectified. (S, K.) [And ↓ Agtfrhu perhaps signifies the same: see murotaA^abN, in art. rA^b.] -A2- gafira, aor.
gafara , (S, K,) inf. n. gafarN, (S,) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became villous; as also ↓ AgfAr~, (S, K,) inf. n. AigofiyraArN. (S.) -A3- gafara, (S, K,) aor.
gafira , inf. n. gaforN, (S,) It (a wound) became recrudescent; or reverted to a bad, or corrupt, state; (S, K;) as also gafira, [of which see another meaning in what follows,] aor.
gafara , inf. n. gafarN. (S.) And in like manner the former is said of a sick person: (S:) [i. e.] gafara signifies likewise He (a sick person) relapsed into disease, after convalescence; as also gufira: (K, TA:) and in like manner one says of a wounded person. (TA.) And [hence, app.,] it is also said of an excessive lover, meaning He experienced a return of his desire, (K, TA,) after consolation. (TA.) ― -b2- gafira said of a wound signifies also It healed: thus having two contr. meanings. (IKtt, TA.) -A4- gafara Aljalabu Als~uwqa, (K, TA,) aor.
gafira , inf. n. gaforN, (TA,) means rax~aSahaA [more correctly A^aroxaSahaA i. e. The beasts, or other things, brought thither for sale, made the market cheap]. (K, TA.)

2 gf~rhu *
He said gafara A@ll~`hu lahu [May God cover his sins, &c.; may God forgive him, or pardon him]. (TA, from a trad.)

4 Agfr * : see 1, in two places. -A2- A^agofarato It (land) produced somewhat of gafar, meaning small herbage: (TA:) [i. e.] it produced herbage like the nap of cloth. (O, L, TA. *) ― -b2- And It (land) produced its magaAfiyr [pl. of mugofuwrN, q. v.]. (IAth, O, L, TA.) And Agfr It (the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov, S, and the EurofuT, [&c.,] TA) exuded, or produced, its magaAfiyr. (S, TA.) -A3- Also, i. e. Agfrt, [from guforN, q. v.,] She (a mountaingoat) had a young one, or young ones. (O, TA.) -A4- And Agfr Aln~axolu The palm-tress had, upon their unripe dates, what resembled bark, or crust; (O, K, TA;) which the people of El-Medeeneh term AlgafaA [or AlgafaY]. (O, TA.)

5 tgf~r * and ↓ tamagofara He gathered what is called migofar and mugofuwr [see the latter of these two words]. (S, K.) He who says mugofuwr says ↓ xarajonaA natamagofaru, and he who says migofar says xrjnA natagaf~aru, We went forth to gather mgfwr, or mgfr, from its trees. (S.)

6 tgAfrA *
They two prayed for the covering of sins, &c., or for forgiveness, or pardon, each for the other. (TA.)
8 A_igotafara see the first paragraph, in two places.

10 Astgfr A@ll~`ha * , (Msb,) and Astgfr All~`h mino *anobihi, (S, K,) and li*anobihi, (S,) and *anobahu, (K,) He begged of God forgiveness, or pardon; (Msb;) he sought of God the covering, or forgiveness, or pardon, of his sin, crime, or offence, (K, TA,) by word and by deed; for so God requires one to do; not with the tongue only. (TA.)
11 A_igofaAor~a see the first paragraph.
Q. Q.2 tamagofara * : see 5, in two places.

gaforN * : see gafarN, in two places. -A2- See also guforN. -A3- Also The belly. (K.) -A4- And A certain thing like the [sack called] juwaAliq. (K.) -A5- And Algaforu is the name of The star [ λ] in the left foot of Virgo: (Kzw in his Descr. of Virgo:) or three obscure stars, (Kzw in his Descr. of the Mansions of the Moon,) or three small stars, (S, K,) [most probably, I think, (not φ and ι and κ, as supposed by Freytag, who refers to Ideler's “ Untersuch. ” pp. 169 and 288, but) ι and κ and λ of Virgo, though said to be] belonging to Libra: (S:) one of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, K,) namely, the Fifteenth. (Kzw in his Descr. of the Mansions.)

guforN * The young of the mountain-goat; (S, K;) as also ↓ gaforN; but the former is the more common; (K;) the latter, rare: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^agofaArN and [of mult.] gifarapN (S, K) and gufuwrN: (Kr, K:) the female is termed guforapN: and it is said that guforN is an appellation of one and of a pl. number: the
phrase guforN kaviyrN is mentioned [as meaning many young ones of the mountain-goat]. (TA.)

giforN * The young of the cow [probably meaning of the bovine antelope called the wild cow]. (ElHejeree, K.) ― -b2- And A certain duwayob~ap [by which may be meant a small beast or creeping thing, or an insect]: (IDrd, O, K:) so, says IDrd, they assert. (O.)

gafarN * (S, K, TA) and ↓ gaforN (S, TA) and ↓ gufaArN (S, K, TA) Hair like down, such as is upon the shank of a woman, and upon the forehead, and the like thereof: (S, TA:) or the hair of the neck, and of the jaws, and of the back of the neck; (K, TA;) as also ↓ gafiyrN accord. to the copies of the K, but accord. to the L and other lexicons gaforN: and the small, short, hairs of the body. (TA.) ― -b2- And gafarN signifies also The growth of hair in the place of the mane of a horse or similar beast. (TA.) ― -b3- And The nap, or villous substance, upon the surface of a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, K, TA,) and the like thereof; (TA;) and ↓ gaforN signifies the same: (K, TA:) n. un. gaforapN [and app. gafarapN]: and gafarN is also expl. as signifying the hudob [app. here meaning likewise nap, or pile, or perhaps the unwoven end,] of a garment, or piece of cloth, and [particularly] of the thin and soft sorts of what are termed xamaAy^iS and quTuf [pls. of xamiySapN and qaTiyfapN]; but not the extremities of A^arodiyap and malaAHif [pls. of ridaA='N and miloHafapN]. (TA.) ― -b4- And Small herbage; (K:) [or] a sort of small, sprouting herbage, of the [season called] rabiyE, growing in plain, or soft, land, and upon the [eminences termed] A=kAm [pl. of A^akamapN]; when green, resembling green passerine birds standing; and when it has dried up, resembling such as are red, not standing. (L, TA. *)
huwagafiru AlqafaA * means He is one who has [hair such as is termed] gafar upon the back of his neck: and hiYa gafirapu Alwajohi, she is one who has gafar upon her face. (AHn, K, * TA.)

guforapN *
A cover; a thing with which another thing is covered. (S.) [Hence] one says, gafara AlA^amora biguforatihi (S, K) and ↓ bigafiyratihi (K) expl. above: see 1.

giforapN HasanapN *
A good manner of covering, forgiving, or pardoning, sins, &c. (Lh, K.)
gufaArN * : see gafarN, first sentence.

gifaArN *
A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon the cheek [app. of a camel]. (TA.)
gafuwrN * : see gaAfirN, in three places.

jam~aA='u gafiyrN *
A helmet that encloses and embraces the whole head. (K.) AO says, in his “ Book on the Coat of Mail and the Helmet, ” that bayoDapN is a general name for a helmet, which has plates like the bones of the skull, fastened together, edge to edge, by nails. (TA.) ― -b2- jaAw^uwA jam~aA='a gafiyrFA, and Aljam~aA='a Algafiyra, (S, K,) and jam~aA='a Algafiyri, and jam~FA gafiyrFA, and Aljam~a Algafiyra, and jam~a Algafiyri, and ↓ jam~aA='a AlgafiyraY, and ↓ jam~aA='a gafiyrapF, and Aljam~aA='a ↓ Algafiyrapa, and ↓ jam~aA='a Algafiyrapi, and ↓ jam~a Algafiyrapi, and bijam~aA='i Algafiyri, and ↓ bijam~aA='i Algafiyrapi, (K,) are phrases meaning They came all together, high and low, none of them remaining behind, and they being many: (S, K:) accord. to Sb, (K,) it (Aljm~A=' Algfyr, S, which is the only form that he mentions, TA, [or rather the former of these two words,]) is a subst., (S, K,) put in the place of an inf. n., (K,) i. e. put in the accus. case like an inf. n. of the same meaning, (TA,) i. e., [as when you say] mararotu bihimo jumuwmFA kaviyrFA [I passed by them they being very many]: (K:) it is not a verb, [by which is here meant, as in many other instances, an inf. n.,] but is put in the accus. case like an inf. n. of the same meaning, as when you say jaAw^uwniY jamiyEFA, and qaATibapF, and Tur~FA, and kaAf~apF, [They came to me all together,] and the article Al is prefixed like as it is prefixed in the saying A^aworadahaA AlEiraAka, meaning A^aworadahaA EiraAkFA [He brought them (the camels) to the water all together]: (S:) Sb says that it is one of those denotatives of state which have the art. Al prefixed, and is extr.; and that Algfyr is an epithet inseparable from Aljm~A='; meaning that you do not say Aljm~A=' and then be silent: (TA:) others hold it to be an inf. n.: IAmb allows it to be in the nom. case, on the condition that hum is understood [before it; i. e., the complete phrase being jaAw^uwA humu Aljam~aA='u Algafiyru]: and Ks says that the Arabs put Aljm~A' Algfyr in the accus. case fiY Alt~amaAmi [i. e. in the case of its occurring after a proposition rendered complete by the mention of the agent. as when you say jaA='a Alqawomu Aljam~aA='a Algafiyra], and in the nom. case fiY Aln~uqoSaAni [i. e. in the case of its occurring when what precedes it is not a complete proposition, and is only rendered complete by it as the agent, as when you say jaA='a Aljam~aA='u Algafyiru]. (K.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., that Mohammad, being asked by Aboo-Dharr, what was the number of the apostles, answered val`vumiAy^apK waxamosapa Ea$ara jam~a Algafiyri, meaning, Three hundred and fifteen: a great number. (Nh, TA.) -A2- See also gafarN, first sentence.

gifaArapN * : see migofarN, in three places. ― -b2- Also A piece of rag worn beneath the miqonaEap [q. v.], by which a woman preserves it from the oil or grease [on her head]: (S: [accord to one of my copies of the S, “ preserves her head: ” ]) or a piece of rag by which a woman preserves her ximaAr [q. v.] from the oil or grease: (K:) or a piece of rag with which a woman covers the fore part and the hind part (but not the middle) of her head. (TA.) ― -b3- [And A cloth that is spread upon the camel-litter. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)] ― -b4- And A patch (ruqoEap) that is put upon the notch, (S, K,) or a piece of skin which is upon the head, (TA,) upon which runs the string, of the bow. (S, K, TA.) ― -b5- And A cloud (S, K) that is as though it were (S) above another cloud. (S, K.) ― -b6- And The head of a mountain. (K.)

gafiyrapN * : see guforapN, and 1. ― -b2- maA fiyhimo gafiyrapN [There is not in them any disposition to forgive;] means they do not forgive any one a sin, a crime, or an offence. (S, K.) And maAEinodahumo Ea*iyrapN walaA gafiyrapN [They have not a disposition to excuse nor a disposition to forgive;] means they do not excuse nor do they forgive a sin, a crime, or an offence, of any one. (TA.) The rájiz (Sakhr-el-Ghei, L) said, (on seeing his companions, with whom he was journeying, fly from the Benu-l-Mustalik, whom they chanced to meet, L,)
yaA qawomi layosato fiyhimu gafiyraho
faA@mo$uwA kamaA tamo$iY jimaAlu AlHiyraho
[O my people, there is not in them any disposition to forgive: therefore march ye as march the camels of El-Heereh]: (S, L:) he mentioned particularly the camels of El-Heereh because they carry burdens; and meant, march ye heavily, and defend yourselves, and do not fly. (L.) -A2- Also Abundance, and increase, in family and cattle or other property. (TA, from a trad.) -A3- See also gafiyrN, in five places.
gafiyraY * : see gafiyrN.
gaf~aArN * : see the next paragraph.

gaAfirN * (TA) and ↓ gafuwrN (S, K, TA) and ↓ gaf~aArN (K, TA) are epithets applied to God. (K, TA,) the second and third of which are intensive; (TA;) meaning, [the first,] Covering and forgiving the sins, crimes, and offences, of his servants; [or simply forgiving; and the second and third, covering and forgiving much the sins, &c., of his servants; or very forgiving.] (S, * K, * TA) The pl. of ↓ gafuwrN is gufurN. (S.) And ↓ gafuwrN is also applied to a woman, without p. (TA.)

gawofarN * The autumnal biT~iyx [i. e. melon or water-melon]: (K:) or a species thereof (Sgh, K, TA) It is said that the biT~iyx and the gawofar are of those things in the cases of which the giving of the tithe is not incumbent. (Mgh.)

A^agofaru * [Having the quality of covering, or the like, in a greater, or in the greatest, degree]. One says AuSobugo vawobaka bAls~awaAdi faA_in~ahu A^agofaru liwasaxihi Dye thou thy garment, or piece of cloth, with black; for it has the quality of bearing and concealing its dirt in the greatest degree. (S, * TA.)
mugofurN * : see mugofuwrN, in two places.
mugofirN * , (O, TA,) or mugofirapN, (S,) or the latter also, (O, TA,) A she-goat of the mountain having a young one or young ones: (S, * O, * TA:) pl. mugofiraAtN. (S, TA.)

migofarN *
What is worn beneath the helmet: (Mgh, Msb:) or a piece of mail, (zaradN, S K,) woven (S) from the diroE [or coat of mail], (S, K,) according to the size of the head, (S,) worn beneath the [kind of cap called] qalanosuwap; (S, K;) as also ↓ migofarapN and ↓ gifaArapN: (K:) or the raforaf [or pendent appertenance] of the helmet: (TA:) or a piece of mail,
(HalaqN, or HilaqN, as in different copies of the K,) which an armed man, (K,) or a man, accord. to some lexicons, (TA,) wears in the manner of a qinaAE (yataqan~aEu bihaA); as also ↓ migofarapN and ↓ gifaArapN: (K:) accord. to ISh, the migofar is a piece of mail (HalaqN) which a man puts beneath the helmet, hanging down upon the neck: and sometimes, he says, it is like the qalanosuwap, except that it is more ample; a man throws it upon his head, and it reaches to the coat of mail; then the helmet is put on over it; and this mgfr hangs down upon the shoulders: sometimes, also, the mgfr is [a covering for the head] made of diybaAj [i. e. silk brocade], and of [the cloth called] xaz~ [q. v.], beneath the helmet: accord. to “ the Book of the Coat of Mail and the Helmet, ” by AO, migofarN and ↓ gifaArapN are names applied to a portion of mail [forming a headcovering], which is also called tasobigapN [q. v.]; and sometimes the rings are exposed to view; and sometimes they line them within, and cover them externally, with diybaAj or xaz~ or [the kind of silk stuff called] bizoyawon; and they stuff it with something (H$~whA bmA kAn); and sometimes they make above it a qawonas [or tapering top] of silver &c.: (TA:) the term migofar is also applied to the helmet itself. (Mgh.) -A2- See also mugofuwrN, in three places.
migofarapN * : see migofarN, in two places.
migofaArN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

mugofuwrN * (AA, T, S, K, &c.) and ↓ migofarN (Ks, T, S, K) and ↓ mugofarN and ↓ migofaArN and ↓ migofyrN (K) i. q. mugovuwrN; (T, S, K;) [A kind of manna;] a produce of the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov and sometimes of the Eu$ar and the EurofuT and the vumaAm and the salam and the TaloH &c.; (S;) the gum of the rmv and ErfT; (T;) the gum that is found upon the rmv, which is sweet, and is eaten; (AA;) a thing that flows, or exudes, from the ends of the twigs of the rmv, resembling dibos in its colour; (ISh, in explanation of the pl. magaAfiyru;) a gum that flows, or exudes, from the ErfT, not of pleasant odour; (IAth;) a gum resembling [the kind of sweetmeat called] naATif, exuded by the ErfT, which is put into a piece of cloth, then sprinkled with water, and drunk: accord. to Lth, ↓ migofaArN is applied to the gum of the A_ij~aASap: and some say that ↓ migofarN is applied to gum of a round shape; SuEoruwrN to that which is in shape like a finger; and *awobN to that which flows upon the ground: and ↓ migofarN is also applied to a twig of a gum-tree, from which [for bihi (with which), in the TA, I read minohu,] is wiped a white fluid, whereof is made a sweet beverage: (TA:) pl. [of mugofuwrN and migofaArN and migofiyrN] magaAfiyru, (T, S, K,) and [of migofarN and mugofurN] magaAfiru: (K:) it is also said that magaAfiyru is applied to a kind of sweet honey, like rub~, except that it is white. (TA.) [Hence the saying,]
↓ h`*aA AljanaY laA A^aono yukad~a Almugofuru
[This is gathering, not the scraping off mgfr]: a prov. alluding to the preference of a thing; said to him who obtains much good. (K.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 874.]
migofiyrN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^aroDN magofuwraA='u *
Land containing [trees producing] magaAfiyr. (IDrd, K.) [See mugofuwrN.]

3 gAfShu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. mugaAfaSapN and gifaASN, (TA,) He came upon him suddenly, or unexpectedly; (A, Msb, K;) he took him at unawares, (S, Msb, K,) and did an evil action to him. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, (Msb,) A^axa*otuhu mugaAfaSapF (A, Msb, TA) I took it (a thing, Msb) striving to overcome. (Msb, TA.)

gaAfiSapN *
A sudden, or an unexpected, calamity, of time, or fortune: (Sgh, * K, * TK:) pl. gawaAfiSu. (A.) You say, waqaAka A@ll~`hu gawaAfiSa Ald~ahori [May God preserve thee from the sudden, or unexpected, calamities of time, or fortune]. (A.)

1 gafala Eanohu * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
gafula , (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. gufuwlN (S, O, Msb, K) and gafolapN, (S, O, Msb,) or the latter is a simple subst., (K,) or it is a simple subst. as well as an inf. n., and so may be gufolaAnN, said in the K to be a simple subst.; and MF says that gafila, aor.
gafala , of which gafalN, mentioned in the K as a subst. syn. with gafolapN, may be the inf. n., has been mentioned by some as a dial. var. of gafala, but had not been found by him in any of the lexicological works notwithstanding much research, so that its correctness requires consideration; (TA;) He was, or became, unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it; (Msb;) namely, a thing: (S, O, Msb:) or he neglected it; and was, or became, unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it: (K:) and sometimes it is used as meaning he neglected it [intentionally], leaving it, and turning away: (Msb:) and ↓ Agflhu signifies the same as gafala Eanohu: or gafala signifies SaAragaAfilFA [he became unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent]: and gafala Eanohu and ↓ Agflhu signify waS~ala gafolatahu A_ilayohi [which is app. said merely for the purpose of showing that the former verb is made trans. only by means of Eano, and the latter is trans. without any prep.; for waS~ala AlfiEola A_ilaY mafoEuwilhi and A^awoSalahu A_ilayohi, which latter phrase is the more usual, mean “ he made the verb transitive ”]: (K:) or ↓ Agflhu signifies he neglected it (i. e. a thing) though remembering it. ('Eyn, Sb, S, O, Msb.) It is said in a trad., mani A@t~abaEa AlS~ayoda gafala i. e. He who pursues the object of the chase has his mind busied and possessed by it so that he becomes unmindful [&c. of other things]. (TA.)

2 gf~lhu * , inf. n. tagofiylN, He made him to become unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- Alt~agofiylu signifies [also] The sufficing one's companion [in respect of an affair] when he who is the object thereof is unmindful, unoccupied [in mind, or actually,] by anything. (ISk, K, TA.) [You say, gf~l SaAHibahu meaning He sufficed his companion in respect of an affair when he (the latter) was unmindful, &c.] -A2- And gf~lhu, (Mgh, O, K, but in my copy of the Mgh written without tesh-deed,) inf. n. as above, (O, K,) He concealed it, (Mgh, O, K,) namely, a thing. (Mgh, O.)
3 gAflhu * [app. He acted with him in the manner of him who is unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent]. (TA voce saAhaAhu, q. v., in art. shw.)

4 Agflhu * : see 1, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, maA A^agofalahu Eanoka $ayoy^FA [app. lit. signifying How unmindful of thee is he as to anything! and therefore virtually] meaning dismiss doubt [from thee respecting him as to anything]. (TA. [See further explanations of it voce $aYo'N.]) ― -b3- And Agflhu Eanohu He made him to be unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it; (S, * O, TA;) namely, a thing. (S.) [Or] Agflhu signifies He, or it, smote him, or lighted on him, he (the latter) being gaAfil [i. e. unmindful, &c.]: or he made him to be gaAfil: or he called him, or named him, gaAfil: and in like manner ↓ gf~lhu, inf. n. tagofiylN: (TA:) or tagofiylN signifies the calling [one] unmindful, &c.: and the rendering [one] stupid, or foolish. (KL.) ― -b4- And Agflhu signifies also He asked him [for, or respecting, a thing] in the time of his occupation, not waiting for the time of his freedom therefrom. (TA.) ― -b5- And Agfl Ald~aAb~apa He left the beast unbranded; did not brand it. (S, O.)

5 tgf~l * as intrans.: see 6, in two places. -A2- tgf~lhu He watched for his unmindfulness, forgetfulness, negligence, heedlessness, or inadvertence; (S, Mgh, O, Msb;) as also Eanohu ↓ tgAfl, (S, O,) and ↓ Astgflhu: (TA:) tgAfl [as trans.] in this sense [without a prep.] is a mistake. (Mgh.)

6 tgAfl *
He feigned himself unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent; not being so really. (Msb.) [And] He was intentionally, or purposely, unmindful, forgetful, &c.; as also ↓ tgf~l: (K:) or the former has this meaning: but ↓ tgf~l signifies he was deceived, or circumvented, in a state of unmindfulness, forgetfulness, &c. (TA.) tgAfl Eanohu: see 5. It means [also] He was unmindful, &c., of him, or it: or he feigned himself unmindful, &c., of him, or it. (MA.)
10 Astgflhu * : see 5.

gufolN * Land without cultivation: (K:) or without any way-mark: (Msb:) or without any waymark and without cultivation: (S, O:) or not rained upon: (Ks, S, O:) or unknown; in which is no known trace; or vestige: and, accord. to the
M, a desert, or waterless desert, that causes one to lose his way, wherein is no sign, or mark: (TA:) pl. A^agofaAlN, (S, TA,) syn. with mawaAtN [q. v.]; (S:) and Lh mentions the phrase A^aroDN A^agofaAlN, as though they made every portion thereof to be what is termed gufolN: and bilaAdN A^agofaAlN, meaning [tracts of country] wherein are no way-marks by which to be directed. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A road, or way, &c., in which is no sign, or mark, whereby it may be known. (K.) ― -b3- And A gaming-arrow (qidoHN) upon which is no mark [or notch to distinguish it]; (K;) such as has no portion assigned to it, and no fine: (O, K:) [or,] accord. to Lh, one says qidaAHN gufolN, using the sing. form [of the epithet] meaning [gaming arrows] in which are no notches, and to which is assigned no portion and no fine: they used to be added to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from fear of occasioning suspicion [of foul play], i. e. to increase the number: and they were four; the first [called] AlmuSad~aru; the next, AlmuDaE~afu; the next, AlmaniyHu; and the next, Als~afiyHu. (TA.) ― -b4- And A beast (daAb~apN) having no brand upon it: (S, O, K:) and a she-camel that is not branded, in order that the poor-rate may not be [considered as] incumbent for her: and ↓ gufulN is a dial. var. thereof, or is used by poetic license: the pl. is A^agofaAlN. (TA.) The pl. (A^agofaAlN) is also applied to Camels, or cattle, (naEamN,) that yield no milk. (TA.) ― -b5- And A muSoHaf [or copy of the Kur-án] bare of the [signs called] EawaA$ir [pl. of EaA$irapN q. v.] and the like of these. (TA.) ― -b6- And A book, or writing, [that is anonymous,] of which the author is not named. (TA.) And Poetry of which the author is unknown. (K.) And A poet unknown (K, TA) and unnamed [or anonymous]: pl. A^agofaAlN. (TA.) ― -b7- Also A man inexperienced in affairs. (S, O, Msb, TA.) One whose beneficence is not hoped for, nor his evilness feared; (K, TA;) he being like the shackled that is neglected: pl. as above. (TA.) And One having no grounds of pretension to respect or honour: (K, TA:) or, as some say, of whom one knows not what he possesses. (TA.) ― -b8- And The fur (lit. furs, or soft portions of hair, A^awobaAr, [perhaps because long left unshorn,]) of camels. (AHn, K, TA.)

gafalN * : see gafolapN. ― -b2- Also [Such as is] abundant and high [in estimation, app. of the means of subsistence]; syn. kaviyrN rafiyEN: (O, K: [or the latter word is correctly rafiygN, (so in the TK,) i. e. ample, and pleasant or good, as applied to the means of subsistence:]) and a state of ampleness of the means of subsistence: (O, K:) thus in the saying, huwa fiY gafalK mino Eayo$ihi [He is in a state of ampleness in respect of his means of subsistence: app. thus termed as being a cause of unmindfulness, or heedlessness]. (O.)
gufulN * : see gufolN, latter half.

gafolapN * the subst. from gafala, (ISd, K,) or it is an inf. n. (S, O, Msb, TA) and also a simple subst., (TA,) or the subst. is ↓ gafalapN, with fet-h to the f to distinguish it from the inf. n.; (Msb;) as also ↓ gafalN, (ISd, K,) or this may be the inf. n. of gafila, mentioned above as a dial. var. outweighed in authority; (TA;) and ↓ gufolaAnN, (K,) or this may be an inf. n. like kuforaAnN, and it may be a simple subst.; (TA;) Unmindfulness, forgetfulness, neglectfulness, heedlessness, or inadvertence; (Msb, K;) [the state in which is] absence of a thing from the mind of a man; and unmindfulness, or forgetfulness: and sometimes, intentional neglect: (Msb;) or gafolapN signifies the forgetting, neglecting, or being unmindful, of a thing: (Abu-l-Bakà, TA:) or the want of requisite knowledge or cognizance of a thing: (El-Harállee, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Raghib, negligence occurring from littleness of consideration and of vigilance; or, as some say, the following the soul in that which it desires, (TA.) [fiY gafolapK In a state of unmindfulness &c., and Eano gafolapK in consequence of unmindfulness &c., may often be rendered at unawares.]
gafalapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
gafolaAnN * , or gafolaAnu: see gaAfilN.
gufolaAnN * : see gafolapN.
gafuwlN * A she-camel that does not take fright and flee, (K, TA,) nor hold back from a young one that she suckles, nor care who milks her. (TA.)
gaAfilN * [and ↓ gafolaAnN, or gafolaAnu, Unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent: and the former, sometimes, intentionally neglecting: pl. of the former gufuwlN and guf~alN]. (K.)

mugofilN *
Possessing camels not branded. (TA.)

magofalapN * The Eanofaqap [or tuft of hair beneath the lower lip]; (O, K, TA;) so says Th, (O,) or Ez-Zejjájee: (TA:) not the two sides thereof as it is said to signify by J: (K:) so called because many men neglect [the washing of] it. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Ealayoka biA@lomagofalapi [Keep thou to the washing of the tuft of hair beneath the lower lip]: meaning that one should use heedfulness in washing it, in the performance of the ablution termed wuDuw'. (TA.)
mugaf~alN * [lit. Made unmindful, &c.; see its verb: and hence, a simpleton; or] devoid of intelligence, sagacity, skill, or natural understanding. (IDrd, Mgh, O, Msb, K.)

div2.head: gfw and gfY
div2.entryFree:
1 gafaA * , and gafiYa: see 4. ― -b2- gafaA, (K, TA,) inf. n. gafowN and gufuw~N, (TA,) also signifies It (a thing, TA) floated upon the water (K, TA.) -A2- gafaY AlT~aEaAma, aor.
1a2i3a , (K, TA,) inf. n. gafoYN, (TA,) He cleared the wheat of what is termed gafFY, i. e. a thing such as [the noxious weed called] zuw^aAn [q. v.], (K, TA,) and other refuse; (TA;) or the straw; as also ↓ AgfY. (K, TA,)

4 AgfY * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. A_igofaA='N; (S, Msb;) and ↓ gafaA, (K,) first pers. gafawotu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. gafowN and gufuw~N; (K;) the latter verb said by ISd to occur in the trads., (TA,) but disallowed by ISk (S, Msb, TA) and by others, (Msb,) and said by Az to be rare; (Msb, TA;) He slept: (S, K:) or he slept a light sleep: (Msb, TA;) or he was, or became, drowsy, or heavy with sleepiness; as also ↓ gafiYa, aor.
1a2a3a , inf. n. gafoyapN. (K.) ― -b2- And AgfY He (a man, TA) slept upon what is termed gafFY, i. e. the straw, in the place in which the grain thereof was trodden out: (K:) mentioned as from IAar by Az, and by Sgh as from AA. (TA.) ― -b3- And AgfY AlT~aEaAmu The wheat was abundant in its nuxaAlap, accord. to the copies of the K, but more properly its nufaAyap [i. e. refuse]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1. -A2- AgfY Al$~ajaru The trees hung down their branches. (IKtt, TA.)
7 AngfY * . It (a thing, TA) became broken. (K, TA.)

gafowN * and ↓ gafowapN and ↓ gafoyapN (K, TA) and ↓ gufoyapN and ↓ gifoyapN (Sgh, TA) A zuboyap [or hollow dug in the ground], (K, TA,) in which a sportsman lurks: the first and second mentioned by Lh. (TA.)

gafFY * The refuse that is taken forth from wheat, and thrown away, (Fr, S, TA,) such as [the noxious weed called] zuw^aAn [q. v.]; (S;) a thing that is in wheat, such as zw^An, (K, TA,) and other refuse: (TA:) or the straw [thereof]; (K, TA;) accord. to IAar, the bad, that is thrown away, of wheat; as also ↓ gafaA='N. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (thus accord. to ISd in all the senses here following in this paragraph that are found in the K, as is said in the TA, and thus in some copies of the K,) or ↓ gufaA='N, (thus in the copies of the K followed in the TA,) i. q. guvaA='N [i. e. The rubbish, or small rubbish, or particles of things, or refuse, and scum, and rotten leaves mixed with the scum, of a torrent]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And Fragments, or broken portions, of wheat: (K, TA;) or the stalks thereof. (TA.) ― -b4- And A blight incident to palm-trees, like dust falling upon the unripe dates, preventing their becoming ripe, (S, K, TA,) and rendering them tasteless. (S [in which the word thus expl. is gafFY] and TA.) And A thick crust that comes upon unripe dates: [see 4 in art. gfr:] or, as some say, bad dates, that become [app. in the skin] thick, or coarse, and like the wings of locusts. (TA.) ― -b5- And A disease incident to straw, rendering it bad. (TA.) ― -b6- Also Such as they drive away, or expel, of their camels. (K, TA.) ― -b7- And gafFY signifies also The bad of anything. (TA.) ― -b8- And The low, vile, mean, or sordid; or the lower, viler, &c.; or the refuse, or rabble; of mankind. (TA.)

gafowapN *
A light sleep: occurring in the traditions. (TA.) -A2- See also gafowN.
gafoyapN * and gufoyapN and gifoyapN: see gafowN.

gafiyapN * , like fariHapN [in measure], in the phrase xTp gfyp, [in which, app., the former word is xuT~apN, and the meaning of the phrase An affair, or a case, or a dubious, or momentous, and difficult affair, in which is something evil, or to be rejected,]
is a possessive epithet, signifying fiyhaA gafFY. (TA: immediately after gafFY expl. as meaning the “ bad ” of anything.)
gafaA='N * and gufaA='N: see gafFY, first and second sentences.
AlgufaA='apu * [in the CK AlgufApu] The whiteness upon the Hadaqap [or iris of the eye], (K, TA,) i. e., that covers the Hdqp. (TA.)

A_igofaA='apu AlS~uboHi *
The sleep of daybreak, or the first part of the day. (TA.)

1 gal~ahu * , (S, O, K, *) aor.
