migolaqN * : see galaqN. ― -b2- Also, (S, O, K, TA,) and ↓ migolaAqN is a dial. var. thereof in this sense, (TA,) An arrow, (K,) i. e. any arrow, (S, O,) used in the game called Almayosir: (S, O, K:) or, (K,) accord. to Lth, (O,) Almigolaqu signifies Als~ahomu Als~AbiEu fiY muDaE~afi Almayosiri [i. e. the seventh arrow, app. belonging to the class, of the arrows of the game of Almysr, to which manifold portions are assigned; for AlmuDaE~afu as used in relation to the game called Almysr I do not find expl. otherwise than as an appellation of “ the second of the arrows termed Algufol, to which are assigned no portion; ” (see art. DEf, and see also safiyHN;) and this cannot be here meant, as the seventh arrow (which is commonly called AlmuEal~aY) has seven portions assigned to it: therefore it seems that muDaE~af is here used, if not mistakenly, in a sense which, though admissible, is unusual in a case of this kind]: (O, K:) pl. magaAliqu: (S, O, K: in the CK [erroneously] magaAliyqu:) or AlmugaAliqu is one of the epithets applied to the winning arrows, and is not one of their [particular] names; (O, K;) they being those that make what is played-for to be a forfeit to the player (tugoliqu AlxaTara liloqaAmiri): so accord. to Az, who says that Lth has made a mistake in his explanation. (O.)

migolaAqN * : see galaqN. [Hence] one says, fulaAnN mifotaAHN liloxayori migolaAqN lil$~ar~i (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is a key to that which is good, a lock to that which is evil]. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. mirotaAjN [A thing with which a door is closed, or made fast, (app. a kind of latch,) affixed behind the door, in the part next to the lock]. (TA.) [See art. rtj: and see miEolaAqN, which seems to have the same, or a similar, meaning.]) ― -b3- And rajulN migolaAqN. (Msb,) and qawomN magaAliyqu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A man, and a company of men, by means of whom (EalaY yadayohi, Msb, and EalaY A^ayodiyhimo, TA,) the pledge is made a forfeit (yugonaqu). (Msb, TA.) And *uw migolaAqK means Aal~a*iY tugolaqu EalaY yadihi qidaAHu Almayosiri (assumed tropical:) [app. One by means of whom the arrows in the game called Almysr are withheld from the rest of the players; i. e. by his winning]: or, accord. to Z, yugoliqu AlHuj~apa EalaY AlxaSomi (assumed tropical:) [app. one who closes the argument against the adversary in a dispute]. (TA in art. Elq.) ― -b4- See also migolaqN.

magoluwqN * : see guluqN. -A2- Also A hide in which [the plant called] galoqap [q. v.] is put, when it is prepared for tanning by the treatment termed EaTonN: (ISk, S, TA:) or a hide tanned with galoqap. (O, K.)
mugoluwqN * : see galaqN.

1 galima * , aor.
galama , inf. n. galamN (Msb, K, TA) and gulomapN; (K, TA;) and ↓ Agtlm, (Msb, K,) only the latter of which, accord. to As, is said of other than man, though sometimes said of a man; (Msb;) He was, or became, excited by lust, or appetence: (TA:) or overcome thereby: (M, K, TA:) said of a man; and in like manner one says of a girl, or young woman: (TA:) or he was, or became, vehemently affected with lust, or carnal desire. (Msb.) And ↓ Agtlm said of a camel; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and [accord. to some, contr. to an assertion mentioned above,] galima, (S, K,) inf. n. gulomapN; (S;) He was, or became, excited (S, Mgh, Msb, K) by lust, (S, K,) or by vehement lust, (Mgh, Msb,) to cover. (S, Msb, K.)

4 Aglmhu *
It (a thing) excited his lust, or appetence. (K, * TA.) And Aglm said of a beverage, It strengthened in the venereal faculty. (TA in art. Awl.) -A2- See also 8, in two places.

8 Agtlm * : see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also He (a boy) attained to the limit of what is termed Alguluwmap [app. meaning the seventeenth year]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- Said of a beverage, or wine, (tropical:) It was, or became, strong in its influence upon the head. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b4- Said of the sea, ?? It became stirred up, in a state of commotion, or tumultuous; its waves dashing together: as also ↓ A^agolama. (TA.) ― -b5- And AlAigotilaAmu and ↓ AlA_igolaAmu signify (assumed tropical:) The exceeding the prescribed limit, of good or of evil. (TA.)

galimN * , (Msb, K, TA,) and ↓ gil~iymN, (S, K, TA,) but this has an intensive signification, (S, TA,) and ↓ migoliymN, (K, TA,) [but this also has an intensive signification,] Excited by lust, or appetence: (TA:) or overcome thereby: (K, TA:) or vehemently affected with lust, or carnal desire (Msb:) [or the first may generally be better rendered in a state of excitement, or of vehement excitement, by lust and the second and third, lustful, or vehemently lustful:] the epithets applied to a female are galimapN and ↓ mugotalimapN and ↓ gil~iymapN and ↓ gil~iymN, (K, TA,) this last being applied to a male and to a female, (Az, TA,) and [particularly] applied to a he-camel, (TA,) and ↓ mgolymapN and ↓ migoliymN, (K, TA,) the last [which is ?? in the CK] being, like gil~iymN, applied to a male and to a female: (Az, TA:) and ↓ gayolamN likewise is applied to a girl, or young woman. in the sense of mugotalimapN. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., xayoruAln~isaA='i Algalimapu EalaY zawojihaA [The best of women is the appetent to her husband]. (TA.)
gulumN * , with two dammehs, [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] is expl. by IAar as signifying maHobuwsuwna [Persons confined, restricted, imprisoned, &c.]. (TA.)

gulomapN * , (S, Msb, K, TA, &c.,) written by some gilomapN, [like a pl. of gulaAmN,] is expl. by a number of authors as signifying Lust, appetence, or carnal desire: and the desire, or eager desire, of [i. e. experienced by] gilomaAn [meaning young men]: (TA:) or it signifies vehement lust or appetence: (Msb:) it is also of women, (K and TA in art. trj,) meaning their lust, or appetence: (TA ibid.:) [and] it is used [also] in relation to a camel, signifying his lust to cover. (S, K, TA.) [See also 1, where it is mentioned as an inf. n. In the K, voce qaEirapN, it is used as meaning The gratification of venereal lust.]

gulaAmN * [A young man, youth, boy, or male child:] one whose mustache is growing forth or has grown
forth: (Mgh, K:) or one from the time of his birth until he attains to the period termed $abaAb [meaning young manhood (see guluwmapN)]: (K:) or i. q. AibonN SagiyrN [meaning a son that has not attained to puberty]: (Msb:) and also applied to (tropical:) such as is termed kahol [i. e. one of middle age, or between that age and the period when his hair has become intermixed with hoariness]: (IAar, Msb, K:) Az states his having heard the Arabs call thus the new-born child and also the kahol: (Msb:) the female is [sometimes] termed gulaAmapN; (S, K;) [i. e.] gulaAmapN occurs in poetry, applied to a jaAriyap: (Msb:) the pl. of gulaAmN is gilomapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) a pl. of pauc., (Msb,) and A^agolimapN, (K,) [also a pl. of pauc.,] or of these two pls. they used only the former, (S, IAth, TA,) or some of them did so, (M, TA,) and gilomaAnN, (S, Mgh, K,) [a pl. of mult.,] or this is pl. of gilomapN: (Msb:) the dim. of gulaAmN is ↓ gulay~imN; (TA;) and that of gilomapN is ↓ A^ugayolimapN, as if it were the dim. of A^agolimapN though [it has been said that] they did not use this last word; but some of them said ↓ gulayomapN, agreeably with analogy. (S, TA.) ― -b2- It is also used as meaning (tropical:) A male slave; like as jaAriyapN is used as meaning “ a female slave: ” ― -b3- and as meaning (tropical:) A hireling [or servant]. (Mgh.)

guluwmapN * and ↓ guluwmiy~apN (S, K) and ↓ gulaAmiy~apN (K) The state, or condition, of such as is termed gulaAm: (S, K: *) the second is expl. by Mohammad Ibn- Habeeb as meaning the period from birth to the seventeenth year. (TA voce $abaAbN.)
gulayomapN * dim. of gilomapN pl. of gulaAmN, q. v. (S, TA.)
gulaAmiy~apN * : see guluwmapN.
guluwmiy~apN * : see guluwmapN.
gulay~imN * dim. of gulaAmN, q. v. (TA.)
gil~iymN * , and its fem., see galimN, in three places.

gayolamN * : see galimN. ― -b2- Also A beautiful woman. (TA.) ― -b3- And A youth, or young man, broad, (K, TA,) in the M large, (TA,) in the place of the parting of the hair of the head, having much hair; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ gayolamiY~N. (Lth, K, TA.) ― -b4- maA biAld~aAri gayolamN means [There is not in the house] any one. (K.) -A2- Also The tortoise: (TA:) or the male tortoise. (S, K, TA. [In the Msb said to be, in this sense, galiym, like zabiyb.]) ― -b2- And The frog. (K.) [Or so EayolamN.] -A3- And The place whence issues the water in wells. (K. [See also EayolamN.]) -A4- The word signifying “ a comb, ” and “ a [thing with which the head is scratched, called] midorFY, ” is fayolam, with f, but has been mistranscribed [gayolam], (K, TA,) by Lth, as has been notified by Az. (TA.)
gayolamiY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^agolamu * [More, and most, exciting to lust]. It is said that A^agolamu AlA^alobaAni labanu Alxaliqapi [The most exciting to lust, of milks, is the milk of the pregnant camel, or such as has completed a year after bringing forth and has then been covered and has conceived]; i. e., to him who drinks it. (TA.)
A^ugayolimapN * a dim. of gilomapN pl. of gulaAmN, q. v. (S, TA.)

magolamapN *
A cause [of lusting, or] of vehemence of lusting: such is said to be the drinking of the milk of the A^ay~il [or A_iy~al i. e. mountain-goat]. (TA.)
migoliymN * , and with p: see galimN, in three places.

mugotalimN * : see its fem. voce galimN. ― -b2- siqaA='N mugotalimN, (Mgh, TA,) and xaAbiyapN mugotalimapN, (TA,) (tropical:) [A skin, and a jar,] of which the beverage, or wine, is strong in its influence upon the head. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b3- The xaArijiY~ is called maAriqN mugotalimN (assumed tropical:) [A deviater from the true religion,] an exceeder of the prescribed limit. (TA.)

1 galaA * , aor. yagoluw, primarily signifies He, or it, exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit; was excessive, immoderate, or beyond measure; but the inf. n. differs in different cases, as will be shown in what follows: (Er-Rághib, TA:) it is said of anything as meaning it exceeded, or was excessive. (Msb.) ― -b2- You say, galaA fiY AlA^amori, (S, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. guluw~N (S, K, TA) and galaAniyapN; as also bihi ↓ tgAlY; (K * and TA in art. glY; [but belonging to the present art., as is said in the TA;]) He exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit, in the affair; was excessive, or immoderate, therein. (S, K, TA.) And galaA fiY Ald~iyni, aor. as above, inf. n. guluw~N, He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, or strictness, or rigour, in religion, so that he exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit: whence the usage of the verb in the Kur iv. 169 and v. 81: (Msb, TA:) accord. to IAth, Alguluw~u fiY Ald~iyni is the investigating of the intrinsic states, or circumstances, of things, [in religion,] and [applying oneself to] the discovery of their causes, and of the abstrusities relating to the rites and ceremonies thereof. (TA.) [See also 3.] ― -b3- And galaA biAls~ahomi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. galowN (S, Er-Rághib, Mgh, Msb, K) and guluw~N; (K;) and bihi ↓ gAlY, (Mgh, K,) and ↓ gAlAhu, (K,) inf. n. gilaA='N (Mgh, K) and mugaAlaApN; (K;) He shot the arrow to the furthest distance (S, Mgh, Msb) that he was able to attain: (S, Mgh:) or he raised his arms with the arrow, desiring [to attain with it] the furthest limit. (K, * TA.) And galaA Als~ahomu The arrow rose in its course, and exceeded the [usual] limit; (K, TA;) and in like manner, AlHajaru the stone. (TA.) ― -b4- And galaA Als~iEoru, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) aor. as above, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. galaA='N, (S, Mgh, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) The price, or rate, at which a thing was to be sold, was, or became, high; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) or exceeded the usual limit; (Er-Rághib, TA;) contr. of raxuSa. (K.) ― -b5- And galaA bihaA EZm [i. e. EiZamN, lit. Bigness exceeded the usual limit in her;] meaning she became plump, or fat: (TA:) one says, glA biAljaAriyapi EZm, and biAlgulaAmi, [the girl, or young woman, became plump, or fat, and the boy, or young man,] in the case of their quickly attaining to young womanhood and young manhood. (TA in another part of this art.) ― -b6- And galaA is said of anything as meaning AirotafaEa [i. e. It rose in degree; as is shown by the following ex.]: Dhur-Rummeh says,
famaA zaAla yagoluw Hub~u may~apa EinodanaA
wayazodaAdu Hat~aY lamo najido maA naziyduhaA
[And the love of Meiyeh ceased not to rise in degree with us, and to increase, so that we found not what more we might give to her]. (TA.) ― -b7- See also 8. ― -b8- And see 6.
2 gal~awa see art. glY.

3 gAlY fiY A^amorihi * , inf. n. mugaAlaApN, signifies [the same, or nearly the same, as galaA fiyhi; i. e.] He exceeded the usual, or proper, bounds, or degree, in his affair; acted immoderately therein; or strove or laboured, or exerted himself or his power or efforts, or the like, therein; syn. baAlaga [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the middle, in two places. ― -b3- gaAlaY bihi, and gAlAhu, (S, Msb, K,) which latter is used by a poet for gAlY bh, (S,) He bought it at a high, or an excessive, price, namely, flesh-meat; (S, Msb;) as also bihi ↓ AglY; (S;) and ↓ AglAhu, i. e. water, and flesh-meat [&c.]: (IKtt, TA: [see an ex. in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. dkn:]) or he exceeded what was usual in purchasing it, or in offering it for sale, and mentioning the price. (M, K, TA.) A poet says,
nugaAliY All~aHoma liloA^aDoyaAfi niyoy^FA
wanuroxiSuhu A_i*aA naDija Alquduwru
[We purchase at a high price flesh-meat, for the guests, raw; and we make it to be low-priced when the contents of the cooking-pots are thoroughly cooked]: he has suppressed the b [after ngAlY], meaning it [to be understood]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And gAlY fiY AlS~idaAqi He made the dowry, or the gift to, or for, a bride, high, or excessive, in amount; [he was excessive, or exorbitant, therein;] whence the saying of 'Omar, laA tugaAluwA fiY SaduqaAti Aln~isaA='i [Be not ye excessive, or exorbitant, in respect of the dowries of women]. (TA. [See also 6.]) ― -b5- And gAlAhu, inf. n. mugaAlaApN, signifies also He contended with him for superiority in tallness or in beneficence; syn. TaAwalahu. (TA.)

4 A^agolawa see 3, in two places. ― -b2- AglAhu also signifies He (God) made it to be high, or excessive, (S, Msb, K, TA,) namely, the price, or rate, at which a thing was to be sold; (S, Msb, K, * TA; *) contr. of A^aroxaSahu. (TA.) ― -b3- And He found it [a thing] to be high-priced: or he reckoned it to be so; as also ↓ AstglAhu. (TA.) ― -b4- And He lightened, or thinned, somewhat, its
leaves, (K, TA,) namely, those of a grape-vine, in order that it might grow high, and become [more productive, or] in good condition. (TA.) -A2- See also 6.
5 tagal~awa see art. glY.

6 tagaAolawa see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- tgAlwA fiY AlS~adaAqi They were excessive, or exorbitant, one towards another, in respect of the dowry, or the gift to, or for, a bride; contr. of tasaAhaluwA and tayaAsaruwA. (TA in art. ysr. [See also 3, last sentence but one.]) ― -b3- tgAlY said of a plant, or herbage, It grew high; (M, K, TA;) it became tall. (M, TA.) And, said of the same, It became tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and large; as also ↓ galaA, and ↓ AglY, and ↓ AigolawolaY; (K;) or this last is said of a grape-vine, signifying its leaves became tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and its branches, or its shoots upon which were the bunches of grapes, or the buds of its leaves and berries, (nawaAmiyhi,) became abundant, and it became tall. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, said of the flesh of a beast, It rose, or went away, (AirotafaEa,) and became upon the heads of the bones: and it fell away on the occasion of preparing for racing, or the like, by scanty feeding &c.: (T, TA:) or, said of the flesh of a she-camel, it went away; syn. *ahaba; (K;) or AirotafaEa and *ahaba. (S.)

8 AgtlY *
He was, or became, quick, or swift; he sped, or went quickly; (S, K, TA;) said of a camel: (K, TA:) and he rose [in the degree of celerity] (AirotafaEa) so as to exceed goodness of rate, or pace; and in like manner one says [Agtlt] of any beast (daAb~ap); as also ↓ galat, inf. n. glw [app. guluw~N]. (TA.)
10 A_isotagolawa see 4.
12 AglwlY * : see 6.

galowapN * The limit, or utmost extent, of a shot or throw; (S, Mgh; *) [i. e.] any maromaAp: (K:) [generally, a bow-shot; i. e.] the measure, space, or extent, of a single shooting of an arrow: (Har p. 234:) [or the utmost measure of a bow-shot; i. e.] a shot of an arrow to the utmost possible distance; also termed gaAyapN: (Msb:) said to be from three hundred to four hundred cubits: (Mgh, Msb:) the twenty-fifth part of a complete farosax [q. v.]: (ISd, Z, Mgh, TA:) or it is reckoned by some as four hundred cubits, and by others as two hundred cubits: (Msb voce miylN [q. v.]:) pl. galawaAtN (Msb, K, TA) and gilaA='N. (S, * K, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a prov., jaroYu Almu*ak~iyaAti gilaA='N, (S, K, TA,) or, as some relate it, gilaAbN. (TA. See art. *kw.) [Thus] galowapN is sometimes used in relation to horse-racing. (TA.)

galowaY *
i. q. gaAliyapN. (K.) See the latter in art. glY.

gulawaA='u * (S, K) and gulowaA='u, (K,) the latter mentioned by AZ, and app. a contraction of the former, (TA,) [and Freytag adds guluwaA=', for which I find no authority,] Excess, or exorbitance; (TA;) syn. with [the inf. n.] guluw~N. (S, K, TA.) One says, xaf~ifo Eano gulawaAy^ika [Alleviate thine excess, or exorbitance]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The quickness, or haste, or hastiness, and the first stage or state, of youth, or young manhood; (AZ, S, K;) as also ↓ gulowaAnN. (ISd, K, TA.) One says, faEalahu fiY gulawaA='i $abaAbihi and $abaAbihi ↓ gulowaAni [He did it in the quickness, or haste, &c., of his youth, or young manhood]. (TA.) ― -b3- And gulawaA='u signifies also The rising, or rising high, and increasing, of a plant, or of herbage. (Mz 40th nwE.)
gulowaAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

galaA='N * the subst. from galaA Als~iEoru; [as such signifying A high price, or rate, at which a thing is to be sold;] (Msb;) or it is an inf. n. (S, Mgh, K.) [See 1, latter half.] -A2- Also, [i. e.] like samaA='N [in measure], (K,) but in the copies of the M ↓ gal~aA='N, with teshdeed, (TA,) A man who shoots the arrow far. (K.) -A3- And A certain small, or short, fish, (K, accord. to different copies,) about a span [in length]: (TA:) pl. A^agoliyapN. (K.)
galiY~N * : see gaAlK, in three places.
gal~aA='N * : see galaA='N.

gaAlK * [act. part. n. of galaA: and hence, Acting, or behaving, with forced hardness, or strictness, or rigour, in religion, so that he exceeds the proper, due, or common, limit: (see 1:) and particularly] an extravagant zealot of the class of innovators: pl. gulaApN. (TA in art. sbA^.) ― -b2- And Shooting, or one who shoots, the arrow to the furthest distance. (Msb.) ― -b3- And High, or excessive, (S, * Msb, K, TA,) applied to a price, or rate, at which a thing is sold; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as also ↓ galiY~N. (K, TA.) Hence one says, biEotuhu biAlgaAliY and ↓ biAlgaliY~i I sold it, or bought it, at what was a high, or an excessive, price, or rate. (K, TA.) A poet says,
walawo A^an~aA nubaAEa kalaAma salomaY
↓ laA^aEoTayonaA bihi vamanFA galiy~aA
[And if we were sold the speech, or discourse, of Selmà, we would give for it a high, or an excessive, price]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Fat flesh-meat. (K.)
gaAliyapN * : see art. glY.

A^agolaY *
More, or most, high [or excessive] in price: hence the saying, A^afoDalu Alr~iqaAbi A^agolaAhaA vamanFA [The most excellent of slaves is the highest thereof in price]. (Mgh.)

migolFY * [in the CK migolaA'] An arrow with which one raises the arm [in shooting] in order to exceed with it the usual limit, or nearly to do so: (K, * TA:) or, accord. to the M, that is used in striving to exceed the usual limit: also termed ↓ migolaApN: pl. magaAlK. (TA.)

migolaApN * : see what next precedes. ― -b2- naAqapN migolaApu Alwahaqi A she-camel that goes quickly when her feet of her fore legs and of her hind legs fall in one place: (S: [it is there expl. by tagotaliY followed by the words A_i*aA tawaAhaqato A^axofaAfuhaA which I have here rendered accord. to an explanation in art. whq in the O: but the phrase mglAp Alwhq is there mentioned as an ex. of Alwahaq as signifying “ the lasso; ” whence it appears that the phrase lit. means that exceeds the limit of the lasso; agreeably with the explanation of Golius, “ rapide currens, et fugiens laqueum sibi injiciendum: ”]) or [the meaning is a she-camel that steps far in vying, or keeping pace, with another; for], in explaining the phrase migolaApu Alwahaqi, IB says that AlmigolaApu applied to the she-camel signifies Aal~atiY tuboEidu AlxaTowa; and Alwahaqu signifies AlmubaAraApu and AlmusaAyarapu. (TA voce hirojaAbN.)

A^aroDN mugolawoliyapN *
A land having abundant, and dense or luxuriant, herbage; and with E also; i. q. mugim~apN and migam~apN. (TA in art. gm.)

1 galati Alqidoru * , aor. tagoliY, inf. n. galoYN and galayaAnN, (S, MA, Msb, K,) The cooking-pot boiled; (MA, &c.;) and galiyat, aor. tagolaY, is an unusual dial. var. thereof, the former being the more chaste; (Msb;) or galiyat is not allowable. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence galaY said of a liquor, It estuated: it effervesced: it fermented: see nabiy*N ― -b3- And hence] yagoliY damuhu [as though meaning (assumed tropical:) His blood is fit to be shed] is a phrase like raAba damuhu, [q. v.], said of one who has exposed himself to slaughter: his blood being likened to milk that has become thick, and fit to be churned. (A in art. rwb.) ― -b4- And galiYa Alr~ajulu, like raDiYa in measure [but see what has been said of this form of the verb above], (tropical:) The man became vehemently angry. (IKtt, TA.)

2 gal~aYa see 4, in two places. -A2- gl~Y Alr~ajula, inf. n. tagoliyapN, He rubbed the man over, or perfumed him, with gaAliyap. (TA.) And gl~Y liHoyatahu (Mgh, O,) Msb, all in art. glf) biAlgaAliyapi (O, ibid.) He daubed, or smeared, his beard with gaAliyap; as also gal~alahaA. (Mgh, O, Msb, ibid. [See 1 in art. glf.]) -A3- And tagoliyapN signifies also The saluting from afar, and making a sign. (K.)

4 AglY Alqidora * , (S, MA, K,) and ↓ gl~AhaA, (K,) He made the cooking-pot to boil. (S, * MA, K. *) IDrd mentions, among some of the sayings of the people of former ages, ↓ A^un~a maA='F wagal~ihi [Pour thou out water, and make it to boil]. (TA.) And one says, A^agolayotu Alz~ayota wanaHowahu [I made the olive-oil and the like to boil], inf. n. A_igolaA='N. (Msb.)

5 tgl~Y * (S, Msb, K) biAlgaAliyapi (S, Msb) He (a man, S, Msb) perfumed himself, (S, * Msb, K,) or rubbed himself over, (K,) with gaAliyap; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ AgtlY signifies the same; (IDrd, O
in art. glf;) as also tagal~ala, (Msb, and O in art. glf,) and Aigotal~a. (O in that art.)
6 tagaAolaYa in all its sense, belongs to art. glw, q. v.
8 A_igotalaYa see 5.
galaAniyapN * , mentioned in the K in this art., belongs to art. glw, being an inf. n. of the verb in the phrase galaA fiY AlA^amori. (TA.)

gal~aAyapN *
A vessel of copper [or brass], in which water is heated; thus called by the people of Syria; the same that is called miHam~N [q. v.] and qumoqumN and qumoqumapN. (Msb voce qumoqumN.)

gaAliyapN * [Galia moschata,] a sort of perfume, (S, K,) well known; (K;) a certain compound of perfumes; (Msb;) musk mixed or boiled [with other perfumes]; (MA;) or a perfume composed of musk and ambergris and camphor and oil of ben: (KL:) it is said that the first who called it thus was Suleymán Ibn-'Abd-El-Melik; (S, TA;) and he did so because it is a compound boiled together upon the fire: or it was thus named by Mo'áwiyeh; the case being, that 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Jaafar went in to him, and the odour of perfume was diffusing itself from him; so he said, “ What is thy perfume, O 'Abd-Allah? ” and he answered, “ musk and ambergris combined with oil of ben; ” whereupon Mo'áwiyeh said, gaAliyapN, meaning highpriced: (TA:) [hence some hold the word to belong to art. glw; and their opinion is strengthened by the fact that] galowaY signifies the same. (K in art. glw.)

1 gam~ahu * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
gamu3a , (Msb,) inf. n. gam~N, (Msb, TA,) He covered it, (S, Msb, K, TA,) veiled it, or concealed it; (TA;) namely, a thing: (Msb, K, TA:) this is the primary meaning. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, gum~a AlhilaAlu (S, Msb, K, TA) EalaY Aln~aAsi, (S, TA,) inf. n. gam~N, (TA,) The new moon was veiled, or concealed, (S, Msb,) to the people, (S,) by clouds, or otherwise, (S, Msb,) or was intercepted by thin clouds, (K, TA,) or otherwise, (TA,) so that it was not seen. (S, Msb, TA.) It is said in a trad., faA_ino gum~a Ealayokumo faA^akomiluwA AlEid~apa, (Mgh, * Msb, TA,) i. e. And if it [the new moon] be veiled, &c., to you, then complete ye the reckoning of Shaabán, thirty [days], in order that the entering upon the fast of Ramadán may be with [inferential] knowledge. (Msb.) Az says that gum~a and A^ugomiYa and gumiYa all signify the same: (TA:) and all three occur in the trad. above mentioned accord. to different relations thereof. (Mgh.) [See also 1 in art. gmY.] ― -b2- And [hence] gam~a Alqamaru Aln~ujuwma The moon concealed the stars: or almost concealed the light of the stars. (TA.) ― -b3- And gum~a Ealayohi Alxabaru The information, or narration, was dubious, confused, or vague, to him; such as to be difficult to be understood; or such as not to be understood; (S, K;) like A^ugomiYa: (S:) or was obscure, or unapparent, to him. (Msb.) ― -b4- And gam~ahu, (S, K, TA,) aor.
gamu3a , inf. n. gam~N, (TA,) It (i. e. ham~ [here meaning “ grief, ” see gam~N below,]) covered [or was as though it covered] his heart: (Har p. 637:) or [accord. to common acceptation] it, or he, grieved him; or caused him to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy; syn. A^aHozanahu. (K, and Har p. 422. [See also 4.]) ― -b5- gam~ahu, in which the pronoun relates to an ass, &c., (S, K, TA,) aor.
gamu3a , inf. n. gam~N, (TA,) means He put [as a covering] to his mouth and his nostrils the ↓ gimaAmap, (S, K, TA,) which is a thing like the kiEaAm [or muzzle], (so in the S and CK,) or a thing like the fidaAm [which seems to be here similar in meaning to kEAm]: (so in other copies of the K:) or he put [as a covering] to his mouth a nose-bag, or the like, to prevent his feeding; and this is termed a ↓ gimaAmap: (TA:) [the verb that I have rendered “ put to ” in these explanations is A^aloqama, of which I do not find in its proper place any signification that would be exactly apposite in this case:] or ↓ gimaAmapN signifies a sort of bag for the mouth of a camel and the like, (K, TA,) his mouth being put into it: (TA:) pl. gamaAy^imu: (S, TA:) and one says, gam~ahu biAlgimaAmapi [he covered his mouth with the gmAmp], aor. and inf. n. as above. (TA.) ― -b6- gam~a Al$~aYo'a, aor.
gamu3a , also signifies EalaAhu [app. as meaning It rose upon, or above, the thing, as though forming a covering over it]: mentioned on the authority of IAar, who cites [as an ex.] the saying of En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab, [app. describing a rawoDap, or meadow,]
A^unufN yagum~u AlD~aAlu nabota biHaArihaA
[Not depastured, the trees called DAl rising upon, or above, the herbage of its fertile tracts, or its tracts near to water]. (TA.) See also 8. -A2- [gam~a is also intrans.: one says,] gam~a yawomunaA, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. gam~N and gumuwmN; (TA;) and ↓ A^agam~a; Our day was, or became, [sultry, or] intensely hot, (S, K, TA,) so that it took away, (S,) or almost took away, (TA,) the breath: (S, TA:) or both verbs, said of a day, and of the sky, mean it brought gam~ [or distress that affected the breath or respiration], arising from closeness of heat, or clouds. (Msb.) -A3- gam~a Al$~axoSu, of the class of taEiba, [the first pers. being gamimotu,] inf. n. gamamN, The person's hair of his head flowed down so that his forehead and the back of his neck were narrowed. (Msb.) [See also gamamN below.]

3 gaAmamotuhu * signifies gamamotuhu wagam~aniY [I grieved him, or caused him to mourn or lament &c., and he grieved me, or caused me to mourn or lament &c.; or I grieved him &c., being grieved &c. by him]. (K.)

4 Agm~t Als~amaA='u *
The sky became clouded: (K, as indicated by the context:) or i. q. tagay~arat [i. e., became altered]: thus in the S; but some say that it is correctly tagay~amat [agreeably with the former of the explanations above]. (TA.) See also 1, near the end. -A2- maA A^agam~aka liY and A_ilaY~a is [an expression of wonder, meaning How great grief, or sadness, dost thou occasion to me!] from Algam~u signifying AlHuzonu. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Accord. to the TK, A^agam~ahu signifies A^aHozanahu; like gam~ahu: but this I think a mistake. ― -b3- And Freytag explains A^agam~a as occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees signifying “ Demersit: ” but in which of its senses he uses this word he does not specify.]

6 tgAm~ *
He made a show of gam~ [or grief, &c.,] without its being in the heart. (Har p. 126.)

7 Angm~ *
It (a thing, K) was, or became, covered, (S, K, TA,) veiled, or concealed. (TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

8 Agtm~ *
He was, or became, grieved, or caused to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy; (S, * K;) as also ↓ Angm~: (K:) both mentioned by Sb. (TA.) ― -b2- And, said of a plant, or herbage, It was, or became, tall, (K, TA,) and tangled, or luxuriant, (TA,) and abundant: (K, TA:) as also AEtm~. (TA.) [And in like manner ↓ gam~a is expl. by Freytag as occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, said of a plant, meaning It was tall and luxuriant.] ― -b3- And, said of a man, He withheld himself from going out, or forth. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 gamogama * , [inf. n. gamogamapN, He (a bull) uttered a cry, or cries, in fright; as also ↓ tagamogama: see gamagomapN below. ― -b2- And] He (a courageous man) raised his voice conflict with his antagonist; (Har p. 531;) [as also ↓ tagamogama: see, again, gamogamapN below.] ― -b3- And He [a man] spoke while taking a thing into his fauces, so that the hearer, or listener, did not understand what he was saying; (Har ubi suprà;) [or spoke indistinctly; agreeably with an explanation of gamogamapN below; as also ↓ tagamogama. ― -b4- And, said of a bow, It produced a sound; agreeably with another explanation of gamogamapN below.] ― -b5- Also, said of an infant, inf. n. gamogamapN, He wept over the breast, desiring the milk: [and the inf. n. is used as a simple subst., and therefore pluralized:] IAar cites as an ex.,
A_i*aA AlmuroDiEaAtu baEoda A^aw~ali hajoEapK
↓ samiEota EalaY vudiy~ihin~a gamaAgimaA
[When the suckling women, after the first light sleep in the beginning of the night, are in such a condition that thou hearest cryings over their breasts]; meaning, as he says, that the milk of these women is little in quantity, so that the sucking child weeps over the breast when sucking it. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tagamogama * : see R. Q. 1, in three places: and see its inf. n. voce gamogamapN, below, in two places. ― -b2- Said of one drowning (gariyq) beneath the water, it signifies He uttered a cry, or cries: or, as is said in the T, he was pressed upon by the waves above him: a poet uses it of Pharaoh when he was overwhelmed [in the sea]. (TA.)

gam~N * [an inf. n. used as an epithet in which the
quality of a subst. predominates,] Grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness; syn. HuzonN; (Msb, K;) so called because it covers happiness and forbearance; (Msb;) or gam~ in the heart is thus called because it veils, or precludes, happiness: (Ham p. 21:) [it may therefore be rendered gloominess of mind:] or i. q. karobN, (K,) which signifies Huzon, (K in art. krb,) or gam~, (S, in that art.,) [that affects the breath or respiration, lit.] that takes away the breath; (S and K in that art.;) as also ↓ gam~aA='u (K) and ↓ gum~apN, (S, K,) the last [expl. in the S as syn. with kurobapN, which is syn. with karobN, and] mentioned by Lh: (TA:) [see also SaqaEN:] it is karob [or grief, &c.,] that befalls the heart because of what has happened; differing from ham~N, which is krb that befalls because of annoyance, or harm, that is expected to happen: or, as some say, both are one [in meaning]: the differing is asserted by 'Iyád and [many] others: (TA:) [see also gaSabN:] the pl. of gam~N is gumuwmN. (S, K.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. used as an epithet in the phrase yawomN gam~N (S, TA) i. e. A day that is [sultry, or] intensely hot, so that it [almost] takes away the breath; and layolapN gam~N [such a night], i. e. ↓ gaAm~apN: (S:) or one says yawomN gam~N and ↓ gaAm~N and ↓ migam~N, (K, TA,) the last with kesr to the m, (TA,) [in the CK ↓ mugim~N,] meaning a day of heat, (K,) or of intense heat: (TA:) or a day of gam~ [i. e. grief, &c.]: and [in a similar sense, as is implied by the context immediately preceding,] layolapN gam~N and gam~apN and ↓ gam~aY: (K:) [but] A'Obeyd mentions, on the authority of AZ, ↓ layolapN gam~aY and ↓ layolapN gam~apN as meaning a night in which there is over the sky [a covering of clouds, or] what is termed gamoYN [a word belonging to art. gmY, being in measure] like ramoYN; (S;) and [in the like sense] yawomN gam~N. (So in one of my copies of the S.) ― -b3- And one says, kaAna EalaY Als~amaA='i gm [app. gam~N, but this, I think, requires confirmation, for which I have searched in vain,] and gmY [app. ↓ gam~aY, or perhaps gamoYN, a word mentioned above,] meaning There was over the sky a collection [or an expanse] of thin clouds, or a DabaAbap [i. e. mist, or the like], faHaAla duwna AlhilaAli [and it intercepted the new moon]: and h`*ihi layolapu ↓ gam~aY, and some say ↓ gum~aY, This is a night [of a covering of clouds, or] of a DabaAbap [or mist, or the like], intervening between the new moon and men; so that the new moon is not seen: (Msb:) and [hence] ↓ SumonaA lilogam~aY, and ↓ lilogum~aY, (S, Msb, K,) both mentioned by ISk on the authority of Fr, (S,) and ↓ lilogam~aA='i, (S, K,) and ↓ lilogum~iy~api, (K, TA, but omitted in the CK,) and ↓ lilogum~api, (TA,) [i. e. We fasted after, or from the time of, the covering of clouds, or the mist, or the like, that concealed the new moon; (the prep. li being here used in the sense of baEoda, or mino waqoti, as in the Kur xvii. 80;) virtually] meaning [we fasted] without a sight [of the new moon]: (Msb, TA:) a rájiz says,
TaAmisK hilaAluhaA ↓ layolapa gum~aY
A^awogalotuhaA wamukorapN A_iyogaAluhaA
[In a night of a covering of clouds, or of a mist, or the like, having its new moon effaced: I journeyed quickly and far in it, (A^awogalotuhaA) being used, app. by poetic license, for A^awogalotu fiyhaA,) and disliked was the journeying so therein]: (S, TA:) and it is said that layolapu gm~Y [i. e. ↓ gam~aY and ↓ gum~aY] signifies also the last night of the [lunar] month; being so called because the case thereof is veiled to people so that it is not known whether it be of the coming [month] or of the past. (TA.)
gam~apN * fem. of gam~N, q. v., used as an epithet.

gum~apN * : see gam~N, first sentence: ― -b2- and also in the latter half. ― -b3- Also, (assumed tropical:) Perplexity, and dubiousness, or confusedness: pl. gumamN: one says, huwa fiY gum~apK (assumed tropical:) He is in a state of perplexity, and dubiousness, or confusedness: (Msb:) and huwa fiY gum~apK mino A^amorihi (assumed tropical:) He is in a state of perplexity and darkness [in respect of his case or affair]; from Algam~u signifying “ the act of covering ” [a thing]. (Ham p. 320.) [See also gim~apN and gam~aA='u.] And one says A^amorN gum~apN (assumed tropical:) A dubious, confused, or vague, case or affair. (S, K. *) [See also gum~aY.] It is said in the Kur [x. 72], vum~a laA yakuno A^amorukumo Ealayokumo gum~apF i. e. (tropical:) [Then let not your case be to you one of] darkness, and straitness, and anxiety: (A'Obeyd, S, TA:) or, as some say, covered, veiled, or concealed. (TA.) And A^aroDN gum~apN means (assumed tropical:) A strait, or narrow, land. (TA.) ― -b4- Also The bottom of the interior of a skin for clarified butter (S, K) &c. (S.) [See also the first sentence in art. gml.]

gim~apN *
i. q. lbsp [app. lubosapN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Obscureness, confusedness, or dubiousness: see also gum~apN]. (TA.)

gamamN * is the inf. n. of 1 in the last of the senses expl. above: (Msb:) or it signifies The flowing down of the hair so that the forehead, (S, K, TA,) or as in the M, the face, (TA,) and the back of the neck, are narrowed: (S, K, TA:) or the hair that veils, or conceals, the jabiyn [generally meaning the part above the temple, but sometimes it means the forehead,] and the back of the neck. (Har p. 21.) Z says that they dislike what is thus termed, and like what is termed nazaEN [i. e. baldness of the two sides of the forehead]. (TA.)

gamaAmN *
Clouds: (S, Msb, K:) or white clouds: (K:) or thin clouds: (Jel in ii. 54:) and ↓ gamaAmapN signifies one thereof: (S, Msb, K:) the former being pl. of the latter, as also is gamaAy^imu: (K:) [or rather gamaAmN is a coll. gen. n., of which gamaAmapN is the n. un.:] they are so called because they veil the sky, or because they veil the light of the sun. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Hab~u AlgamaAmi signifies Hailstones, or hail. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. An, p. 109.]

gumaAmN *
i. q. zukaAmN [A rheum, such as is termed coryza]. (K.)
gumuwmN * [a pl. of which no sing. is mentioned,] Small stars, such as are faint, or indistinct. (K.)

gamiymN *
i. q. gamiysN, (S, K,) i. e. Fresh herbage (kalaA^N) beneath such as is dried up; (S, TA;) or green herbage beneath such as is dry. (TA.) ― -b2- And Milk heated until it thickens: (S, K:) because it becomes covered over. (TA.)

gamaAmapN * : see gamaAmN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Herbage: so in the saying, A^aHomaY fulaAnN gamaAmapa waAdiY ka*aA i. e. (tropical:) [Such a one made to be prohibited to the public] the herbage that was the growth of such a valley: thus called [because produced by the water of the clouds,] in like manner as it is called samaA='N. (TA.)
gumaAmapN * : see the next paragraph.

gimaAmapN * : see 1, near the middle, in three places. ― -b2- Also A thing with which the eyes of a she-camel are bound, or with which her muzzle is bound: (K:) or a piece of cloth with which the nose of a she-camel is stopped (yusad~u) [or bound (yu$ad~u)] when she is made to incline to the young one of another: pl. gamaAy^imu. (A'Obeyd, TA.) [See also darojapN: and SiqaAEN.] ― -b3- And (by way of comparison [thereto], TA) (tropical:) The prepare of a boy; as also ↓ gumaAmapN. (K, TA.)

gam~aY * : see gam~N, in six places. ― -b2- Also Dust; syn. gabarapN. (K.) ― -b3- And Darkness. (K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Hardship, or difficulty, or distress, [as though] covering [or overwhelming] a party in war, or battle. (K.) See also the next paragraph.

gum~aY * : see gam~N, latter half, in four places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune; and so ↓ gam~aA='u; (K, TA;) and ↓ gum~aA='u, likewise, is said to be allowable. (TA. [But this last I think doubtful.]) And (assumed tropical:) A hard, or difficult, affair or case, in relation to which one knows not the right course to pursue; as also ↓ gam~aY, (K, TA,) and ↓ gam~aA='u. (TA.)

gam~aA='u * [fem. of A^agam~N, q. v.: ― -b2- and also used as a subst.]: see gam~N, first sentence: ― -b3- and also in the latter half: ― -b4- and see also gum~aY, in two places. ― -b5- A_in~ahumo lafiY gam~aA='a mina AlA^amori means [Verily they are in a state of dubiousness, or confusedness, in respect of the case, or affair; or] in a dubious, or confused, case or affair. (TA.) [See also gum~apN and gim~apN.]
gum~aA='u * : see gum~aY.
gum~iy~apN * : see gam~N, latter half.
gaAm~N * , and its fem. gaAm~apN: see gam~N, former half.

gamogamapN * [mentioned above as an inf. n. (see
R. Q. 1), used as a simple subst.,] signifies The cries [or cry] of bulls [or wild bulls] in fright: (S, K, TA:) and of courageous men in conflict: (S, Mgh, K, TA:) and so ↓ tagamogumN: pl. of the former, in both senses, gamaAgimu. (TA.) See also an ex. of the pl. voce gamogama. ― -b2- And Indistinct speech; (K;) as also ↓ tagamogumN: (S, K:) gamogamapN is when one hears the voice but does not distinguish the articulation of the words; and when speech resembles that of the Eajam. (T, in TA, voce rut~apN.) ― -b3- Also The sound of bows. (TA.)

rajulN A^agam~N * , (S,) and A^agam~u Alwajohi waAlqafaA, (S, Msb, K,) A man whose hair flows down so that the face and the back of the neck are narrowed: (S, Msb, K:) and in like manner [the fem.] gam~aA='u is applied to a woman. (Msb.) ― -b2- gam~aA='u applied to the forelock (naASiyap) of a horse means Excessively abundant in the hair: and such is disliked. (S.) ― -b3- And saHaAbN A^agam~N means (tropical:) Clouds in which is no gap, or interstice. (K, TA.)
mugim~N * and migam~N: see gam~N, former half. ― -b2- A^aroDN mugim~apN (K, TA) and migam~apN (TA) A land having abundant (K, TA) and dense or luxuriant (TA) herbage. (K, TA.)

mugam~imN * , applied to clouds (gayom), and to a sea, Abounding with water: (K:) and in like manner, without p, to a well (rakiy~ap), that fills everything, and submerges it: (IAar, TA:) and to what is termed HisoYN [q. v.], (IAar, S, TA,) meaning covering. (IAar, TA.)

magomuwmN * [pass. part. n. of gam~ahu, i. e. Covered, &c.]. ― -b2- [Applied to unripe dates (accord. to the TA to ruTab, a mistranscription for busor), like magomuwlN,] Put into a jar, and covered over until they have become ripe. (TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a new moon, Veiled, or concealed, by clouds, or otherwise, (Msb,) or intercepted by thin clouds, (K,) so as not to be seen. (Msb.) ― -b4- Applied to a man, Grieved, or caused to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy. (TA.) ― -b5- And Affected with the malady termed gumaAm. (K.)

1 gamatahu * , aor.
gamita , (S, O, K,) inf. n. gamotN, (S, O,) It (i. e. food) was, or became, heavy upon his heart [or stomach], (Ks, S, O, K,) he having eaten much thereof so that it caused him to suffer indigestion, (Ks, O,) and it rendered him like one intoxicated: (K:) or, accord. to Sh, it (i. e. grease) rendered him like one intoxicated, (O, TA,) in consequence of indigestion. (TA.) ― -b2- And He covered it; (O, K;) namely, a thing. (K.) ― -b3- And gamatahu fiY AlmaA='i i. q. gaT~ahu [i. e. He immersed, or plunged, him, or it, into the water; like gat~ahu]. (IDrd, O, K.) ― -b4- And gamata nafasFA He made a sign, or motion, with' his head, (O,) or he raised his head, (K,) [for the purpose of taking breath,] in drinking. (O, K.) -A2- gamita He became like one intoxicated, by grease [in his stomach]: (Sh, O:) or he suffered from the heaviness of food upon his heart [or stomach] so that he became like one intoxicated. (K.)

1 gamadahu * , aor.
gamida and
gamuda , inf. n. gumodN; and ↓ Agmdhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_igomaAdN; (Msb;) mentioned by AO, (S,) or by A'Obeyd, (L, TA,) as two chaste forms; (S, L, TA;) He put it (i. e. a sword, S, Msb, K, or the like, Msb) into its gimod [i. e. scabbard, or sheath; he sheathed it]: (S, Msb, K:) or he made for it, or furnished it with, a gimod. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, gamadahu bika*aA (tropical:) He covered him, or it, with such a thing; as though he made the latter a gimod to the former. (A.) ― -b3- See also 5, in two places. -A2- gamada, inf. n. gumuwdN, said of a tree of the species called EurofuT, (assumed tropical:) It had its branches abounding with leaves so that one could not see its thorns; (L, K;) as though they were sheathed. (L.) ― -b2- gamadati Alr~akiy~apu, (L, K,) aor.
gamuda , inf. n. gumuwdN, (L,) (tropical:) The well lost its water. (L, K.) ― -b3- And gamidat, (L, K,) aor.
gamada , (K,) inf. n. gamadN, (L,) (tropical:) It (a well) had much water: (As, L, K:) or it had little water. (AO, L, K.)
2 gam~ada see 5, in two places.

4 A^agomada see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] Agmd AlA^a$oyaA='a (tropical:) He put the things one within another. (K.) ― -b3- And Agmd AlHilosa (tropical:) He put the [cloth called] Hilos beneath the camel's saddle, to preserve the animal's back from being galled by the saddle. (Akh, A, * L.)

5 tgm~d Alv~awoba * (tropical:) He put the garment, or piece of cloth, beneath him, to conceal it from the eyes of others. (A.) ― -b2- And tgm~dAlr~ajula, (JK, L,) and ↓ gm~dhu, (L,) (assumed tropical:) He took the man beneath him (taHotahu, thus in the JK, in the L bixatolK [by deceit, or guile]), to cover him over, or conceal him. (JK, L.) ― -b3- And tgm~d fulaAnFA, (S, L, K,) and ↓ gm~dhu, (K,) (tropical:) He concealed, as with a veil, what had proceeded from such a one, or what such a one had done. (S, L, K.) ― -b4- And tgm~dhu A@ll~`hu biraHomatihi, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and bihaA ↓ gamadahu and fiyhaA ↓ gamadahu, (L,) (tropical:) God covered him with his mercy, (A'Obeyd, S, A, L, Msb, K,) as with a veil; veiled him therewith; (A'Obeyd, A, L, Msb;) clad him, or invested him, therewith. (A'Obeyd, L.) ― -b5- tgm~d AlA^aEodaA='a (assumed tropical:) He threw himself upon the enemies; or came upon them, or over them; and overwhelmed them. (L.) ― -b6- And tgm~dhu (tropical:) He filled it, (A, K,) namely, a measure of capacity, (A,) or a vessel. (K.)

8 Agtmd All~ayola * (tropical:) He (a man, S, L) entered into [the darkness of] the night; (S, A, L, K;) as though it became as a gimod to him; like as one says Aid~araEa All~ayola: (S, L:) and simply Agtmd he ventured upon, encountered, or braved, the night, (rakibahu,) to seek food for his family. (S, L.)
10 Aisotagomadati Als~amaA='u fiY Als~aHaAbi Alkaviyri * (assumed tropical:) [The sky became obscured amid the many clouds]. (TA in art. Tnfs.)

gimodN * (S, L, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ gumud~aAnN, (L, K,) but the latter is not of established authority, (IDrd,) of a sword, (S, L, Msb, K,) and the like, (Msb,) The scabbard, or sheath; [this is well known to be the correct meaning; it is shown to be so in the S, voce qiraAbN; and is the meaning obtaining in the present day;] syn. gilaAfN, (S, O,) or jafonN: (L, K:) [both of these words have the signification mentioned above; but not that only; for glAf has a wider application; and it is said in the S, voce qiraAbN, that the jfn of a sword is a case, or receptacle, in which is (put) the sword together with its gimod and suspensory belt or cord:] the pl. is A^agomaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] (O, Msb, K) and gumodaAnN, (O,) or gumuwdN. (K.)
gumud~aAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

rakiY~N gaAmidN * , a phrase like Eiy$apN raADiyapN, [gaAmidN meaning magomuwdN,] (tropical:) Wells having their water covered by earth, or dust; contr. of rakiY~N mubodK. (A.) And gaAmidapN (tropical:) A well (biy^orN) filled up, or choked up, with earth, or dust. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And gaAmidapN and gaAmidN (assumed tropical:) A ship (safiynapN) filled, or laden; (K, TA;) as also A=midapN (TA) and A=midN. (K, TA.)
mugomadN * : see what here follows.
magomuwdN * and ↓ mugomadN A sword [or the like] put into its gimod [meaning scabbard, or sheath; i. e. sheathed]. (S, A.)

1 gamura * , as in some lexicons, or gamara, aor.
gamura , accord. to all the copies of the K [consulted by SM], (TA,) or gamira, [aor.
gamara ,] (as in the CK and my MS. copy of the K,) inf. n. gamaArapN and gumuwrapN, [agreeably with analogy if gamura be the form of the verb, which is therefore most probably correct,] (K,) It (water) was, or became, much in quantity, abundant, copious, [or deep,] (K, B, TA,) so that it concealed its bottom. (B, TA.) You say maA A^a$ad~a gumuwrapa h`*aA Aln~ahori How great is the abundance of the water of this river ! (S.) ― -b2- [And (tropical:) He abounded in beneficence.] You say rajulN bay~inu Algumuwrapi (tropical:) A man bearing evidence of abounding in beneficence. (S, K.) -A2- gamarahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
gamura , (S, Msb,) inf. n. gamorN, (Msb, K,) It (water, S, K, or the sea, Msb) [overflowed,] came over, or rose above, (S, Msb,) or covered, (K,) and concealed, (TA,) him, or it; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Agtmrhu: (K:) and he (a man) veiled, concealed, hid, or covered, him, or it. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, gamarahu Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people rose above him, or surpassed him, in eminence, (S, TA,) and in excel-lence. (TA.) ― -b3- And raA^ayotuhu qado gamara AljamaAjima biTuwli qawaAmihi (assumed tropical:) [I saw him to have overtopped the heads of others by the tallness of his stature]. (TA.) -A3- gamira Sadoruhu EalaY~a, aor.
gamara , (S, Msb, K, *) inf. n. gamarN (Yaakoob, S, Msb) and gimorN, (Yaakoob, S,) [or the latter is a simple subst.,] His bosom bore con-
cealed enmity and violent hatred, or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against me. (S, Msb, K.) -A4- gamirato yaduhu, (S, K,) aor.
gamara , (K,) inf. n. gamarN, (TA,) His hand was, or became, foul with the smell of flesh-meat, (S, K,) and with the grease thereof adhering to it. (K.) -A5- gamura, aor.
gamura , (S, Msb,) inf. n. gamaArapN, (S, [in my copy of the Msb written gamaAr, probably by a mistake of the copyist,]) He was inexperienced in affairs: (S, Msb:) Benoo-'Okeyl say gamira, aor.
gamara . (Msb.) You say fiyhi gamaArapN and garaArapN [In him is a want of experience in affairs]. (TA.)

2 gm~rt wajohahaA * , inf. n. tagomiyrN, She (a woman) smeared her face with gumorap [q. v.]; (S;) as also biAlgumorapi ↓ Agtmrt, (K,) and ↓ tgm~rt. (S, K.) -A2- gum~ira, inf. n. tagomiyrN, He (a man) was deemed ignorant. (TA.) -A3- gm~r farasahu, inf. n. as above, He gave his horse water to drink in a cup, (K,) in the small cup called gumar, (TA,) because of the scarcity of water. (K.) IAar mentions the phrase gm~rhu A^aSoHunFA He gave him to drink some bowls of water: making the verb doubly transitive. (TA.)

3 gAmr fiY AlqitaAli * and gAms fiyhi signify the same [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He plunged, or threw himself, into the midst of fight, or conflict]. (TA in art. gms.) [See also mugaAmirN.] ― -b2- And gAmrhu (assumed tropical:) He engaged with him in fight, or conflict, not caring for death. (S, O.) ― -b3- And gAmr signifies also (assumed tropical:) He contended in an altercation, or a dispute. (O.)

5 tgm~rt * : see 2. -A2- tgm~r He drank from a small cup such as is called gumar: (K:) he drank a small quantity of water: (TA:) he drank less than would satisfy his thirst: (S:) he drank the smallest draught, less than would satisfy his thirst: (TA:) he did not satisfy his thirst with water; (K, * TA;) said of a camel, (K,) and of an ass. (TA.) -A3- And tgm~rt AlmaA$iyapu The cattle ate what is termed gamiyr [q. v.]. (K.)

7 Angmr *
He immerged, dipped, or plunged, himself, or he became immerged, dipped, or plunged, (S, K,) in water, (S, TA,) and in a thing; (TA;) as also ↓ Agtmr. (K.)
8 A_igotamara see 1: -A2- and 7: -A3- and 2.

gamorN *
Much, abundant, copious, [or deep,] water; (S, K;) as also ↓ gamiyrN: (K:) or much, abundant, copious, [or deep,] water, that drowns, or submerges: (ISd, TA:) or that covers over him who enters into it: (IAth, TA:) [also used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, meaning much, abundant, copious, or deep, water;] and ↓ gamorapN signifies the same as gamorN [when thus used; or a submerging deep, a deep place, or an abyss, of water]: (TA:) pl. gimaArN and gumuwrN. (S, K.) You say baHorN gamorN An abundant sea: and [in the pl.] biHaArN gimaArN, and gumuwrN. (S.) And of a thing that has become much, you say, h`*aA kaviyrN ↓ gamiyrN This is much. (AZ.) [See also Algamari.] ― -b2- The main of the sea: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.) -A2- (tropical:) Liberal in disposition: (K, * TA:) pl. as above: (TA:) and in like manner, gamoru Alxuluqi: (TA:) or this last, and gamoru Albadiyhapi, signify (tropical:) abounding in beneficence: pl. as above: (S, K: [see also ridaA='N:]) and gamoru Albadiyhapi (tropical:) a man who takes by surprise with large bounty. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A horse fleet, or swift, or excellent, in running. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A garment ample, or full. (K, * TA.) -A3- (assumed tropical:) A mixed crowd of men, (K,) and their thronging, pressing, or pushing, and multitude; (TA;) as also ↓ gamarN and ↓ gamorapN and ↓ gumaArN and ↓ gamaArN: (K: [in the TA, instead of the last two words, I find gumaArapN and gamaArapN, as from the K, and gumaArN and gamaArN are afterwards there added: but most probably these only (without p) are correct:]) and ↓ gamorapN and ↓ gumaArN and ↓ gamaArN signify a crowding, or pressing, of men, (S, Msb,) and of water: (S:) the pl. of ↓ gamorapN is gimaArN. (S.) You say Aln~aAsi ↓ daxalotu fiY gumaAri, and ↓ gamaArihimo, (S, Msb, TA,) and ↓ gamarihimo, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) I entered among the crowding, or pressing, of the people, (S, Msb, TA,) and their multitude: (S, TA;) as also fY xamarihimo [and xumaArihimo &c.] (TA.) And ↓ A^akuwnu fiY gumaAri Aln~aAsi, meaning I shall be among the dense congregation of the people, occurs in a trad. (TA.) -A4- See also gumorN. -A5- layolN gamorN means Intensely dark night. (TA.)

gumorN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ gumurN (S, ISd) and ↓ gamorN and ↓ gimorN, accord. to the K, but this last is unknown, (TA,) and ↓ gamarN (K) and ↓ gamirN, (TA,) originally, A boy devoid of intelligence: and hence, (Msb,) a man (S, Msb) inexperienced in affairs: (S, Msb, K:) ignorant: (TA:) inexperienced in war and in counsel; not rendered firm, or sound, in judgment, by experience: (L:) one in whom is no profit nor judgment: (ISd, TA:) one in whom is no good nor profit with respect to intelligence or judgment or work: (AZ, Msb:) and ↓ mugam~arN signifies the same as gumorN; (S, TA;) or deemed ignorant: (TA:) the fem. of gumorN is with p; (S, Msb;) and so is that of ↓ gamirN: (TA:) and the pl. of gumorN is A^agomaArN; (S, Msb, TA;) and this may also be pl. of ↓ gamarN, like as A^asobaAbN is pl. of sababN. (TA.) -A2- See also gumorapN.

gimorN *
Concealed enmity and violent hatred, or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (S, Msb, K.) [See also gamira.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Thirst: (S, Msb:) pl. A^agomaArN. (S.) El-'Ajjáj says,
Hat~aY A_i*aA maAbal~ati AlA^agomaAraA
(tropical:) [Until, when they damped their thirst]. (S.) bal~ati AlA_ibilu A^agomaArahaA means (tropical:) The camels drank a little. (TA.) -A2- See also gumorN.

gamarN *
A drowning; being drowned: so in the phrase mawotu Algamari Death by drowning. (TA.) -A2- See also gamorN. -A3- The foul smell of flesh-meat, (S, Mgh, K,) and its grease adhering to the hand: (K:) and the smell of fish. (S.) Hence, minodiylu Algamari (S, Mgh) The napkin, or rough napkin, with which the hand is cleansed therefrom. (L, TA.) -A4- See also gumorN, in two places.

gamirN * [part. n. of gamira]. You say yadN gamirapN A hand foul with the smell of flesh-meat, (S, K,) and with the grease thereof adhering to it. (K.) [See also sahikN.] -A2- See also gumorN, in two places. -A3- gamirapN as an epithet applied to a she-camel, see voce gabirN.

gumarN *
A small drinking-cup or bowl, (S, K,) with which people divided the water among themselves in a journey when they had little of it; and this they [sometimes] did by putting a pebble into a vessel, and then pouring into it as much water as would cover the pebble, and giving it to each man among them: (TA:) or the smallest of drinking-cups or bowls: (K:) [see qaEobN; and tibonN:] accord. to ISh, it contains twice or thrice the quantity of the measure called kiylajap: [but this seems to be a large gmr, used for watering a horse; and the words which here immediately follow are app. not added by ISh, but relate to the gmr used by a man for himself or for another man:] the qaEob is larger than it, and satisfies the thirst of a man: the pl. is A^agomaArN. (TA.) El-Aashà of Báhileh says, in an elegy on his brother ElMunteshir Ibn-Wahb,
takofiyhi Huz~apu filo*K A_ino A^alom~a bihaA
mina Al$~iwaA='i wayurowiY $urobahu Algumaru
[A slice of camel's liver, roasted, if he lighted upon it, used to suffice him; and the gumar used to satisfy his thirst]. (S, TA.) And Mohammad is related, in a trad., to have said, laA tajoEaluwniY kagumari Alr~aAkibi Sal~uwA EalaY A^aw~ala Ald~uEaA='i waA^awosaTahu waA=xirahu Make ye me not like the gumar of the rider: salute me in the beginning of prayer and in the middle thereof and in the end thereof: meaning that they should not make the salutation of him to be a thing of no great importance, and to be postponed: for the rider puts on his camel his saddle and his travel-ling-provisions, and last of all hangs upon his saddle his drinking-cup. (IAth, TA.)
gumurN * : see gumorN.

gamorapN *
Water that rises above the stature of a man. (Bd in xxiii. 56.) See also gamorN, first sentence. ― -b2- Hence, (Bd,) fa*arohumo fiY gamoratihimo, in the Kur xxiii. 56, (tropical:) Therefore leave thou them in [the submerging gulf, or flood, of] their ignorance; (Fr, Bd;) or in their error: (Jel:) or in their error and obstinacy and perplexity: (Zj, in explanation of another reading, fY gamaraAtihimo:) and in like manner, fiY gamorapN, in the same chap., verse 65, signifies in overwhelming heedlessness: (Bd:) or in ignorance: (Jel:) and in the Kur li. 11, in overwhelming ignorance: (Bd, Jel:) or gamorapN signifies [here] a state of obstinate perseverance in vain or false affairs: (Lth, Msb, TA:) and gamaraAtN is the pl. (Msb.) You say huwa fiY gamorapK mino lahowK, and $abiybapK, and sukorK, (tropical:) [He is in a submerging gulf, or flood, of frivolous diversion, and of youthful folly, and of intoxication]. (TA.)
And gamaraAtu jahan~ama signifies [The fiery depths of Hell; or] the places, of Hell, that abound with fire. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence] gamorapu AlxuSuwmapi (assumed tropical:) The main part of the contention. (TA.) [And gamorapu AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) The main part, i. e. the thick, or thickest, of the fight or battle. (See also gamaraAtu AlHarobi in what follows.)] ― -b4- Hence likewise, gamorapN signifies also (tropical:) Difficulty, trouble, distress, or rigour, (S, Msb, K,) and pressure, of a thing: (K:) pl. gamaraAtN (S, Msb, K) and gimaArN (K) and gumarN. (S.) Hence, (Msb,) gamaraAtu Almawoti (tropical:) The rigours, or pangs, ($adaAy^idu,) of death: (S, Msb:) or gamorapu Almawoti signifies the agony, i. e. the vehemence of the troubles or disquietudes, of death: (TA:) and gamaraAtu AlHarobi, and gimaAruhaA, (assumed tropical:) the rigours of war. (TA.) ― -b5- See also gamorN again, latter half, in three places.

gumorapN *
A kind of liniment, made from [the plant called] waros, (S, TA,) used by a bride, for her person: (TA:) or [the plant] wrs [itself]: (TA:) or saffron; as also ↓ gumorN: (K:) or kurokumN [which also means saffron and bastard saffron]: or gypsum; syn. jiS~N: or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, a mixture of dates and milk, with which the face of a woman is smeared, to render her skin fine: and the pl. is gumarN. (TA.) [See also xumorapN.]
gmrp * , [thus in the TA, app. gumarapN, of the class of SuraEapN &c.,] as an epithet applied to a man, Valid in judgment or opinion, in cases of difficulty. (TA.)
gamaArN * : see gamorN, latter half, in three places.
gumaArN * : see gamorN, latter half, in four places.

gamiyrN * : see gamorN, in two places. -A2- Also A certain plant: (K:) or green herbage that is overtopped, or covered, and concealed, by what is dried up: (S, K: *) or herbage growing in the lower part, or at the root, of [other] herbage, (K, * TA,) so that the first [in growth] overtops, or covers, and conceals, it: (TA:) or any verdure that is little in quantity, (L, K, TA,) either ryHp [i. e. ray~iHap, meaning what becomes green after the upper parts have dried,] or nbAt [app. meaning herbage in general]: (L, TA:) or the grain of the [species of barley-grass called] buhomaY, (K, TA,) that falls from the ears thereof when it dries; so says AHn: or somewhat that comes forth in the buhomaY in the first of the rain, succulent, or sappy, amid such as is dry; and gamiyr is not known in anything but the buhomaY: (TA:) the pl. is A^agomiraA='u. (K.) ↓ gamiyrapN [is app. its n. un., but] is said by AO to mean Dry [trefoil, or clover, of the species called] raTobap and qat~, with which horses are foddered when they are prepared, by being reduced to scanty food, for racing or for a military expedition. (TA.)
gamiyrapN * : see what next precedes.

gaAmirN *
Much, or abundant: applied in this sense to property. (Ham p. 593.) [See also gamorN.] -A2- [In a state of immersion; immerged. (See A^ataAnN; and see also a verse cited voce A^ano, p. 106, first col.)] ― -b2- And [hence, perhaps,] gaAmirapN signifies Palm-trees (naxolN) not requiring irrigation: (AHn, K:) but Az did not find this to be known. (TA.) [See also mugotamirN.] ― -b3- Applied to land, (S, Msb, TA,) and to a house, (TA,) [but written with p when A^aroDN is mentioned, or daArN,] it signifies the Contr. of EaAmirN; (S, TA;) and thus, (TA,) waste; desolate; in a state the contrary of flourishing; in a state of ruin; syn. xaraAbN: (Msb, K, TA:) [land to which this term is applied is thus called] because overflowed by water, so that it cannot be sown; or because it is covered with sand or dust; or because water generally exudes from it, so that it produces only reeds and the barodiY~ [i. e. papyrus or other rushes]: by gaAmirN is meant *uw gamorK; like as one says ham~N naASibN, meaning *uw naSabK: (TA:) or any land that is not tilled (lamo yusotaxorajo) so as to be fit for sowing (K, TA) and planting: (TA:) or land that is unsown, but capable of being sown: so called because the water reaches it and comes over it: of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (S, Msb;) like the epithets in sir~N kaAtimN and maA='N daAfiqN; and made of the measure fAl only to correspond to EaAmirN as its opposite: (S, TA:) waste land which water does not reach is not called gaAmirN; (S;) but such is called qaforN. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., [which shows that the last two explanations given above are correct,] that 'Omar imposed a tax of a diroham and a qafiyz upon every jariyb [of land], both EaAmir and gaAmir: and this he did in order that the people might not be remiss in sowing. (Az, TA.)

A^agomaru * [More, or most, abundant, copious, or deep: applied to water. ― -b2- ] More, or most surpassing, or excelling: so in the saying, huwa A^agomaruhumo biTuwli qawaAmihi He is the most surpassing of them by the tallness of his stature. (TA.)

mugam~arN * A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with [gumorap, or] saffron. (M, TA.) ― -b2- mugom~arapN and ↓ mutagam~irapN and ↓ mugotamirapN A girl having her face smeared with gumorap. (TA.) -A2- See also gumorN.
mugam~irN * : see mugaAmirN.

magomwurN * [Overflowed, or covered, and concealed, by water, &c. ― -b2- ] Rained upon. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Overcome, subdued, or oppressed. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) An obscure man; of no reputation: (K, TA:) as though others surpassed him. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN mgomuwru Aln~`asabi (assumed tropical:) Such a one is of obscure race. (TA.)

mugaAmirN * (assumed tropical:) One who plunges, or rushes without consideration, into places of peril: (S:) one who throws himself into difficulties, troubles, or distresses; as also ↓ mugam~irN: (K:) or one who enters into difficulties, troubles, or distresses, and makes another, or others, to do so; like mugaAmisN. (Ham p. 338.) Applied to a courageous man as meaning (assumed tropical:) One who incurs the rigours, or pangs, of death. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) One who contends in an altercation, or a dispute: or who enters into the main part [or the thick or thickest] of an altercation or a dispute: and some say that it is from Algimoru, and means regarding, and regarded, with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (TA.)

mugotamirN * Palm-trees (naxolN) imbibing water from a copious source. (AHn, K.) [See also gaAmirapN, voce gaAmirN.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A drunken man: (Sgh, K, TA:) as though intoxication had drowned his reason. (TA.) -A2- See also mugam~arN.
mutagam~irapN * : see mugam~arN.

1 gamazahu * , (S, A, K,) or gamazahu biyadihi, (Msb,) aor.
gamiza , (Msb, K,) inf. n. gamozN, (TA,) He felt him, (namely, a ram,) to know if he were fat: (S, A, Msb, K:) and gamazahaA he put his hand upon her (a camel's) back, to see how fat she was. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) gamazahu biyadihi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
gamiza , (K,) inf. n. gamozN, (A, K,) He pressed, or squeezed, it, [with his hand,] namely, a limb, (A, K, TA,) and a man's back. (TA.) So in a trad. of 'Omar: daxala Ealayohi waEinodahu gulayomN yagomizu Zahorahu [He went in to him, and with him was a little boy pressing, or squeezing, or kneading, his back]. (TA.) And in a trad. respecting the ablution termed Algusol, it is said, AigomiziY quruwnaki, meaning Press thou, or squeeze thou, the locks of thy hair, in washing. (TA.) You also say, gamaza Alv~iqaAfu AlqanaApa The straightening-instrument pinched and pressed the spear. (A, * Mgh, TA. *) A poet (namely Ziyád El-Aajam, TA) says,
wakunotu A_i*aA gamazotu qanaApa qawomK
kasarotu kuEuwbahaA A^awo tasotaqiymaA
[And I used, when I pinched and pressed the spear of a people, to break its knots, or internodal portions, unless it became straight]. (S, TA. It is a prov., respecting which see remarks in art. Aw.) -A2- gamaza, (A, Msb,) and gamazahu, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
gamiza , (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. gamozN, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He made a sign, (A, Msb,) and he made a sign to him, (Mgh, K, *) with the eye, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or eyebrow, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or eyelid [by winking]. (K.) So in the saying, in a trad., gamazaniY EaliY~N A^ano qulo naEamo (tropical:) '4lee made a sign to me with the eye, or eyebrow, meaning, Say thou Yes. (Mgh.) The people of the West say, gamazahu fulaAnN bifulaAnK, meaning, (tropical:) Such a one blinked towards such a one, to instigate him against him, or in order that he should have recourse to him for protection or the like, or seek aid of him. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, Algamozu biAln~aAsi: (S:) you say, gamaza biAlr~ajuli, aor.
gamiza , (K,) inf. n. gamozN, (TA,) (tropical:) He calumniated, or slandered, the man. (K.) [See also 4.] ― -b3- You say also, gumizato $ahaAdatahu
[(assumed tropical:) His testimony was suspected (see magomuwzN), or impugned]. (TA in art. zwr.) -A3- gamazati Ald~aAb~apu, (K,) or gamaza fiY ma$oyihi, (Msb,) or mino rijolihi, (S,) aor.
gamiza , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. gamozN, (S, Msb,) (assumed tropical:) The beast limped, or it halted, with its hind leg; had a slight lameness thereof: (K, * TA:) or he had what resembled Earaj [or natural lameness] in his gait: (Msb:) or, as IKtt says, gamazati Ald~aAb~apu birijolihaA the beast gave an indication of a limping, or halting, or slight lameness, in its hind leg: whence it appears that this signification may be tropical. (TA.) -A4- gamaza said of a disease, or of a vice, or fault, of a man, It appeared. (AA, K.) -A5- See also 4.

3 gaAomaza [This verb is mentioned by Golius as syn. with EAyb, a verb for which I find no authority: and Freytag renders it “ Vitii arguit, ” and refers to a passage in Har (p. 427 of the see. ed.) where (like as is done by Golius) AlmugAmiz and AlmuEAyib, as syn., are erroneously put for AlmagAmiz and AlmaEAyib.]

4 A^agomazato *
She (a camel) had fat, (O, K,) or a little fat, (ISd, IKtt, TA,) in her hump. (ISd, IKtt, O, K.) Hence the epithet ↓ gamuwzN, applied to her. (TA.) -A2- Agmz fiY fulaAnK (tropical:) He blamed, or found fault with, such a one; attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, or fault; (S, IKtt, K, TA;) deemed him weak; (TA;) lessened his rank, or dignity: (S, IKtt, K, * TA:) he found in him that for which he should be deemed weak: (A, TA:) and ↓ Agtmzhu he impugned his character; blamed him; censured him; or spoke against him. (K.) You say, fulaAnN ↓ faEalotu $ayoy^FA fA@gotamazahu (tropical:) I did a thing, and such a one impugned my character, or found in it that by which my character was impugned. (S, TA.) And samiEa min~iY kalimapF fiY Eaqolihi ↓ faA@gotamazahaA (tropical:) He heard from me a saying, and deemed it weak: (A, TA:) and in like manner, A^agomaza fiyhaA found in it that for which it was to be deemed weak. (TA.) -A3- A^agomazaniY AlHar~u (tropical:) The heat remitted, or abated, to me, so that I became emboldened to encounter it, and went upon the road: (AA, ISk, S, IKtt, K, * TA:) Az says ↓ gamazaniY AlHar~u, on the authority of AA: (TA:) and AA mentioned AgmrnY AlHr~ in this sense, but afterwards doubted, and said, I think that it is with zAY. (TA in art. gmr.) ― -b2- And A^agomaza (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became gentle, so that others were emboldened against him. (IKtt, TA.) -A4- And A^agomaza [for which A^agomazah is erroneously put in the CK] He acquired cattle such as are termed gamaz [q. v.]: (O, K, TA:) like A^aqomaza. (O.)
5 tagam~aza [This verb is said by Freytag to have a signification belonging to tagam~ara.]

6 tgAmzwA *
They made signs, one to another, with their eyes, (S, A, K, B,) or with the eyebrow, (A,) or hand, indicating something blameable or faulty. (B.) In this sense it is expl. as used in the Kur lxxxiii. 30. (S, B.)
8 A_igotamaza see 4, in three places.

gamazN *
Cattle (i. e. camels, and sheep or goats, TA) of a bad quality. (As, S, O, K.) ― -b2- And A weak man: (S, O, K:) like qamazN: pl. A^agomaAzN, like A^aqomaAzN of qamazN. (TA.)
gamuwzN * A she-camel of which one doubts whether she be fat or not and therefore feels the hump: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) pl. gumozN [or gumuzN, or both?]. (TA.) See 4, first sentence.
gamiyzN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

gamiyzapN * (tropical:) A thing for which one's character is to be impugned; for which one is to be blamed, censured, or spoken against; a vice, or fault; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ gamiyzN (TA) and ↓ magomazN (S, A, Mgh, K) or ↓ magomazapN: (Msb:) and weakness in work, and impotence of mind, (TA,) and ignorance: (T, TA:) the pl. of ↓ magomazN is magaAmizu, (TA,) syn. with maEaAyibu. (S.) You say, layosa fiyhi gamiyzapN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ gamiyzN, (TA,) and ↓ magomazN, (A, Mgh, K,) or ↓ magomazapN, (Msb,) (tropical:) There is not in him anything for which his character is to be impugned; or for which he is to be blamed; &c.: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or there is not in it anything for which it is to be coveted: (K:) or ↓ maA fiyhi magomazN has both of the above-mentioned significations. (A.) And fiY jam~apN ↓ fulaAnapa magaAmizu (tropical:) In such a woman are many vices, or faults. (A.) [See magomazN, below.]

jaAriyapN gam~aAzapN *
A girl who presses, or squeezes, or kneads, the limbs well with the hand. (A, K, * TA.) -A2- AimoraA^apN gam~aAzapN (tropical:) A woman who makes frequent signs with the eye, &c.; who has a habit of doing so; syn. ram~aAzapN. (TA in art. rmz.) ― -b2- gam~aAzN One who blames, or finds fault with, others, much, or habitually. (TA in art. hmz.)

gaAmizN * [meaning Limping, or halting, &c., and having a limping, or halting, &c.,] is like ZaAliEN: sometimes used as a possessive noun; and [therefore] one does not say gaAmizapN. (O and TA in art. ZlE.)

magomazN * [should by rule be magomizN: its primary signification is A place of feeling, to know if an animal be fat: hence, a place of pressing or squeezing a limb &c.: and a place of pinching and pressing a spear, to straighten it]. ― -b2- nukotapN laAmagomaza liqanaAtihaA walaA maqoraEa liSafaAtihaA (tropical:) [lit. A nice or subtile saying, the spear of which has no place where it requires to be pinched and pressed to straiten it, and the rock of which has no rough place requiring to be beaten, or for the rock of which there is no beating,] means, (assumed tropical:) that has no crookedness: mqrE is an inf. n., or means “ a place of beating, ” and SfAp is “ a rock; ” and the above-mentioned use of these two words is borrowed from the phrase qaraEa SafaAtahu, meaning (tropical:) “ he impugned his character; blamed, or censured, him; or spoke against him. ” (Mgh.) ― -b3- See also gamiyzapN, in five places.
magomazapN * : see gamiyzapN, in two places.
magomuwzN * (tropical:) A man (A, TA) suspected (S, A, * K) of a vice, or fault. (TA.)

1 gamasahu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
gamisa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. gamosN, (Msb, TA,) He immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him or it, (JK, TA,) syn. maqalahu, (S, A, K,) in water, (JK, S, A, Msb, K,) or other fluid; (JK, * TA;) as, for instance, a morsel of food in vinegar, and the hand in Hin~aA=', (A,) and a garment, or piece of cloth, [for Alv~adoY in the TA, I read Alv~awob,] in water or in dye. (TA.) ― -b2- AixotaDabato gamosFA, so in the T and the Tekmileh; [and so in the JK;] but in the [O and] K, gamosFA ↓ Aigotasamato; (TA;) She (a woman, O, TA) immersed her hand, (K,) or, as in the [O and other] correct lexicons, her hands, (TA,) [in the Hin~aA='] so as to dye [it or them] uniformly, without taSowiyr [or figuring], (O, K,) for which last word Sgh [in the TS] writes tSryr, and for which we find in the A naqo$ [meaning the same as the word in the K]. (TA.) ― -b3- gamasahumo fiY AlbalaA='i (tropical:) [It (an event) plunged them into trial, or affliction]. (A.) [See also a similar usage of the verb below, voce gamuwsN.] ― -b4- gamasa HalifFA fiY A=li AlEaASi He took a share in the compact and confederacy of the family of El-'Ás, and swore to it: for it was their custom to bring, in a wooden bowl, some perfume or blood or ashes, and they inserted their hands into it on the occasion of swearing, one to another, that their compact might be completed by their sharing together in one thing. (TA, from a trad. respecting the Hijreh.) ― -b5- yagomisu Als~inaAna Hat~aY yanofu*a [He thrusts in the spear-head so that it may pass through, or that its extremity may protrude]. (A.) ― -b6- gamasa Ealayohimu Alxabara (assumed tropical:) He concealed from them the news, or information. (TA.) ― -b7- gumisa Aln~ajomu, (so in a copy of the A,) or gamasa, (so in the JK and O and K,) The star set. (JK, A, O, K.)
2 tagomiysN * signifies The making a drinking to be little in quantity: (O, K, TA:) or, accord. to Kr, a man's watering his camels and then going away. (TA.)

3 gaAomasa [gAmshu, inf. n. mugaAmasapN, He vied, or contended, with him in plunging, or diving, in water:] mugaAmasapN is syn. with mumaAqalapN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- mugaAmasapN also signifies (tropical:) The throwing one's self into the midst of war or fight. (S, TA,) or of an affair or a great affair or an affliction: (TA:) and the mixing, or engaging, in fight or conflict. (TA.) You say, gaAmasa fiY AlqitaAli (tropical:) He plunged, or threw himself, into the midst of fight or conflict; or he rushed headlong into it. (TA.) And gaAmasahumo (tropical:) He mixed, or engaged, with them in fight or conflict. (TA). [See also mugaAmisN].

6 tgAmsA *
They two vied, or contended, each with the other, in plunging, or diving, in water; syn. tamaAqalaA and tagaATasaA. (TA in art. gTs.)

7 Angms * (S, A, Msb) and ↓ Agtms (S, A) He, or it, became immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, in water: or he immersed or immerged himself, plunged, or dived, in water: (S, A, Msb:) or he did so remaining long therein. (TA in this art. and in art. rms.) [See Artms.] ― -b2- [Hence,] ↓ the latter also signifies, [and so app. the former,] (assumed tropical:) He hid, or concealed, himself. (T, O.)
8 A_igotamasa see 7, in two places. ― -b2- Aigotamasato gamosFA: see 1.

gamasN * , [like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN, &c., or perhaps a mistranscription for gamosN, like garosN in the sense of magoruwsN, and many other instances,] Immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk. (TA.)

TaEonapN gamuwsN * (tropical:) A spear-wound, or the like, that passes through: (S, A, Msb, K:) the epithet properly applies to the person who inflicts the wound, because he thrusts in (yagomis) the spearhead so that it passes through, or so that its extremity protrudes: and it is such as cleaves the flesh: (A:) or wide, and passing through; that plunges into the flesh. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- A^amorN gamuwsN (tropical:) A difficult, or distressful, affair; (S, A, Msb, K;) that plunges people into trial, or affliction. (A, K. *) ― -b3- Hence, (A,) yamiynN gamuwsN (tropical:) An oath that plunges its swearer (tagomisuhu) into sin, (S, K,) and then into the fire [of Hell]: (K:) or a false oath, (Mgh, Msb,) known by its swearer to be so; (Msb;) so called because it plunges its swearer into sin, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and then into the fire [of Hell]: (A, Mgh:) or a false oath which one purposely swears, knowing the case to be the contrary thereof, (K, TA,) in order to cut off the rights of others: (TA:) or an oath by which one cuts off for himself the property of another: (K:) or an oath in which there is made no exception [by saying A_ino $aA='a A@ll~`hu (if God will), or the like]. (TA.) [See also Algamiysap.] ― -b4- rajulN gamuwsN (assumed tropical:) A strong, courageous man; as also ↓ mugaAmisN: which latter epithet is also applied to a lion. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A man who, in journeying, does not alight to rest in the night until he enters upon the time of dawn or morning. (TA.) ― -b5- And naAqapN gamuwsN A she-camel whose pregnancy is not plainly known (S, O, K) until she is near to bringing forth (Hat~aY tuqoriba). (S, O.) And (O, K) accord. to En-Nadr, (O,) A she-camel that has a young one in her belly and that does not raise her tail so that the case should become manifest: (O, K:) pl. gms [app. gumusN, agreeably with analogy, like SuburN pl. of SabuwrN, &c.]. (TA.) And (some say, TA) A she-camel respecting whose marrow one doubts whether it be in a corrupt and melting state or be fat, or thick and fat. (O, K.)

gamiysN *
Such as is termed gamiyr [q. v.] of herbage; (S, O, K, TA;) i. e. such as has become green in consequence of rain, in the lower parts of that which is dry. (O.) See also gamiymN. ― -b2- And A thing that has not appeared to men, and that is not known, as yet: whence the phrase qaSiydapN gamiysN [an ode that has not become known: the epithet being masc. and fem.]. (O, K.) ― -b3- And i. q. A^ajamapN [A collection of tangled, or dense, trees or shrubs, or of reeds or canes; (see also gamiysapN;)] and anything tangled, confused, or dense, in which one hides, or conceals, himself: (T, O, K, * TA:) in the copies of the K, A^awo yusotaxofaY is erroneously written for A^aYo ystxfY as in the T and O. (TA.) ― -b4- And A water-course, or channel in which water flows, (S, O, K, TA,) or (TA) such as is small, amid [plants such as are termed] baqol and nabaAt, (S, O, K, TA,) or, as in the L, combining (yajomaEu) [app. within it] trees, or shrubs, and baqol. (TA.) ― -b5- Also Night: (O:) or dark night. (K.) And Darkness. (O, K.) ― -b6- And AO is related by El-Athram to have said, Almajoru is what is in the belly of the she-camel; and the second [i. e. the offspring of the major] is [called] Habalu AlHabalapi; and the third is Algamiysu [i. e. this last signifies The offspring of the offspring of the major: see majorN and HabalN]. (TA.)

gamyisapN *
A collection of dense reeds or canes; or a bed, or place of growth, thereof. (TA. [See also gamiysN.]) -A2- Halafa EalaY Algamiysapi He swore a false oath. (TA. [See gamwusN.])
gam~aAsN * : see what next follows, in two places.

gam~aAsapN * [A bird of the kind termed divers, or plungeons: thus called in the present day; expl. by Golius and Freytag as meaning “ mergus avis; ”] a certain aquatic bird, (O, K,) that dives, or plunges, much: (O:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ gam~aAsN: (K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, gum~AsN:]) IDrd says, the ↓ gam~aAs is a wellknown bird. (O.)

mugaAmisN * One who plunges into wars, or battles, (yago$aY AlHuruwba,) and engages in them repeatedly: (Ham p. 27:) or one who enters into difficulties, troubles, or distresses, and makes another, or others, to do so; like mugaAmirN. (Id. p. 338.) See also gamuwsN.

1 gamaSahu * , (S, A, Mgh, K,) aor.
gamiSa inf. n. gamoSN; (S;) and gamiSahu, aor.
gamaSa , inf. n. gamoSN; and gamiSahu, aor.
