gamaSa , inf. n. gamaSN; (K, * TA;) but the first is the most chaste; (TA;) He despised him; held him in contempt; (A, Mgh, K;) accounted him little, or vile; regarded him as nothing; (S;) as also ↓ AgtmShu. (S, A, K.) You say also, raA=hu fagamaSatohu Eayonuhu He saw him and his eye despised him. (A.) ― -b2- He blamed him; found fault with him; imputed to him a vice, or fault; and despised his right. (A, K.) You say, wajadato Aln~aAsa yagomiSu baEoDuhumo baEoDFA [I found the people blaming one another, &c.]; as also ↓ yagotamiSu. (A.) And gamaSotahu bisuwo'K [Thou imputedst evil to him]. (TA, from a trad.) And gamaSotu Ealayohi qawolFA qaAlahu I blamed him, or found fault with him, for a saying that he said. (S.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) gamaSa Aln~iEomapa, (S, K,) and gamiSahaA, (K,) the latter is the form authorized by the T and the Deewán el-Adab, this verb and [its syn.] gmT being there said to be both with kesr to the m, (TA,) He was ungrateful, or unthankful, for the favour or benefit; (S, K, TA;) he despised it, and disacknowledged it. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also, app.,] gamaSa A@ll~`hu Alxaloqa God diminished the height, and breadth, and strength, and might in war, or valour, of mankind; and made them small and contemptible: occurring in a trad. of 'Alee respecting the slaughter of his brother by a son of Adam. (TA.) -A2- gamaSato Eayonuhu, (S, K,) aor.
gamaSa , (K,) inf. n. gamaSN, (S,) His eye had in it what is termed gamaSN, q. v. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] gamiSa h`*aA AlA^amoru EalaY~a This thing, or affair, turned against me, and became attended with trouble. (JK.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps,] laA tagomaSo EalaY~a [in the CK tagomiSo] Be not thou angry with me: so accord. to the O [and the JK]: but accord. to the K, do not thou lie against me, or utter falsehood. (TA.)
8 A_igotamaSa see 1, in two places.

gamaSN *
Fluid filth [or foul matter] in the inner corner of the eye: (Mgh:) or what is fluid of [the filth, or foul matter, or white filth, which collects in the inner corner of the eye, and which, when concrete, is called] ramaS: (S, K:) or a thing like froth, which the eye emits; a portion whereof is termed ↓ gamaSapN: (TA:) or what resembles white froth, in the side of the eye: but ramaSN is in the side of the eyelashes: (ISh:) or both these words signify dirt which the eye emits: or gamaSN is what is concrete. (M in art. rmS.)
gamiSN * , a possessive epithet, A great imputer of vices or faults. (TA.)
gamaSapN * : see gamaSN.

yamiynN gamuwSN *
i. q. gamuwsN. ― -b2- huwa gamuwSu AlHanojarapi He is a liar. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) -A2- AlgamuwSu: see AlgumayoSaA='u.

maA fiY fulaAnK gamiySapN *
There is not in such a one anything for which his character is to be impugned, or for which he is to be blamed, censured, or spoken against; any vice, or fault; i. q. gamiyzapN. (A.)

gumayoSaA='u * dim. of gamoSaA='u [fem. of A^agomaSu]. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) AlgumayoSaA='u [The star Procyon;] one of the $iEorayaAni, (S, K,) whereof the other is Al$~iEoraY AlEabuwru [i. e. Sirius]: (TA:) the former is also called ↓ AlgamuwSu, (S, K,) and Alr~umayoSaA='u, (TA,) and Al$~iEoraY Al$~aAmiy~apu: (IAth:) it is one of the Mansions of the Moon [accord. to those who make the term nawo'N to signify the auroral setting;
namely, the Seventh]; (TA;) and is in the *iraAE; (S;) i. e., it is the greater of the two stars called Al*~iraAEu AlmaqobuwDapu: (IAth:) it is called AlgmySA' because of its smallness and its littleness of light [in comparison with the other $ErY], from gamaSu AlEayoni: (TA:) [or the reason of its being so called is this:] the Arabs assert that the $iEorayaAni are the sisters of suhayol [or Canopus]; (IDrd, S;) and that they [three] were together; but that shyl descended into the south, and Al$~iEoraY AlyamaAniy~apu [which is Sirius] followed it; (IDrd;) this latter, they say, crossed the Milky way, and was therefore named AlEabuwru; and AlgmySA' remained in her place, weeping for the loss of the two others until her eye became affected with gamaS: (IDrd, K: *) they also assert that thou seest AlEbwr when she rises as though she desired to cross [the Milky Way] (kaA^an~ahaA tasotaEobiru); but AlgmySA' thou seest not [as yet in any part of Arabia], she having wept until she has become affected with gamaS. (S.)

A^agomaSu *
Having, in his eye, what is termed gamaSN, q. v.: (Mgh, K:) or disordered in the eye; whose eyes are dim, or watery; like A^aEoma$u: (L and TA in art. Em$:) fem. gamoSaA='u: and pl. gumoSN. (TA.)

huwa magomuwSN Ealayohi *
He is censured, or blamed, or reproached, (S, K,) with respect to his religion, (S, A, K,) and with respect to his grounds of pretension to respect. (A.) It is said in a trad., A_il~aA magomwSN Ealayohi Aln~ifaAqu, meaning, Except one censured, &c., with respect to his religion; accused, or suspected, of hypocrisy. (TA.)

entryFree.key: A^anaA musotagomiSN mino h`*aA Alxabari wamutawah~imN

div2.entryFree: A^anaA musotagomiSN mino h`*aA Alxabari wamutawah~imN * [I am suspicious of this information, and opining;] is said by one when a piece of information rejoices him but he fears that it may not be true; or when he fears it and yet it rejoices him. (TA.)

1 gamaDa * , and gamuDa, aor. of each
gamuDa , and inf. n. of each gumuwDN, It (a thing) was, or became, unperceived, unapparent, hidden, or concealed. (TA.) ― -b2- gamaDa AlHaq~u, aor. and inf. n. as above; and gamuDa; The way of attaining, or obtaining, the right, or due, was, or became, unapparent, or hidden. (Msb.) ― -b3- gamuDa AlkalaAmu, inf. n. gumuwDapN; (S, Sgh, K;) and gamaDa, aor.
gamuDa , inf. n. gumuwDN; (IB, K; [but IB seems to express a doubt of the correctness of the latter form of the verb in this case;]) The speech, or language, was unapparent to the mind, not plain or perspicuous, obscure, recondite, or abstruse. (S, IB, Sgh, K.) ― -b4- gamuDa Ealayohi AlA^amoru The affair was not easy to him; (L, TA; *) and you say also, gamaDa AlA^amoru, inf. n. gumuwDN: and fiyhi gumuwDN [In it is a want of easiness]: but, Lh says, they scarcely ever, or never, say fiyhi gumuwDapN. (TA.) ― -b5- gamaDa AlmakaAnu, aor.
gamuDa , inf. n. gumuwDN; and gamuDa, inf. n. gumuwDapN and gamaADapN; The place was, or became, low, or depressed; (S, K;) [because a place that is so is unseen from a distance.] ― -b6- gamaDa AlxaloxaAlu fiY Als~aAqi, inf. n. gumuwDN, The anklet was, or became, depressed in the leg; lit., choked therein. (A, TA.) ― -b7- gamaDati Ald~aAru, aor.
gamuDa , inf. n. as above, The house was not upon a common thoroughfare-road or street. (Lth, L.) ― -b8- gamaDa Als~ayofu fiY All~aHomi, (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K,) aor.
gamuDa , (Ibn-'Abbád,) The sword became hidden in the flesh. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b9- gamaDa fiY AlA^aroDi, (Lh, A, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K, fY AlA^amori, which is a mistake, (TA,) aor.
gamuDa and
gamiDa , (K,) inf. n. gumuwDN, (A,) He went away in, or into, the land, or country: (Lh:) or he went away and disappeared therein: (A, L:) or he went away and journeyed therein. (K.) ― -b10- And gamaDa, aor.
gamuDa , also signifies It (a thing) was, or became, small. (IKtt.) -A2- See also 4, under AgmS Enh, in four places.

2 gm~D AlkalaAma * , (S, K,) inf. n. tagomiyDN, (S,) He made the speech, or language, unapparent to the mind, not plain or perspicuous, obscure, recondite, or abstruse. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- gm~D Had~a Als~ayofi, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made the edge of the sword thin [so that it might become hidden in the flesh when one smote with it]; (A, TA;) as also ↓ A^agomaDahu. (K.) -A2- See also 4, in twelve places.

4 AgmD Had~a Als~ayofi * : see 2. ― -b2- AgmD Eayonayohi, (Mgh,) or AlEayona, (Msb,) inf. n. A_igomaADN; (S, Msb;) and ↓ gam~aDahumaA, (Mgh,) or gam~aDahaA, (Msb,) inf. n. tagomiyDN; (S, Msb;) He shut, or closed, (Mgh, Msb,) [his eyes, or] his eyelids, (Mgh,) or [the eye, or] the eyelids. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence,] maA A^agomaDotu, (A, TA,) and ↓ maA gam~aDotu, (TA,) I have not slept; (TA;) and ↓ maA A@gotamaDotu [signifies the same]; (JK;) and so maA A@kotaHalotu A_igomaADFA, (ISd, K,) and ↓ tagomaADFA (S, Sgh, K) and tagomiyDFA, (S, K,) [two inf. ns. of 2,] and ↓ gamaADFA, and ↓ gimaADFA, and ↓ gumoDFA with damm, (S, Sgh, K,) [and app. ↓ gumaADFA, and ↓ gumuwDFA, and ↓ gamoDFA, for] IB says that gamoDN and gumuwDN and gumaADN are inf. ns. of a verb not used: (TA:) and maA *uqotu ↓ gumoDFA, [in a copy of the A ↓ gamoDFA,] and ↓ gamaA DFA, I have not tasted sleep. (JK.) [And hence,] Albaroqu ↓ AgtmD (tropical:) The lightning ceased to gleam; as though sleeping. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, AgmD Tarofahu Ean~iY, and ↓ gm~Dhu, He shut, or closed, his eye, or eyes, at, or upon, or against, me: and AgmD Ealayohi, and ↓ gm~D, he shut, or closed, his eyes at, or upon, or against, him, or it. (TA.) ― -b5- And [hence,] AgmD Eanohu, and Ealayohi, (tropical:) [He shut his eyes at it, or upon it, or against it], namely a thing that he had heard: a metonymical phrase, denoting patience. (TA.) And AgmD Eanohu (tropical:) He connived at it; feigned himself neglectful of it; passed it by; (A, Mgh, Msb, TA;) as also Eanohu ↓ gm~D, inf. n. tagomiyDN; and ↓ gamaDa; and ↓ AgtmD; namely a thing that he had heard; and an evil action: (A, TA:) and Eayonayohi ↓ gm~D Eanohu he feigned himself blind to it. (TA.) And AgmD Eanohu fiY AlbayoEi, (S, K,) or Al$~iraA='i, (S, TA,) (tropical:) He acted, or affected to act, in an easy, or a facile, manner towards him, (tasaAhala Ealayohi,) in selling, (S, K,) or buying; (S;) as also ↓ gamaDa Eanohu, (S, K,) aor.
gamiDa . (K.) And A^agomiDo liY fiymaA biEotaniY, (S, A, K, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the K like AiDoribo, [i. e. ↓ AigomiDo,] but the former is the right reading, (TA,) [though the latter is perhaps allowable, as will presently be seen,] meaning, (A, TA,) or as though it meant, (S, K, TA,) (tropical:) Give thou to me more of what thou hast sold to me, on account of its badness; or [so in the A, but in the S and K “ and, ”] lower thou to me the price thereof; (S, A, K, TA;) as also liY fiyhi ↓ gam~iDo. (K, TA.) And AgmD fiY AlbayoEi (tropical:) He demanded that another should give him more of the thing sold; and that he should lower the price [thereof]; and he complied with his demand. (IAth.) And AgmD fiY Als~iloEapi (tropical:) He demanded a lowering of the price of the commodity, on account of its badness. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 270], walasotumo biA=xi*iyhi A_il~aA A^ano tugomiDuwA fiyhi, (S, A, * K,) or, accord. to one reading, ↓ tagomiDuwA, (TA,) i. e. (tropical:) When ye do not take it unless ye lower the price; (Lth, Zj, * K;) meaning, EalaY A_igomaADK, or biA_igomaADK. (Fr.) ― -b6- [Hence also,] fulaAnN EalaY h`*aA AlA^amori ↓ gam~aDa (assumed tropical:) Such a one executed, performed, or accomplished, this affair: or kept, or applied himself, constantly, or perseveringly, to it; (maDaY Ealayohi;) [as though he shut his eyes at it;] knowing what was in it. (O, K.) And Aln~aAqapu ↓ gam~aDati, (S, A, K,) inf. n. tagomiyDN, (K,) The she-camel, being driven away (rud~ato, as in the K, and in some copies of the S, or *iydato, as in other copies of the S, and in the A, as is said in the TA,) from the watering-trough, (S, K,) rushed upon the driver, (Al*~aAy^id, [in the CK, erroneously, AlzAy^id,]) closing her eyes, and came to the water. (S, A, K.) ↓ tagomiyDN also signifies The embarking [in an affair], or undertaking [it], blindly. (TA.) ― -b7- [Hence also,] A^agomaDati AlmafaAzapu Ealayohimo (tropical:) [The desert concealed them;] they did not appear in the desert, (A, TA,) being concealed by the mirage, and in the depressed parts; (TA;) as though it closed its eyelids upon them. (A, TA.) ― -b8- AgmD Aln~aZara (tropical:) He considered, or judged, well, and gave a good opinion: (M, TA:) and AgmD fiY Aln~aZari (tropical:) he gave a right opinion: (A:) or (assumed tropical:) he considered, or judged, minutely. (IKtt.) ― -b9- A^agomaDati AlEayonu fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) The eye despised such a one: (K, TA:) or you say A^agomaDatohu EayoniY meaning I despised him: ― -b10- and likewise meaning I vied, or contended, in running with him, (HaADarotuhu,) and outstripped him, after he had outstripped me: (Ibn-'Abbád, O:) or AgmD fulaAnN fulaAnFA means Such a one vied, or contended, in running with such a one, (HaADarahu,) and outstripped him, after
having been outstripped by him. (K.) ― -b11- AgmD Almay~ita, (A, Mgh, TA,) inf. n. A_igomaADN; (TA;) and ↓ gam~aDahu, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) He closed the eyelids of the dead man. (Mgh.)

7 AngmD AlT~arofu *
i. q. AinogaD~a: (S, Sgh, K:) [or the former more probably signifies The eye, or eyes, became closed: and the latter, the eye, or eyes, became contracted. See also 8.]

8 maA A@gotamaDato EayonaAYa *
My eyes slept not, or have not slept. (S, * Sgh, K.) See also 4, in the first half of the paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- A^ataAniY *`lika EalaY A@gotimaADK (tropical:) That came to me easily, without trouble, or pains-taking. (As, A, K.)
gamoDN * : see gaAmiDN, in four places: ― -b2- See also 4, in the third sentence, in two places.
gumoDN * : see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.
gamaADN * : see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.
gumaADN * : see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.
gimaADN * : see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.
gumuwDN * : see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.
gumuwDapN * : see what next follows.
maA fiY h`*aA AlA^amori gamiyDapN * , (S, O, L, K,) and ↓ gumuwDapN, (L,) There is not, in this affair, any fault, (S, O, L, K,) liY [to be imputed to me]. (TA, where this is added next after mA.)

gaAmiDN * [Unperceived; unapparent; hidden, or concealed. (See 1, first signification.)] ― -b2- Unapparent to the mind, not plain or perspicuous, obscure, recondite, or abstruse, speech, or language. (S, A, K.) You say also, maEonFY gaAmiDN A nice, subtile, or quaint, meaning. (TA.) And masoA^alapN gaAmiDapN A question in which is matter for consideration, and subtility, or nicety. (TA.) And masoA^alapN fiyhaA gawaAmiDu [A question in which are obscurities, abstrusities, subtilities, or niceties: the last word being pl. of ↓ gaAmiDapN, an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates]. (A.) ― -b3- Obscure; not well known: (A:) or not known: (Msb, K:) applied to rank or quality (Hasab), (A, K,) or to parentage or relationship (nasab): (Msb:) pl. A^agomaADN, like as A^aSoHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN: or, as some say, this is pl. of ↓ gamoDN. (TA.) ― -b4- Obscure, or of no reputation; low, mean, or vile; (K, TA;) applied to a man: (TA:) such is termed ↓ *uw gamoDK, (S, O, TA,) also. (TA.) [And hence, perhaps,] A man remiss in the charge, or in rushing on the enemy: (Lth, K:) pl. gawaAmiDu [which is anomalous, like fawaArisu &c.]. (Lth.) ― -b5- Low, or depressed; applied to land, (S, A, K,) and a place; (A;) [because unseen from a distance;] as also ↓ gamoDN; (S, A, K;) applied to a place: (S, A:) or this latter signifies land very low, or very much depressed, so that what is in it is not seen: (AHn:) and in like manner ↓ magomaDN, a place more depressed (S, TA) than what is termed gamoDN: (TA:) pl. of the first, gawaAmiDu: (K:) and of ↓ the second, A^agomaADN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, K) and gumuwDN: (S, A, K:) and of the third, magaAmiDu. (S.) ― -b6- An anklet depressed, lit. choked, (gaAS~N, [in the CK gAD~,]) in the leg: (JK, A, L, K:) and, applied to an ankle-bone, concealed by the flesh: (TA:) or fat: (K:) and in this latter sense applied to a leg, or shank. (K, TA.) ― -b7- A house not upon a common thoroughfare-road or street; (Lth, A, L, K;) retired therefrom. (A, TA.) -A2- A young camel; the young one of a camel: pl. gawaAmiDu: (TA:) which also signifies camels not accustomed to drawing water. (JK.)
gaAmiDapN * ; pl. gawaAmiDu: see the next preceding paragraph.
magomaDN * ; pl. magaAmiDu: see gaAmiDN as applied to land, and a place.

mugam~aDaAtu All~ayoli *
The darknesses of night. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the following paragraph.

Almugam~iDaAtu mina Al*~unuwbi * , (O, K, * TA,) or mugam~iDaAtu AlA^umuwri, accord. to different relations of a trad. in which it occurs, (TA,) Sins, or offences, which a man commits knowing them [to be such]: (O, K, TA:) or enormities which a man commits knowing them [to be such]; as though he closed his eyes upon them, feigning himself blind while he saw them: (TA:) IAth says that accord. to one relation it is with fet-h to the second m, [↓ mugam~aDaAt,] and means small sins, or offences; so called because minute and unapparent, so that a man commits them with a kind of doubt, not knowing that he will be punished for committing them. (TA.)

1 gamiTa * , aor.
gamaTa ; and gamaTa, aor.
gamiTa ; inf. n. gamoTN, (S, K,) of both; (S;) He despised men; held them in contempt; (S, K;) accounted them little, or vile. (TA.) It is said in a trad., A_in~amaA *`lika mano safiha AlHaq~a wagamaiTa Aln~aAsa That (S, TA,) meaning transgression, iniquity, or injustice, (TA,) is only (S, TA) the action of (TA) such as regards the truth, or right, as foolishness, or ignorance, and despises men: (S, TA:) Sgh says that accord. to one relation, it is gamaSa: and Az relates it thus; Alkiboru A^ano tasofaha AlHaq~a watagomiTa Aln~aAsa [Pride is thy regarding the truth, or right, as foolishness, or ignorance, and thy despising men]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also the former, (TA,) or both, (K,) He was ungrateful for health, and safety, (K, TA,) and a favour, or benefit, or blessing: (S, * TA:) and both, (S, K,) he held in light estimation, was ungrateful for, and despised, (S, K,) a favour, or benefit, or blessing, (K, TA,) and his life. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And the former, He denied, or disacknowledged, a right, or due. (TA.)

4 AgmT *
It continued; it kept, or clave; (K;) like AgbT. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) A^agomaTato Ealayohi AlHum~aY, a dial. var. of AgbTt, q. v. (S, TA.)

8 AgtmThu baAlkalaAmi *
He treated him contemptuously with speech: (O:) and (O) he overcame, and subdued, him therewith; (O, L, K;) and so AigotaT~apu. (O, L.) ― -b2- And AgtmThu He vied, or contended, in running with him, and outstripped him, after he had been outstripped (O, K) by him; mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád; (O;) and so AigotaT~ahu; (TA;) and A^agomaDahu. (Ibn-'Abbád and O in art. gmD.

samaA='N gamaTaY *
i. q. gabaTaY, q. v. (IDrd, K.)

sayorN mugomaTN *
i. q. mugobaTN, q. v. (ISh.)

1 gamala Aljiloda * , (S, O,) or AlA^adiyma, (K,) aor.
gamula , inf. n. gamolN, He folded the skin, or hide, and buried it, in order that it might become soft, or flaccid, and pliant, when its wool was pulled: (S, O: *) if neglected for a while, it becomes spoiled, or marred: the epithet applied to it is ↓ gamiylN; (S, O;) and gamiynN also: (S:) or he spoiled, or marred, the skin, or hide: or he put it in the bottom of some receptacle (fiY gum~apK), [and left it a while,] in order that its wool might become detached: (K:) or he buried it, (K, TA,) having folded it, (TA,) in the sand, (K, TA,) after moistening [it], (TA,) in order that it might become stinking, and its hair [or wool] might be plucked off: (K, TA:) or, accord. to AHn, he folded it while it was moist, and left it folded longer than it required, so that it became spoiled, or marred: or, as some say, he folded it after it was tanned, then covered it a day and a night, so that its hair, or its wool, became loose, when it was plucked off: if left more than a day and a night, it becomes spoiled, or marred: (TA:) and ↓ Agml signifies [the same: (see gaSaba Aljiloda:) or] he left his skin, or hide, [buried, or put in the bottom of some receptacle, &c., while moist,] until it became spoiled, or marred. (TA.) ― -b2- And gamala Alt~amora, (S,) or Albusora, (O, K,) He did in like manner to the dates, or the unripe dates, in order that they might become ripe: (S, O, K:) and the epithet applied to them is ↓ magomuwlN; and magomuwnN. (TA.) ― -b3- And gamala AlEinaba, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put the grapes together, in quantities one above another, (K, TA,) in the basket of palm-leaves. (TA.) ― -b4- gamala fulaAnaA He covered such a one, (K, TA,) with clothes, (TA,) in order that he should sweat. (K, TA.) ― -b5- gamala AljuroHa He put pieces of rag, one above another, upon the wound. (O, TA.) ― -b6- gamala AlA^amora He hid, concealed, or covered, the affair, or case. (TA.) ― -b7- And gamala Al$~ayo'a, (K,) inf. n. gamolN, (O,) He put the thing into a good, sound, right, or proper, state. (O, K.) -A2- gamala Aln~abaAtu, (O, K,) inf. n. gamolN, (TA,) The plants, or herbage, became accumulated, one, or one part, overlying another, (O, K, TA,) so as to become withered, and decayed. (TA.) [See also 5.] -A3- gamila Aln~abotu, the verb being like fariHa, The plant, or plants, or herbage, became in a bad, or corrupt, state. (TA.) ― -b2- And one says gamila h`*aA AlmakaAnu
biAln~aboti [app. meaning This place became, or has become, in a bad, or corrupt, state by reason of the herbage: or concealed, or covered, by herbage; as may be inferred from an explanation of A^aroDN gamilapN]. (O.) ― -b3- And gamila AljuroHu, (TA,) inf. n. gamalN, (K,) The wound became in a bad, or corrupt, state, by reason of the bandage. (K, TA.)
4 A^agomala see the preceding paragraph, former half.

5 tgm~l Aln~abaAtu *
The plants, or herbage, became accumulated, one, or one part, overlying another. (TA.) [See also gamala Aln~abaAtu.] ― -b2- And tgm~l He became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, syn. tawas~aEa, (O, K,) in wealth. (O.)

7 Angml * , said of a skin, quasi-pass. of gamala signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art. [i. e. It was, or became, such as is termed gamiyl, or in the state denoted by the pass. part. n. of the latter verb]. (K.)

gimolN *
A certain tree of the [kind called] HamoD, that grows surmounted by a fruit, or produce, white like the [garments called] mulaA='. (AA, O, TA.)
gamilN * [accord. to rule, part. n. of gamila, q. v.]. ― -b2- A^aroDN gamilapN Land abounding with herbage, having its surface concealed, or covered, thereby. (TA.)

gamiylN * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Applied to herbage, (S, * O, *) or to such as is called naS~iY, (K, TA,) Accumulated, one part above another, (S, O, K, * TA,) so as to be withered: (TA:) pl. gamolaY, (S, O, TA,) [which is also expl. as] meaning herbage tangled and dense, one part above another. (O voce $urobubN.) ― -b3- And Low, or depressed, land. (As, O, TA.)

gumoluwlN *
A valley containing trees, (S, O, K,) or containing numerous trees, (TA,) and plants, or herbage, (S, O,) tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense: (S:) or such as is long, of little width, and tangled or luxuriant or abundant and dense [in its trees]: (K:) or a narrow valley having much of such produce: or a deeplydepressed tract of land: or, accord. to ISh, a tract having the form of a [road such as is termed] sik~ap, in the ground, narrow, and having two [lateral] acclivities, each acclivity two cubits in height, extending to the measure of a bow-shot, producing an abundance [of trees or herbage], and narrower than what is termed a maliyE: (TA:) and [its pl.] gamaAliylu is said to signify low, or depressed, tracts of land, covered with herbage. (O.) ― -b2- And (in like manner, S, O) Anything that is collected together, (S, O, K,) obscure, and accumulated, one part upon another, (K,) of trees, or of clouds, or of darkness, (S, O, K,) or a raAwiyap, or zaAwiyap, (the former in the CK, and the latter in other copies of the K and in the TA,) [or] so that a raAwiyap, or zaAwiyap, (the former in my copies of the S, and the latter in the O,) is thus called: (S, O:) [but I think that these two words rAwyp and zAwyp are both mistranscriptions for raAbiyap, which is mentioned in the K as one of the meaning of gumoluwlN; i. e. a hill:] pl. gamaAliylu. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (O, K,) as is said by AHn on the authority of some other or others, (O,) A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN, O, K,) likewise called qun~aAbiraY, [thus accord. to the O in art. qnbr, and there said in the TA to be correctly with teshdeed to the n and with kesr to the b, but in the present art. written in the O qun~aAbaraY,] in Pers. barogasot; a herb of the desert (baqolapN da$otiy~apN), which come forth early in the [season called] rabiyE; (O;) eaten (O, K) by men, (O,) cooked. (K.)

magomuwlN * : see 1, near the middle. ― -b2- Also A man having clothes thrown upon him in order that he may sweat. (S, O.) ― -b3- And Flesh-meat covered over; whether cooked by roasting or the like or with broth or gravy; as also magomuwnN. (TA.) ― -b4- And Palm-trees (naxol) near together. (TA.) ― -b5- And A man obscure, unnoted, or reputeless. (As, O, K.)

1 gamana Aljiloda * , (S, K,) aor.
gamuna , (S,) inf. n. gamonN, (TA,) i. q. gamalahu; (K;) [see the latter;] He put together the skin after it had been stripped off, and covered it over until its wool became loose, for the purpose of tanning: (TA:) or he covered over the skin (S, TA) for two nights, for the purpose of tanning, (TA,) in order that its wool might become loosened from it: (S, TA:) and the epithet applied to it is ↓ gamiynN, (S, K,) like gamiylN. (S.) ― -b2- And gamana Alt~amora, (S,) or Albusora, (K, TA,) has the like meaning, (S,) i. q. gamalahu; (K;) He covered over [the dates, or] the unripe dates, in order that they might become ripe; (TA:) and the epithet applied to them is ↓ magomuwnN, like magomuwlN. (TA in art. gml.) ― -b3- And gamana fulaAnFA [like gamalahu] He threw his clothes upon such a one, in order that he should sweat. (K.) -A2- gumina fiY AlA^aroDi means A^adoxila fiyhaA [app. It, or perhaps he, was put into the earth; or made to enter into it]. (K.)

7 Angmn *
It, or he, entered [into the earth: see gumina (immediately preceding); of which it is expl. as denoting the consequence]. (K.)
gumonapN * [A mixture of] white lead (A_isofiydaAj) and [the cosmetic termed] gumorap [q. v.] with which a woman rubs over her face: (K:) pl. gumanN [meaning sorts thereof]. (TA.)
gamiynN * : see 1, first sentence.
magomuwnN * : see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- Also, applied to flesh-meat, i. q. magomuwlN, q. v. (TA in art. gml.) ― -b3- And Palm-trees (naxol) near together; like magomuwlN. (TA.)
1 gamaA Albayota * , aor. yagomuwhu, inf. n. gamowN: see 1 in art. gmY.
gamaA * in the phrase gamaA waA@ll~`hi, i. q. A^amaA [expl. in art. AmA]; (K, TA;) as also with E. (TA.)
gamFA * ; dual gamawaAni: see gamFY in art. gmY.

1 gamayotu Albayota * , (S, K, TA,) aor. A^agomiyhi, inf. n. gamoYN, (TA,) I roofed the house, or chamber: (K, TA:) or covered its roof (S, K) with earth &c. (K) or with reeds, or canes, and earth, and the like: (S:) and ↓ gam~ayotuhu signifies the same: (K:) and gamaA Albayota, aor. yagomuwhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. gamowN, (TA,) signifies he covered [the roof of] the house, or chamber, [in like manner, or] with clay, or earth, and wood. (K, TA.) And gamaYi Al$~aYo'a He covered the thing. (Har p. 422.) ― -b2- gumiYa Alyawomu, and All~ayolu, The day, and the night, was constantly clouded, so that the sun was not seen therein nor the new moon: so accord. to Es-Sara- kustee: and he says that Ealayokumo ↓ faA_ino A^ugomiYa means And if your day be constantly clouded, so that ye see not the new moon, then complete ye [the reckoning of the days of] Shaabán: (Msb:) or faA_ino gum~a Ealayokumo and gumiYa and ↓ A^ugomiYa, thus differently related, all mean, and if it, i. e. the new moon, be covered, or concealed: or and if there be a covering [of clouds] over you: (Mgh:) [see also 1 in art. gm:] or yawomunaA ↓ A^ugomiYa means Our day was one whereof the covering of clouds was constant: and layolatunaA ↓ A^ugomiyato, Our night was one whereof the new moon was veiled, or concealed. (K, TA.) ― -b3- See also 4.
2 gam~aYa see the preceding paragraph, first sentence.

4 A^agomaYa see 1, in four places. ― -b2- One says also, A^ugomiYa Ealayohi Alxabaru The information, or narration, was dubious, confused, or vague, to him; such as was difficult to be understood; or such as was not to be understood; like gum~a: (S:) or was obscure, or unapparent, to him. (Msb.) ― -b3- And A^ugomiYa Ealayohi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_igomaA='N; (Mgh, Msb;) and Elyh ↓ gumiYa; (S, Msb, K;) said of a sick man, (S, Msb, K,) He swooned, i. e. became senseless, (gu$iYa Ealayohi, S, * K,) and then recovered his senses: (K:) or A_igomaA='N is a weakness of the faculties by reason of the overpowering effect of disease: (Mgh:) or it is an abstraction, or absence of mind, that overtakes a man, with languor of the limbs, or members, or organs, by reason of a malady; (Mgh, Msb;) thus it is defined by the scholastic theologians; and is the same as gu$oYN: (Mgh:) or it is a repletion of the venters of the brain with a cold, thick, phlegm; (Mgh, Msb;) thus accord. to the physicians, who distinguish between it and gu$oYN, as do the lawyers: (Mgh:) [see also gu$iYa Ealayohi:] the patient is said to be Ealayohi ↓ mugomFY, (S, Mgh, and so in some copies of the K,) and Ealayohi ↓ magomiY~N, (S, Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) and ↓ gamFY, which
last epithet is applied to a single person, (S, K,) and to two persons, (S,) and to a pl. number, (S, K,) and to a female [as well as a male], (S,) or (if you will, S) you say humaA gamayaAni and humo A^agomaA='N. (S, K.)

fiY Als~amaA='i gamoYN * , (K,) or kaAna EalaY Als~amaA='i gamoYN, (Msb,) and ↓ gamFY, (Msb, K,) mean [Upon the sky is, or was,] what veiled, or concealed, the new moon: (Msb, K:) not from gum~a: (K:) this addition in the K is meant as an indirect slur upon J, for his having mentioned [in this art.] the statement of Fr that one says SumonaA lilogum~aY and lilogam~aY, meaning We fasted when the new moon was veiled, or concealed, to us; and hiYa layolapu Algam~aY [or Algum~aY]; the [proper] place of which is [the section of words whereof the last radical is] m: (TA:) [see gam~N, in that art.: but accord. to Fei,] one says [also], ↓ SumonaA lilogumoyapi. (Msb. [It is there added that this noun is like mudoyap in measure: otherwise I should think that the right reading is lilogum~iy~ap, which has been mentioned voce gam~N.])

gamFY * and ↓ gimaA='N (T, S, K) The roof of a house, or chamber: (T, K:) or the covering of the roof, (S, K,) consisting of earth &c., (K,) or consisting of reeds, or canes, and earth, and the like; (S;) and gamFA also signifies [the same, or] the covering of a house, or chamber, consisting of clay, or earth, and wood: (TA in art. gmw:) the dual [of the first and last] is gamayaAni and gamawaAni: and the pl. is A^agomaA='N, (K, TA,) which is [of the same] like A^anoqaA='N pl. of naqFY [and naqFA], (TA,) and A^agomiyapN, (K, TA,) which is of ↓ gimaA='N. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the first, [in the CK, erroneously, gamA',] A covering that is put upon a horse in order that he may sweat. (ISd, K.) ― -b3- See also gamoYN. -A2- And see 4, near the end.
SumonaA lilogumoyapi * : see gamoYN.
gimaA='N * : see gamFY, in two places.

gaAmiyaA='u *
One of the entrances to the burrow of the jerboa. (K.)
mugomFY Ealayohi * and magomiY~N Ealayohi: see 4, near the end.

1 gan~a * , (MA, Msb, K,) originally ganina, (Msb, MF,) [sec. pers. ganinota,] aor. yagin~u, (Msb, K,) inf. n. gun~apN (MA, KL) and gananN, (MA, [and the same seems to be indicated in the Msb by its being said that the verb is of the class of taEiba,]) or gan~N, (TK, [but this I think a mistake,]) He spoke (MA, Msb, KL) in, (MA,) or from, (Msb, KL,) or [rather] through, (KL,) his nose, (MA, KL,) or his xayaA$iym [app. here meaning the innermost parts of the air-passages of the nose]. (Msb.) [The author of the K gives no indication of the proper signification of this verb but that of its implying what he states to be meant by gun~apN, which see below.] ― -b2- See also 4, in two places.

2 gn~nhu * , inf. n. tagoniynN, It rendered him A^agan~ [q. v.]. (K.) One says, maA A^adoriY maA gan~anahu I know not what rendered him, or has rendered him A^agan~. (TA.) ― -b2- And gn~n Sawotahu He made his voice to have in it a gun~ap [q. v.]. (Mughnee, art. Harofu Aln~uwni. [See mugan~K, voce gan~aA='N, in art. gnY.])

4 Agn~ * said of a man, He made one to hear his ↓ gun~ap, i. e. soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious, voice, in singing. (Har p. 645.) ― -b2- Agn~ Al*~ubaAbu The flies made a sound [or humming]. (K.) ― -b3- Agn~ AlwaAdiY (tropical:) The valley had in it the sound [or humming] of flies, [or resounded therewith,] being abundant in herbs, or herbage: (S:) or abounded with trees; as also ↓ gan~a. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Agn~t AlA^aroD (assumed tropical:) The land had its herbs, or herbage, tall, full-grown, or of full height, and in blossom. (TA.) ― -b5- Agn~ Aln~axolu (tropical:) The palm-trees attained to maturity; as also ↓ gan~a. (K, TA.) ― -b6- And Agn~ Als~iqaA='u (tropical:) The skin became filled (S, K, TA) with water. (S, TA.) -A2- And [it is also trans.:] one says, Agn~ A@ll~`hu guSonahu (tropical:) God made its branch beautiful and bright. (K, TA.)

gun~apN * [mentioned above as an inf. n. of gan~a but generally expl. as a simple subst. signifying A sort of nasal sound, or twang:] a sound that comes forth from the nose; (Ham p. 339;) a sound (S, Msb) in, (S,) or that comes forth from, (Msb,) the xayo$uwm [app. here meaning the innermost part of the air-passages of the nose]: (S, Msb:) or a sound from the lahaAp [q. v., app. here meaning the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth,] and the nose, like [that which is heard in the utterance of] the n of minoka and Eanoka, for the tongue has not part in it: (Mgh:) or the flowing [or passage] of the speech in the lahaAp [app. here also meaning as expl. above]: (K:) or a mixture of the sound of the xayo$uwm [expl. above] in the pronunciation of a letter: (Mbr, TA:) n is that one of the letters in which it is greatest in degree: (Kh, Mgh, Msb, TA:) xun~apN is [a sound] greater in degree than gun~apN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also The roughness of the voice, of a boy, consequent upon the attaining to puberty; or, as Mtr says,] Algun~apu signifies also what is incident to the boy on the occasion of his attaining to puberty, when his voice becomes rough. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And A soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious, voice, in singing. (Har p. 645.) See 4. ― -b4- And The sound [or humming] produced by the flying of flies; (TA;) and ↓ gunaAnN [likewise] signifies the sound of flies. (K, TA.) [See mugin~N and A^agan~u. And see also an ex. voce vun~apN: and another voce Eun~apN.] ― -b5- And the poet Yezeed Ibn-El-Aawar has used it in relation to the sounding of stones: (K:) [or rather] he has so used the epithet ↓ A^agan~. (TA.)
EunaAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

A^agan~u * One who speaks [with a nasal sound, or twang, i. e.] in [or rather through] his nose; (TA;) who speaks from his xayaA$iym [app. here meaning (as expl. before) the innermost parts of the airpassages of the nose]: (S, Msb:) or, accord. to AZ, (Mgh, TA,) whose speech flows, (Mgh, K, *) or passes forth, (TA,) in his lahaAp [app. (as expl. voce gun~apN) the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth]: (Mgh, K, TA:) fem. gan~aA='u, applied to a woman. (Msb.) ― -b2- It is also applied to a gazelle (ZaboYN), meaning Whose cry issues from his xayaA$iym [expl. above]: J has erred in saying that it is applied to Tayor [i. e. birds, or flying things]: (K:) or if by Tyr he mean flies (*ubaAbN), his saying thus is not a mistake, for it is applied to them [as meaning making a humming sound]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] waAdK A^agan~u (assumed tropical:) A valley abounding with herbs or herbage: for to such the flies constantly keep, and in their sounds is a gun~ap. (S. [See also mugin~N.]) And (for this reason, TA) one says rawoDapN gan~aA='u i. e. (assumed tropical:) [A meadow, or garden,] abounding with herbs or herbage: or in which the winds pass with a sound that is not clear, [i. e. with a confused, humming, or murmuring, sound,] by reason of the denseness of its herbs or herbage. (K, TA.) And [for the same reason one says] Eu$obN A^agan~u (assumed tropical:) Herbs, or herbage, tall, full-grown, or of full height, and in blossom. (TA.) ― -b4- And (hence also, S) qaroyapN gan~aA='u (tropical:) [A town, or village,] abounding with inhabitants (S, K, TA) and buildings (K, TA) and herbs or herbage [so that in it is heard the hum of men and women and of flies &c.]. (S, TA.) ― -b5- HarofN A^agon~u means A letter from [the utterance of] which results what is termed gun~ap [i. e. the nasal sound thus termed]. (TA.) ― -b6- See also gun~apN, last sentence.

waAdK mugin~N * (tropical:) A valley in which is [heard] the sound [or humming] of flies; these not being in any valley but such as abounds with herbs or herbage; (S;) a valley of which the flies are abundant, by reason of the denseness, or luxuriance, of its herbs or herbage, so that a gun~ap [or humming] is heard, produced by their flying: the epithet being applied to it, but being properly applicable to the flies. (TA.) [See also A^agan~u.]

1 ganijato * , (S, A, MA, O, K;) aor.
ganaja , (K,) inf. n. gunojN (S, MA) and ganaAjapN; (MA;) and gunijato; (MA;) and ↓ tgn~jt; (S, A, MA, K;) said of a girl, or young woman, (S, K,) or of a woman, (A, MA,) She used amorous gesture or behaviour, or such gesture or behaviour combined with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition, (S, * A, * MA, O, * K, * TA,) and an affecting of languor. (TA.) [See gunojN below.]
5 tagan~aja see the preceding paragraph.

gunojN * [mentioned above as an inf. n.] and ↓ gunujN (S, O, K) and ↓ gunaAjN and ↓ ginaAjN, (O, K,) in a girl, or young woman, (S, K,) Amorous gesture
or behaviour, or such gesture or behaviour combined with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition, (Bkh, S, * O, * K, * TA,) and an affecting of languor: (Bkh, TA:) [in the present day generally used to signify lascivious motion, or a wriggling of the body or hips, under the excitement of sexual passion, or to excite such passion:] accord. to some, beauty of the eyes. (TA.) -A2- And gunojN and ↓ ginaAjN signify also Smoke-black (duxaAnu Aln~aw^uwri [see the latter of these two nouns in art. nwr] AA, O, K) which a woman performing the operation of tattooing puts upon her green colour in order that it may become black. (AA, O, TA.)

ganajN *
An old man: (S, K:) or a man: (TA:) in the dial. of Hudheyl. (S, K.) So in the saying ganajN EalaY $anajK (TA) meaning A man upon a camel: (Lth, IDrd, O, all in art. $nj:) or a man or an old man, upon a heavy camel: (L in that art.:) a phrase of the tribe of Hudheyl. (TA.) [See EanajN.]
gunujN * : see gunojN.
gunojapu * , (O,) or gunajapu, (TA,) without Aalo, and imperfectly decl., (O, TA,) The qunofu* [or hedge-hog], (O,) or the qunofu*ap [or female hedgehog]. (TA.)

ganijapN * (Bkh, S, A, MA, O, K) and ↓ magonuwjapN (A, MA) and [in an intensive sense] ↓ migonaAjN, (O, K) applied to a girl, or young woman, (S, K,) or to a woman, (A, MA,) Using or who uses, amorous gesture or behaviour, &c., such as is termed gunoj. (Bkh, S, A, MA, O, K, TA.)
gunaAjN * : see gunojN.
ginaAjN * : see gunoj, in two places.
gawonajN * A quick, or swift, camel: mentioned by Kr, but said to be not known on the authority of any other. (TA.)

A^agonuwjapN *
A gesture, or an action, of the kind termed gunoj: pl. A^agaAniyju: Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
lawaY raA^osahu Eani~Y wamaAla biwud~ihi
A^agaAniyju xawodK kaAna fiynaA yazuwruhaA
[The amorous gestures or actions, &c., of a soft or tender, or goodly-shaped and young, damsel, whom he used to visit among us, turned his head from me, and diverted his love]. (TA.)
migonaAjN * : see ganijapN.
magonuwjapN * : see ganijapN.
Algunodubu * : see the paragraph here following.

Algunodubapu *
A hard portion of flesh [app. a gland] around [or app. on either side of] the Huloquwm [which seems to mean here, as it often does, the Haloq, i. e. fauces, or upper part of the throat]; (O, K;) thus expl. by Lth; as also ↓ Algunodubu; (O;) or ↓ Algunoduwbu: (K:) pl. ganaAdibu: and it is said that the gunodubataAni are [two things] like two ganglions ($ibohu gud~atayoni) in the nakofataAni; (O, K;) in each nakofap [q. v.] is a gunodubap, and between the gndbtAn is the place of swallowing: (O:) the ganaAdib and the flesh that is upon them, or above them, around the lahaAp [app. here meaning the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth], compose the lagaAniyn [pl. of lugonuwnN, q. v.], which are also called the nagaAnig, pl. of nugonugapN [or nugonugN, q. v.]: (TA:) or the gndbtAn are two glands (EuqodataAni) in, or at, (fiY,) the root of the tongue: (K, TA:) and they are said to be the two amygdalæ of the fauces; i. e. the tonsils: (All~awozataAni: TA:) or two portions of flesh which are situate on either side of the lahaAp [app. meaning as expl. above, i. e. the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth], (K, TA,) and between which is a space: (TA:) and gunodubataA AlEuro$ayoni is expl. as meaning the two things that conjoin (All~ataAni taDum~aAni) the lagaAniyn [above mentioned (I read AllgAnyn instead of AlEyn, an evident mistranscription in my original, for I can only suppose the description to mean the tonsils, as lodged between, and thus conjoining, the anterior and posterior pillars of the soft palate,)] on the right and left. (TA.)
Algunoduwbu * : see the preceding paragraph.

1 ganaZahu * , aor.
ganiZa (S, O, K, TA) and
ganuZa , (TA,) inf. n. ganoZN, (S, O, TA,) It, (an affair, or event, S, O, K, TA,) and he, (a man, O, TA,) distressed him. (S, O, K, TA.) And It, or he, filled him with wrath. (TA.) And It (anxiety) clave, or kept constantly, to him; as also ↓ AgnZhu. (TA.) [See also ganoZN below.]
3 gAnZhu * , inf. n. ginaAZN, He acted with him contrariously, or adversely, and inimically, each doing to the other that which was distressing, or grievous; syn. $aAq~ahu. (TA.)
4 A^agonaZa see the first paragraph.

Q. Q. 1 ganoZaY bihi *
He reviled him; made him to hear that which was disliked, hated, or abominable; (S, O;) like EanoZaY bihi. (K.)

ganoZN * [an inf. n.: used as a simple subst.,] Grief, or distress, syn. karobN, (IDrd, S, O, K, TA,) as also ↓ ganaZN, (IDrd, O,) and ma$aq~apN, (TA,) [or] such as is vehement, (TA,) [or] such as is most vehement: (S, TA:) and, (K,) accord. to IF, (O,) constant anxiety; (O, K;) as also ↓ ganaZN: (K:) and, (K,) accord. to AO, (S, O,) a man's being at the point of death (S, O, K) by reason of distress, or grief, and then escaping therefrom. (S, O.) It is related of 'Omar Ibn-'Abd-el-'Azeez, that he mentioned death, and said, ganoZN layosa kaAlganoZi wakaZ~N layosa kaAlkaZ~i [i. e. Distress, &c., that is not like other distress, &c., and grief, &c., that is not like other grief, &c.: see kaZ~N]. (S, O.) [See also ginaAZN.]
ganaZN * : see ganoZN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A plant's becoming altered [for the worse] by heat. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)
ganaAZN * : see an ex. of its dual in the next paragraph.

ginaAZN * inf. n. of 3 [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And Distress; syn. jahodN, and karobN: El-Fak'asee says, [of a camel,]
tanotaHu *iforaAhu mina AlginaAZi
[His two protuberances behind the ears drip with sweat by reason of distress]. (TA.) [See also ganoZN.] faEala *`lika ginaAZayoka, as also ↓ ganaAZayoka, (K,) or, accord. to Lh, ganaAZayoka and EanaAZayoka, with g and E, (TA, [in which it is implied that ginaAZayoka is wrong, but this I think improbable,]) means He did that in order to distress thee time after time; (K;) like giyaAZaka and giyaAZayoka. (K in art. gyZ.)

ganiyZN *
Unripe dates that are cut off from the palm-trees, (AA, O, K,) after they have become yellow or red, or that are upon the racemes when the fruit of the palm-tree is cut off, (AA, O,) and are left (AA, O, K) upon the racemes (K) until they become ripe. (AA, O, K.)
gan~aAZN * an epithet applied by Ru-beh, or by El- 'Ajjáj, to a sword [app. as meaning That causes, or causing, much distress]. (IDrd, O, TA.)

ginoZiyaAnN * A man foul, unseemly, or obscene, in speech; (As, O, K, TA;) coarse, rude, or rough: (O, TA:) or who mocks at, derides, or ridicules, others: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA:) and EinoZiyAnN signifies the same: fem. with p. (O, TA.)

huwa A^agonaZuhumo *
He is the most vehemently grieved, or distressed, of them. (TA.)

magonuwZN *
Distressed. (S, TA.) [See also 1, of which it is the pass. part. n.]
rajulN mugaAniZN * (S, O) A man acting, or who acts, with another, contrariously, or adversely, and inimically, each doing to the other that which is distressing, or grievous; syn. mu$aAq~N. (O.)

1 ganima * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ganama , (Msb,) inf. n. gunomN (S, MA, Msb, * K, KL) and ganomN, (K,) or, as some say, the former is a simple subst. and the latter is an inf. n., (TA,) and ganamN and ganiymapN and gunomaAnN, (K,) He, or they, (i. e. a man, Msb, or a party of men, S,) obtained, got, or took, (Msb, K, * TK,) spoil, (K, * TK,) or a thing [as spoil]. (Msb, TA.) [And He acquired, or gained, a thing without difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience: or in this sense the inf. n. is gunomN,
which see below, voce ganiymapN.] maA ganimotumo in the Kur viii. 42 means What ye take by force [in war] from the unbelievers. (Bd, Jel.) [See also 8.]

2 gan~amotuhu * , inf. n. tagoniymN, I gave him spoil, or a free and disinterested gift; syn. naf~alotuhu: (S:) or gan~amahu ka*aA, inf. n. as above, he gave him such a thing as spoil, or as a free and disinterested gift; syn. naf~alahu A_iy~aAhu. (K.)

4 A^agonamahu Al$~aYo'a *
He made the thing to be to him spoil. (TA.)

5 tagan~ama see 8. ― -b2- One says also, huwa yatagan~amu AlA^amora, meaning He eagerly desires the affair like as one eagerly desires spoil. (TA.) -A2- And tgn~m, (TA in the present art.,) or tgn~m ganamFA, (AZ, T and TA in art. Abl,) He took for himself, got, gained, or acquired, sheep or goats or both: like as one says tA^b~l A_ibilFA. (AZ, T and TA in art. Abl; and TA * in the present art.)

8 Agtnmhu * , as also ↓ tgn~mhu, He reckoned it spoil: (S, K:) or both signify he took, seized, caught, or snatched, it as spoil. (KL.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, Agtnm AlfuroSapa He took, or seized, or [availed himself of,] the opportunity; or he hastened to take it; syn. AinotahazahaA. (S and A and K in art. nhz.)

gunomN * : see ganiymapN, in three places. ― -b2- It signifies also [The regaining (as is shown by an explanation of A 'Obeyd cited in the first paragraph of art. glq), and] the increase, and growth, and excess in value, of a pledge. (O in art. glq, and TA in the present art.) Thus in a trad., in which it is said, Alr~ahonu limano rahanahu lahu gunomuhu waEalayohi guromuhu [The pledge pertains to him who pledged it; to him pertains the regaining of it, and its increase, and growth, and excess in value, if such there be, and upon him lies the obligation to pay the debt for it, without requiring any abatement thereof if the pledge have unavoidably suffered damage or total loss: see the explanation of A 'Obeyd mentioned above]. (TA.) Algunomu biAlguromi means The gunom is compensated (muqaAbalN) by the gurom [i. e. the regaining of the pledge, with the increase and the growth and the excess in value thereof if such there be, is compensated by the payment of the debt for it]; for like as the owner [of the pledge] is exclusively entitled to the gunom, no one sharing it with him, so he bears the gurom, no one bearing it with him: and this is the meaning of their saying, Alguromu majobuwrN biAlgunomi [which may therefore be rendered The loss suffered by the payment of the debt is repaired by the regaining of the pledge; app. a phrase of the lawyers, implying that such is to be considered as the case whatever be the state of the pledge at the time of its being restored unless it have suffered damage through the fault of the pledgee]. (Msb.) [See more in the first paragraph of art. glq.] ― -b3- See also gunaAmaAka. -A2- gnm [app. gunomN] is mentioned by Suh as the name of A certain idol. (TA.)

ganamN *
i. q. $aA='N, (T, Msb, K,) meaning Sheep and goats; (Msb;) [and both together;] a gen. n., (S, Msb, K,) of the fem. gender, (S, K,) applied to the males and the females, and to both together: (S, Msb, K:) it has no sing. from which it is derived, the sing. being $Ap: the dual ganamaAni is used as meaning two flocks or herds [of sheep or of goats or of both together]; (Msb, K;) each flock or herd having its distinct place of pasture and its pastor: (Msb, TA: *) and hence it is said in a trad. that the poor-rate [meaning a portion thereof] is to be given to him to whom the year of drought has left a ganam, but not to him to whom it has left ganamayoni: (TA:) the pl. is A^agonaAmN, (Msb, K,) [properly a pl. of pauc.,] sometimes used, (Msb,) meaning flocks or herds of ganam, (Msb and TA in art. Abl,) and also gunuwmN and A^agaAnimu, (K,) the last used in an ode of Aboo-Jundab El-Hudhalee: (TA:) the dim. is ↓ gunayomapN, with p, because quasi-pl. ns. of the class having no sing. from which they are derived, when applied to what are not human beings, are constantly fem.; so one says xamosN mina Alganami *ukuwrN [five of sheep, males], making the n. of number fem., though one means rams, when it is followed by mina Alganami, for the n. of number is masc. and fem. accord. to the word, not accord. to the meaning. (S.) ― -b2- In the saying laA A=tiyka ganama Alfizori i. e. Hat~aY tajotamiEa ganamu Alfizori [I will not come to thee until the sheep, or goats, of El-Fizr congregate], gnm [with its complement] is made to stand in the place of Ald~ahor, [the meaning being, I will not come to thee ever,] and is [therefore] put in the accus. case as though it were an adv. n. [of time]. (TA. [This saying with miEozaY in the place of ganama is mentioned by El-Meydánee in his “ Proverbs, ” and thus in the S and K in art. fzr. For an explanation of its origin see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 484.]) ― -b3- AlA^agonaAmu is the name of (assumed tropical:) Certain small stars between the legs of Cepheus and the star AljadoYu. (Kzw, in his descr. of Cepheus.) [See $aApN (in art. $wh), last sentence.]
ganiymN * : see what next follows.

ganiymapN * and ↓ magonamN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ ganiymN and ↓ gunomN all signify faYo'N [as meaning Spoil, booty, or plunder]: and the acquisition of a thing without difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience: or this is termed ↓ gunomN, and faYo'N is termed ganiymapN: (K:) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, Alganiymapu signifies what is obtained from the believers in a plurality of gods, by force, during war; (Mgh, Msb:) and of this, a fifth is to be taken, [and applied in the manner prescribed in the Kur viii. 42,] and what remains after the fifth is for those who have obtained it, exclusively; (Mgh;) the horseman having three shares, and the foot-soldier having one share: (Az, TA:) and AlfaYo'u signifies what is obtained from them after the laying-down of arms, (Mgh, Msb,) when the country, or place, becomes a country, or place, of Islám; and this is for all of the Muslims, and is not to be divided into fifths: (Mgh:) or the faYo' is what God has given, or restored, of the possessions of the believers in a plurality of gods, to the Muslims, without war, such as the poll-tax, and that for which peace has been made with them; and of this also a fifth is to be applied in the manner prescribed by God, and the remainder is to be expended in the purchase of horses and weapons and other apparatus for the defence of the frontiers: (Az, TA:) and Aln~afalu is what is given to the warrior in addition to his share; and is when the Imám or the commander says, “ He who slays one shall have his spoil; ” or says to a detachment, “ What ye obtain shall be yours, ” or “ the quarter of it, ” or “ the half of it; ” and it is not divided into fifths; and it lies on the Imám to fulfil the promise: or, accord. to 'Alee Ibn-'Eesà, Alganiymapu is more general in signification than Aln~afalu; and AlfaYo'u is more so than Alganiymapu, because it is a name for everything of the possessions of the believers in a plurality of gods that becomes the property of the Muslims: accord. to the lawyers, everything that may be lawfully taken, of their possessions, is faYo': (Mgh:) the pl. of ganiymapN is ganaAy^imu; and the pl. of ↓ magonamN is magaAnimu, (Msb, TA,) and gunuwmN occurs as pl. of ↓ gunomN. (TA.) ganiymapN baAridapN see expl. in art. brd.
guniyomapN * dim. of ganamN, q. v. (S.)

gunaAmaAka A^ano tafaEala ka*aA * (S, K, * TA) means The utmost of thy power, or ability, and of thy case, (S, * TA,) and that which thou eagerly desirest like as one desires spoil, (S, * JM, TA, *) [is, or will be, thy doing such a thing;] i. q. quSaAraAka: (K, TA: [see also EunaAnaAka, in art. En:]) and so ↓ gunomuka: (TA:) and [in like manner] one says, A^ano yafoEala ka*aA ↓ gunayomaAw^uhu, like HusayonaAw^uhu, meaning quSaAraAhu [The utmost of his power, &c.]. (TA in art. Hsn.)
gunayomaAw^uhu * : see what next precedes.

gaAnimN *
Taking, or a taker, of ganiymap [or spoil]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also two exs. voce $aAjibN.
magonamN * : see ganiymapN, in two places.

ganamN mugonamapN * and mugan~amapN Sheep, or goats, collected together: (TA:) or many or numerous: (K, TA:) or, accord. to AZ, one of these two epithets, thus applied, [probably the latter, like muw^ab~alapN applied to A_ibilN, as he seems to say,] signifies [app. divided into distinct flocks or herds,] each [flock or herd] having its own pastor. (TA.)
gunowapN * : see the art. here following.

1 ganiYa * , (S, MA, Msb, K, *) from AlmaAl, aor. yagonaY, (Msb,) inf. n. ginFY (S, * MA, Msb, K *) and ganaA='N, (MA, K, * TK, [but the latter is app. held by some to be a simple subst.,]) He was, or became, free from want; in the state, or condition, of having no wants; and also, of having
few wants; or in a state of competence, or sufficiency; or rich, or wealthy; AlginaY being the contr. of Alfaqoru, as also AlganaA='u; (K, TA;) and thus denoting the absence, or non-existence, of wants, which is [properly, or strictly speaking,] attributable to none but God; and also the paucity of wants; (TA;) or syn. with AlyasaAru: (S:) and the epithet applied to him of whom this is said is ↓ ganiY~N, (S:) or ↓ gaAnK, (Msb,) [or both, for] both signify the same [as will be shown below]. (K.) One says ganiYa and ↓ AstgnY and ↓ tgn~Y and ↓ tgAnY and ↓ AgtnY, (K, TA, [but wanting in the CK, and app. in several copies of the K, though it is said in one place in the K, as it is in the S, that tgn~Y is syn. with AstgnY,]) all having one and the same meaning, and followed by bihi [as therewith signifying He was, or became, free from want; in the state, or condition, of having no want, or need; or in a state of competence, &c.; by means of it, or him; i. e. he was, or became, sufficed by it, or him; and hence, he was, or became, content, or satisfied, with it, or him]. (TA.) ↓ layosa min~aA mano lamo yatagan~a biAlquroA=ni, (Msb, TA,) a saying of the Prophet, (Msb,) mentioned in a trad., (TA,) means mn lm ↓ yasotagoni [i. e. He is not of us who is not content, or satisfied, with the Kur-án]: so says Sufyán Ibn-'Oyeyneh; not regarding it as meaning the utterance of the voice [in chanting]: and A 'Obeyd says that this obtains extensively in the speech of the Arabs; that they say ↓ tagan~ayotu and ↓ tagaAnayotu in the sense of ↓ Aisotagonayotu. (Az, Msb, TA.) And one says, ganiYa Eanohu, inf. n. ginFY and gunoyaAnN, meaning He was in no need of it [or him]: as also Enh ↓ AstgnY; and gnh ↓ A^agonaY [which seems to be rarely used in this sense]: and ↓ gunoyapN signifies the state of being in no need: and ↓ gaAnKi, a man free from need. (MA.) [And maA Eanohu ↓ yasotagoniY He is not without need, or not free from want, of it, or him.] And ganiYa bihi Eanohu, (S, Msb,) i. e. Eano gayorihi, (Msb,) inf. n. gunoyapN, (S,) or ↓ gunoyapN is the subst., (Msb,) meaning ↓ AstgnY [He was sufficed by it, or was satisfied, or content, with it, so as to be in no need, or so as to be free from want, of it, i. e. of another thing]: and the epithet is ↓ ganiY~N. (Msb.) And [in like manner] ganiyati AlmaroA^apu bizawojihaA (S, Msb, K) Eano gayorihi, (Msb,) inf. n. gunoyaAnN (S, K) and ganaA='N also, (TA,) meaning ↓ Aisotagonat [The woman was satisfied, or content, with her husband, so as to have no want of other than him]. (S, K) And ganiyato [alone], (K, TA,) inf. n. ginFA [for ginFY, or perhaps a mistranscription for ganaA='N, as in the next preceding sentence], She (a woman) was, or became, such as is termed gaAniyapN [q. v. voce gaAnK]. (K.) ― -b2- ganiYa, (TK,) inf. n. ginFY, (K, TK,) also signifies He married, or took a wife; [as also ↓ tgn~Y; (see Ham p. 226 l. 1, where tagan~ato occurs said of a woman as meaning she married;)] syn. tazaw~aja. (K, * TK. [In the K, only the inf. n. of the former verb in this sense is mentioned; AlginaY being there expl. in some copies as signifying Alt~azaw~uju; and in others, Alt~azowiyju.]) Hence the saying, AlginaY HiSonN liloEazabi [Marriage is a bulwark to him who has no wife; protecting him from the attacks of seductive women by rendering him free from the want of them]: mentioned by Az. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, ganiYa, (S, K,) inf. n. ginFY, (TA,) He dwelt, or abode, (S, K,) biAlmakaAni in the place: (S:) or ganiYa Alqawomu fiY daArihimo The people, or party, dwelt long in their place of abode: (T, TA:) or ganiYa fiY makaAni ka*aA He dwelt long in such a place, satisfied, or content, therewith, so as to be in no need of any other. (Er-Rághib, TA.) kaA^ano lamo yagonawoA fiyhaA, in the Kur [vii. 90 and xi. 71 and 98], means As though they had not dwelt therein. (TA.) [See also the last sentence but two in this paragraph.] ― -b4- And He lived; syn. EaA$a. (S, K.) ― -b5- And I. q. baqiYa: (TA:) one says, ganiytu laka min~iY biAlmawad~api, meaning baqiytu [i. e. I remained, or have remained, constant to thee with my love, or affection]. (ISd, K, TA: in the CK [erroneously] ganayotu.) ― -b6- [And I. q. kaAna.] qado A^agonaY AlHabiyba AlmuSaAfiYa, in a verse of Ibn-Mukbil, means A^akuwnu AlHabiyba [i. e. Certainly I will be, or shall be, the sincere friend]. (TA.) And ganiyato daArunaA tihaAmapa, (K, TA,) in a verse of another poet, (TA,) means kaAnato [i. e. Our place of abode was Tihámeh]. (K, TA.) And one says of a thing when it has perished, passed away, or come to nought, kaA^ano lamo yagona biAlA^amosi, meaning kaA^ano lamo yakuno [i. e. As though it had not been in existence yesterday]. (Az, TA.) -A2- ganiYa also signifies laqiYa: (K:) [SM doubts this; saying,] thus in the copies; but perhaps it should be baqiYa, a signification of ganiYa accord. to ISd and the K [and mentioned above]: (TA:) [it appears, however, to be correct; for it is said that] maA ganiytu fulaAnFA means lamo A^aloqahu [i. e. I did not meet, or meet with, or find, or I have not met, &c., such a one]. (JK.) [Accord. to the TK, ganiYa followed by bihi signifies laqiY: but this is perhaps said conjecturally.]

2 gan~aYa see 4. -A2- gn~Y, (S, MA, Msb,) inf. n. tagoniyapN, (KL,) as syn. with ↓ tgn~Y, (S, MA, Msb, *) He sang, or chanted, (S, * MA, KL;) or he trilled, or quavered, or prolonged his voice and modulated it sweetly, singing, or chanting. (Msb in explanation of the former.) You say gn~Ahu Al$~iEora [He sang, or chanted, to him the poetry], and gn~Y bihi [he sang, or chanted, it, i. e., the poetry], inf. n. tagoniyapN; and bihi ↓ tgn~Y; tgn~Y and gn~Y having one and the same meaning. (K, TA.) biAlquroA=ni ↓ yatagan~aY, in a trad. cited in the first paragraph of art. A*n, means, as expl. by EshSháfi'ee, Reciting [or chanting] the Kur-án with a plaintive and gentle voice. (Az, Msb, TA. [See also that trad. somewhat differently related voce taran~ama.]) ― -b2- gn~Y is also said of a pigeon, meaning It [cooed, or] uttered a cry; (K, TA;) and so ↓ tgn~Y. (TA.) ― -b3- gn~Y biAlmaroA^api means tagaz~ala bihaA, (K, TA,) i. e. He mentioned the woman [in amatory language, as an object of love,] in his poetry: (TA:) and gn~Y bizayodK He eulogized Zeyd: or he satirized him: like ↓ tgn~Y in these two senses: (K, TA:) in that of eulogizing and that of satirizing: or, in the opinion of ISd, both of the verbs are used in these two senses and likewise in the sense mentioned immediately before them; meaning that he did thus after prolonging and modulating his voice; singing, or chanting, the same, i. e. the gazal and the eulogy and the satire. (TA.)

3 gaAonaYa see ganaA='N. [From what is there said, it seems that gAnAhu signifies He was in no need of him, or it; like ganiYa Eanohu and AstgnY Enh: compare tagaAnawoA. -A2- And app. it signifies also He spoke, or talked, to him, i. e. to a child, or boy, saying to him what was pleasing to him; for it is said that] AlmugaAnaApu means takoliymuka AlS~abiY~a bimaA yahowaY. (JK.)

4 AgnAhu *
He (i. e. God, S, K, TA, [but wanting in the CK and app. in several copies of the K,]) rendered him, or made him to be, in no need, or free from want; (S, * MA, K; *) [or in a state of competence, or sufficiency;] or possessed of wealth; (S, * K, * TA;) [or rich, or wealthy; (see 1, first sentence;)] and ↓ gn~Ahu signifies the same; (K, TA; [but wanting in the CK and app. in several copies of the K;]) or, as some say, this latter is [used] in prayer [app. as meaning he said to him, May God enrich thee, or the like: compare saq~ayotuhu (“ I said to him, May God send down rain to thee ”), and Eaq~arotuhu (as expl. in art. Eqr), &c.]. (TA.) [And AgnAhu Eano ka*aA He, or it, caused him to be in no need, or free from want, of such a thing. (See Ham p. 152.) And yugoniY Eano A^ano tafoEala ka*aA It renders needless thy doing such a thing: lit. it causes that there shall be no need of thy doing such a thing.] ― -b2- And AgnY Eanohu ka*aA Such a thing sufficed him; or stood him in stead: whence the saying in the Kur [lxix. 28], maA A^agonaYEan~iY maAliyaho [My property has not sufficed me, or stood me in stead]: and [in iii. 8 and lviii. 18 of the same,] lano tugoniYa Eanohumo A^amowaAluhumo [Their possessions will not suffice them in lieu of God]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or this last means, will not defend them from God, i. e. from his punishment. (Jel in iii. 8.) And ↓ A^agonayotu Eanoka magonaY fulaAnK and ↓ magonaAtahu, (S, Msb, K, *) and ↓ mugonaY fulaAnK and ↓ mugonaAtahu, (S, Mgh, K,) and fulaAnK ↓ ganaA='a, (K,) I sufficed, or satisfied, or contented, thee, or I have sufficed, &c., as such a one; or I stood thee, or served thee, or I have stood &c., in the stead of such a one. (S, * Mgh, Msb, K.) And maA yugoniY Eanoka h`*aA This does not suffice, or satisfy, or content, thee; or stand thee, or serve thee, in any stead; and does not avail, or profit, thee.
(S.) AZ mentions maA A^agonaY fulaAnN $ayoy^FA, thus, and with E, [i. e. A^aEonaY,] as meaning Such a one did not avail, or profit, at all, in a difficult, or an arduous, affair or case; and did not suffice for such an affair or such a case, or for the supply of what was necessary for subsistence. (Msb, TA.) And he says also that he heard a man chide his slave, and say to him, A^agoni Ean~iY wajohaka balo $ar~aka, meaning Free me from, and avert from me, [thy face, nay, rather,] thy evil, or mischief: and hence the phrase $aA^onN yugoniyhi, [respecting which see the second sentence in art. EnY,] in the Kur [lxxx. 37]. (TA.) [Hence also,] wamaA A^ugoniY Eanokumo mina A@ll~`hi mino $aYo'K, in the Kur xii. 67, means But I do not avert from you, by my saying this, anything decreed to befall you from God: the second mn is redundant. (Jel.) And one says, A^agoni Ean~iY ka*aA, meaning Put thou away from me, and remove far from me, such a thing: properly [A^agoniniY Eano ka*aA, originally meaning render thou me in no need of such a thing,] a phrase of the same kind as EaraDa Ald~aAb~apa EalaY AlmaA='i [for EaraDa AlmaA='a EalaY Ald~aAb~api]. (Mgh.) -A2- A^agonaY Eanohu as intrans.: see 1, former half. -A3- maA A^agonaAhu [How free from wants, or how rich, or wealthy, is he!]: this and maA A^afoqarahu are [said to be] anomalous; for their [respective] verbs are AstgnY and Aftqr, from either of which the verb of wonder may not properly [or regularly] be formed. (S in art. fqr. [But see ganiYa as syn. with AstgnY; and see also art. fqr.])
5 tagan~aYa see 1, former half, in three places: ― -b2- and again in the latter half: -A2- and see also 2, in five places.

6 tagaAonaYa see 1, former half, in two places. ― -b2- tagaAnuwoA means They were, or became, free from want, one of another, or, as we say, of one another. (S, K.) El-Mugheereh Ibn-Habnà says,
Eano A^axiyhi HayaAtahu ↓ kilaAnaA ganiY~N
wanaHonu A_i*aA mutonaA A^a$ad~u tagaAniyaA
[Each of us is free from want of his brother in his life-time; and when we die, we shall be more free from such want]. (S.)
8 A_igotanaYa see 1, second sentence.

10 A_isotagonaYa see 1, in seven places. -A2- AstgnY A@ll~`ha He asked, or begged, God to render him, or make him to be, in no need, or free from want; [or in a state of competence, or sufficiency;] or rich, or wealthy. (K, TA. [But wanting in the CK, and app. in several copies of the K.]) Hence the prayer, Aall~`hum~a A_in~iYa A^asotagoniyka Eano kul~i HaArimK waA^asotaEiynuka [O God, I ask Thee to render me in no need of any one who refuses to give, and I beg thine aid]. (TA.)

ganFY * , (K, TA,) with fet-h, and maqoSuwr, (TA,) i. q. may^in~apN; so in the saying, makaAnu ka*aA ganFY mino fulaAnK [Such a place is meet, fit, or proper, for such a one; as though meaning a place of freedom from want]; as also minohu ↓ magonFY. (K, TA.)

ginFY * and ↓ ganaA='N signify the same; (MA, K;) both are inf. ns. of ganiYa: (MA:) [see the first sentence of this art.: used as simple substs., they mean Freedom from need or want; competence, or sufficiency; or richness, or wealthiness:] or ginFY is the inf. n. of ganiYa; (Msb;) and ↓ ganaA='N signifies competence, or sufficiency; (Mgh, Msb;) as in the saying, layosa Einodahu ganaA='N He has not competence, or sufficiency: (Msb:) or ganaA='N signifies profit, utility, or avail; (S;) and you say, rajulN laA ganaA='a Einodahu meaning A man who is not profitable to any one: (TA voce dadaAnN; [and in like manner this phrase, occurring in the S voce dadaAnN, is expl. in the PS:]) and ↓ gunowapN signifies the same as ginFY in the saying liY Eanohu gunowapN [I have no need of it, or him]: (K and TA in art. gnw:) so says Ks: but, as ISd says, the word commonly known is ↓ gunoyapN; (TA in that art.;) which see in two places in the former half of the first paragraph of this art.: this last word [said in the S to be an inf. n.] and ↓ ginoyapN and ↓ gunowapN and ↓ gunoyaAnN [which is said in the S and in one place in the K to be an inf. n.] are substs. having one and the same meaning [syn. with ginFY used as a simple subst.]: and maA lah Eanohu ginFY [in the CK erroneously ganFY] and ↓ gunoyapN and ↓ gunoyaAnN and ↓ magonFY mean [lit. He has not freedom from need of it, or him; and hence,] he has not any means, or way, of separating himself from, or avoiding, it, or him; syn. bud~N: (K:) and one says Eani ↓ fiY Aln~ikaAHi gunoyapN Als~ifaAHi [In marriage is freedom from need of fornication]. (A and Msb in art. sfH.) maA kaAna Eano Zahori ginFY, in a trad. respecting alms, means What is over and above that which suffices for the sustenance of the household, or family. (TA.)
gunowapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
gunoyapN * and ginoyapN: see ginFY; the former in three places.
gunoyaAnN * : see ginFY, latter half, in two places.

ganaA='N * : see ginFY, in two places; and see also 4, former half. A poet says,
sayugoniyniY A@l~a*iY A^agonaAka Ean~iY
falaA faqorN yaduwmu walaA ganaA='u
[He will render me free from need who has rendered thee free from need of me: for poverty will not always continue, nor competence, or richness]: or, as some relate it, ginaA='u, meaning thereby the inf. n. of ↓ gaAnayotu: [see 3, above:] but it is said that the proper reading is ganaA='u; because this has no other meaning than that of ginFY: so says ISd. (TA.) ― -b2- maA fiyhi ganaA='u *aAka means There is not in him [ability for] the setting-up of that, and strength, or power, to bear it, or carry it, or to raise it upon his back and rise with it. (ISd, K, TA.)

ginaA='N * is an inf. n. of 3. (TA, [See the next preceding paragraph.]) -A2- Also, (TA,) [Song, or vocal music; i. e.] an utterance of the voice with a prolonging and a sweet modulation thereof; (K, TA;) or a raising of the voice, and continuing it without interruption; (Nh, TA;) [a singing, and a chanting;] it is said in the S to be mina Als~amaAEi [meaning that it is a sort of musical performance]: (TA:) being an utterance of the voice, its analogical form would be with damm [i. e. gunaA='N, like HudaAdN &c.]: (Msb, TA:) its pl. is A^agoniyapN: (MA:) [and ↓ magonFY signifies the same as ginaA='N; and a mode of singing; and any particular air, or tune; and a song, i. e. a composition in verse that is sung or to be sung: and its pl. is magaAnK: but perhaps it is post-classical: the pl. occurs in the K, in art. nSb:] ginaA='N [also] signifies [a song, i. e.] poetry, or verse, that is [sung, or chanted, or] uttered with a trilling, or quavering, or a prolonging and a sweet modulation, of the voice; (Har p. 286;) and ↓ A^ugoniy~apN is syn. with ginaA='N (S, Har) in this sense; (Har;) or, as also ↓ A_igoniy~apN, (Fr, K, TA,) and ↓ each of them also without teshdeed, (K, TA,) as mentioned by ISd, but said by him to be not of valid authority, (TA,) signifies a certain sort of ginaA=' (K, TA) which they sing or chant: (TA:) and the pl. is A^agaAniY~u (S, TA) [and A^agaAnK, this latter being the pl. of each sing. that is without teshdeed]. ― -b2- AlginaA=' is also used by a poet in the place of an inf. n., meaning Alt~agan~iY: he says,
tagan~i biAl$~iEori A_im~aA kunota qaAy^ilahu
A_in~a AlginaA='a bh`*aA Al$iEori miDomaAru
[Sing thou, or chant thou, the poetry, if thou be uttering it: verily the singing, or chanting, this poetry is a mDmAr (expl. in art. Dmr)]. (TA.)

ganiY~N * and ↓ gaAnK: see 1, former half; each in two places: both signify [Free from want; or in a state of competence, or sufficiency; or rich, or wealthy; or] possessing much property or wealth: (K, * TA:) pl. of the former A^agoniyaA='u. (Msb, TA.) See an ex. of the former in a verse cited above, conj. 6. One says, A^anaA ganiY~N bika*aA Eano gayorihi [I am sufficed by such a thing, or satisfied, or content, with it, so as to be free from want of another thing]. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlganiY~u as a name of God signifies [The Self-sufficient; i. e.] He who has no need of any one in any thing. (TA.)

gan~aA='N *
A singer; (MA;) [as also ↓ mugan~K; and mugan~iyapN a female singer, a songstress:] accord. to Ibn-Ya'eesh, a ↓ mugan~K is thus called liA^an~ahu yugan~inu Sawotahu, i. e. because he makes his voice to have in it a gun~ap [or sort of nasal sound, or twang]; the word being, in his opinion, originally, mugan~inN, with three n, the last of which is changed into Y, when one says Almugan~iY, for the purpose of alleviating the utterance. (Mughnee, art. Harofu Aln~uwni.)

gaAnK * : see ganiY~N. ― -b2- [The fem.] gaAniyapN signifies A young woman who is sufficed by her husband; or satisfied, or content, with him, (S, Msb, TA, *) so as to be in no need, or free from want, of any other: (Msb:) and sometimes, also, applied to a woman, (S,) such as is sufficed by her beauty, (S, ISd, K, TA,) so as to be in no need of decoration (ISd, K, TA) with women's ornaments: (ISd, TA:) or such as is sought, or desired, by men, but does not seek, or desire: (ISd, K, * TA:) or such as has abode in the house, or tent, of her father and mother, and whom captivity (sibaA=') has not befallen; (IJ, ISd, K, * TA;) which is the strangest of the explanations: (TA:) or such as is youthful and chaste, whether having a husband or not: (ISd, K, TA:) or, accord. to AO, one that is married: (Ham p. 226:) or, accord. to Az, such as pleases men, and is pleased by $abaAb [which means both youthfulness and youths or young men]: (TA:) pl. gawaAnK; (K;) with the article, AlgawaAniY; [and also gaAniyaAtN: (see an ex. in a verse cited in the second paragraph of art. zj:)] in the saying of Ibn-Er-Rukeiyát,
laA baAraka A@ll~`hu fiY AlgawaAniYi halo
yuSobiHona A_il~aA lahun~a muT~alabu
[May God not bless those young women that are sufficed by their husbands, or by their beauty, &c.: do they enter upon the time of dawn without their having desire (lit. a time or place, meaning an occasion, of seeking, or desire) ?], the Y is made movent by a poetic license: (S, TA:) and another poet uses AlgawaAni for AlgawaAniY. (TA.)
A^agonaA='N * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] The A^amolaAkaAt [meaning Goods and chattels, or paraphernalia,] of brides. (Az, K.)
A^ugoniy~apN * and A_igoniy~apN, and each of them also without teshdeed: see ginaA='N, latter half.

magonFY * : see 4, former half: ― -b2- and ganFY: ― -b3- and ginFY, near the end. ― -b4- Also A place in which were its occupants, or inhabitants: (S:) or a place of abode by which its occupants, or inhabitants, were sufficed, or with which they were satisfied, or content, and from which they then departed, or removed: or in a general sense; (K, TA;) a place of abode, absolutely; but this seems to be a distinct application: (TA:) pl. magaAnK; with the article, AlmagaAniY. (S, TA.) -A2- See also ginaA='N.
mugonFY * : see 4, former half.

mugonK * [act. part. n. of 4,] A man sufficing, or satisfying, or contenting. (TA.) ― -b2- AlmugoniY as a name of God signifies He who satisfies, or contents, whom He will, of his servants. (TA.) ― -b3- And mugoniyapN A woman who satisfies, or contents, her husband, so as to render him in no need of looking at other than her. (Har p. 451.)
magonaApN * and mugonaApN: see 4, former half.
mugan~K * ; fem. mugan~iyapN see gan~aA='N, in two places.

1 gahiba * , [aor.
gahaba ,] inf. n. gahabN, He was unmindful, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless. (S.) You say, gahiba Eanohu He was unmindful, &c., and forgetful, of him, or it; (K, TA;) as also ↓ Aghb. (TA.) And A^aSaAba SayodFA gahabFA He hit an object of the chase, or objects thereof, inadvertently, unintentionally. (A 'Obeyd, S, K, from a trad.) ― -b2- And gahibahu He was ignorant of it; as also Eahibahu. (TA in art. Ehb.)
4 A^agohaba see the preceding paragraph.

8 Agthb *
He (a man, TA) journeyed in the darkness: (K, TA:) and went far away therein. (TA.)
gihib~aY Al$~abaAbi * and gihib~aAw^uhu, and likewise with the unpointed E, The first part, or state, of youth. (K, TA.)

gayohabN *
Darkness; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ gayohabaAnN: (K:) pl. of the former gayaAhibu. (S.) ― -b2- And A horse, and night, intensely black: (K, TA:) or, instead of waAll~ayoli in the K, we may read waAll~ayolu; so that the meaning may be, a horse intensely black: and night: agreeably with the A, in which this latter meaning [as well as the former] is assigned to the word; and it is added that one says, A^aHosanu mino bayaADi Alkawokabi fiY sawaAdi Algayohabi [More beautiful than the whiteness of the star in the blackness of night]: (TA:) or it signifies intense blackness of the night and of a camel and the like: you say jamalN gayohabN a deep-black camel: (Lth, TA:) and also A^asowadu gayohabN and gayohamN: (Lh, TA:) and rajulN gayohabN a black man; likened to the darkness of night: and layolN gayohabN a dark night: (Sh, TA:) and farasN A^adohamu gayohabN a horse intensely black: (Sh, S, TA:) and it is said in “ the Book of Horses ” by A 'Obeyd that A^adohamu ↓ gayohabiY~N signifies [a horse] of the deepest black hue: that the fem. is gayohabapN; and the pl., gayaAhibu: and that dajuwjiY~N is less than gayohabN in blackness, signifying “ of a clear black hue. ” (TA.) -A2- Also, applied to a man, Unmindful, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless: (K, TA:) and weak, and timid: (TA:) or (K, TA, but in the CK “ and, ”) a heavy, troublesome man: or stupid, dull, or wanting in intelligence; or inert, or wanting in vigour. (K, TA.) And Lacking ability to seek his blood-revenge, or retaliation; as also EayohabN. (TA in art. Ehb.) -A3- And A [garment of the kind called] kisaA=' having much wool; very woolly; (K, TA;) as also EayohabN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A male ostrich. (R, TA.)

gayohabapN *
A clamour, or confused noise, (K, TA,) and commotion, (TA,) in fight, or conflict. (K, TA.)
gayohabiY~N * : see gayohabN.
gayohabaAnN * : see gayohabN. -A2- Also The belly. (K.)

div2.head: gw or gwY
div2.entryFree: 1 gawaY * , aor. yagowiY, inf. n. gaY~N (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K, TA) and gawaAyapN; (A 'Obeyd, S, TA;) [respecting which latter see what follows;] and gawiYa (A 'Obeyd, K, TA, but not in the CK,) but this is not commonly known, (TA,) aor. yagowaY, inf. n. gawFY, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) accord. to the M and K gawaAyapN, mentioned above as of gawaY, (TA,) or this last, which is with fet-h, (Msb,) not to be pronounced with kesr, (K,) is a simple subst.; (Msb;) He erred; deviated from the right way or course, or from that which was right: (S, Msb, K:) and was disappointed; or failed of attaining his desire: (S, Msb:) and he laboured, and persisted, (IAth, Msb, TA,) in that which was vain, or false, (IAth, TA,) or in ignorant conduct: (Msb:) or he acted ignorantly from misbelief. (Er-Rághib, TA.) -A2- See also 4, in two places. -A3- gawiYa, aor. yagowaY; (S, Msb, K;) and gawaY, aor. yagowiY; (K;) inf. n. [of the former] gawFY; (S, K;) said of a young camel, (S, Msb, K,) and of a lamb or kid, (S,) He suffered indigestion from the milk; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) he drank the milk until he suffered indigestion; and his belly, or chest, became in a corrupt state; (S, Msb, * TA;) or he drank much thereof, so that he suffered indigestion: (TA:) or, accord. to ISk, (S, TA,) he did not satisfy his thirst with the biestings of his mother, (S,) or he did not drink thereof, (TA,) nor satisfy his thirst with the milk [after it], so that he died of emaciation: (S, TA:) or he (a kid, AZ, TA) was withheld from sucking (AZ, K, TA) until hunger injured him (AZ, TA) so that he became emaciated, (AZ, K, TA,) and almost perished: (K:) or he obtained not sufficient milk to satisfy his thirst so that he almost perished: (T, TA:) or, said of a child, and of a young camel, he found not a sufficiency of milk, so that he did not satisfy his thirst, and was seen to be meagre, or emaciated; thus accord. to ISh; and Sh says that his companions held this to be the correct meaning: (TA:) the epithet applied to the young camel [&c.] is ↓ gawK. (K.) Z has mentioned the reading in the Kur [xx. 119], waEaSaY A=damu rab~ahu fagawiYa, expl. as meaning [And Adam disobeyed his Lord, and] suffered indigestion from much eating: but better than this is what Az and Er-Rághib say; that it is fagawaY; and that the meaning is, and his life became evil to him; or he was disappointed; or he acted ignorantly; or some other of the meanings mentioned by the expositors. (TA.)

2 1a2~a3a see 4. ― -b2- gaw~ayotu All~abana, (K, TA,) inf. n. tagowiyapN, (TA,) I made the milk to become such as is termed raAy^ib [i. e. thick, or coagulated, &c.]; (K, TA;) as though I spoiled it, so that it became thick. (TA.)

4 AgwAhu * ; (S, MA, Msb, K;) and ↓ gw~Ahu, (K,) inf. n. tagowiyapN; (TA;) and ↓ gawaAhu, (K, TA,) mentioned by El-Muärrij; (TA;) [but] accord. to As, one should not say otherwise than AgwAhu; (S, TA;) He caused him to err; or to deviate from the right course, or from that which was right: (S,
Msb, K:) and caused him to be disappointed; or to fail of attaining his desire: (S:) or he seduced him, misled him, or led him astray; as also ↓ AstgwAhu. (MA.) A poet, cited by El-Muärrij, says,
