wakaAy^ino taraY mino jaAhilK baEoda Eilomihi
↓ AlhawaY jaholFA Eani AlHaq~i faA@nogawaY ↓ gawaAhu
[How many an ignorant dost thou see, whom, after his knowledge, love, or desire, has urged to turn, in ignorance, from that which was right, and who has turned: or has turned, in ignorance, from that which was right, and who has suffered himself to be turned; for,] accord. to Az, gawaAhu AlhawaY is most correctly rendered as meaning lawaAhu, and Sarafahu; and AngwY is quasi-pass. thereof. (TA.) The saying in the Kur [vii. 15], related as from Iblees, fabimaA A^agowayotaniY means [Then by, or because of,] thy having caused me to err: or, as some say, invited me to [do] a thing whereby I have erred. (TA.) But the saying in the same [xi. 36], A_ino kaAna A@ll~`hu yuriydu A^ano yugowiyakumo is said to mean If God desire to punish you for erring: or to decree, against you, your erring [i. e. that ye shall err]. (TA.)

6 tagaAwawoA Ealayohi *
They collected themselves together, or combined, and aided one another, against him; (S, TA;) originally, (TA,) in an evil affair; from AlgaY~ and AlgawaAyap: (S, TA:) or they aided one another against him, and slew him; (K;) but this addition “ and slew him ” is from a trad. respecting the slaying of 'Othmán, in which it is said, fatagaAwawoA Ealayohi waA@ll~`hi Hat~aY qataluwhu [and they collected themselves together, &c., against him, by God, so that they slew him]: (TA:) or they came against him from this quarter and from that; though they did not slay him: (ISd, K, TA:) or they collected themselves together, and aided one another, against him, as do those who err, or deviate from the right way or course; thus expl. by Z. (TA.) [See also 6 in arts. gY and Ew.]

7 AngwY * signifies AinohawaY and maAla [app. He declined from the right way or course; for all of these three verbs seem to be here used in one and the same sense, agreeably with a saying in the JK, AlmunogawiY $ibohu AlmunohawiY AlmaAy^ilu]: (K:) [or rather,] accord. to Az, [it signifies he was, or became, or suffered himself to be, made to decline, or to turn, from the right way or course, by love, or desire; for he says that] it is quasi-pass. of gawaAhu AlhawaY, which signifies A^amaAlahu and Sarafahu: (TA:) or he fell into error by yielding to love and desire. (TK: there given as the meaning of the explanation in the K.) See also 4.
10 A_isota1o2a3a see 4, first sentence.

R. Q. 2
if belonging to art. gw, or Q. Q. 2 if belonging to art. gwg. tagaAgaY Ealayohi AlgawogaA='u [as though originally tagawogaY]: see art. gwg.

gawFY *
Thirst. (TA.) ― -b2- And one says, bit~u gawFY, and ↓ gawiy~FA, and ↓ mugowiyFA, (K, TA,) in the T ↓ mugaw~FY, (TA,) [in the CK magowiy~FA,] meaning muxoliyFA (K, TA) [in the CK muxal~ayFA] muwHi$FA (TA) [i. e. I passed the night empty]: and so qawiyFA, and qaAwiyFA, and muqowiyFA. (TA.) [See also gawiY~N.]
gawK * : see gaAwK: -A2- and see also 1, near the end.

gaY~N * is an inf. n.; as also ↓ gawaAyapN; (A 'Obeyd, S, &c.; [see 1, first sentence;]) or the latter is a simple subst.: (Msb:) [both, used as substs., signify Error; &c.: ↓ gay~apN, of which the pl. (gay~aAtN) is mentioned by Freytag as meaning errors, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees, is an inf. n. of un., and signifies an error, &c.:] and gaY~N signifies also a state of perdition. (Ham p. 643.) See also gay~apN. ― -b2- Also A certain valley in Hell: or a river [therein]: (K, TA:) prepared by God for those who err: it is said that it has one or the other of these meanings in the Kur xix. 60: (TA:) or it there means (assumed tropical:) punishment; because it is the consequence of gaY~ [properly thus termed]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it there means evil: or the recompense of gaY~ [i. e. of error]: or deviation from the way of Paradise. (Bd.)
gaw~apN * : see the next paragraph.

gay~apN * : see gaY~N. ↓ gaw~apN and gay~apN signify the same. ― -b2- [Hence,] waladu gay~apK, and ↓ giy~apK, (K, TA,) but the latter is said by Lh to be rare, (TA,) The offspring of fornication or adultery; (K, TA;) contr. of waladu ri$odapK. (TA.) And one says also ↓ Aibonu AlgaY~i [meaning The son of fornication or adultery]. (L in art. bhv.) And huwa ligay~apK, (S, Msb,) and ↓ ligiy~apK, said in reviling a person, He is, or was, unlawfully begotten; (Msb;) contr. of liri$odapK. (S.)
giy~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

gawiY~N * : see gaAwK: -A2- and see also gawFY. You say of a hungry person, raA^ayotuhu gawiy~FA mina AljuwoEi [I saw him empty, or lean, from hunger]; like as one says qawiyFA and DawiyFA [or DaAwiyFA] and TawiyFA. (TA.)
gawaAyapN * : see gaY~N, above.
gay~aAnu * [as though originally gawoyaAnu]: see what next follows.

gaAwK * , and ↓ gawiY~N, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ gawK, (S, TA,) and ↓ gay~aAnu, (K,) [or the first is an act. part. n., and the others are intensive epithets,] Erring; deviating from the right way or course, or from that which is right: (S, Msb, K:) and suffering disappointment; or failing of attaining his desire: (S, Msb:) [&c.: (see 1, first sentence:)] and the first signifies also perishing: (Ham p. 643:) the pl. of the first is guwaApN, (Msb, TA,) like quDaApN pl. of qaADK, (Msb,) and gaAwawna. (K.) AlgaAwuwna in the saying waA@l$~uEaraA='u yat~abiEuhumu AlgaAwuwna [in the Kur xxvi. 224] means The devils: or those, of mankind, who err: (K, TA:) or those who love the poet when he satirizes a people, or party, (Zj, K, TA,) by saying that which is not allowable: (Zj, TA:) or those who love him for his praising them for that which is not in them. (Zj, K, TA.) ― -b2- And AlgaAwiY signifies The locust, or locusts collectively: (K, TA:) one says, jaA='a AlhaAwiY waAlgaAwiY, meaning The wolf and the locust, or locusts, came: (TA:) so says IAar. (TA in art. hwY, where, in the K, AlhaAwiY is said to signify “ the locust ” or “ locusts. ”) ― -b3- raA^osN gaAwK is a tropical phrase, meaning, accord. to the K, A small head: but accord. to the A, a head that turns, or looks, aside, much, or often. (TA.)

gaAwiyapN *
i. q. raAwiyapN, (Sgh, K, TA,) [as meaning] A camel that carries water: pl. gawaAyaA: [the sing. and pl. being] like zaAwiyapN and zawaAyaA. (JK.)
gaAgN * and gaAgapN, the latter mentioned in the K in this art. as meaning A certain plant: see art. gwg.
gawogaA='N * and gawogaA='u: see art. gwg.

A^ugowiy~apN *
A [pitfall such as is termed] zuboyap; (K, TA;) or a hollow, or pit, dug in the ground, like a zuboyap, for the wolf, and in which a kid is put; and when he [the wolf] looks at it, he falls, desiring to obtain it, and so is taken: (TA:) and ↓ mugaw~aApN [likewise] signifies a zuboyap, (TA,) or a hollow, or pit, dug in the ground, like a zaboyap, (S,) for [catching] beasts of prey: (TA:) whence the saying, (S, TA,) which is a prov., (TA,) mano Hafara mugaw~aApF A^awo$aka A^ano yaqaEa fiyhaA [He who digs a pitfall is near to his falling into it]: (S, * TA:) pl. mugaw~ayaAtN. (S.) ― -b2- And A cause, or place, of perdition or death; (K, TA;) as also ↓ mugaw~aApN: (TA:) or a calamity, or misfortune; thus in the saying, waqaEa Aln~aAsu fiY A^ugowiy~apK [The people fell into a calamity, or misfortune]. (S.)
mugowK * ; whence the phrase bit~u mugowiyFA: see gawFY.
magowaApN * : see mugaw~aApN, in two places.
mugaw~FY * , in the phrase bitu mugaw~FY: see gawFY.

mugaw~aApN * : see A^ugowiy~apN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A land in which one errs from the right way; syn. maDil~apN; (K, TA; in the CK miDal~ap;) as also ↓ magowaApN, like mihowaApN; (K, TA; in the CK migowAp, like mihowAp;) and so A^aroDN mugaw~aApN: (TA:) the pl. of mugaw~aApN is mugaw~ayaAtN; (K, TA;) and that of ↓ magowaApN is magaAwK. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Any well. (AA, TA.)
1 gaAva * : see 4. -A2- [And see also gawiyvN.]

2 gw~v * , (S, K,) inf. n. tagowiyvN; (K;) and ↓ AstgAv; (TA;) He cried out, (TA,) and said, (S, K,) ↓ waA gawovaAhu (S, K, TA) [Alas! a cry for aid, or succour! also pronounced wA gawovaAhi (accord.
to one of my copies of the S) and wA gawovaAho]. You say, Duriba fulaAnN fagaw~ava Such a one was beaten, and cried wA gwvAh. (TA.) This is declared by the leading grammarians to be the primary signification of gw~v: then they used it as meaning He cried out, or called, desiring, or demanding, aid, or succour. (MF.) -A2- See also gawiyvN.

4 AgAvhu * , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_igaAvapN (Msb, K) and ↓ maguwvapN [which is anomalous], (K,) He aided, or succoured, him; (Msb;) He (i. e. God, Msb) removed from him trouble, or affliction: (Msb, TA:) ↓ gaAvahu, aor. yagiyvuhu, is used in the sense of AgAvhu, but is rare, and is said [by some] to be from Algayovu, not AlA_igaAvapu: gAvhu, aor. yaguwvuhu, is mentioned by Az as not heard by him from any one; but ISd mentions gAvhu, inf. n. gawovN and giyaAvN, though saying that AgAvhu is more approved. (TA.) And one says also, A^agaAvanaA AlmaTaru (assumed tropical:) [The rain gave us relief]. (Msb.)
6 tagaAwavuwA * , accord. to Freytag, appears to be used in the Deewán of the Hudhalees as signifying They said, one to another, waA gawovaAhu: -A2- and tgAwv as syn. with A^agaAva.]

10 AstgAvhu * , (S, O, Msb, K,) and AstgAv bihi, (O, Msb, TA,) the latter disallowed by some, but used by Sb, (TA,) He sought, desired, or demanded, aid, or succour, of, or by means of, him, or it; he sought, &c., [or called for,] his aid, or succour. (O, MF, TA.) ― -b2- See also 2. [Hence, AstgAv AlEuwdu (assumed tropical:) The lute sent forth plaintive sounds: a modern phrase.]

gawovN * and ↓ guwaAvN and ↓ gawaAvN, (S, K,) the last deviating from the common course of speech, (K, TA,) with respect to analogy, as will be seen from what follows, (TA,) A cry for aid, or succour. (S, K, KL, PS.) One says, A^ajaAba A@ll~`hu ↓ duEaA='ahu wguwaAvahu and ↓ gawaAvahu [God answered his prayer, and his cry for aid]. (Fr, S.) ↓ gawaAvN is said by Fr to be the only word significant of a sound, or cry, having fet-h [to the first letter]; other words of this kind being with damm, as bukaA='N and duEaA='N, or with kesr, as nidaA='N and SiyaAHN. (S.) See also 2. ― -b2- And see giyaAvN.
gawaAvN * : see gawovN, in three places: ― -b2- and see also giyaAvN. ― -b3- In the dial. of Himyer it signifies (assumed tropical:) Travelling-provision. (TA.)
guwaAvN * : see gawovN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following.

giyaAvN * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) in which the w is changed into Y because of the kesreh preceding it, (S,) a form disapproved by some of the lexicographers, but several others assign to it priority, (MF,) a subst. from A^agaAvahu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) as also ↓ gawaAvN, ascribed by Ibn-Hajar to the majority, and ↓ guwaAvN, mentioned on the authority of Aboo-Dharr, (MF,) and ↓ gawovN; (Msb;) signifying Aid, or succour; (Msb;) or deliverance from difficulty, distress, or adversity, and [from] revenge; and aid to release from difficulties, distresses, or adverse circumstances. (MF.) In the T, AlgiyaAvu is expl. as signifying That with which God aids, or succours, one. (TA.) ― -b2- And giyaAvN signifies also An aider, or a succourer: you say, fulaAnN giyaAvunaA Such a one is our aider, or succourer; i. q. ↓ mugiyvunaA: (TA in art. nwr:) and God is said to be giyaAvu Almusotagiyviyna [The Aider of the seekers of aid]. (O.) ― -b3- [Hence,] A^um~u giyaAvK is a name for (assumed tropical:) The cooking-pot. (T in art. Am.)

gawiyvN *
Food, or other succour, with which one aids a person in necessity. (O, K.) -A2- Also, (O, K,) in one copy of the K ↓ tagowiyvN, (TA,) [both perhaps inf. ns., the former like dabiybN &c.,] Vehemence of running ($id~apu EadowK). (O, K.)
mugiyvN * : see giyaAvN, last sentence but one.
maguwvapN * , an [anomalous] inf. n.: see 4.

magaAwivu *
Waters: (O, K:) said to be one of those plurals that have no singulars. (TA.)

yaguwvu *
A certain idol which belonged to [the tribe of] Medhhij: (Zj, ISd, K, TA:) or a certain good man, who lived between [the times of] Adam and Noah, and of whom, after his death, was made an image, which, after a long time, became an object of worship; like wad~N and suwaAEN and yaguwqu and nasorN, mentioned therewith in the Kur lxxi. 22 and 23. (Bd.)

1 gaAja * , (S, O, K,) aor. yaguwju, (S, O,) said of a man; (TA;) and ↓ tgw~j, (O, K,) likewise, (TA,) or this is said of a horse; (O;) He affected a bending of his body, syn. tavan~aY and taEaT~afa, (S, O, K, TA,) and inclined from side to side, in his gait. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
Ea$iy~apa qaAmato biAlfinaA='i kaA^an~ahaA
Eaqiylapu nahobK tuSoTafaY wataguwju
[In the evening when she arose, in the yard of the dwelling, as though she were the most excellent portion of booty, to be selected therefrom, and affecting a bending of her body, and inclining from side to side]: i. e. displaying herself to the chief of the army, in order that he might take her for himself. (S, O.)
5 tagaw~aja see the preceding paragraph.

gawojN * , applied to a horse, Pliant, pliable, limber, or lithe; syn. lay~inu AlA^aEoTaAfi: pl. guwjN. (En-Nadr, TA.) ― -b2- And A man relaxed by reason of drowsiness. (TA.) ― -b3- And A broad-breasted camel. (TA.) ― -b4- And gawoju All~abaAni A horse ample in the skin of the breast, (S, O, K,) but not unless he be saholu AlmaEoTifi [i. e. pliant, pliable, limber, or lithe]: (S, O, TA:) or a horse long in the qaSab [or bones of the legs]: or that bends, going and coming. (TA.) ― -b5- And gawojN mawojN, the latter word being an imitative sequent, A horse fleet, or swift; excellent in running; or that outstrips others. (TA.)

gaw~aAjN *
That goes with energy: an epithet applied by Aboo-Wejzeh to a camel. (O.)

1 gaAra * , (As, Fr, IAar, S, Msb, &c.,) aor. yaguwru, (S, &c.,) inf. n. gaworN (S, K) and guw^uwrN; (K;) and ↓ AgAr, (Fr, Msb,) inf. n. A_igaArapN; (K;) but IAth says that this form of the verb is of rare occurrence, (TA,) and As disallows it; (S, Msb, TA;) and ↓ gw~r, inf. n. tagowiyrN; (S, K;) and ↓ tgw~r; (K, TA;) He came to the gawor, (As, Fr, IAar, S, Msb, K,) i. e., low land or country, (Msb,) [or the region so called, in Arabia:] or gAr signifies he journeyed in the region of the gwr: (As, TA:) or gAr and ↓ AgAr signify he took his way towards the gawor. (TA.) There is a difference of opinion respecting the saying of El-Aashà,
nabiY~N yaraY maA laA tarawona wa*ikoruhu
laEamoriY fiY AlbilaAdi waA^anojadaA ↓ A^agaAra
[meaning, accord. to the first explanation of AgAr, A prophet who seeth what ye see not, and whose fame has come to the low lands, by my life, or by my religion, in the several regions, and has come to the high lands]: As says that AgAr signifies has gone quickly; and Anjd, has risen; and that the poet does not mean has come to the low lands nor to the high lands; holding gAr only to signify the coming to the low land: but Fr asserts that AgAr is a dial. var. of gAr; and cites this verse as authority: and some say AgAr wAnjd, but when they do not conjoin the two verbs they say gAr; like as they say hanaA^aniY AlT~aEaAmu wamaraA^aniY, but when they do not conjoin these two verbs they say A^amoraA^aniY: (S:) As also mentions another relation of the second hemistich, commencing AgAm [app. a mistake for A^aqaAma or some other word]: (IKtt:) and there is another relation, accord. to which the second hemistich is maxoruwm, commencing with gaAra. (L.) You say also gaAra waA^anojada meaning (assumed tropical:) He became famous in the low countries and the high. (A in art. njd.) ― -b2- gAr fiY $aYo'K, inf. n. gaworN and guw^uwrN (K) and giyaArN, (Sb, K,) He, or it, entered [or entered deeply] into a thing. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] gAr fiY A^amorK (tropical:) He examined minutely [or deeply] into an affair; (IKtt, Msb;) as also ↓ AgAr. (IKtt.) You say fulaAnN biEiydu Algawori (tropical:) Such a one is a deep examiner: (TA:) or acquainted [deeply] with affairs: or very rancorous, malevolent, malicious, or spiteful. (Msb.) [See also gaworN, below.] ― -b4- gAr AlmaA='u, (Lh, S, Msb, K,) fiY AlA^aroDi (K,) inf. n. gaworN (Lh, S, K, &c.) and guw^uwrN; (S, TA;) and ↓ gw~r, (Lh, TA,) inf. n. tagowiyrN; (K;) The water sank, (S, IKtt,) or went away, (Msb, K,) into the ground, or earth: (S, Msb, K:) or went away into the sources, or springs. (Lh.) ― -b5- gaArati
Al$~amosu, (S, K,) aor. taguwru, (S,) inf. n. giyaArN (S, K) and guw^uwrN; (K;) and ↓ gw~rt; (K;) The sun set: (S, K:) and in like manner one says [gAr and ↓ gw~r] of the moon and of a star. (TA.) ― -b6- gaArato Eayonuhu, aor. taguwru, (S, Msb,) inf. n. gaworN (S, TA) and guw^uwrN; (S, Msb, TA;) and gaArato, aor. tagaAru; (S, TA;) and ↓ gw~rt; (TA;) His eye sank, or became depressed, (lit. entered,) in the head; (S, TA;) i. q. Ainoxasafato. (Msb.) ― -b7- gAr Aln~ahaAru (assumed tropical:) The day became intensely hot [app., like gaw~ara, meaning when the sun had declined from the meridian]: (K:) hence AlgaAy^irapu [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b8- See also 2. -A2- gaAra $ayoy^FA, aor. yaguwru, He sought for, or after, a thing. (TA.) -A3- gaArahumo, and gaAra lahumo, [aor. yaguwru,] inf. n. giyaArN, He (God) bestowed upon them giyrap, (K,) i. e. miyrap [a provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]. (TA.) [See also art. gyr.] ― -b2- He benefited them; (S in art. gyr, and TA;) and so gaArahumo bixayorK: (S:) and gaArahumo, aor. yaguwru, (K,) inf. n. giyaArN; (TA;) or gaArahumo bixayorK; (TA;) He (God) bestowed upon them abundance of the produce of the earth, and rain: (K, TA:) and gaArahumo birizoqK He bestowed upon them means of subsistence. (TA.) You say also Aall~`hum~a guronaA bigayovK, (K,) and bimaTarK, and bixayorK, (TA,) and guronaA minoka bigayovK, (S,) O God, aid us, or succour us, with rain (S, K) from Thee, (S,) and with prosperity. (TA.) [See also art. gyr.] -A4- gaAra Alr~ajula, aor. yaguwruhu and yagiyruhu, He gave the man the bloodwit [which is termed giwarN and giyarN]: (ISk, TA:) and so gay~arahu. (TA in art. gyr.) -A5- gaAra EalaY A^aholihi, aor. yagaAru, inf. n. giyrapN [or rather gayorapN (see art. gyr)] and gaArN, [He was jealous of his wife.] (IKtt.) gaArN and gayorapN, (S, so in my two copies,) or gaArN and giyrapN, with kesr, (K,) signify the same. (S, K.) You say fulaAnN $adiydu AlgaAri EalaY A^aholihi i. e. Algyrp [Such a one is vehemently jealous of his wife]. (TA.) See also art. gyr.

2 gw~r * , inf. n. tagowiyrN: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- Also He slept in the middle of the day; (S, * K, TA;) and so ↓ gaAra. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And He alighted (Lth, S, K, TA) to sleep (Lth, S, TA) in the middle of the day. (Lth, S, K, TA.) And gaw~iruwA binaA Make ye the camels to lie down with us during the vehement midday-heat. (Jm and TA in art. rmD.) IAar says that ↓ mugaw~irN signifies One alighting in the middle of the day for a little while and then departing [i. e. resuming his journey]. (TA.) And maA bit~u h`*ihi All~ayolapa A_il~aA tagowiyrFA occurs in a trad. as meaning [I did not tarry, or have not tarried, this night,] save in taking a nap [like the sleep in the middle of the day]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also He entered upon the middle of the day. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And He journeyed in the middle of the day: (Lth, K:) or he (a rider upon a camel, or upon a horse or other beast,) journeyed until the declining of the sun from the meridian, and then alighted. (ISh, TA.) ― -b6- And gw~r Aln~ahaAru (tropical:) [app. The day became intensely hot when] the sun declined from the meridian. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA. [See also gaAra Aln~ahaAru.]) -A2- gw~rhu, inf. n. as above, He put it, or made it to enter, into a low, or depressed, place: he hid, or concealed, it; or caused it to disappear. (Har p. 165.) ― -b2- And gw~r, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) signifies also He routed, defeated, or put to flight; and he drove away. (K, * TA.)
3 gaAowara see 4; and see also 6.

4 AgAr Eayonahu * [He made his eye to sink, or become depressed, in his head: see 1]. (TA.) -A2- AgAr as intrans.: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- Also He went away in, or into, the country, or land. (K.) ― -b3- And, (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. A_igaArapN (S, Mgh, Msb) and gaArapN, (Mgh,) or the latter is a simple subst., [or quasi-inf. n.,] (Msb,) He hastened, (K,) or was quick, (Msb,) in walking, or marching, or journeying: (Msb, K:) he was quick, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and pushed, or pressed, on, or forward, (dafaEa, S,) in his running; (S, Mgh, Msb;) said of a horse, (Mgh, Msb,) and of a fox: (S, Mgh:) he (a horse, K) ran vehemently, and was quick, (S, K,) in a gaArap [or raid, or sudden attack upon a people, or their dwellings,] &c. (K.) Hence the saying, (in a trad. respecting the pilgrimage, TA,) A^a$oriqo vabiyro kayomaA nugiyro [Enter thou upon the time of sunrise, Thebeer, (the name of a mountain near Mekkeh,)] that we may proceed quickly, (S, K,) or push, or press, on, or forward, (Yaakoob, Msb,) to the sacrifice of the pilgrimage: (S, Msb, K:) or to the return from Minè: (Yaakoob:) or that we may plunder the meats of the sacrifices: or that we may enter into the low land. (TA. [See also 2 in art. $rq.]) Hence also the saying, A^agaAra A_igaArapa Alv~aEolabi He was quick, and pushed, or pressed, on, or forward, like as does the fox. (S.) ― -b4- AgAr EalaY AlEaduw~i, (S, Msb,) and EalaY Alqawomi, (K,) inf. n. A_igaArapN (S, K) and gaArapN, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst., [or quasi-inf. n., as in the case mentioned above,] (TA,) and mugaArN, (S, TA,) He made [a raid, or hostile or predatory incursion, into the territory of the enemy; or] a sudden, or an unexpected, attack [upon the enemy, or] upon the territory or dwellings of the enemy, [with a party of armed horsemen, generally meaning a predatory incursion,] and engaged with them in conflict; (Msb,) or he urged the horses upon, or against, the people; as also ↓ AstgAr: (K, TA:) and in like manner you say AlEaduw~a ↓ gAwr, inf. n. mugaAwarapN and giwaArN. (S.) See also 6. And AgAr Al*~iy^obu fiY Alganamoi The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats; (K * and TA in art. $E;) as also ↓ AstgAr. (TA ibid.) ― -b5- Also AgAr Ealayohi He plundered it; took it by pillage. (TA.) ― -b6- And AgAr bibaniY fulaAnK, and sometimes A_ilaY bnY flAn, He came to the sons of such a one to aid, or succour, them: (IKtt, K:) or to be aided, or succoured, by them. (IKtt.) -A3- AgAr, (S, K,) inf. n. A_igaArapN and quasi-inf. n. gaArapN, (TA,) signifies also He twisted hard (S, K) a rope. (S.) -A4- AgAr A^aholahu He married another in addition to his wife [and so caused her to be jealous: see 1]. (S.) [See also art. gyr.]
5 tagaw~ara see 1, first signification.

6 tgAwrwA *
They made [raids, or hostile or predatory incursions, into each other's territories; or] sudden attacks, one upon another, or one party upon the dwellings of another party, and engaged in conflict, one with another; or urged their horses one upon, or against, another; expl. by ↓ A^agaAra baEoDuhumo EalaY baEoDK: (S, K:) and so ↓ gAwrwA, inf. n. mugaAwarapN. (TA.)

8 AgtAr *
He procured miyrap [or provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And He derived, or obtained, benefit, advantage, or profit. (K.)

10 A_isotagowara
He, or it, descended: (TA:) or he desired to descend into a low land or country. (K, TA.) ― -b2- See also 4, in two places. -A2- Also He became fat; and fat entered into him: (S, TA:) or you say, AstgAr Al$~aHomu fiyhi fat spread in him; and he became fat; (K, TA;) the pronoun referring to a horse, which is not mentioned in the K; but the explanation in the S is better: or, accord. to Az, AstgAr is said of the fat and flesh of a she-camel, meaning it became hard, and compact; like the rope of which one says yasotagiyru i. e. it is twisted hard: or, accord. to some, said of the fat of a camel, it means it entered his inside. (TA.) ― -b2- AstgArt said of a wound, (qaroHapN, S, in the K juroHap,) means It became swollen. (S, K.) -A3- Aisotagowara A@ll~`ha He asked, or begged, of God, giyrap, (K, TA,) i. e. miyrap [provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]. (TA.)

gaArN *
A cave, or cavern; syn. kahofN; (S, K;) in a mountain; (S;) as also ↓ magaArapN and ↓ magaArN (S, K) and ↓ mugaArapN and ↓ mugaArN and ↓ gaworN: (K: [but gaArN in this sense is omitted in the CK:]) or what resembles a khf in a mountain, [only differing in being less large,] like a sarab: (TA:) or what is hewn out in a mountain, resembling a magaArap: when it is large, or spacious, it is called khf: (Msb:) or what resembles a house, or chamber, in a mountain: (Lh, K:) or a low, or depressed, place in a mountain: (Th, K:) or any low, or depressed, land, country, or ground: (K:) see also gaworN [and xaworN]: or the hole, or burrow, to which a wild animal betakes itself: (K: [see an instance in art. smw, conj. 8:]) and sometimes ↓ magaArN is applied to the coverts of gazelles, among trees: (S:) the dim. of gaArN is guwayorN: (S, K:) [of which see two exs. (a prov. and a verse) voce buw^osN:] and the pl. (of pauc., TA) A^agowaArN (IJ, K) and (of mult., TA) giyraAnN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also The portion of the upper part of the mouth which is behind the faraA$ap [or thin bone of the palate]: or the hollow (A^uxoduwd) which is between the two jaws: or the interior of the mouth: (K: [for daAxila Alfami, in the CK, I read daAxilu Alfm, as in the TA:]) or, as some say, the two parts whereof each is called niToEN, [app. meaning the anterior part of the palate and the corresponding
part next the lower gums,] in the HanakaAni [or the palate and the part corresponding to it below]. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlgaAraAni signifies The [sockets of the eyes; or] two bones in which are the eyes. (ISd, K.) ― -b4- And The belly and the pudendum: (S:) or the mouth and the pudendum. (K.) Hence the saying of a poet, yasoEaY ligaArayohi [He works, or earns, for his belly, or his mouth, and his pudendum]. (S, TA.) -A2- Also (gaArN) An army: (S, K:) or a numerous army. (TA.) You say AilotaqaY AlgaAraAni The two armies met. (S.) ― -b2- And A company, or body, of men: (TA:) or a numerous company or body of men. (ISd, K.) -A3- And I. q. gayorapN, (S,) or giyrapN. (K.) [See 1, last signification.] -A4- And A kind of tree, (S, Mgh, K,) of large size, (Mgh, K,) having leaves longer than those of the xilaAf, (Mgh, TA,) and a fruit [or berry] smaller than the hazel-nut, which is black, and which, being divested of its covering, discloses a heart that is employed in medicine [that is designed to produce a narcotic or an intoxicating effect: the berries are called Hab~u AlgaAri]: its leaves have a sweet odour, (Mgh, TA,) and are employed in perfume: (TA:) its fruit is called [in Persian] dahomasot: (Mgh, TA:) and it has an oil, (K,) which is called duhonu AlgaAri: (S:) [it is the bay-tree; or female laurel-tree; the laurus nobilis; also called the sweet bay; of which there are several sorts, as the broad-leaved bay, the narrow-leaved bay, &c.: it is commonly supposed to be the laurus of the ancients:] n. un. with p. (TA.) ― -b2- And The leaves of the grapevine. (K.)

gaworN * The bottom, or lowest part, of anything; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ gaworaY: (K:) and its depth. (TA.) ― -b2- You say, Earafotu gawora h`*ihi AlmasoA^alapi (tropical:) [I have become acquainted with the bottom of this question]. (TA.) And fulaAnN baEiydu Algawori (S) (tropical:) Such a one is deep and excellent in judgment; one who examines deeply. (TA.) [See also 1.] And hawa baHorN laA yudoraku gaworuhu (tropical:) [He is a sea whereof the bottom shall not be reached]. (TA.) And mano A^aboEadu gaworFA fiY AlbaATili min~iY (tropical:) [Who is deeper in knowledge with respect to what is vain, or false, than I?]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- Low, or depressed, land, country, or ground; (S, Msb, K;) [like xaworN;] as also ↓ gaArN. (K.) ― -b4- See also gaArN, in the first of its senses expl. above. -A2- Applied to water, i. q. gaAy^irN [Sinking, or going away, into the ground, or earth]: (S, K:) an inf. n. used as an epithet, like maA='N sakobN, and dirohamN DarobN. (S.)

giwarN *
A bloodwit; syn. diyapN: (K, TA:) a dial. var. of giyarN: (TA:) or the latter is a pl., of which the sing. is giyrapN. (AA, K in art. gyr, q. v.)

gaArapN * , a subst. from A^agaAra; A going away into a country, or land. (TA.) ― -b2- A quick running, (Mgh, Msb,) or vehement running, (TA,) of a horse, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and of a fox; (Mgh;) as also ↓ gawiyrN, of a fox. (TA.) ― -b3- [A raid; or an incursion into the territory of an enemy; or a sudden, or an unexpected, attack upon an enemy, or upon the territories or dwellings of an enemy, with a party of armed horsemen, and engagement with them in conflict; an urging of horses upon, or against, a people; generally, a hostile, or predatory, incursion: or the making such an incursion:] a subst. [or quasi-inf. n.] from A^agaAra EalaY AlEaduw~i. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And Plunder, or pillage. (TA.) ― -b5- And hence, (Mgh, Msb,) [Horsemen making a raid, or a sudden, or an unexpected, attack, upon an enemy, or upon the dwellings of an enemy, and engaging with them in conflict: horsemen urging their horses upon, or against, a people:] i. q. ↓ xayolN mugiyrapN: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and one says also ↓ xyl migiyrapN, with kesr. (TA.) You say $an~a Ealayohimu AlgaArapa i. e. He scattered, (S in art. $n, and Mgh * and Msb, *) or poured, (K in art. $n,) upon them [the horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, and engaging in conflict, or the horsemen urging their horses]. (S, K.) The poet (El-Kumeyt Ibn-Maaroof, TA) says,
wanaHonu SabaHonaA A=la najoraAna gaArapF
tamiyma bona mur~K waAlr~imaAHa Aln~awaAdisaA
[And we gave as a morning-drink to the people of Nejrán a troop of horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, upon them, or urging their horses against them, namely the tribe of Temeem Ibn-Murr, and the piercing spears]: he means, saqayonaAhumo xayolFA mugiyrapF: and tmym bn mr~ is put in the accus. case as a substitute for gArp. (S, TA.) -A2- HabolN $adiydu AlgaArapi means A rope twisted hard; or hard in respect of the twisting; (S, TA;) gaArapN being in this case [as in that first mentioned above] a subst. standing in stead of the inf. n. A_igaArap: (TA:) and so ↓ HabolN mugaArN; (S, TA;) applied to a rope that is twisted with another. (TA voce misoHalN.) -A3- And AlgaArapu signifies The navel: (Sgh, K:) app. so called because of its depth. (Sgh, TA.)

Algaworapu *
The sun. (IAar, K, TA.) -A2- See also gaAy^irapN.

giyrapN *
Abundance of the produce of the earth: and rain: and i. q. miyrapN [a provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]: belonging to this art. and to art. gyr. (TA.) -A2- [See also 1, last signification.]
gaworaY * : see gaworN.
gawiyrN * : see gaArapN, second sentence.

gaAy^irapN *
i. q. qaAy^ilapN [app. as syn. with qayoluwlapN, i. e. A sleeping in the middle of the day; though the primary signification of qaAy^ilapN is that which here next follows]; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ gaworapN. (O, K.) ― -b2- And The middle of the day [itself]. (K.) ― -b3- And one says, buniYa h`*aA Albayotu EalaY gaAy^irapi Al$~amosi, meaning (tropical:) [This house, or tent, was, or has been, built, or set up,] facing the place of sunrise. (TA.)

magaArN * : see gaArN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A place of entrance: and a place where a thing is sought for: you say, A_in~aka gurota fiY gayori magaArK Verily thou hast entered into that which is not a place of entrance: and verily thou hast sought in that which is not a place where a thing is sought for. (TA.)

mugaArN * : see gaArN. -A2- Also A place of a gaArap [or raid, or sudden attack upon an enemy, or upon the dwellings of an enemy, with a party of armed horsemen, &c.]. (TA.) -A3- See also gaArapN, last sentence but one. ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) A horse strong, or compact, in make; as though twisted: (Az, TA:) or a horse strong in the joints: (Lth, TA:) or, applied to a horse, i. q. muDam~arN [made lean, or light of flesh; &c.: see 2 in art. Eyr: and see also miEaArN in that art.]. (Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, TA in art. Eyr.) And A horse that runs swiftly. (TA. [But in this last sense, the word should be, accord. to rule, as here next follows.])

mugiyrN * A horse swift in running: [see also what next precedes:] and ↓ migowaArN [likewise] signifies a swift horse: or this latter, accord. to Lh, vehement in running: and its pl. is magaAwiyru. (TA.) ― -b2- xayolu mugiyrapN and migiyrapN: see gaArapN.
mugaw~irN * : see 2.
magaArapN * and mugaArapN: see gaArN, first sentence.

migowaArN * : see mugiyrN. ― -b2- Also A fighting man; and so ↓ mugaAwirN: (S:) or the former signifies one who occupies himself much in gaAraAt [or raids, or sudden attacks upon enemies, or upon the dwellings of enemies, with armed horsemen, &c., pl. of gaArapN]; (K, TA;) as also ↓ mugaAwirN: (TA:) pl. magaAwiyru: (S:) and magaAwiru may be a contracted pl. of migowaArN or a pl. of mugaAwirN. (TA.)
mugaAwirN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 gaASa fiY AlmaA='i * , aor. yaguwSu, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. gawoSN (S, A, K) and magaASN and giyaASapN and giyaASN, (K,) He dived in, or descended beneath, the water; (S, A, K;) or entered into the water; (TA;) to fetch out what was in it. (Msb [in my copy of which, the particle fY is omitted, app. by a slip of the transcriber].) ― -b2- giyaASapN [also] signifies The diving in the sea for pearls; (S;) and gawoSN signifies [the same: or both signify] the fetching out pearls from beneath the water. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [Hence,] you say also, gaASa EalaY AlA^amori, (K,) inf. n. gawoSN, (TA,) (tropical:) [He dived for the thing, or affair, so as to elicit it; or] he knew the thing, or affair. (K, TA.) And gaASa EalaY AlmaEaAniY Hat~aY balaga A^aqoSaAhaA waA@sotaxoraja maA baEuda minohaA wadaq~a fahomuhu (tropical:) [He dived for the meanings so that he reached the uttermost of them, and elicited what was remote of them, and the understanding whereof was subtile]. (Msb.) And fulaAnN yaguwSu EalaY HaqaAy^iqi AlEilomi (tropical:) [Such a one dives for the verities of science].
(A, TA.) And maA A^aHosana gawoSahu EalayohaA (tropical:) [How good is his diving for them!]. (A, TA.) And maA gaASa gawoSapF A_il~aA A^axoraja dur~apF (tropical:) [He did not dive a single diving but he fetched out what was like a pearl, or a large pearl]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- You say also, gaASa EalaY Al$~aYo'i, aor. yaguwSu, inf. n. gawoSN, He pounced, or came suddenly, or at unawares, upon the thing. (Msb.)

2 gw~Shu fiY AlmaA='i *
He made him to dive in, or descend beneath, the water; (A;) he immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him therein. (TA.)
gawoSN * [originally an inf. n.]: see magaASN, in two places.
gawoSapN * [A single diving in, or descent beneath, water: see 1, last sentence but one]. (A.)
gaw~aASN * : see the next paragraph, in four places.

gaAy^iSN *
One who dives in, or descends beneath, or enters into, water; as also ↓ gaw~aASN [which, however, has an intensive signification, or implies the habit of so doing]: (TA:) and ↓ the latter, (S, A, K,) or both, (Az, TA,) particularly one who dives in the sea for pearls, (S, A, K,) or for pearl-shells, and fetches them out: (Az, TA:) pl. guw~aASN, (A, TA,) of the former, (TA,) and gaASapN, (A, TA,) [also of the former,] and [of the latter] gaw~aASuwna. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] hawa mino SaAgapi Alfiqari wagaASapi Ald~urari (tropical:) [He is of the moulders of fiqar, lit., as thus used, ornaments fashioned in the form of the vertebræ of the back, but here meaning choice phrases or sentences; and of the divers for, and producers of, (expressions like) pearls, or large pearls]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence likewise,] ↓ gaw~aASN also signifies (tropical:) One who exercises art, craft, cunning, or skill, in ordering the means of obtaining subsistence. (TA.) ― -b4- And gaAy^iSN also signifies One who pounces, or comes suddenly, or at unawares, upon a thing; (JK, S, Msb;) as also, (JK, Msb,) but in an intensive sense, (Msb,) ↓ gaw~aASN: (JK, Msb:) pl. of the former gaASapN. (Msb.)

magaASN *
A place where one dives in, or descends beneath, water; (Lth, A, K;) as also ↓ gawoSN: (Lth, Mgh:) or ↓ the latter signifies particularly a place [where one dives and] whence pearls are fetched out. (JK, Mgh. *) You say also, h`*aA magaASu All~uw^oluw^i This is the diving-place for pearls. (A.) ― -b2- Also The upper part of the saAq [or shank, &c.]. (JK, Sgh, K.)

1 gaATa * , aor. yaguwTu, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. gawoTN, (S, Msb, K,) It entered, or sank, (S, Msb, K, TA,) into (fiY) a thing; (S, K, TA;) as, for instance, the foot into sand; (S, TA;) and a man into mud, (TA,) or into water; (Msb;) and into a valley; (TA, in this art. and in art. gyT; in the former expl. by Ainogamasa;) and gaATa, aor. yagiyTu, (S, TA,) inf. n. gayoTN, (K,) signifies the same: (S, K:) both also signify he, or it, became hidden, (As, and K in art. gyT,) in the ground. (As.) You say also, gaATato A^anosaAEu Aln~aAqapi, aor. and inf. n. as above, The plaited thongs of the she-camel clave to her belly, and so entered, or sank, therein. (TA.) And gaATati AlA^anosaAEu fiY daf~i Aln~aAqapi The plaited thongs caused their impressions to be visible in the side of the she-camel. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a place) sank, or became depressed, in the ground. (ISh.) And It (anything) descended, or sloped downwards, in the ground. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He dug, excavated, or hollowed out. (TA: and in some copies of the K, AlgawoTu is expl. by AlHaforu; but the reading given in the TA, in that instance, is AlHuforapu.) -A2- guTo guTo means Be thou with the jamaAEap [i. e. the mass, or main body], (IAar, O, K,) who are termed the gaAT, (O,) [be thou with them, not with the factious,] when fitan [i. e. factions, &c.,] come. (IAar, O, K.)

2 gw~T * , inf. n. tagowiyTN, He gobbled [food]: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K: *) or gobbled largely, or in large mouthfuls: (K, * TA:) from gawoTN meaning variyd. (TA.) -A2- And tagowiyTN signifies also The making a well deep. (K. [See also 4.])

4 A^agowaTa *
He made deep a well. (Fr, O, TA. [See also 2.])
5 tgw~T * (tropical:) He voided excrement, or ordure. (S, Msb, K, TA. [In the CK, AanodY` is put by mistake for AbdY.])

6 tagaAwaTaA fiY AlmaA='i *
They two vied, or contended, each with the other, in plunging, or diving, in the water. (K, * TA.)

7 AngAT *
It (a branch, or twig, or the like,) bent. (O, K.)

gaATN * : see gaAy^iTN. -A2- AlgaATu signifies also AljamaAEapu [meaning The mass, or main body, of the people]. (O, K.) One says, maA fiY AlgaATi mivoluhu [There is not in the mass, or main body, of the people, the like of him]. (O, TA.)

gawoTN *
A hollow, cavity, pit, or the like, dug, or excavated, in the ground; syn. HuforapN. (So in the K, accord. to the TA, on the authority of AA: but in some copies of the K, AlgawoTu in this instance is expl. by AlHaforu: see 1, last sentence.) See also gaAy^iTu. -A2- And i. q. variydN [Crumbled bread moistened with broth]. (O: in the K variydap.)
gayoTN * : see gaAy^iTN, latter half.

gawoTapN *
A [low, or depressed, place, or hollow, such as is called] wahodap, in the ground. (ISh, K.) [See also gaAy^iTN.]

guwTapN *
A place comprising water and herbage: whence guwTapu dima$oqa, (Har pp. 130, et seq.,) i. e. the city, or district, of Damascus, (K,) which is a place abounding with water and trees. (S.)

biy^orN gawiyTapN *
A deep well. (TA.)

gaAy^iTN *
A wide, depressed piece of ground or land, (ISh, S, O, Msb, K,) but not much depressed, and in some instances having acclivities [bordering it]; (ISh;) sometimes, as they assert, a league (farosax) in extent, and having in it meadows; (AHn;) and ↓ gaATN and ↓ gawoTN signify the same; (O, K;) or the last is more depressed than the gAy^T: (IDrd, O:) and gAy^T is also applied to a valley: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is A^agowaATN, (S, Msb, K,) or this is pl. of gawoTN, (IB,) and [of mult.] giyTaAnN, (S, Msb, K,) which is pl. of both these sings., (IB,) and guwTN (S, Msb, K) and giyaATN. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) A place in which one satisfies a want of nature; the custom being to do so in a depressed place, where one is concealed. (S, * Msb, * TA.) In the Kur [iv. 46, or v. 9], accord. to an extraordinary reading, it is written ↓ gayoT, [a form now commonly used, and signifying a garden, but there meaning a privy place,] the original form of which may be gayowiT, and then gay~iT, [and then gayoT,] it being contracted; or, accord. to Abu-l- Hasan, the Y may be originally w, these two letters being in this instance interchangeable. (IJ.) You say, A^ataY AlgaAy^iTa, (S, TA,) and Daraba AlgaAy^iTa, (TA,) (tropical:) He satisfied a want of nature; (S, TA;) voided excrement, or ordure. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (S, TA,) (tropical:) Human excrement, or ordure: (S, K, TA:) because they used to cast it away in a gAy^T: or because they used to go thither to satisfy a want of nature. (TA.)

Q. Q. 2
if belonging to this art., or R. Q. 2 if belonging to art. gw. tagaAgaY Ealayohi AlgawogaA='u [as though originally tagawogY] i. q. rakibuwhu [i. e. The mixed multitude, or the low, base, vile, &c., of men, bore, or pressed, or crowded, (as though mounting,) upon him]. (TA in art. gw.)

gaAgN * The Habaq [q. v.], (IDrd, K, TA,) a species of sweet-smelling plants, (TA,) i. e. the fuw*anoj, (IDrd, K, TA,) an arabicized word from [the Pers. Puwdiynaho: (TA:) [accord. to the TK, the plant called in Turkish yArPwz, which is marjoram:] ↓ gaAgapN [the n. un.] is said by Lth to mean a certain plant resembling the haronawaY [a word of which both the orthography and the application are disputed]. (TA.)
gaAgapN * : see what here precedes: -A2- and see also the paragraph here following.

gawogaA=' * [i. e. gawogaA='N and gawogaA='u, as will be shown by what follows; mentioned in this art. in the Msb and K; and in the S, and again in the K and TA, in art. gw;] masc. and fem., [being] perfectly and imperfectly decl., (S and TA in art. gw,) in the former case like qamoqaAmN, the ' being substituted for ,, and in the latter case like EaworaA='u, (S,) Locusts after the growth of their wings, (AO, T, Msb, K,) i. e. (AO, T, Msb) after the state in which they are called dabFA or dabFY; (AO, T, S, Msb;) before which earlier state they are called sirowap [or rather
siaro']: (A'Obeyd, T, Msb: [see also jaraAdN:] or locusts when they become light, or active, so as to fly; thus accord. to AO, and IAth says the like thereof: (TA:) or locusts when they have wings, and almost fly, before they raise themselves and fly; thus says As: (S:) or locusts, when they have become divested of the [changing] colours, and are becoming in a state of transition to redness. (As, K, TA.) ― -b2- And A sort of insects resembling baEuwD [or gnats], that do not bite, (AO, S, Msb, K,) nor hurt, (AO, S, Msb,) by reason of their weakness. (AO, S, K.) ― -b3- And, (S, Msb, K,) accord. to As, (S,) or AO, (Msb,) as being likened to the locusts thus termed, (S, Msb,) applied to men, (S, Msb, K,) meaning (tropical:) A mixed multitude of men; as also ↓ gaAgapN: (S and K in art. gw:) or the safilap [i. e. low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid; or lowest or lower, basest or baser, &c.;] of men; and such as haste to do evil: and it may be from the signification here following, because of the muchness of their clamour, or confused noise, and vociferation. (TA.) ― -b4- [Like gawogaA in Pers., and probably from this latter, if the converse be not the case,] it signifies also Clamour, and a confusion of cries or shouts or noises. (TA.)

1 gaAlahu * , (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. yaguwluhu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. gawolN, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) He, or it, [accord. to the TA said of a thing,] destroyed him; (Lth, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AgtAlhu: (K:) and (K) it (a thing, S, O) took him, seized him, or took him away, unexpectedly, at unawares, or from an unknown quarter; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ AgtAlhu: (S: [see also an ex. of this latter voce xaruwjN:]) and accord. to IAar, gAl Al$~aYo'u zayodFA signifies The thing took away Zeyd. (TA.) One says, ↓ gaAlatohu guwlN A [cause of] destruction destroyed him: (K, TA:) or [destroyed him so that it was not known whither he had gone away; for] it is said of one who has fallen into destruction (S, TA) and it is not known whither he has gone away: (TA:) and it also signifies Death or the decree of death [destroyed him, or took him away]. (TA.) One says also when persons have perished in a land, gaAlatohumo tiloka AlA^aroDu [That land caused them, or has caused them, to perish in it]: and AlA^aroDu bifulaAnK ↓ tagaw~alati means The land caused such a one to perish; and to pursue a course that led him astray. (TA.) And one says of a land (A^aroD), taguwlu Als~aAbilapa, meaning It casts away the travellers, or wayfarers; causes them to fall, or drop down; and removes them far away. (TA.) ― -b2- gaAlati Alxamoru fulaAnFA means (assumed tropical:) The wine that he had drunk deprived such a one of his reason: or, of the soundness of his body: (AHeyth, TA:) [or corrupted, or vitiated, him; for] gaAlahu, aor. yaguwluhu, signifies A^afosadahu; (Ksh and Bd in xxxvii. 46;) as well as A^aholakahu: (Ksh, ibid:) and a poet, cited by AO, says,
wamaA zaAlati AlkaA^osu tagotaAlunaA
(assumed tropical:) [And the cup of wine caused not to deprive us of our reason]. (S, O.) ― -b3- taguwlu Alv~iyaAba fataqoSuru EanohaA is said of a tall woman [app. as meaning She exceeds the measure of the clothes, so that they are too short for her]: such a woman is said to be ↓ *aAtu gawolK. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says, maA gaAlaka Ean~aA i. e. What withheld, or debarred, or has withheld or debarred, thee from us? (O.) ― -b5- And gulotuhu, inf. n. giyaAlapN and giyaAlN and guw^uwlN, signifies I stole it. (O and TA in art. gyl [though belonging to art. gwl].)
2 falaApN tugaw~ilu * , inf. n. tagowiylN, [A desert, or water-less desert,] of which the roads, or ways, are unapparent, so that it causes the people thereof [who traverse it] to go astray. (TA.)

3 mugaAwalapN * is syn. with mubaAdarapN [The hastening, making haste, or striving to be first or beforehand, in doing or attaining or obtaining a thing], (S, O, K, TA,) [or] in journeying, &c. (TA.) Jereer says, (S, O,) or El-Akhtal, (so in the TA,) mentioning a man upon whom horsemen had made a sudden attack, (S, TA,)
EaAyanotu mu$oEilapa AlriEaAli kaA^an~ahaA
TayorN tugaAwilu fiY $amaAmK wukuwraA
[I saw those that were spreading themselves of the small parties of horsemen, as though they were birds hastening to nests in (the mountain of) Shemám]. (S, O, TA.) And it is related in a trad. of 'Ammár, that he was brief in prayer, and said, kunotu A^ugaAwilu HaAjapF liY [I was hastening to accomplish a want that I had]. (TA.) And in a trad. of Keys Ibn-'Ásim, [it is related that he said,] kunotu A^ugaAwiluhumo fiY AljaAhiliy~api i. e. I used to strive to be beforehand with them (A^ubaAdiruhumo) in making a sudden attack or incursion, and in doing mischief, [in the Time of Ignorance:] or, as some relate it, it is with r [i. e. kunotu A^ugaAwiruhumo I used to make sudden attacks or incursions upon them]. (TA.)

5 tagaw~ulN * is syn. with talaw~unN [which primarily signifies The becoming altered in colour; but here, the varying in state or condition, or in form or appearance; or, agreeably with explanations of its verb by Esh-Shereeshee, (cited in Har p. 480,) the becoming altered in state or condition; and the becoming of various sorts or species]. (S, O, K.) One says, tgw~lt AlmaroA^apu, meaning tlw~nt [The woman varied in state or condition, or in form or appearance, &c.]: (S, O, TA:) and in like manner tgw~lt is said of the guwl [q. v.]. (TA.) And The woman made herself to be like the guwl. (TA.) And tagaw~ulu AlfalaApi means The dubious, and varying, state or condition, of the desert, or waterless desert. (TA.) And one says also, tgw~l AlA^amoru (tropical:) The affair, or case, became altered so as to be unknown; [for tanaAkara, in my original, I read tanak~ara;] and became dubious, or confused. (TA.) ― -b2- And tgw~lt AlA^aroDu bifulaAnK: see 1, former half. ― -b3- And tagaw~alatohumu Alguwlu is said of them who have been made to deviate from, miss, or lose, the right way [by the guwl; i. e. it means The gwl made them to deviate &c.]. (TA.)

6 tagaAwaluwA *
i. q. tabaAdaruwA i. e. They hastened together; vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening; made haste to be, or get, before one another; strove, one with another, to be first, or beforehand, (comp. 3:) expl. by Freytag as meaning “ sese invicem studuerunt capere. ”]

8 AgtAlhu * : see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- Also (S) He slew him (S, Mgh, O, Msb) covertly (S, * Mgh, O *) or on an occasion of inadvertence; (S, * O, * Msb;) syn. ↓ qatalahu giylapF. (S, Mgh, O.) ― -b3- See also 1, latter half. ― -b4- laA yagotaAluhu Al$~abaEu, said of a hawk, (S, O, TA,) &c., (TA,) signifies (tropical:) Satiety will not deprive him of his strength, (S, O, TA,) and his vehemence of flight: meaning that he will not become satiated: (TA:) [it is said that] it occurs in a verse of Zuheyr, [but I do not find it in his Deewán,] describing a hawk. (S, O, TA.) ― -b5- h`*ihi A^aroDN tagotaAlu Alma$oYa means (assumed tropical:) This is a land that renders unapparent in it the footing, or marching, [of travellers,] by reason of its far extent and its width: an ex. of the verb [in this sense] occurs in a verse of El-'Ajjáj cited voce niyaATN, in art. nwT. (S, O.) -A2- [And Freytag adds, in art. gyl, the two following significations: the former, or both, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees: He overtook him in running: (compare 3 and 6 in this art.:) -A3- and He filled it so that the space became too contracted to take, or hold.]

gawolN *
Far extent of a desert, or waterless desert; (S, O, TA;) because it destroys him who passes along in it: (S, TA:) or of a land; because it casts away the travellers, or wayfarers, causes them to fall, or drop down, and removes them far away: and accord. to Lh, it is said of a land when one journeys in it without stopping. (TA.) One says, maA A^aboEada gawola h`*ihi AlA^aroDi How far is the extent of this land! and A_in~ahaA labaEiydapu Algawoli [Verily it is far in extent]. (ISh, TA.) And A^aroDN *aAtu gawolK A land far extending, though in the view of the eye of little extent: (IKh, TA:) and gay~ilN applied to land is said to have the same meaning. (TA in art. gyl.) And A^agowaAlu AlA^aroDi [in which AgwAl is app. pl. of gawolN] signifies The extremities of the land. (TA.) ― -b2- AimoraA^apN *aAtu gawolK A tall woman. (TA.) See 1, last sentence but two. [And see also gay~ilapN, voce gay~ilN, in art. gyl.] ― -b3- [nAqp gwl AlnjA=' is a phrase mentioned without any indication of the meaning in the TA: perhaps naAqapu gawoli Aln~ajaA='i, and signifying A she-camel of an exceeding degree of swiftness.] -A2- In the saying in the Kur [xxxvii. 46], laA fiyhaA gawolN, [referring to the wine of Paradise,] it means The evil result of headache; because it is said in another place, [lvi. 19,] laA yuSad~aEuwna EanohaA: (S, O, TA:) or it [there] means [simply] headache: or intoxication: (K, TA:) thus some expl. it as used in that instance: (TA:) or, as expl. by AO, it there means privation of the intellectual faculties.
(S, O, TA.) ― -b2- See also guwlN, latter half. ― -b3- Also Distress, trouble, or molestation: (K, TA:) thus expl. by some as used in the Kur ubi suprà. (TA.) ― -b4- And Unfaithfulness; or unfaithful acting. (TA.) ― -b5- ↓ A^ataY gawolFA gaAy^ilapF means He did a cunning, bad, action. (K.) -A3- Also Much earth. (S, O, K.) Hence the phrase gawolFA mina Alr~amoli, [app. meaning A large quantity of sand,] in a verse of Lebeed. (S, O.) ― -b2- And A collection of [the trees called] TaloH, (K, TA,) with which nothing participates. (TA.) ― -b3- And A low, or depressed, part of the earth, or of land. (K.)

guwlN *
A kind of [goblin,] demon, devil, or jinnee, which, the Arabs assert, appears to men in the desert, assuming various forms, causing them to wander from the way, and destroying them; (JM, and TA * on the authority of IAth;) but this the Prophet denied, saying, laA guwla; by which, however, accord. to some, he did not mean to deny the existence of the gwl, but only the assertion of the Arabs respecting its assuming various forms and its being able to cause any one to go astray: (IAth, JM, * TA:) i. q. siEolaApN [q. v.]: or a sort of siEolaAp: (S, O, Msb:) or a male jinnee; the female being called siEolaAp: (Abu-l-Wefee ElAarábee, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^agowaAlN and [of mult.] giylaAnN (S, O, Msb, K) and giwalapN: (O, TA:) and it signifies also an enchantress of the jinn: (K:) and a demon, or devil, that eats men: (En-Nadr, O, K:) or any jinnee, or devil, or animal of prey, that destroys a man: (TA:) or a certain beast, (K, TA,) terrible [in appearance], having tusks, or fangs, (TA,) seen by the Arabs, and known by them; and killed by Taäbbata Sharrà: (K, TA:) and such as varies in form or appearance, of the enchanters and of the jinn; (K, TA;) on his doing which, as is said in a trad., one should hastily utter the call to prayer, to prevent his mischief by the mention of God: (TA:) or anything by reason of which the intellect departs; as also ↓ gawolN: (K:) and anything that takes a man unexpectedly and destroys him: (S, O, Msb:) [whence] one says, AlgaDabu guwlu AlHilomi Anger [is that which] destroys, and does away with, forbearance, or clemency. (S, O.) ― -b2- Also Destruction: [or a cause thereof:] and death; or the decree of death. (K.) See 1, second sentence. ― -b3- And A calamity, or misfortune; (K, TA;) as also ↓ gaAy^ilapN; (TA;) of which latter the pl. in this sense is gawaAy^ilu; (K, * TA;) thus mentioned by Ks. (Msb.) ― -b4- And A serpent: pl. A^agowaAlN: (K:) accord. to Az, the Arabs call serpents A^agowaAl; and thus this word is said to mean in the verse of Imra-el-Keys,
liyaqotulaniY waAlma$orafiY~u muDaAjiEiY
wamasonuwnapN zuroqN kaA^anoyaAbi A^agowaAli
[To slay me, while the Meshrefee sword was my bedfellow, and so were sharpened, polished arrowheads, like the fangs of serpents]: (O, TA: *) but AHát says that this is meant as an exaggeration: (TA:) and it is said that the poet here means devils. (O, TA.)
giylapN * The slaying covertly, (Mgh,) or on an occasion of inadvertence; a subst. from AigotaAlahu: (Msb:) originally with w [i. e. giwolapN]. (S.) See 8: and see also art. gyl.

gawolaAnN *
A plant of the [kind called] HamoD, (A'Obeyd, AHn, S, O, K,) like the A^u$onaAn [i. e. kali, or glasswort], (K,) or, accord. to AHn, resembling the EunoZuwaAn [which is described as a plant of the HamoD, or, as some say, the best of the A^u$onaAn], except that it is more slender; and it is a pasture. (TA.) -A2- Also sing. of gawaAliynu, which signifies [The ribs of a ship or boat, i. e.] the things that resemble the DuluwE in a ship or boat. (AA, O, TA.)

gaAy^ilN * [act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aroDN gaAy^ilapu Aln~iTaA='i A land that destroys its inhabitant by reason of its far extent. (TA.) ― -b3- And gaAy^ilapN [as an epithet applied to a fem. n.] signifies Caused to become absent, or to disappear; hidden, or concealed: or stolen. (ISh, TA.)

gaAy^ilapN * [as a subst.] Bad, or corrupt, conduct; and evil, or mischief. (Msb.) See also gawolN, last quarter. [And see art. gyl.] ― -b2- And [particularly] Wickedness, or disobedience, of a slave; and his running away; (Mgh in art. Edw, and Msb;) and the like thereof: pl. gawaAy^ilu. (Msb.) ― -b3- And [hence, perhaps, (as denoting a cause for reclaiming the price of a slave,) it is said that] it signifies A right which another than the seller has to the possession of a slave, whereby the sale is annulled, and the seller is obliged to return the price to the purchaser. (TA. voce xibovapN.) ― -b4- See also guwlN, latter half. ― -b5- [Its pl.] gawaAy^ilu also signifies Places of destruction. (TA.) ― -b6- And you say, A^axaAfu gaAy^ilatahu, meaning I fear the result, and the evil, or mischief, thereof. (TA.) -A2- Also A hole, or perforation, of a watering-trough, or tank, (IAar, O, K, * TA,) that causes the water to pass away: (TA:) pl. gawaAy^ilu. (IAar, O, TA.)
Eayo$N guw~alN * : see A^agowalu.

A^aroDN gay~ilapN *
A land far extending. (Lh, TA.) [Mentioned also in art. gyl.]

A^agowalu * [More, and most, destructive]. One says, A^ay~apu guwlK A^agowalu mina AlgaDabi [What destroyer is more destructive than anger?]. (S, O: immediately following the explanation of the saying, AlgaDabu guwlu AlHilomi.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] Eayo$N A^agowalu A soft, or plentiful and easy, life; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) as also ↓ guw~alN. (K.)

migowalN * [primarily] An instrument with which a thing is destroyed. (Ham p. 648.) ― -b2- And [hence] used as meaning A knife: and in common acceptation, a knife that is put in the midst of a whip which is as a sheath to it: (Ham ibid.:) a knife to which a whip is a sheath: (Mgh:) or a slender sword, having a flat back (lahu qafFA), (S, O, Msb,) like the knife, (Msb,) the sheath of which is like the whip: (S, O:) or an iron [weapon] that is put within a whip, which thus becomes to it a sheath: (K:) or a whip in the interior of which is a sword: (A'Obeyd, TA:) said to be thus called because its owner destroys with it his enemy unexpectedly: pl. magaAwilu: (TA:) and a thing like a mi$omal [or short and slender sword over which a man covers himself with his garment], except that it is more slender, and longer: (K:) and a long naSol [or blade], (AHn, K, TA,) of little breadth, thick in the maton [which generally means the part in the middle of which is the ridge, but may here mean the back]: (AHn, TA:) or a short sword which a man wears inwrapped beneath his clothes: (TA:) or a slender sword, having a flat back (lahu qafFA): (K:) or a slender iron [weapon], having a sharp edge and a flat back (waqafFA), which the assassin binds upon his waist in order that he may therewith destroy men. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] farasN *aAtu migowalK (tropical:) A mare having a quality, or faculty, of outstripping: (O, K, TA:) as though she destroyed the [other] horses so that they fell short of reaching her. (TA.)

nazaluwA mugaAwiliyna * , occurring in a trad. respecting the lie [that was uttered against 'Áïsheh, to which allusion is made in the Kur xxiv. 11], means They alighted [after] going far in the journeying. (TA.)
1 gaYV3a see what next follows.

2 gay~ayotu gaAyapF * , (S, K, TA,) inf. n. tagoyiyapN; (TA;) [in the CK ↓ gayayotuhaA, which is wrong, unless they said thus as well as gay~ayotuhaA, like as they say rayayotu raAyapF as well as ray~ayotuhaA;] and ↓ A^agoyayotuhaA; (S, K, TA; but in the last as not found in the K;) I set up the banner, or standard; (S, K, TA;) from A'Obeyd. (S.) ― -b2- And gay~aY liloqawomi He set up a banner, or standard, for the people, or party: or he made it for them. (TA.) ― -b3- And gay~ati AlT~ayoru The birds flapped their wings, or fluttered, in the air, without moving from their place; or did thus around a thing, desiring to alight upon it; syn. raforafato. (TA.) [See also 6.] -A2- gay~ayotu gaAyapF signifies [also] bay~anotuhaA [i. e. I made apparent, or manifest, or known, an utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, or the like; or I set it]. (Msb.)

entryFree.key: gaAyaA Alqawomu fawoqa raA^osi fulaAnK biAls~ayofi

div2.entryFree: 3 gaAyaA Alqawomu fawoqa raA^osi fulaAnK biAls~ayofi * [The people, or party, acted with the sword above the head of such a one] as though they shadowed him with it; [i. e., flourished it above his head;] from As; (S, K; *) inf. n. mugaAyaApN. (TA.)

4 A^agoYa3a see 2. ― -b2- A^agoyaA AlsaHaAbu The clouds were, or became, stationary, (K, TA,) Ealayohi upon, or over, him, or it; shadowing him, or it. (TA.) ― -b3- AgyA Alr~ajulu The man attained the utmost limit, or reach, in eminence, or nobility, and in command: and in like manner, Alfarasu fiY sibaAqihi [the horse in his contending in a race]. (IKtt, TA.)

6 tagaAyati AlT~ayoru EalaY Al$~aYo'i *
The birds hovered, or circled, round about the thing. (TA.) [See also 2.] -A2- tagaAyawoA Ealayohi Hat~aY qataluwhu signifies the same as tagaAwawoA. (TA.) [See the latter, in art. gw or gwY.]
gaY~N * : see art. gw or gwY.
gay~apN * and giy~apN: see art. gw or gwY.
gay~aAnu * : see art. gw or gwY.
gaAYN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

gaAyapN * , originally gyyp [i. e. gayayapN], (TA,) The utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, point, or reach; or the extremity; of a thing; (MA, KL, PS;) in respect of time and of place; (MA, PS;) syn. madFY, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and munotahFY: (M, TA:) pl. ↓ gaAYN, (S, Msb, K, *) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. properly so termed is] gaAyaAtN. (Msb.) [Hence, A goal to which racers run; as is indicated in the TA. And A scope; an object to be reached or accomplished, or that one has in view. And The ultimate object or intent of an action or a saying. And The ultimate import of a word: thus in the phrase, yuTolaqu biA@EotibaAri gaAyatihi It is used with regard, or respect, to its ultimate import: opposed in this sense to mabodaA^N. And The utmost degree, maximum, climax, or acme, that is, or may be, attained.] And The utmost of one's power or ability, i. e., of one's deed: thus in the saying, gaAyatuka A^ano tafoEala ka*aA [The utmost of thy power or ability, or of thy deed, is, or will be, thy doing such a thing]. (Msb.) [And A person or thing, and persons or things, superlative, or consummate, in eminence or baseness, in goodness or evilness; that has, or have, attained the utmost degree therein. And, applied to a medicine, &c., Possessing the utmost efficacy, or efficiency, lika*aA for such a thing.] ― -b2- [Also, like madFY, A space that is, or that is to be, traversed; or an extent, or the space between two points or limits: whence AibotidaA='u gaAyapK, and AinotihaA='u gaAyapK, The beginning, and the end, of a space between two points or limits.] ― -b3- And i. q. galowapN, meaning [A bow-shot; or] a shot of an arrow to the utmost possible distance. (Msb in art. glw.) -A2- Also A banner, or standard: (S, Msb, K:) pl. gaAyaAtN (Msb, TA) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ gaAYN. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A banner (raAyap) which the vintner used to raise [or set up] in order that he might be known to be a seller of wine. (TA.) [See an ex. voce EuqaAbN.] ― -b3- And A cloud that is alone; apart from others: or that is falling, or alighting. (TA.) ― -b4- And Birds flapping their wings, or fluttering, in the air, without moving from their place; or doing thus around a thing, desiring to alight upon it. (TA. [See 2.]) ― -b5- And The qSbp [app. qaSabap, generally meaning reed, or cane, but what is meant by it here I know not,] with which small birds (EaSaAfiyz) are taken, or caught, or sought to be taken or caught. (TA.)
gaAy^iY~N * [the rel. n. gaAyapN]. AlEil~apu AlgaAy^iy~apu, with the scholastic theologians, means The final cause. (TA.)

gayaAyapN * The light of the rays of the sun; (S, K;) not the rays themselves: (S:) or, as some say, the shade of the sun [i. e. the shade that is cast by the sun] in the morning and in the evening: (TA:) pl. gayaAyaAtN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And Anything that shades a man, over his head, such as a cloud, (AA, S, K,) and dust, and darkness, and the like. (AA, S.) ― -b3- And The bottom of a well; (S, K;) like gayaAbapN. (S.)
gayaAyaA='u * A man heavy in spirit; as though he were a dark, dense shadow, in which is no brightness. (TA.)

Almugay~aA *
That to which a limit is set, or put: so in the saying, AlgaAyapu laA tadoxulu fiY Almugay~aA [The limit shall not enter into, or be included in, that to which the limit is set]. (Mgh.) [And,] as used by the lawyers and the scholastic theologians, The end of the gaAyap [or space between two points or limits]: a post-classical term. (TA.)

1 gaAba * , (S, O, Mgh, Msb, TA,) aor. yagiybu, (Msb,) inf. n. gayobapN [the most common form] (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K) and gayobN (S, O, Msb, K) and gayaAbN, (S, O,) or giyaAbN, (Msb, K,) and guyuwbN (S, O, Msb, K) and guyuwbapN (O, K) and gayobuwbapN, (O, K,) accord. to some of the measure faEoluwlapN, but accord. to others of the measure fayoEaluwlapN i. e. originally gay~abuwbapN, (MF,) and magiybN (S, O, Msb, K) and magaAbN; (K;) and ↓ tgy~b; (Msb, K;) He, or it, was, or became, absent; gaAba being the contr. of HaDara; (S and K in art. HDr;) or distant, or remote; (Mgh;) or hidden, concealed, or unapparent; (TA;) [or absent from the range, or beyond the reach, of perception by sense, or of mental perception: see gayobN.] You say, gAb Eanohu, inf. n. gayobapN (S, Mgh, TA) &c., as above, (S, TA,) He, or it, was, or became, [absent from him; or] distant, or remote, from him; (Mgh;) or hidden, or concealed, from him; [&c.;] as also ↓ tgy~b. (TA.) And A^awoHa$atoniY gayobapu fulaAnK [The absence of such a one has made me to feel lonely]: and A^aTalota gayobataka [Thou hast made thine absence to be long]. (A.) And ↓ A^anaA maEakumo laA A^ugaAyibukumo [I am with you: I will not be absent from you]. (A.) And banuw A^aHoyaAnFA ↓ fulaAnK ya$ohaduwna A^aHoyaAnFA wayatagaAyabuwna (ISk, S, TA) i. e. [The sons of such a one are present sometimes] and are absent (yagiybuwna) sometimes: but one does not say ↓ yatagay~abuwna [unless with Eano following it]: (TA:) [it seems, however, that ytgy~bwn, here, is a mistranscription for yatagay~abuwnanaA or the like; for] one says, Ean~iY fulaAnN ↓ tgy~b [Such a one was, or became, absent from me; or absented himself from me]; (S, K, * TA;) and ↓ tagay~abaniY also in a case of necessity in verse, (S, K, TA,) but not in any other case, (K, TA,) accord. to the generality of authorities except the Koofees: (TA:) Imra-el-Keys says,
faZal~a lanaA yawomN la*iy*N binaEomapK
faqulo fiY maqiylK naHosuhu mutagay~ibiY
[thus in my copies of the S and in the TA; but we should read mutagay~ibi, whether it mean mutagay~ibiY or not, as is shown by what follows: the verse may be rendered, So a delightful day, with ease and comfort, betided us: and say thou, of a place of midday-sleep whereof the ill luck was absent from me,. . .]: but Fr says that the word mtgy~b is marfooa, [i. e. that the right reading is mutagay~ibu, meaning simply absent,] that the verse is mukofaA^ [or made faulty in the termination], and that it is not allowable to make that word refer to maqiylK, like as it is not allowable to say mararotu birajulK A^abuwhu qaAy^imK. (S, TA. [One might be tempted to suppose that we should read faqilo; but this would not suit the context, which see in Ahlwardt's “ Divans of the six ancient Arabic poets, ” p. 119.]) ― -b2- [gAb, inf. n. gayobapN, is also said of the mind (Alqalob), meaning (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, absent. The inf. n. (gayobapN) is often used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Absence of mind; and particularly, from self and others by its being exclusively occupied by the contemplation of divine things: see an ex. voce $awFY; and another voce sakiynapN.] ― -b3- maA gaAba Eanohu A@bonu A^abiY quHaAfapa (assumed tropical:) [Ibn-Abee-Koháfeh was not a stranger to it, i. e. was not unacquainted with it,] occurs in a trad. respecting a satirical saying of Hassán against [the tribe of] Kureysh; meaning that Aboo-Bekr [the son of Aboo-Koháfeh] was skilled in genealogies and traditions, and that it was he who instructed Hassán. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says also, gAb Alr~ajulu, inf. n. gayobN and magiybN; and ↓ tgy~b; The man journeyed; and went away, or far away. (TA.) ― -b5- And gAbt Al$~amosu, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) inf. n. giyaAbN and gayobuwbapN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and gayobapN (Mgh) and guyuwbN and guyuwbapN and magiybN; (TA;) and ↓ tgy~bt; (Msb;) The sun set: (S, Msb, TA:) and the like is also said of the moon, (Msb,) and of other celestial bodies. (TA.) ― -b6- And gAb Al$~aYo'u fiY Al$~aYo'i, inf. n. giyaAbapN and guyuwbapN and giyaAbN and gayaAbN and giybapN, [The thing became hidden, or concealed, in the thing.] (K.) -A2- See also 8, in two places.
2 gy~bhu * (S, Msb, TA) He caused him, or it, to become absent, or to disappear; or he hid, or concealed, it, Eanohu from him. (TA.) See also gayaAbN. ― -b2- And see 8.

3 mugaAyabapN * signifies The being absent, &c., one from the other. (KL.) See also 1, former half. ― -b2- Also The addressing words to another [in his absence,] not in his presence, not face to face; (KL;) contr. of muxaATabapN. (S, TA.) [You say, AgAbt, inf. n. as above, He held a verbal communication with him in his absence, i. e. by means of a letter or letters, or by a messenger or messengers.]

4 AgAbt *
She (a woman) had her husband, (S,
Msb, TA,) or one of her family, (TA,) absent from her. (S, Msb, TA.)

5 tagay~aba see 1, in seven places. ― -b2- The inf. n. tagay~ubN occurring in a trad. respecting the contract for the sale of a slave means The selling a stray slave, or one who has been found and whose owner is not known. (L, TA.)
6 tagaAoyaba see 1, former half.

8 AgtAbhu * [He spoke evil of him; or did so in his absence, i. e. backbit him; (the latter being obviously the primary signification;) not always, though generally, meaning with truth:] he spoke evil of him in his absence; (TA;) or said of him, in his absence, what would grieve him (S, TA) if he heard it; (S;) with truth: (S, TA:) he carped at him behind the back, or in absence, by saying what would grieve him, (bimaA ↓ tanaAwalahu biZahori Algayobi yasuww^uhu,) of what was [reprehensible] in him: (TA:) or he spoke of him imputing to him what he disliked, of vices, or faults, with truth: (Msb:) when the charge is false, it is termed buhotaAnN: (S, Msb, TA:) or he attributed, or imputed, to him a vice, or fault, or the like; and mentioned him with what was in him of evil; (K, TA;) or said of him what would grieve him: (TA:) and ↓ gaAbahu signifies the same: (K, TA:) [so does ↓ gy~bhu: (see Ksh in civ. 1:) that AgtAbhu does not always signify he spoke evil of him, or the like, in his absence, appears from several instances, such as the phrases AlmugotaAbu fiY Alwajohi (K in art. lmz) and AlmugotaAbuwna biAlHaDorapi (IAar, TA in that art.): nor does it always signify he spoke evil of him, or the like, with truth; for the verb is used in the Ksh and by Bd and Jel in civ. 1 having for its object the Prophet:] IAar says that ↓ gAb is syn. with AgtAb, and signifies he mentioned a man with the imputation of good or of evil. (TA.) [It may also mean He expressed, or signified, an evil opinion of him by making signs with the side of the mouth, or with the eye, or with the head, or otherwise; as is indicated in the TA in arts. lmz and hmz.]
gaAbN * : see gaAbapN, in three places.

gayobN *
Whatever is absent, or hidden, from one; (S, A, Msb, K, TA;) as though it were an inf. n. used in the sense of the act. part. n. [in which the meaning of a subst. is predominant]; (TA;) and so ↓ gaAy^ibN, which [in this sense] is a subst., like kaAhilN, (K, TA,) or an act. part. n. used in the sense of a subst.: (MF:) anything that is absent, or hidden, from the eyes; invisible, unseen, or unapparent; whether it be, or be not, perceived in the heart, or mind: (IAar, TA:) [or anything unperceivable; absent from the range, or beyond the reach, of perception by sense, or of mental perception; or undiscoverable unless by means of divine revelation; a mystery, or secret, such as an event of futurity;] a thing that has been hidden from men, and with which the Prophet has acquainted them, of the events of the resurrection and of Paradise and of Hell &c.; thus in the Kur ii. 2; (Zj, TA;) and [hence] Zj explains Algayob as meaning, in the Kur lxxxi. 24, that which has been revealed: (TA in art. Dn:) pl. guyuwbN. (Msb.) [See also the Ksh and Bd in ii. 2.] [Hence, EaAlamu Algayobi The world of the unseen; the invisible world.] And [hence also] one says, rajama biAlgayobi [and qa*afa biAlgayobi (see art. q*f)] He spoke of that which he did not know: (Ham p. 494:) and qaAla rajomFA biAlgayobi He said conjecturally, [or speaking of that which was hidden from him or unknown by him,] without evidence, and without proof. (Msb in art. rjm, q. v.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Doubt, or a doubting: (K:) but some disapprove this: some regard it as tropical: and some pronounce it correct: (MF, TA:) pl. giyaAbN and guyuwbN. (K.) A poet says,
A^anota nabiY~N taEolamu AlgiyaAbaA
laA qaAy^ilFA A_ifokFA walaA murotaAbaA
[Thou art a prophet, knowing doubts, or things doubted; not saying a lie, nor a thing suspected: or, more probably, the meaning is, the things unseen]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A place, in the ground, that hides, or conceals, one: (TA:) a low, or depressed, place in the ground, or in a tract of land: (S, K, TA:) or any place such that one knows not what is in it: and a place such that one knows not what is behind it: (Sh, TA:) pl. guyuwbN. (TA.) Hence the phrase Eano Zahori gayobK in a verse of Lebeed cited voce ZahorN, q. v. (TA.) [Hence also] one says, samiEotu SawotFA mino waraA='i Algayobi i. e. [I heard a sound, or voice,] from [behind] a place that I saw not. (A, TA.) And tanaAwalahu biZahori Algayobi bimaA yasuww^uhu: see 8. And takal~ama bihi Eano Zahori gayobK (A) or Eano Zahori Algayobi (TA, and A and O in art. Zhr) [app. He spoke of it by memory; in the absence of a book or the like; as one says in modern Arabic, EalaY AlgaAy^ib. See also ZahorN.] ― -b4- Also The xamoSap [i. e. pit, or depression, as is shown by what here follows, (thus in the A, and in the Ksh in ii. 2, in the TA Huforap, which has a similar meaning,)] that is in the place where the kidney is situate, (Ksh, A, TA,) and which swells up when the beast becomes big in the belly: so says ISh: (Ksh ubi suprà:) or the xamoSap that is next to the kidney: (Bd in ii. 2: [De Sacy doubted respecting its meaning, but conjectured that it might be thus: see his Anthol. Gramm. Arabe p. 55:]) pl. guyuwbN: one says, $aribati Ald~aAb~apu Hat~aY waArato guyuwba kulaAhaA, (ISh, Ksh ubi suprà, A, TA,) meaning huzuwmahaA [i. e. The beast drank until it concealed the pits of its kidneys]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And Fat: (K, TA:) i. e. the fat of the varob [q. v.] of a sheep or goat: so called because it is hidden from the eye. (TA.) -A2- See also gaAy^ibN.
gayabN * : see gaAy^ibN, in two places.

gaAbapN * is originally [gayabapN] of the measure faEalapN, with fet-h to the E. (Msb.) It signifies A low, or depressed, place, or a hollow in the ground, (El-Hawázinee, K, TA,) before which, or in the way to which, (duwnahaA,) is an eminence. (El-Hawá- zinee, TA.) ― -b2- And (K) i. q. A^ajamapN: (S, K, TA:) [i. e.] A bed of canes or reeds: (AHn, Msb, TA:) and [a thicket, wood, or forest; like A^ajamapN;] a collection of trees, (AHn, ISd, TA,) densely disposed; so called because it conceals what is in it: (ISd, TA:) or a tall A^ajamap, having high, or very high, extremities [app. to its canes or reeds]: (TA:) pl. gaAbaAtN (Msb, TA) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ gaAbN. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A long spear (K, TA) that has extremities like those of the A^ajamap [expl. above]: (TA:) [but I think that this addition in the TA correctly applies to gaAbapN signifying a number of spears, like a bed of canes or reeds, or like a forest; agreeably with two of the explanations here following:] or a spear that quivers in the wind: (K, TA:) or (tropical:) numerous spears, like abundant and dense trees: (A:) or an assemblage of spears; app. so called as being likened to a gAbp meaning an A^ajamap of dense trees: (ISd, TA:) pl. gaAbaAt and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ gaAbN. (TA.) One says, A^atawonaA fiY gaAbapK i. e. (tropical:) [They came to us] amid numerous spears, like abundant and dense trees: (A:) or gAbp may be used in this case in the sense here following. (TA.) ― -b4- And A company, or congregated body, of men: (Aboo-Jábir ElAsadee, K, TA:) pl. gaAbaAtN and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ gaAbN. (TA.)

gayobapN * an inf. n. [See 1, in several places.] ― -b2- Also, and ↓ gayaAbapN, A low, or depressed, piece of land or ground: so in the phrases waqaEonaA fiY gayobapK and gayaAbapK [app. meaning We lighted upon a low, or depressed, piece &c.; or perhaps the meaning may be we fell into &c.]. (S.) ― -b3- See also gayaAbapN.

giybapN * the subst. from AigotaAbahu: (Msb:) it signifies [Evil speech respecting a person; or such speech in his absence; not always, though generally, meaning with truth:] evil speech respecting a person in his absence; (TA;) or a saying of him, in his absence, what would grieve him (S, TA) if he heard it; (S;) with truth: (S, TA:) or speech respecting a person imputing to him what he dislikes, of vices, or faults, with truth: (Msb:) when it is false, it is termed buhotaAnN: (S, Msb, TA:) or an imputing to a person a vice, or fault, or the like; and a mentioning him with what is in him of evil; (K, TA;) or a saying of him what would grieve him: (TA:) or it may be speech imputing good or evil. (K, * TA.)

gayibaAnN * or gayobaAnN, [accord. to different copies of the K, between which the TA does not enable us to decide with certainty, as it only states, with respect to the Y, that it is muxaf~afap, which may mean either the contr. of doubled or the contr. of movent, though the former is the more general meaning, (in the TA it is said to be erroneously written in a copy of the K with a final t instead of n,)] and ↓ gay~ibaAnN, The roots of trees, (K, TA,) that are hidden from view: or, accord. to AHn, the gybAn and ↓ gy~bAn and ↓ gayaAbap, of plants, or herbage, are, with the Arabs, what the sun has not shone upon: and accord. to Aboo-Ziyád ElKilábee, the gybAn and ↓ gy~bAn of plants, or herbage, and also of their roots, are what is con-
cealed from the sun, so as to be not shone upon by it. (L, TA.)
gay~ibaAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

gayaAbN *
A thing that hides, or conceals, a thing from one: (Meyd:) and hence, (Meyd, TA,) a grave; (S, Meyd, TA;) and so ↓ gayaAbapN: (TA:) one says, gayaAbuhu ↓ gay~abahu (S, Meyd, TA) and ↓ gayaAbatuhu (TA) meaning dufina fiY qaborihi (S, Meyd, TA) [i. e. May he be buried in his grave]: an imprecation of death against the man. (Meyd.)

gayaAbapN * The part of anything that veils, or conceals, one. (K.) And hence, (K,) The bottom of a jub~ [or well]; (S, K, * TA;) or this, accord. to some, is the primary signification; as also ↓ gayobapN, accord. to one reading, in the Kur xii. 10; (TA;) [and gayaAyapN;] and of a valley; (S, TA;) &c.: (TA:) pl. gayaAbaAtN. (K, TA.) [And A covert, or place of concealment, of birds. (See ZilaAlapN.)] See also gayaAbN, in two places: and gayobapN. ― -b2- And see gayibaAnN.

gaAy^ibN * act. part. n. of 1 [signifying Absent; distant, or remote; and hidden, concealed, or unapparent; or absent from the range, or beyond the reach, of perception by sense, or of mental perception]: pl. (applied to men, K, TA) guy~abN and guy~aAbN (S, Msb, K) and gaAy^ibuwna (K) and ↓ gayabN, (S, Mgh, K,) or rather the last is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and ↓ gayobN, [which is also properly speaking a quasi-pl. n.,] like SaHobN: (Msb [in which gayabN is not mentioned]:) the Y in ↓ gayabN remains unchanged, notwithstanding the two fet-hahs, because it is likened to SayadN, and, although it is a pl. [in signification] and SayadN is an inf. n., it may be used as meant for an inf. n. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also gayobN, first sentence. ― -b3- Also A run in which a horse reserves [somewhat of his force for the time of need]. (A in art. $hd: see $aAhidN.)
magiybN * [an inf. n.: ― -b2- and also a n. of place and of time, signifying] The place [and the time] of setting of the sun and of the moon [&c.]. (Msb.)

mugiybN * and mugiybapN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) or you say mugiybapN [only], with p, and [in the contr. sense] mu$ohidN, without p, (IDrd, S,) and mugoyibN (K) and ↓ mugay~ibN, (TA,) A woman having her husband (or one of her family, TA) absent from her. (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA.)
mugay~bN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 gaAva A@ll~`hu AlbilaAda * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor. yagiyvu, inf. n. gayovN, (S, O, Msb,) God watered the country, or countries, with rain. (O, Msb, TA.) And gaAvanaA He (God) sent down rain upon us. (TA.) And gAv Algayovu AlA^aroDa, (aor. and inf. n. as above, Msb,) The rain fell upon the earth. (S, O, Msb, K.)
