And giyvati AlA^aroDu, aor. tugaAvu, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, O,) The land was watered with rain. (S, O, Msb, K.) giyva Alqawomu The people were rained upon; rain fell upon the people [or upon their land]. (TA.) And givanoA maA $iy^onaA [We were rained upon as much as we desired]: (S, O, Msb, TA:) originally guyivonaA. (TA.) ― -b2- gAv Aln~aworu (tropical:) The blossom shone. (O, K, TA.) -A2- See also 4 in art. gwv.

2 gy~v * , said of a blind man, He sought, or searched, [or groped, with the hand,] for a thing: (Kr, TA:) also written [Ey~v] with [the unpointed] E, and thus correctly, though ISd thought this latter to be a mistranscription. (TA.)

5 tgy~v *
He became fat: (K:) said of a camel. (TK.)

gayovN * inf. n. of gaAva [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb.) ― -b2- And [a subst.] signifying Rain: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) or rain that occupies the space of a bariyd [i. e. six miles, or twelve miles,] in width: (AA, O, K:) or rain that is productive of much good; [supposed to belong to art. gwv, for it is added,] because mankind are aided thereby; thus expl. in the “ Sharh esh-Shifè: ” pl. A^agoyaAvN [a pl. of pauc.] and guyuwvN. (TA.) [Hence a tropical usage in a saying mentioned voce vaj~aAjN.] ― -b3- And [hence] *ubaAbu gayovK [or *ubaAbu Algayovi (see *ubaAbN) lit. The fly of rain or the fly of the rain] signifies (assumed tropical:) the bee, or bees collectively: so called because the bee seeks after herbage and flowers, which are consequent upon the rain: (IAth, TA:) [for] ― -b4- gayovN signifies also (tropical:) Herbage (Lth, S, A, O, Msb, K) which grows by means of the water of the sky: (Lth, A, O, K:) called thus by the name of its cause. (Msb.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Clouds. (S, O, TA.) [See an ex. voce faruwqapN.]
giyaAvN * , originally giwaAvN, see in art. gwv.

gay~ivN *
i. q. Eayolamu maA='K [i. e. Water that is beneath a stratum of rock]. (TA.) [Hence] biy^orN *aAtu gay~ivK A well having a constant accession of water. (O, K.) ― -b2- And [hence] farasN *uw gay~ivK (tropical:) A horse that performs, (O,) or that increases [his running], (K, TA,) run after run. (O, K, TA.)
A^aroDN magiyvapN * , and ↓ magoyuwvapN, (the latter being the original form, TA,) Land watered with rain. (S, O, Msb, K.)

gayovN mugiyvN *
A general rain. (TA.) [But the epithet mugiyvN evidently belongs to art. gwv; and the phrase properly signifies A rain that gives aid, or succour.]
A^aroDN magoyuwvapN * : see magiyvapN.

1 gayida * , aor.
gayada , (L, K,) inf. n. gayadN, (L,) He had a bending neck, and limber sides: (L, K:) or he had a lax, or limber, neck. (L.) ― -b2- [And gayidat is app. said of a young woman as meaning She was soft, or tender; or soft, or tender, and limber in the sides. (See gayadN below.) ― -b3- And gayida He was, or became, drowsy; or drowsy and with a bending of the neck. (See, again, gayadN below.)]

6 tgAyd *
He affected a bending of his body, or he bent his body, from side to side, in his gait. (A.) And tgAydt She (a woman, L) affected a bending of her body, or bent her body, (L, K, TA,) from side to side, (TA,) in her gait, by reason of softness, or limberness. (L, K, TA.)

gaAdN * A fresh, tender, juicy twig: (L:) and so gaAdapN applied to a tree ($ajarapN). (L, K.) ― -b2- And the latter, A soft, or tender, goodly, thin-skinned, plump, and fresh, or flourishing, young woman: (L:) or, (S, A, L, K,) as also ↓ gayodaA='u, (S, A, K,) a woman, soft, or tender: (S, A:) or soft, or tender, and limber (L, K, TA) in the sides. (TA.)
giydi giydi * , or giydo giydo, (accord. to different copies of the K,) Hasten thou; make haste; be quick: (K:) a word of the people of Esh-Shihr. (TA.)

gayadN * [mentioned above as an inf. n.], in a woman, (S, K,) or in a young woman, (L,) Softness, or tenderness, (S, L, K,) and limberness (L, K) of the sides. (L.) ― -b2- And Drowiness: (A:) [or drowsiness with a bending of the neck: see A^agoyadu.]
gayodaAnN * The prime, spring, or first part, of youth. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA.)

A^agoyadu * A plant, or herbage, soft, or tender, and bending. (L, K.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A place abounding with plants, or herbage, (O, K, TA,) bending by reason of softness. (O.) ― -b3- Also A man, and a gazelle, having a bending neck, and limber sides: or having a lax, or limber, neck. (L.) And [the fem.] gayodaA='u (L, K) A woman (L) who bends her body, or affects a bending thereof, by reason of her softness, or limberness. (L, K.) See also gaAdN. ― -b4- Also Drowsy, and having a bending of the neck: (S, A, L, K:) fem. gayodaA='u: (TA:) and pl. giydN. (L.) AlkaraY AlA^agoyadu, occurring in a verse cited voce SubaAbapN [q. v.], means (tropical:) Drowsiness that makes one to bend the neck from side to side. (L, TA.)

1 gaAra A^aholahu * , (S, Msb,) and gAr lahumo, (TA,) aor. yagiyru, inf. n. giyaArN (S, Msb) and gayorN, (Msb, TA,) i. q. maArahumo, (S, Msb, TA,) i. e. He brought, or conveyed, to his family, miyrap [or a provision of corn, or wheat, &c.] (Msb.) [See also art. gwr.] ― -b2- And He benefited them. (S, K, * TA.) 'AbdMenáf Ibn-Riba El-Hudhalee says
maA *aA yagiyru A@bonataYo riboEK EawiyluhumaA
[What will their loud weeping benefit, or avail, the two daughters of Riba?] meaning that their weeping for their father will not avail them aught in lieu of seeking his blood-revenge. (S, TA.) You say gaArahumo bixayorK, (S, K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as
above, (TA,) He (God) bestowed upon them abundance of the produce of the earth, and rain; (TA in art. gwr;) like as you say A^aEoTaAhumo xayorFA: (S, K:) and so gArhm birizoqi [He bestowed upon them means of subsistence]. (TA.) And Aall~`hum~a gironaA bixayorK (S, Msb) O God, benefit us with prosperity. (Msb.) And gaArahumo bimaTarK He (God) watered them with rain, (S, K, TA,) and bestowed upon them abundance of the produce of the earth. (TA.) And gaAra AlA^aroDa Algayovu The rain watered the land. (Fr, S.) [See also art. gwr.] -A2- gaArahu, aor. yagiyruhu, (AO, S, K,) inf. n. gayorN, (TA,) He gave him the bloodwit; (AO, S, K;) as also gArhu, aor. yaguwruhu; (AO, S, TA;) mino A^axiyhi [for his brother]: and so ↓ gy~rhu. (TA.) [See giyrapN.] -A3- gaAra EalaY A^aholihi, (S,) or ElY A@moraA^atihi, (Msb, K,) aor. yagaAru, inf. n. gayorapN, (S, Msb, K,) with fet-h, (S, Msb, TA,) and gayorN and gaArN (S, Msb, K) and giyaArN, (K,) [He was jealous of his wife:] he was jealous for her (mino fulaAnK of such a one: Mgh): [he was careful of her, to avoid suspicion: or he regarded her conduct with disdain, scorn, or indignation: (see gayorapN, below:) or] he was angry at the conduct, or action, of his wife. (Msb.) And gaArati A@moraA^atuhu Ealayohi [His wife was jealous of him: &c.]. (M, b, K.) [See also art. gwr.] And you say also, fulaAnN laA EalaY A^aholihi ↓ yatagay~aru, meaning laA yagaAru [Such a one is not jealous of his wife: &c.]. (TA.)

2 gy~r Al$~aYo'a * , (S, Msb, K, *) inf. n. tagoyiyrN, (Msb,) He made the thing other than it was; (K;) made it cease to have the quality which it had; (Msb;) altered it; changed it. (K.) He, or it, altered, or changed, the thing in odour, or otherwise, for the worse; corrupted, tainted, or infected, it; rendered it ill-smelling, stinking, fetid, rancid, rank, fusty, or frouzy. (The lexicons passim.) It is said in the Kur [viii. 55], *`lika biA^an~a A@ll~`ha lamo yaku mugay~irFA niEomapF A^anoEamahaA EalaY qawomK Hat~aY yugay~iruwA maA biA^anofusihimo [This was because God changeth not favour which He hath conferred upon a people until they change what is in themselves: or] until they change what God hath commanded them to do. (Th, TA.) ― -b2- [And He exchanged the thing for another thing.] ― -b3- gy~r Al$~ayoba He plucked out the white, or hoary, hairs. (TA.) ― -b4- gy~r Eano baEiyrihi He put down the saddle from his camel, and put it to rights, or adjusted it, or repaired it. (TA.) One says taraka Alqawoma yugay~iruwna He left the people putting to rights, or adjusting, or repairing, the camels' saddles. (S, TA.) -A2- See also 1, latter half.

3 gaAoyara [gaAyaraA, inf. n. mugaAyarapN, They differed, each from the other.] You say bayonahumaA mugaAyarapN Between them two is a difference. (Msb.) [See also 6.] -A2- gAyrhu, (S, K,) inf. n. mugaAyarapN, (S,) He bartered, or exchanged, with him, in buying and selling. (S, K.) And gAyrhu biAls~iloEapi, inf. n. as above, He bartered, or exchanged, the article of merchandise with him. (TA.) And gAyr Als~iloEapa, (TA,) inf. n. giyaArN, (S, K, TA,) He exchanged the article of merchandise. (S, * K, * TA.) El-Aashà says
falaA taHosiban~iY lakumo kaAfirFA
walaA taHosiban~iY A^uriydu AlgiyaAraA
[Therefore do thou by no means think me ungrateful towards you; and do thou by no means think I desire the making an exchange]. (S, TA.)
4 AgAr A^aholahu * [He made his wife jealous;] he married another in addition to his wife, so she became jealous (gArt): (As, A'Obeyd, Msb, K:) belonging to this art. and to art. gwr. (TA.)

5 tgy~r * quasi-pass. of gy~r, (S, Msb,) [It became other than it was;] it ceased to have the quality which it had; (Msb;) it became altered, or changed, Eano HaAlihi, from its state or condition. (K.) It became altered, or changed, in odour, or otherwise, for the worse; turned, or turned bad; became corrupted, spoiled, tainted, infected, illsmelling, stinking, fetid, rancid, rank, fusty, or frouzy. (The lexicons passim.) ― -b2- [And It became exchanged for another thing.] ― -b3- See also 1, last signification.

6 tgAyrt AlA^a$oyaA='u *
The things differed, one from another. (S.)

8 AgtAr *
He procured miyrap [a provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]. (K.) You say xaraja yagotaAru liA^aholihi He went forth to procure myrp for his family. (Fr, Sgh.) ― -b2- He derived, or obtained, benefit, advantage, or profit. (TA.) See also art. gwr.

gayorN * signifies i. q. siwFY [Other]: and the pl. is A^agoyaArN: (S:) [but gayor itself often has a pl. meaning, as will be seen in what follows:] or [accord. to general usage, as will be seen below,] gayoru signifies i. q. siwaY [other than; exclusively of; or not, as used before a substantive or an adjective]. (Msb, K: in the CK [erroneously] siwFY.) It is used to qualify a subst.; [governing (as a prefixed noun) the noun that follows it in the gen. case;] and when so used, it is put in the same case as the noun preceding it. (S.) It qualifies an indeterminate noun: (Mughnee, Msb:) you say jaA='aniY rajulN gayoruka [A man, other than, or not, thou, came to me]: (Msb:) and naEomalo SaAliHFA gayora A@l~a*iY kun~aA naEomalu [We will in that case do good, other than, or not, what we used to do: (Kur xxxv. 34:)]: (Mughnee:) and mino maA='K gayori A=sinK [Of water other than, or not, altered in taste and colour]. (Kur xlvii. 16.) It is a noun necessarily prefixed, as to the sense, to a noun which it governs in the gen. case: but sometimes it is without the latter, when the meaning is understood and it is preceded by layosa, (Mughnee, K,) or by laA: (K:) [in which case it signifies Any other person or thing; any person or thing beside, or else:] you say qabaDotu Ea$arapF layosa gayoruhaA [I received ten; not other than they was received by me; i. e., not any other thing; or not anything beside, or else]; (Mughnee, K;) the enunciative, maqobuwDFA, being suppressed: (Mughnee:) and lys gayorahaA, (Mughnee, K;) the noun [of lys] being understood; i. e., layosa AlmaqobuwDu gayorahaA: (Mughnee:) and lys gayora; in which the affixed noun [for AlmDAf, in the K, I read AlmDAf Alyh, as in the Mughnee,] is suppressed, and the noun [of lys] is also understood: (Mughnee, K:) and lys gayoru; (Mughnee, K;) in which, accord. to Mbr, and the later authors, gyr is indecl., being likened to qabolu and baEodu, so that it may be either the noun or the enunciative [of lys] or, accord. to Akh, it is decl., because it is not a noun of time like qabolu and baEodu, nor of place like fawoqu and taHotu, but like kul~N and baEoDN, so that it is the noun [of lys], and the enunciative is suppressed; (Mughnee;) or it may be either indecl. or decl., (Mughnee, K,) accord. to Ibn-Kharoof: (Mughnee:) and lys gayorFA, and lys gayorN; (Mughnee, K;) in both which cases it is decl., as though the affixed noun were mentioned: (Mughnee:) and laA gayoru; for the saying, [which we find in the Mughnee,] app. taken from a statement of Seer, that this is incorrect, is not good, since it occurs in the following verse, cited by Ibn-Málik;
jawaAbFA bihi tanojuw A@Eotamido fawarab~inaA
laEano EamalK A^asolafota laA gayoru tusoA^alu
[Aim thou at having an answer by which thou mayest be safe; for, by our Lord, respecting an action which thou shalt have done before, not any other thing, or not anything beside or else, thou wilt be asked]. (K.) ― -b2- It does not become determinate by its being prefixed to another noun, because it is very vague: but it is also applied as an epithet to a determinate noun which is near to being indeterminate; as in SiraATa A@l~a*iyna A^anoEamota Ealayohimo gayori A@lomagoDuwbi Ealayohimo [The way of those upon whom Thou hast conferred favour; the other than, or those who are not, the objects of anger; (Kur i. 6 and 7;)] because the noun rendered determinate by the art. Al denoting a genus is near to being indeterminate, and because when gyr occurs between two contraries its vagueness becomes weakened, (Mughnee, K, *) or altogether departs: (K:) or it is here applied as an epithet to a determinate noun because it resembles a determinate noun in its being prefixed to such a noun: (Msb:) Az says that gyr is here in the gen. case because it is an epithet to Al*yn; and that it may be an epithet to [what is technically termed in this instance] a determinate noun [as having the article Al prefixed to it] because Al*yn has not [in itself] a direct meaning (liA^an~a Al~a*iyna gayoru maSomuwdK Samoduhu), [it being merely a conjunct noun, the meaning of which is determined by what follows it,] notwithstanding it has the art. Al prefixed to it: Abu-l-'Abbás says that Fr holds Al*yn to have the office of an indeterminate noun; and gyr to be an epithet of it; not of any other noun; but that gyr, accord. to some, may be an epithet relating to the nouns implied in AnEmt Elyhm, these not having a direct meaning: Akh says that gyr [with what follows] is a substitute [for Al*yn with what follows], as though the meaning were SiraATa gayori AlmagoDuwbi Ealayohimo [the way
of those who are not the objects of anger]. (TA.) The reading gayora is also related, on the authority of Ibn-Ketheer, in the accus. case, as a denotative of state, [meaning they being not the objects of anger,] relating to the pronoun governed in the gen. case by the prep. [in Elyhm]; or by A^aEoniY [I mean] understood; or as an exceptive, [accord. to a usage to be explained below,] if the favours be interpreted as conferred in common upon the two classes of persons. (Bd.) ― -b3- As it resembles a determinate noun in its being prefixed to a determinate noun, [as AlmgDwb in the above-cited passage of the Kur,] some have presumed to prefix to it the article Al: but against this it may be urged, that its prefixion to a determinate noun is not to render the expression determinate, but for specification; and Al does not imply specification. (Msb.) ― -b4- In the following verse of Hassán,
A^ataAnaA falamo naEodilo siwaAhu bigayorihi
nabiY~N badaA fiY Zulomapi All~ayoli haAdiyaA
the meaning is, [A prophet came to us, who appeared in the darkness of night, a director in the right way,] and we did not weigh another than him with another than the other, i. e., with him. (Mughnee.) ― -b5- [wagayoru *`lika is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning Et cœtera.] ― -b6- gayoru is also used in the sense of layosa [He, or it, is not]; as in the phrase kalaAmu A@ll~`hi gayoru maxoluwqK [The word of God is not created], syn. layosa bimaxoluwqK. (Az, TA.) ― -b7- It is also used in the sense of laA [meaning Not, as used before a participle]; (S, K;) and then it is in the accus. case, as a denotative of state; (S;) as in the phrase famani A@DoTur~a gayora baAgK, (S, K,) in the Kur [ii. 168, and other places], (S,) i. e., jaAy^iEFA laA baAgiyFA [But whosoever is necessitated, being hungry, not transgressing the due bounds]. (S, K.) ― -b8- It is also used as an exceptive, (S, Mughnee,) in the sense of A_il~aA [Except; save; or but]; (Msb, K;) and then it is put in the same case in which the word following A_il~aA would be put in the same phrase, (S, Mughnee, Msb, K,) because it is originally a qualificative, and its use as an exceptive is adventitious: (S:) therefore you say jaA='a Alqawomu gayora zayodK [The people came, except Zeyd]; and maA jaA='aniY A^aHadN gayora zayodK and gayoru zayodK [Not any one came to me, except Zeyd]: (Msb, K:) or its case depends upon the governing words, so that you say maA qaAma gayoru zayodK [No one stood, except Zeyd], and maA raA^ayotu gayora zayodK [I saw not any, except Zeyd]: (Msb:) but Fr says that some of the Benoo-Asad and Kudá'ah put gyr in the accus. case, when used in the sense of A_il~aA, whether the phrase before it be complete or incomplete; saying maA jaA='aniY gayoraka [Not any one came to me, except thou], and mA jA'nY A^aHadN gayoraka [Not any one came to me, except thou]: (S, Msb:) and AA says that when gyr has the place of A_il~aA, it is put in the accus. case. (Msb.) In the saying laA A_il`ha gayoru A@ll~`hi [There is no deity other than God], gyr is in the nom. case because it is the enunciative of lA; but it may be put in the accus. case, as meaning A_il~aA. (Msb.) When, as an exceptive, it is prefixed to an indecl. word [and not preceded by a prep.], it may be itself indecl., with fet-h for its termination; as in the following verse;
lamo yamonaEi Al$~uroba minohaA gayora A^ano naTaqato
HamaAmapN fiY guSuwnK *aAti A^awoqaAli
[Nought prevented the drinking from it, except that a pigeon cooed, upon branches having AwqAl, which app. means stumps of cut shoots]. (Mughnee, K.) [See also an ex. (of gayora A^an~a) in a verse cited voce bayoda.] ― -b9- [It is often used with a prep.; as in bigayori HisaAbK Without reckoning; (Kur ii. 208, &c.;) and mino gayori suwo'K Without leprosy. (Kur xx. 23, &c.)] -A2- gayorN (JK, K) and (JK) ↓ giyarN (JK, S) signifying The act of altering, or changing, i. q. tagoyiyrN, (JK,) are substs. from gay~arahu; (S with respect to the latter, and K with respect to the former;) not inf. ns., as having no unaugmented verb. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ald~ahori ↓ giyaru, the former of these two words being of the same measure as Einab, The accidents, or casualties, of time or fortune, which alter, or change, things: (K:) [or alteration, or change, of time or of fortune; for] IAmb says, with respect to the saying laA A^araAniY A@ll~`hu bika giyarFA [May God not show me, in thee, alteration of state], that giyarN is from tagay~uru AlHaAli, a subst. like qiTaEN [as meaning “ a portion of the night ”]; or that it may be a pl., of which the sing. is ↓ giyorapN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] banaAtu gayorK [or ↓ giyarK, as in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 309,] (tropical:) Lying: or a lie, or falsehood: syn. ka*ibN: (TS, K:) or [rather] lies. (JK, A.) You say jaA='a bibanaAti gayorK [or ↓ giyarK] (tropical:) He uttered lies. (A.)
giyarN * : see gayorN, last quarter, in four places: ― -b2- and see also giyrapN.

gayorapN * [Jealousy;] a man's dislike of another's participating in that which is his [the former's] right: (Kull p. 268:) or care of what is sacred, or inviolable, to avoid suspicion: or disdain; scorn; or indignation: syn. Hamiy~apN and A^anafapN: (TA:) or anger at the conduct, or action, of a wife. (Msb.) [See 1, last signification.]

giyrapN *
A provision of corn, or wheat, &c., which a man procures for himself; syn. miyrapN; (S, Msb, K,) as also ↓ giyaArN: (TA:) [or the latter is probably syn. with miyrapN used in the sense of an inf. n.:] pl. of the former giyarN. (Msb.) [See art. gwr.] -A2- See also gayorN, last sentence but two. ― -b2- Also A bloodwit; (AA, S, K;) syn. diyapN: (AA, S: *) and giwarN is a dial. var. thereof: (TA in art. gwr:) pl. ↓ giyarN: (AA, S, K:) or, as some say, this is a sing., (S, TA,) of the masc. gender; TA;) and the pl. is A^agoyaArN: (S, TA:) and the diyap is said to be termed giyarN because it is a substitute for retaliation. (TA.)
gayoraAnu * ; fem. gayoraY: see gayuwrN, in two places.

giyaArN * The cognizance, or badge, of the free nonmuslim subjects of a Muslim government; such as the zun~aAr [or waist-belt] (Mgh, K) to the Magians, (Mgh,) and the like: (Mgh, K:) or, as some say, the cognizance, or badge, of the Jews. (TA.) ― -b2- kalAmN bigiyaArihi (assumed tropical:) Speech, or language, having its own proper guise; not altered therefrom. (Msb in jlf.) -A2- See also giyrapN.

gayuwrN * and ↓ gayoraAnu (S, Msb, K) and ↓ gay~aArN (TA) and ↓ migoyaArN (S, K) epithets [all of which are intensive] from gaAra EalaY A^aholihi, (S, Msb, K,) i. e., from Algayorapu: (TA:) [Very jealous: &c.: see gayorapN:] and gayuwrN and gayoraY (S, Msb, K) and gay~aArapN (TA) signify the same applied to a woman: (S, Msb, K:) the pl. of gayuwrN is guyurN, (S, Msb, K,) masc. and fem., (S, K,) and he who says rusolN [for rusulN] says guyorN [or giyrN?]; (TA;) and of ↓ gayoraAnu, gayaAraY and guyaAraY; (S, Msb, K;) and of gayoraY, also, gayaAraY (S, Msb, K) and guyaAraY; (Msb;) and of ↓ migoyaArN, magaAyiyru. (S, K.)
gay~aArN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
A^agoyaru mina AlHum~aY * [More jealous than fever:] because a fever cleaves fast to its patient, like as a very jealous woman cleaves to her husband. (TA.)
A^aroDN magiyrapN * and ↓ magoyuwrapN, Land watered: (S, K:) or rained upon: (TA:) the former [like the latter] is with fet-h to the m. (S.)
mugay~irN * One who puts down the furniture of his camel from off him, to relieve and ease him. (TA.)
migoyaArN * : see gayuwrN, in two places.
ArD magoyuwrapN * : see magiyrapN.

1 gaADa * , aor. yagiyDu, inf. n. gayoDN (S, A, Msb, K) and magaADN (Msb, K) and magiyDN, (TA,) It (water) became scanty, or little in quantity, and sank into the earth, or disappeared in the earth: (S, and so in some copies of the K:) or became scanty, or little in quantity, and decreased, or diminished, or became deficient: (A, and so in some copies of the K:) or sank into the earth, and went away: (TA:) or went away into the earth; (Msb;) [contr. of faADa, aor. yafiyDu;] as also ↓ AngAD, (S, K,) which is of the dial. of El- Hijáz. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a thing, Msb, a flow of milk, TA, and (assumed tropical:) the price of a commodity, S, Msb, K) decreased, or diminished, or became deficient. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b3- wamaA tagiyDu A@loA^aroHaAmu wamaA tazodaAdu, (S, * K, * TA,) in the Kur [xiii. 9], (S,) means And the wombs' falling short [of completion or of what is usual], (Akh, S, Bd,) and their exceeding [therein], in respect of the body [of the fœtus], and the period of gestation, and the number borne: (Bd:) or, as some say, in respect
of the menstrual blood: (Bd:) or the wombs' falling short of the nine months (Zj, O, L, and so in copies of the K, but in others seven months,) of gestation, and their exceeding the nine [or seven] months: (Zj, O, L:) or the wombs' falling short of completion, so that the fœtus dies, and their exceeding so that the gestation becomes complete: and accord. to this explanation, the reading of seven months in the K may be correct: see also Katádeh's explanation of gayoDN, below, which favours this reading. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, gaADa AlkiraAmu wafaADa All~iy^aAmu (S, A) (tropical:) The generous became few, (S, TA,) and failed, or perished, (TA,) and the mean became many. (S.) -A2- gaADahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. gayoDN, (TA,) He (God, S, Msb) made it (i. e. water) to become scanty, or little in quantity, and to sink into the earth, or disappear in the earth: (S:) or made it to decrease, or diminish, or become deficient: (K:) or made it to go away into the earth: (Msb:) and ↓ AgADhu signifies the same; (S, A, K;) and so does ↓ gy~Dhu, inf. n. tagoyiyDN: (TA:) thus the first of these verbs is trans. as well as intrans. (S.) [It is said in the Kur xi. 46,] wagiyDa A@lomaA='u (S, A) And the water was made to become scanty, &c.: (S:) or was made to decrease, or diminish. (A, * Bd.) And hence the saying of 'Áïsheh, describing her father, wagaADa naboEa Alr~id~api (assumed tropical:) And he did away with what appeared of apostacy. (TA.) You say also, damoEahu ↓ gy~D, (S, * K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He made his tears to diminish, (S, K,) and restrained them: (S:) or he took the tears from his eye and dashed them away. (Th.) A poet says, (TA,) namely, Jereer, (O and TA in art. gbD,)
mino EabaraAtihin~a waqulona liY ↓ gay~aDona
maA *aA laqiyta mina AlhawaY walaqiynaA
meaning They made their tears to flow until they exhausted them [and they said to me, What is it that thou hast experienced, of love, and we have experienced?]: ISd says that mn here denotes some; or it may be redundant, accord. to the opinion of Abu-l-Hasan; for he holds that it may be so in affirmative [as well as negative] phrases, mentioning, as an instance, qado kaAna mino maTarK, meaning qado kaAna maTarN. (TA.) One relation of this verse gives gab~aDona; but the former is the right. (O and TA in art. gbD.) ― -b2- Also He opened a way, passage, or channel, for it (namely water) to flow forth to a magiyD [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He diminished it, namely the price of a commodity; (Ks, S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AgADhu. (K.) ― -b4- And He caused him to suffer loss, or detriment; and wronged, or injured, him. (ISd, TA.)
2 gy~Dhu * : see 1, latter half, in three places. -A2- gy~D said of a lion He frequented, or kept to, the gayoDap [q. v.]. (S, Sgh, L, K.)
4 AgADhu * : see 1, latter half, in two places.
7 A_inogayaDa see 1, first sentence.

gayoDN *
An abortive fœtus, not completely formed; (Katádeh, K;) i. e. less than seven months old. (TA.) -A2- (tropical:) Little; or a small quantity: as in the saying, or in A^aEoTaAhu gayoDFA mino fayoDK (tropical:) He gave him little from much. (S, A, K.) -A3- An abundance of the trees called A^aEolaAv; i. e. TarofaA=' and A^avol and HaAj and Eikori$ and yanobuwt. (TA.) [See also gayoDapN.]

giyDN * The TaloE [or spadix of a palm-tree]; (IAar, IDrd, O, K, TA;) like gaDiyDN and A_igoriyDN: (TA:) or the Eajam (AA, O, K) [thus correctly (in the CK Eujom) evidently, I think, here meaning the heart (commonly called jum~aAr q. v.) of the palm-tree (the only produce that is eaten except the dates)] that comes forth, or coming forth, (K,) or that has not come forth, (O,) from [amid] its [membranous fibres termed] liyf [q. v.], and all of which is eaten. (AA, O, K.)

gayoDapN *
A thicket; syn. A^ajamapN; i. e. a collection of tangled, or confused, or dense, trees: (Mgh, Msb:) or an A^ajamap; i. e. a ↓ magiyD [q. v.] of water collected together, in which, in consequence thereof, trees grow: (S:) or an A^ajamap: and a place in which is a collection of trees in a magiyD of water: (K:) or particularly, of [trees of the willow-kind called] garab; not of all trees; (AHn, O, K;) accord. to the first Arabs of the desert; but this is at variance with what we find in the poems of the Arabs; for Ru-beh, for instance, makes it to consist of fruit-bearing trees and trees not fruit-bearing, and makes it to be a gaAbap: (AHn, O:) [see also gayonapN:] pl. [of pauc.] A^agoyaADN (S, K) and [of mult.] giyaADN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and gayoDaAtN: (Msb:) the first of these being formed with disregard of the augmentative [p]; not being a pl. pl., for this is not so formed: (TA:) any garab in Nejd adjacent to the garab of the cultivated lands, when they are collected therein, are termed giyaAD. (O, TA.) [See also gayoDN.]

gaAy^iD * as used in the following verse,
A_ilaY A@ll~`hi A^a$okuw mino xaliylK A^awad~uhu
valaAva xilaAlK kul~uhaA liYa gaAy^iDu
is said by some to mean gaAy^iZ, the D being substituted for Z; [so that the verse should be rendered, To God I complain of three qualities, or habits, of a friend whom I love, every one of which is to me such as angers;] thus says IJ: but ISd says that it may be without substitution, from gaADahu as expl. in the last sentence of the first paragraph of this art.; and thus the meaning may be, such as causes me to suffer loss, or detriment, and such as wrongs, or injures, me. (TA.)

magiyDN * is an inf. n. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- And also the pass. part. n. of gaADahu; applied to water. (Msb, TA. *) ― -b3- And a n. of place, signifying A place where water sinks, or goes away, into the earth: (Msb, TA:) or magiyDu maA='K signifies a place where water enters [into the earth]: and a place where water collects: (Mgh:) see also gayoDapN: pl. magaAyiDu. (Mgh.)
1 gaATa * , aor. yagiyTu, inf. n. gayoTN: see gaATa, aor. yaguwTu, inf. n. gawoTN, in art. gwT.
gayoTN * : see gaAy^iTN in art. gwT.

1 gaAZahu * , (S, Msb, K,) aor. yagiyZu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. gayoZN, (Msb, TA,) He, or it, affected him with gayoZ [or anger, wrath, or rage; &c.; i. e. angered him; or enraged him; &c.]; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) as also ↓ gy~Zhu; (IAar, Th, K; [in a copy of the Msb, tgy~Zhu, which is doubtless a mistranscription;]) and ↓ gAyZhu; (S, K;) and ↓ AgAZhu; (IAar, Th, Msb, K;) but this last is not common; (Zj;) or it is not allowable. (ISk, S.) [See also gayoZN below.]
2 gay~aZa see the preceding paragraph.

3 gAyZhu * , inf. n. mugaAyaZapN: see 1: [originally, He angered him, or enraged him, or the like, being angered, or enraged, or the like, by him. ― -b2- And hence, because emulation, or the like, often causes mutual anger,] (tropical:) He emulated him, vied with him, or strove to overcome or surpass him, and did like as he did. (TA.) ― -b3- mugaAyaZapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) An acting in a leisurely manner: or it is [a] mutual [acting in that manner]. (TA.)
4 A^agoyaZa see the first paragraph.

5 tagay~aZa see 8. ― -b2- samiEuwA lahaA tagay~uZFA, in the Kur [xxv. 13] means (tropical:) They shall hear it to have a sound of boiling, (Zj, Bd, Jel,) like the boiling of the breast of an angry man. (Bd, * Jel.) ― -b3- tagay~aZati AlhaAjirapu (tropical:) The midday, or summer-midday, became [ragingly or] vehemently hot. (K, TA.)

8 AgtAZ *
He was or became, affected with gayoZ [or anger; or rage; &c.; i. e. he was, or became, angered; or enraged; &c.]; (S, Msb, K;) mino ka*aA by reason of such a thing; and sometimes one says, mino laA $aYo'K by reason of nothing; (Msb;) as also ↓ tgy~Z. (S, K.)

gayoZN *
Anger; wrath; syn. gaDabN: (K) or [rage, or vehement anger; for] it has a more intensive signification than gaDabN: (IDrd:) or the former is latent [anger]; and the latter is apparent: or the former is that which affects a person who has not power to exercise it; and the latter, that which affects a person who has power to exercise it: (TA:) or the former, latent anger affecting one who has not power to exercise it: (S:) or most vehement anger, (Msb, K,) encompassing the liver, by reason of some event that is disliked or hated, and sometimes by reason of nothing: (Msb:) or the outbreak, and commencement, of anger. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- takaAdu tamay~azu mina A@logayoZi, in the Kur
[lxvii. 8], means (assumed tropical:) It shall almost burst asunder by reason of vehemence of heat. (TA.)

faEala *`lika giyaAZaka * , and giyaAZayoka, (K, * TA,) [in the CK giyaADayoka,] i. q. ganaAZayoka, (K,) i. e. He did that in order to distress thee, [or anger thee, or enrage thee,] time after time. (K in art. gnZ.)

gaAy^iZN *
Affecting with gayoZ [or anger; or rage; &c.; i. e. angering; or enraging; &c.]: (TA:) pl. gaAy^iZuwna. (Kur, xxvi. 55.)

A^agoyaZu * [comparative and superlative of gaAy^iZN]. A^agoyaZu AlA^asomaA='i Einoda A@ll~`hi maliku AlA^amolaAki means The most severely to be punished, of persons bearing names, is he who is named the king of kings: (TA:) [lit. the most angering, or enraging, of names, is the king of kings.]

magiyZN *
Affected with gayoZ [or anger; or rage; &c.; i. e. angered; or enraged; &c.]. (S, Msb.)
HaliymapN mugotaAZapN * (tropical:) [lit. Calm, angry; or the like; because what it contains is sometimes still and sometimes boiling;] is an appellation given to a stone cooking-pot. (A, TA.)

1 gaAfati Al$~ajarapu * , (S, O, K,) aor. tagiyfu, (O, K,) inf. n. gayafaAnN; (S, O, K;) and ↓ tgy~ft, (S, O, K, *) in the copies of the K erroneously tgy~f; (TA;) as also ↓ A^agoyafat, inf. n. A_igoyaAfN; (TA;) The tree inclined, (S,) or had its branches inclining, (O, K,) to the right and left. (S, O, K.)

2 gy~f * , (O, K,) inf. n. tagoyiyfN, (K,) He fled, or turned away and fled; and drew back, or drew back in fear; (O, K;) and was cowardly. (K.) You say, Hamala fulaAnN fiY AlHarobi fagay~afa i. e. [Such a one charged, in war, or battle, and] was cowardly; or retreated, and was cowardly. (S.) ― -b2- See also 5.
4 A^agoyafa see 1. -A2- AgAf Al$~ajarapa, (O, K, *) inf. n. A_igaAfapN, (TA,) He made the tree to bend, or incline, (O, K, * TA, *) by reason of softness, or tenderness. (TA.)

5 tagay~afa see 1. ― -b2- tgy~f said of a horse, He inclined, or bent, (S, O, K, TA,) towards one side, (S, O, TA,) in running. (TA.) And He [app. a man] walked with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side, and in the manner of the tall: or he passed along easily and quickly: or, accord. to AHeyth, he affected an inclining of the body from side to side, by reason of width of step, and gentleness of pace: accord. to El-Mufaddal, he was proud, or haughty, in his gait. (TA.) The phrase mar~a AlbaEiyru yatagay~afu, mentioned by As, but not expl. by him, is said by Sh to mean [The camel passed along] going quickly. (TA.) ― -b3- One says also, tgy~f Eani AlA^amori, meaning He refrained, or drew back, from the affair, in fear; as also ↓ gy~f; this latter mentioned by Th. (TA.) ― -b4- And tagay~ufN signifies also The being, or becoming, creased, or wrinkled: like tagaD~ufN. (TA in art. EDf.)

gaAfN *
A species of trees, (AHn, S, O, K,) growing in the sands, and becoming large, the leaves of which are smaller than those of the apple, which it resembles in character, or form, (AHn, O,) having a very sweet fruit, (AHn, O, K,) of the kind termed Eul~af, like the pods (quruwn) of the bean, and its wood is white; so, says AHn, I have been informed by some of the Arabs of 'Omán, which is the place of its origin: n. un. with p: (O:) accord. to some of the Arabs, the species of trees called yanobuwt, [see this word, of which one description agrees exactly with that given above,] (O, K, * TA, *) which is found in 'Omán: (TA:) accord. to AZ, it is of the [trees called] EiDaAh, and is a tree like the qaraZ [q. v.], thorny, of the region of El-Hijáz, growing in the [high, or high and rugged, grounds called] qifaAf [pl. of quf~N]. (TA.)

gayofN *
A flock of birds. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

gayofaAnN * and ↓ gay~afaAnN, (O, K, TA,) the latter like hay~abaAnN, (K, TA, in the CK hay~ibAn,) i. q. maraHN; (O, TA;) in the Tekmileh mariH, like katif; and in the copies of the K marox; but the first of these is the right; meaning [A proud and self-conceited carriage, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side,] in pace, or [manner of] going. (TA.)
gayofaAniY~N * : see A^agoyafu.
gay~afaAnN * : see gayofaAnN.
gay~aAfN * One whose beard is long, (O, K, TA,) and wide on every side, (O, TA,) and very large. (K, TA.)

A^agoyafu *
Having a bending of the neck, (like A^agoyadu,) but without drowsiness. (O, K.) ― -b2- And, applied to trees ($ajarN), quivering, or playing loosely, succulent, or sappy, soft, tender, or supple; as also ↓ gayofaAniY~N; and so gayofaA='u [the fem. of the former] applied to a tree ($ajarapN). (TA.) ― -b3- And Eayo$N A^agoyafu A soft, or an easy, and a a plentiful, life; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) like A^agoDafu. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

gaAqN *
A certain aquatic bird; as also ↓ gaAqapN. (Lth, O, K.) ― -b2- And The crow, or raven: (ISd, K:) so sometimes called because of his cry. (ISd, TA.) -A2- gaAqi is a word imitative of The cry [i. e. caw] of the crow, or raven: when indeterminate, [meaning a caw,] it is with tenween, (IJ, S, O, K,) i. e. gaAqK. (IJ, TA.)
gaAqapN * : see the preceding paragraph.
1 gaAlato waladahaA * , inf. n. gayolN [q. v.]: see 4. -A2- gaAla fulaAnFA ka*aA Such a thing brought evil to such a one. (TA.)

4 A^agaAla * and A^agoyala , (Mgh,) or A^agaAla waladahu (S, Msb) and A^agoyalahu, (Msb,) He compressed the mother of his child while she was suckling it. (S, Mgh, * Msb.) ― -b2- And A^agaAlato and A^agoyalato, (Mgh,) or A^agaAlato waladahaA and A^agoyalatohu, (S, Msb, K,) She gave her child to drink what is termed gayol, (S, K, TA,) i. e. the milk of her who was compressed, or the milk of her who was pregnant: (TA:) or [accord. to common usage] she suckled her child while she was pregnant: (Mgh, Msb:) and waladahaA ↓ gaAlato, aor. tagiylu, inf. n. gayolN, signifies [the same, or] she suckled her child while she was being compressed, or while she was pregnant. (TK.) [See also 10.] -A2- A^agoyalato said of sheep or goats, (O, K,) and of cows, (O, TA,) They brought forth twice in the year. (O, K, TA.) -A3- See also the next paragraph.

5 tgy~l Al$~ajaru *
The trees became tangled, or abundant and dense, (As, S, K,) in their branches, having leafy coverings or shades; as also ↓ A^agoyala and ↓ Aisotagoyala: (K:) or all signify the trees became large, and tangled, or abundant and dense. (TA.) ― -b2- And tgy~lwA They became many: (O, K:) and (so in the O, but in the K “ or ”) their cattle, or possessions, became many. (O, K.) -A2- tgy~l He entered the giyl [i. e. thicket, or covert]. (O.) And tgy~l Al$~ajara He (a lion) entered among the trees, and took them as a giyl [or covert. (TA.)

8 AgtAlhu *
He did evil to him without his knowing whence it came so that he might prepare himself. (TA.) It is said in a trad., A^aEuw*u bika A^ano A^ugotaAla mino taHotiY i. e. [I seek protection by Thee from] my being the object of an event's befalling me whence I shall not know; meaning thereby the sinking [into the ground] and being swallowed up. (TA.) AlAigotiyaAlu and Algiylapu are syn. in a sense expl. below. (S, O, K.) See the latter word below: and see also 8 in art. gwl. One says, Augotiyla, meaning He was deceived, and taken to a place, and [there] slain. (TA.) -A2- AgtAl said of a boy, He became thick and fat. (S, K.)

10 Aisotagoyalato * , said of a woman, a verb of which the subst. is giylapN [q. v.]: (K:) [accord. to the context in the K, in which the meaning is not clearly indicated, it seems to signify She suckled her child while being compressed, or while pregnant; like A^agaAlato for A^agaAlato waladahaA; and this I believe to be the right meaning: or] it signifies she was compressed while suckling a child, or while pregnant. (TK.) -A2- See also 5, first sentence.

gayolN * : see giylapN, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- As some say, (Msb,) it signifies The milk with which a woman suckles while she is being compressed, (S, Msb, K, TA,) or while she is pregnant: (S, K, TA:) you say, saqatohu gayolFA, (Msb,) or Algayola, (K, TA,) i. e. She gave him to drink such milk. (TA.) -A2- Also Water running upon the surface of the earth; (S, Mgh, O, Msb,
K;) thus correctly, with fet-h; but ↓ giylN, with kesr, is a dial. var. thereof, mentioned by ISd: (TA:) both are said to signify water running amid trees: (Ham p. 555:) IB says that the former signifies thus; and that its pl. is guyuwlN: and it is also said to signify water running in rivers or rivulets, and in streamlets for irrigation: (TA:) and by some, to signify water running amid stones, in the interior of a valley. (Ham ubi suprà.) It is said in a trad., that in the case of that [produce] which is irrigated by the water thus termed (maA suqiYa baAlgayoli, S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA, or gayolFA, Mgh) there shall be [given for the poor-rate] the tenth; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA;) and in the case of that which is irrigated by the bucket, half of the tenth. (S, TA.) [See also an ex. voce SubaAbapN.] ― -b2- And Any valley in which are flowing springs: (K:) or a place in a collection of tangled, or abundant and dense, trees, in which is water running upon the surface of the earth: (Lth, TA:) and any place in which is water, (K, TA,) such as a valley and the like: (TA:) and ↓ giylN, with kesr, signifies any valley in which is water; and the pl. of this is A^agoyaAlN [a pl. of pauc.] and guyuwlN. (K.) ― -b3- See also giylN. -A3- Also A plump, full, saAEid [or fore arm]; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ mugotaAlN: (K:) the latter said by Fr to be applied to a wrist as meaning full because from Algawolu; but this saying is not valid, as gayolN is found in the same sense. (IJ, TA.) [See an ex. of the former in a verse cited voce TafolN.] And A fat, big, boy; as also ↓ mugotaAlN: (K:) fem. of the former gayolapN; (TA;) which is applied to a woman as meaning fat; (S, K;) or a fat, big, woman. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- See also gay~ilN, in two places. -A4- Also The ornamental, or figured, or variegated, border (syn. Ealam) in a garment: (AA, K:) pl. A^agoyaAlN. (AA, TA.) ― -b2- And A line that one makes, or marks, upon a thing. (K.)

giylN *
A thicket; or trees in a tangled, confused, or dense, state: (As, S, O:) or an abundance of such trees, (K, TA,) not thorn-trees, amid which one may conceal himself: (TA:) and ↓ gayolN signifies the same: (K:) and the former, a collection of reeds or canes, and of [the kind of high, coarse, grass called] HalofaA=': (K:) and i. q. A^ajamapN [i. e. a collection, or an abundant collection, of tangled, confused, or dense, trees, or of reeds or canes]: (S, O, K) [and in like manner ↓ gayolapN, occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, is expl. by Freytag, as signifying “ saltus: ”] and the place [meaning covert] of the lion: it may not have the termination p: the pl. is guyuwlN; (S, O;) and gayaAyiylu is said to be an anomalous pl. of giylN. (O and TA in art. Eyl, voce Eay~aAlN, q. v.) ― -b2- See also gayolN, in two places.
gayolapN * : see giylapN. ― -b2- Also A single act of AigotiyaAl [q. v. voce giylapN]. (TA.) -A2- See also giylN. -A3- It is also fem. of the epithet gayolN [q. v.]. (TA.)

giylapN * and ↓ gayolN signify the same; (Mgh, O, Msb); i. e. The compressing one's wife while she is suckling: (Mgh, Msb:) thus expl. by AO as stated by A'Obeyd: (Mgh:) and thus the former signifies accord. to El-'Alkamee; and so says Málik: or, accord. to El-Munáwee, it signifies the compressing one's wife while she is suckling or pregnant: or, accord. to ISk, a woman's suckling while pregnant: (from a marginal note in a copy of the Jámi' es-Sagheer of Es-Suyootee, in explanation of a trad. mentioned in what here follows, commencing with the words laqado hamamotu:) and ↓ gayolN has this last signification (Mgh, TA) accord. to Ks: (Mgh:) giylapN is the subst. from Aisotagoyalato: (K:) and IAth says that ↓ gayolapN is a dial. var. thereof; or, as some say, this denotes a single act [of what is termed giylap]; or the pronunciation with fet-h is not allowable unless with the elision of the p. (TA.) One says, A^aDar~ati Algiylapu biwaladi fulaAnK, meaning His mother's being compressed while she was suckling him [injured the child of such a one], and likewise his mother's being pregnant while she was suckling him. (S, O.) [But] in a trad. is related the saying, (of the Prophet, O) “ Verily I had intended to forbid Algiylap (S, Mgh, * O, Msb, K) until I remembered that the Persians and the Greeks practise it and it does not injure their children. ” (Mgh, O, Msb.) [See also 4 in art. fsd.] ― -b2- Also The act of deceiving, or beguiling: (K:) and i. q. ↓ AigotiyaAlN: (S, O, K: [see 8, and giylapN, as expl. in art. gwl:]) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, in the language of the Arabs it signifies the causing evil, or slaughter, to come to another from an unknown quarter. (TA.) One says, qatalahu giylapF, meaning He deceived, or, beguiled, him, and went with him, or took him, to a place, and slew him (S, O, K) when he reached it: (S, O:) or he slew him at unawares. (Abu-l- 'Abbás, TA.) -A2- Also The $aqo$iqap [or faucial bag of the he-camel]. (IAar, K.)

A^um~u gayolaAna * [in Pers. mugayolaAn] A species of the [trees called] giDaAh; (Mgh, Msb;) the [species of lote-] trees called sidor; (S, O, K, TA;) the fruit of which is said to be sweeter than honey: the saying, of some, that it is with kesr to the g, and that it is thus called because the giylAn [pl. of guwlN] are often found before it, is rejected and false: (TA:) Lth and ISh say that it is the same as the TaloH [q. v.]. (TA in art. TlH.)

gayuwlN * , as stated by IJ, on the authority of Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, who had it from his grandfather, is sing. of guyulN, (TA,) which is an epithet applied to oxen, or bulls and cows, (AO, IJ, O, K, TA, [nafarN in the CK being a mistake for baqarN,]) and to camels, (K,) signifying Numerous: and also [in the K “ or ”] fat. (AO, IJ, O, K.) ― -b2- And, applied to anything, Alone; solitary: pl. guyulN. (AA, TA.)

gay~ilN * , like say~idN, (O, TA,) in the K ↓ gayolN, but this latter is said by ISd to be of weak authority, (TA,) applied to a garment, Wide, or ample. (O, K, TA.) And so gay~ilapN applied to a land: (O, TA: [mentioned also in art. gwl:]) or, as some say, gay~ilN, thus applied, (O, TA,) but accord. to the context in the K ↓ gayolN, (TA,) signifies Such as one judges to be of little extent, though it is far extending: (O, K, * TA:) and *aAtu gawolK, so applied, has been mentioned in art. gwl as having this meaning. (TA.) And gay~ilapN applied to a woman signifies Tall: (O, TA:) and so does *aAtu gawolK. (TA in art. gwl.)

Algay~aAlu *
The lion: (K) or the lion that is in the giyl [or covert]. (O.)

gaAy^ilN *
Much, or abundant, dust or earth. (TA.)

gaAy^ilapN *
Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, that is covert, or concealed. (K.) And Evil, or mischief; as also ↓ magaAlapN: (S, K:) thus in the saying fulaAnN qaliylu AlgaAy^ilapi and ↓ AlmagaAlapi [Such a one is a person of little evil or mischief]. (S.) ― -b2- See also the same word in art. gwl.

A^agoyalu *
Full; big, or large. (TA.)
mugaAlN * (Mgh, K) and ↓ mugoyalN (S, Mgh, K) A child given to drink what is termed gayol: (S, * K: [See 4:]) or suckled while its mother is pregnant. (Mgh.)
mugoyalN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mugiylN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and mugoyilN (Mgh, Msb, K) A woman giving her child to drink what is termed gayol: (S, K: [see 4:]) or suckling it while she is pregnant. (Mgh, Msb.)
magaAlapN * : see gaAy^ilapN, in two places.
mugay~ilN * [in the CK mugay~al] and ↓ mutagiy~ilN Continuing, or remaining fixed, or stationary, in the giyl [meaning thicket, or covert, in the CK gayol]: and entering therein. (K, TA.)
migoyaAlN * A tree ($ajarapN) having tangled, or abundant and dense, branches, with leafy coverings or shades. (K.)
mugotaAlN * : see gayolN, latter half, in two places.
mutagay~ilN * : see mugay~ilN.

1 gaAmati Als~amaA='u * , (S, Msb, K,) aor. tagiymu, inf. n. gayomN; (Msb;) and ↓ tgy~mt; and ↓ gay~amat, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tagoyiymN; (K;) and ↓ A^agaAmat (S, Msb, K) and A^agoyamat; (S, K;) all signify the same; (S;) The sky was, or became, clouded, or covered with clouds. (S, * Msb, K. *) -A2- gaAma, aor. yagiymu, (S, K,) inf. n. gayomN, (KL,) He was, or became, thirsty, (S, K, KL, * [like EaAma,]) and affected with internal heat. (S, K) ― -b2- And gAm A_ilaY AlmaA='i, aor. as above, inf. n. gayomapN and gayamaAnN and magoyamN, is mentioned by IAar [as signifying He thirsted for water, or the water: or he thirsted for it vehemently, accord. to an explanation of gayomapN given below]. (TA.)

2 gay~ama see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] gy~m All~ayolu, (K,) inf. n. tagoyiymN, (TA,) (tropical:) The night became like the gayom [or clouds]; (K;) became dark, and came like the clouds. (TA.) ― -b3- And gy~m AlT~aAy^iru (assumed tropical:) The bird fluttered over one's head, not going to a distance; on the authority of Th: mentioned by IAar as with gyn and tA' [evidently mistranscriptions for Eyn and vA': see Eay~ava]. (TA.)

4 A^agaAmati Als~amaA='u * and A^agoyamat : see 1. ― -b2- A^agoyama Alqawomu [The people, or party, had a clouded sky;] clouds came upon the people, or party. (S, K.) ― -b3- And A^agoyama He (a man, TA) became stationary (K, TA) like the clouds. (TA.)
5 tagay~ama see the first paragraph.

gayomN * , originally an inf. n., from gaAmati Als~amaA='u [q. v.], (Msb,) Clouds; (S, Msb, K, TA;) n. un. with p: (Msb:) or [an expanse of clouds covering the sky,] when one sees not a sun (Kr, TA) by reason of much covering of the sky: (TA:) [and often meaning mist:] pl. guyuwmN and giyaAmN. (TA.) -A2- Also Thirst: and internal heat. (AA, S, K.) [See also gayomapN.] ― -b2- And Anger, wrath, or rage, (K, TA,) which is from internal heat. (TA.) ― -b3- And a certain disease in camels, like that called qulaAb [q. v.], except that it does not kill: (K, TA:) it is said that the asterism of the Pleiades (Alv~uray~aA, q. v.,) does not rise nor set aurorally without there being sickness, mostly in the camels, which are then affected with the disease thus called. (Az, TA.) -A3- $ajarN gayomN Dense, or tangled, trees: like gayonN [which is a dial. var. of gayomN in other senses]. (TA.)

gayomap *
Thirst; so says A 'Obeyd: or vehemence of thirst: thus in the trad. cited under EayomapN [q. v.]. (TA.) [See also gayomN.]

gayomAn *
Thirsty: and affected with internal heat: fem. gayomaY: (S, K:) the latter applied to a woman. (S.)
yawomN gayuwm * [A cloudy day;] a day having gayom [or clouds, or clouds covering the sky]. (Th, TA.)
magoyuwmN * A camel affected with the disease termed gayom: (Az, K, TA:) such scarcely ever, or never, dies. (Az, TA.)

1 gaAna Ealayohi ka*aA * , [aor. yagiynu, inf. n. gayonN,] Such a thing covered, veiled, or concealed, him, or it: (Ham p. 574:) [and so ↓ A^agaAnahu; whence] one says, Algayonu Als~amaA='a ↓ AgAn The clouds covered, or overspread, or wholly covered, the sky. (S, K.) And giyna EalaY ka*aA Such a thing was covered over. (S.) [Hence,] giyna EalaY qalobihi, inf. n. gayonN; as also ↓ A^ugiyna [in the CK (erroneously) Aagoyana]; (assumed tropical:) His heart was invaded by desire, or appetite, as by a thing that covered it: or was covered [so as to be rendered unsusceptible]: or was enveloped by the like of rust [or clouded or rendered dull]. (K, TA. [For Alr~ayon, meaning “ the like of rust ” covering the heart, the CK has Ald~ayon.]) The saying, in a trad., A_in~ahu layugaAnu EalaY qalobiY (S, Msb, TA) Hat~aY A^asotagofira A@ll~`ha fiY Alyawomi saboEiyna mar~apF (TA) is from the phrase giyna EalaY ka*aA signifying as expl. above, (S,) and means (assumed tropical:) Verily my heart is invaded as though it were covered, by unmindfulness from which mankind will not be free so that I beg forgiveness of God in the day seventy times: (TA:) or it means, being used metonymically, verily I become diverted from AlmuraAqabap [meaning the fear of God, or, as a conventional term, the constant knowledge of God's cognition of me in all my states or circumstances,] by the affairs that are for good relating to the present world; for these, though matters of importance, are, in comparison with the affairs relating to the other world, as idle sport, in the estimation of the people who follow the rule of AlmuraAqabap. (Msb.) ― -b2- One says also, giynati Als~amaA='u, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. gayonN; as also gaAnat, inf. n. gayonN; [like gaAmat;] (TA;) The sky became covered (Msb, TA) with gayon (Msb) or gayom (TA) [i. e. clouds, or an expanse of clouds]. -A2- ginotu, aor. A^agiynu, [inf. n. gayonN,] I was, or became, thirsty. (S, K.) And gaAnati AlA_ibilu i. q. gaAmat (S, K, TA) i. e. The camels were, or became, thirsty. (TA.) ― -b2- And gaAnato nafosuhu, (S,) or nafosiY, (K,) aor. tagiynu, (S, K,) inf. n. gayonN, (TA,) His, or my, soul [or stomach] heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato. (S, K.)
2 HasanapF * ↓ gay~ana gayonFA and HasanFA He wrote a beautiful g. (TA.)
4 A^agoyana see the first paragraph, in three places.
gaAnN * : see gayonapN.

gayonN * [mentioned above as an inf. n. is also a subst., as such] i. q. gayomN, (K, TA,) a dial. var. of the latter word, (S, Msb, TA,) signifying clouds; (TA;) [or an expanse of clouds;] as in the phrase fiY yawomi gayonK in a day of clouds: (S, * TA:) or, meaning “ clouds, ” it is from gaAna Ealayohi ka*aA signifying as expl. in the beginning of this art. (Ham p. 574.) ― -b2- And $ajarN gayonN Dense, or tangled, trees: (TA:) like gayomN. (TA in art. gym.) -A2- Also [like gayomN signifying] Thirst. (S, K. [See also 1.]) -A3- And [The letter g;] one of the letters of the alphabet: (S, K:) pl. [of mult.] guyuwnN and [of pauc.] A^agoyaAnN and gayonaAtN. (TA.) See 2, and art. g.
gaAnapN * The ring at the head of the bow-string. (K.) [See EunotuwtN.]

gayonapN *
i. q. A^ajamapN; [like gayoDapN, q. v.;] so in the M; (TA;) [and it is said that] Algayonapu Al$~ajoraA='u is like AlgayoDapu AlxaDoraA='u: or, accord. to Abu-l- 'Ameythel [or 'Omeythil], (S, TA,) gayonapN signifies [A collection of] tangled, or confused, or dense, trees, (S, K, TA,) in the mountains, and in the plain, or soft, land, (TA,) without water; (S, K, TA;) if with water, called gayoDapN: (S, TA:) [and Golius states, as on the authority of Yákoot, that ↓ gaAnN signifies the same as gayonapN.]
giynapN * The fluid that runs from a carcass, or corpse, (S,) or from the dead: and [the humour, or matter, termed] Sadiyd, q. v. (K.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

A^agoyanu *
Green: (S, TA:) or green inclining to blackness: (so in one of my copies of the S:) and [its fem.] gayonaA='u is applied to a tree ($ajarapN) as meaning green, (AO, S, K, TA,) abounding with leaves, having tangled, or dense, branches, (AO, S, TA,) and soft, or tender: and sometimes it is thus applied to herbs: (TA:) or [applied to a tree] it signifies great, having wide shade: from the phrase gaAna Ealayohi ka*aA, expl. in the beginning of this art.: (Ham p. 574:) and A^agoyanu signifies [also] such as is tall, (K, TA,) of trees, or, by way of comparison [thereto], of men: (TA:) the pl. is giynN: (S, TA:) which is expl. by Kr as meaning the abundance, and collected state, and beauty, of [the trees called] A^araAk and sidor; but what is well known is that it is pl. of gayonaA=' applied to a tree; of which ↓ giynapN, with kesr, has also been mentioned as a pl., though, as ISd says, this is not known in the [genuine] language, nor is it agreeable with the analogy of Arabic. (TA.)

mugoyin * , in the original form, [for mugiyn, act. part. n. of A^agaAna,] is used by Ru-beh in the following verse:
A^amosaY bilaAlN kaAlr~abiyEi Almudojini
A^amoTara fiY A^akonaAfi gayonK mugoyini
[There was, or came, in the evening, a moisture like the continual rain of winter that has rained in the tracts of overspreading clouds]. (S.)
